column10: Another survivor spinoff. But of high quality and a rocky twist.
100% worth the money, not really a game I can grind but every now and then 1-2 hours it's an absolute blast!

Is this the best game? No
Is it a bit of grindfest? Yes
Are they riding the DRG fame? Kinda.
Did I spend 30+ hours having great fun? Hell yeah.

The gameplay loop is mostly the slowly grind to have better stats, however, the gameplay itself is satisfying and fun as hell.

I recommend trying it.
This game is not recommended until the developer resolves the Upgrade Selection stuck bug.

The Resource mining aspect makes upgrading in my opinion very rewarding. It can be challenging, but because you can focus on the upgrades you prefer fairly easily, you never feel like you don't make progress.

More frustration than fun at every turn.

have played this game many hours now. still have not yuet beat a single mission set successfully. Sacling is waay too high, its a never ending rush to try and stay ahead of the curve, no matter what way you build etc, you will struggle on the last level. the moment you feel a bit strong against enemies, they will scale up. 30 seconds to run across the map to the drop pod instead of getting some minerals is also absurd. I honestly have no idea how you're meant to beat the final boss in the dives, it seems like you need absurd luck with your boring rolls for weapon increases and amazing pathing. 

and on that, it advertised a huge amount of weapon customization... total bs. its more reload speed, higher fire rate or more damage. then the odd overclock which is almost never a buff but a trade off (lose one stat, gain another) pretty disappointing for now. make this fun, dont make it some insane difficult grind. make it something you can log in and switch off whilst playing. way too stressful and frustrating at current state.

Edit: 

Played a few more hours. still just as frustrating. Do not use grenades, they are absolutely terrible. ive watched many grenades be thrown off the end of the map, or thrown at a single drown versus the throng following me. Regardless of how you play, this game will frustrate you and always leave you wondering what you were supposed to do at all to be successful - poor game design. very close to being good..

1. slow down the gameplay
2. dont make the hordes so strong so quickly
3. allow FAR more time to the drop pod - often you will have a map full of xp once you kill the boss but then you have 30 seconds to sprint through the swarm (taking huge damage) just to make it. 

This game is far too difficult and nowhere near rewarding enough for the time you have to put in, it is not fun, and i am consistently frustrated after each level.

Published by Ghost Ship, "Developed" by Funday Games. When checked on their games, you ll only see a broken early access cowboy woo game. Gameplay is as others stated half done (i would even say they just copy pasted from other indie survivor games) and utterly meta progression reliant (which are of course %1-%5 increases that you can buy between the runs, but note that runs usually take between 15-50 minutes). Besides horrendous difficulty and nothing to make you feel good about playing the game, they also force you to waste maybe 30 minutes to UNLOCK a weapon mod that you can use on the next run, you do this for almost EVERY weapon. 

Its almost made in a way to waste your time intentionally, the only reason i bought the game was because of the drg but i wish i didnt, maybe my perspective will change when devs actually do something and patch/fix the game up that was disgusting at launch, instead of streaming how they play the game for hours. Check every negative feedback if you must, but do not waste your money and time if they are valuable to you. I will change the review when they fix the game. (though yes im a drg addict so i will keep playing and ruining my mood)

edit: i wanted to try my chance to skip through meta "proggression"  and found out its more like a meta slavery. upon using cheat engine to get minerals and credits to buy all upgrades... guess what, it could have taken me weeks to fullfill that, asking me 10k credits and 100 X mineral (which you barely get a few per run and buy rest with minimal credit reward). Geez man, the more i learn the more disgusting it gets, but i guess game is more enjoyable if you cheat your way through meta progression.

edit 2: i was severely mistaken, upgrades offered in meta prog are completely unrelevant, they are the same upgrades you could get in a few levels in one run. i thought i'd have fun after maxxing every stat but its just disappointment , you can barely see any difference between no meta upgrades versus maxxed meta upgrades. this game is in a more severe situation than i thought, i wont be playing it for a long while.

my final conclusion is that the game is very predatory, making it hard to know if its a good game in 2 hours of gameplay. currently trying to refund, this game is not even worth a single dollar.

It's okay. I like the addition of mining and extraction. Weapons could use more variation.

Currently it's the running away simulator, especially on higher difficulties.
You practically never feel strong enough to kill the swarm until you at the later levels. So you spend most of the run running away.

Difficulty scaling is uninspired, the bugs just have more health and do more damage (and there's more of them). You can't go to a higher hazard level without meta-progression, because you would just die to the littlest bullet-sponge bug. At the same time the same progression makes lover hazard levels trivial. So your choices are to run away from bullet-sponges on higher hazards or breeze through lover ones after enough upgrades.

Some weapons are absolutely terrible and only become "decent" after the third overclock and even then they are outshone by non-upgraded non-terrible weapons.
Directional weapons are mostly bad. Minigun, Subata, etc can be useful, and even good after overclocks, because they have auto-aim in a limited arc. But Warthog just shoots "forward" and this "forward" is in no way the direction the character model is facing, but your last input direction, which makes it even harder to aim.
Beam weapons look like they were made for a game that should play 10 times slower. With terrible turn rate and even direct damage. The flamethrower is so bad, it can't kill the littlest bug before it bites you when you start the run.

The pacing is also wack. After running away and kiting swarms whole stage you have 30 seconds to get to the pod, often leaving piles of XP scattered around with no time to backtrack and pick it up. Stages often feel way too short.

Overall, it makes the game in its current state an unsatisfying slog. I'm ok with lack of content, but I want what's there to be at least enjoyable.
As this is Early Access, I very much hope they will fix those issues, but at the moment I can't recommend it.

The game has a lot of potential as in EA. However it has some questionable designs personally I will wait for later updates. 
1. Weapon overclock forces the player to use a weapon with capped capability, it is especially tough in the early game since every weapon will be without their major upgrades.
2. Meaningless progression resources, there are around 10 different ores for upgrading stats. They all are mined from the same way. Except for artificially adding hassle to the player, I can't find a reason for it.
3. Drop pod timer. This is debatable, map and mob spawn RNG will screw up player, and it feels awful when it happens.
4. No manual aiming. I can't fathom the reason.
addicting

Meh…
It's essentially an endless grind simulator where you run the same three levels over and over and over and over and over and over and over again.
And face the same enemies over and over and over….. 
The loop is that you unlock a new thing and then need to unlock additional things on the new thing. Rinse - repeat.

I’m 5 hours in and already bored as there is no difference. Yes you get stronger with time but since you reset to 0 for every “run” and RNG decides what you get during your run, there is not really any reason to stick around. 
The fact that all the unlocks, at least so far, feel like they are more or less the same, does not help the situation either. 
There are some “minor” buffs that will unlock and be available to you always, but they are a hardcore grind as well.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is sort of like the Diablo 3 endgame, where you run nephalem rift after rift in the hopes to get half a % stronger, maybe. 
Just in this game you get reset to 0 after each run, there is no real manual “difficulty” that you can choose, no co-op nor a leaderboard to compete against, no crafting and no skills.

Seriously, if you haven't played Diablo 3 yet, play it instead. 
Or Grim Dawn.
Or PayDay 2, if you want to do the same but in an FPS. 
These games cost more, yes but they will offer you several hundred hours of playtime as well as a massive amount of content more than Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor does currently and likely ever will. 


4 / 10 
A prime example that if you see a game explode on steam charts it does not mean it's good or worthwhile.

Is the game a new concept? Yes
Is the concept good in a way that one could keep players interested and build upon it? Likely not.


[b]Edit after reaching hazard 5 aka the highest difficulty[/b]
(And no, I’m not mad, I got through the difficulty, but literally wtf..)

Downright pathetic gamestate, score reduced to 2 / 10

Up until hazard 5 the game is, honestly, not hard but then it goes from a difficulty level of, let's say 6/10, to 11/10 due to:
.) Dropping down to as low as 20 FPS and/or stuttering around like crazy because, seemingly, the game engine is overloaded with the amount of mobs.

.) Half of the game's weapons are rendered immediately useless. Some due to balance issues, some due to the inability to control your character properly (no mouse input) and lacking manual targeting/shooting abilities.  

.) Skill? Nah -> RNG.
I played D3 up to rift level 145~ (150 is max), beat Grim Dawn on the highest difficulty and played through Payday 2 on “Death Sentence”, so I got the core idea of mop manipulation and movement but the simple fact that sheer RNG will be the major factor to decide how your game turns out is just dumb and lazy. Even if you count in re-rolls and just “farming”, in the end it amounts to the same: RNG.
I get that this game is following the concept of you just sinking insane amounts of time into it for minor “gain” but even if I look at other RNG based games like autochess, TFT or Hearthstone, they all have an equally high concept of skill behind it.
The only skill in DRG Survivor is to try 20 times so you get good RNG once and win. 
Sure you need to spend an equal amount of hours to find out what weapon combos work but ultimately, yet again, you then rely on RNG to get them (or rather upgrade far enough).

It's a roguelike. I love DRG, I love Roguelikes. I don't love this. I see what it's trying to be, but it isn't, and while it is in EA, the progression loop as it stands right now is bland af. I'll give it another go if it ever hits 1.0

Addendum: This shouldn't have been pushed to EA *this* early, the gameplay loop isn't there, the synergy of items that make good roguelikes great isn't there. The progression loop is tedious and boring, you can kill too much(speed up timer, no time to get resources) which is the dumbest feature, runs feel like there's either no time to do anything at all, or they're so slow because you don't have damage for the swarm. The IP is great, I'll check back on full release day 1, but as of right now, skip it and wait till later. Or don't. I'm not your dad. Get real beta testers instead of using steam users as your pilot testers. That behavior sucks.

The addition of mine-able blocks really adds a great deal of tactical depth to the horde-survival genre. Since the enemy pathfinding flows around the rocks to rach you (with minor exceptions), intelligent pathing and timing, of when you open a new passage, makes a huge difference, both in terms of concentrating the enemy into kill zones and clearing an escape route.

The mining of resources is also more dynamic than the typical of just picking stuff up off the ground. There's a lot of skill involved in choosing whether to go for upgrade minerals, meta-minerals, or focus on farming mobs for XP. The best players will find ways to do both at once, while also facing the right direction while mining, to get maximum effect from their directional weapons. There are also weapon types that excel in tight spaces, like piercing attacks. Digging a long tunnel can be a killer tactic with these.

The classes are all very distinct.
Scout focuses on running and gunning, with a bonus to Move and Crit.
Gunner has a forward-facing gatling, which alters his playstyle. He specializes in Kinetic weapons.
Engineer is very different - using stationary turrets or short-range fire/acid beam weapons and fast mining.
And I haven't done the 4th class yet.

All in all, it's a very refreshing take on the genre and far more engaging than the traditional style. Definitely recommend!

What I don't like:

So to conclude, very good start for an early access game and I can't wait to see what's added next.

Overall the game is very good and addictive. It looks good, mining is fun, farming gold is even more fun, rolling great level ups is fun, being super strong is fun, the classes feel solid, many weapon choices and most of them are quite fun to play and some of them actually feel novel and unique, different builds one can do, etc. However the game is early access and lacks some content one would expect from a full release, on the other hand the game is less than <10€ which makes it worth a purchase even as it is.

Some things that I would love to see some improvement in:
- Only three maps and the main objective of each map is the same and the final boss of each map is the same, however there are some tasks that requires one to play certain class or weapon which is nice.
- Meta process is thin even though I like that one can unlock new weapons and classes but the simple %-upgrades are not novel or interesting, they are linear and do not even scale, there are not milestones or anything to them (even some milestones could make them more interesting, like for example if spend 8 on luck one gets single free-roll per stage or whatever, something that adds more to the game-play).
- Some balance issues, all the classes and most weapons feel solid and strong at their highest potential however due to the fast scaling of difficulty during the game, getting there for most classes is much more inconsistent. Weird decisions such as melee mobs dealing less damage than ranged mobs, which makes the game feel a bit unpolished (player needs to spend most of his attention to dodge barrages of bullets that are 3-hit-kill instead of trying to solve for movement strategy against the horde of melee mobs). Mob damage scaling overall is also a bit too dramatic in my opinion on highest difficulty making the player feel made of glass which makes technically any single mob as dangerous as being just surrounded by the swarm itself. The main difficulty to the game comes from the fact that the mobs just hit too hard which is a bit boring and gives a little room for real improvement, "just try to dodge all of the 100 bullets instead of 99". Random factor is too heavily impacting the run in weapon selections, I think this should change so that at least the second weapon (first unlock) could be just picked or that the roll mechanism would never roll the same weapon choices already given. This applies also for the artifacts due to they being heavily unbalanced in strength which makes the random factor again impacting the run too heavily on which choices of artifacts one is given.
- Overclock unlocking mechanism is in my opinion bad. I mean it might be okay for the very first 15 minutes to the game but after longer time it becomes just redundant. It is just a single boring unlock one is forced to do before unlocking the weapons full potential for the future plays.
- Drop pod timer is always the same (30 seconds) after killing the last minor or major boss, I think trying to stall the killing of the boss due to this drop pod timer mechanism to farm the map more is counter productive. A flexible timer (giving player more time to return to drop pod if the boss is killed early) would in my opinion be better by not punishing the player for killing the bosses too fast.

I like DRG, I like survivor-like games (Can't say I'm an expert in them, but I did find a few I really enjoy). I don't think DRG Survivors is in a great state right now. The game does not provide the same highs a survivor-like game does and often times the runs left me feeling frustrated above anything else. 
The secondary objectives for each stage feel really tedious and almost always require you to go out of your way to do them, which is opposite of what the secondaries feel like in base Deep Rock Galactic. But they are crucial for a successful completion of the run, especially once you start playing on higher hazards. 
The permanent upgrades that you buy for credits + resources are extremely basic and minor (+2% to pickup radius, damage, mining speed, etc) and do not provide you with any sense of progression. It doesn't seem to be too "grindy" to max them, but they didn't feel rewarding to me once I got them anyway. 
Regarding the weapon upgrades, most of the weapon upgrades for leveling are just basic stat increases (+5/10/15/20% reload speed/fire rate/damage/whatever). There are overclocks, to unlock them you need to dump 12 upgrades into a specific weapon in the same run, and they don't even unlock in the same run, so have fun potentially throwing a few runs just to get the good weapon upgrades. A minor thing is that I found in-game information a bit lacking (for example what does each element's effect does), but I reckon it will be addressed in the future.
I also have personal gripes with the lack of manual aiming for at least one weapon. I understand that it's a design choice, but it did cause me a few frustrating experiences in my short playtime, such as the gunner staring down a dreadnought 10m directly ahead of him and not using the minigun for whatever reason.
I didn't have a good time with the game, but maybe you will? Definitely will revisit this in the future as there's still a lot of interesting ideas that I'd like to see expanded.

Changed the review after unlocking most stuff in the game. Stage 5 of the first biome is a slog and it doesn't feel like the remaining three-four weapons are worth grinding over.

Generally speaking, a lot of people explained in detail why it is not a good game right now. 

- balance is bad, 
- most upgrades are useless, 
- leveling up is slow, 
- mob/boss variety is nonexistent, 
- explosion ranges on higher levels are way too large, 
- all "class-specific" bonuses bar dodge can be acquired in the game and are worthless, 
- locking weapons behind classes is useless and limits variety,
- the need to restart the run to use overclocks is just there to pad out the runtime, etc.

Would love to see this game become better than it is now. It is not impossible, and most problems are solvable. I want this game to succeed, but cannot recommend it now, because it is arguably one of the more difficult VS-clones on the market right now, and the difficulty is not particularly fair or worth it most of the time.

Original review at 10ish hours:

[strike]The game's great. Balance is all over the place and it is mercilessly difficult early and late-game. However, if a game dev thinks that it is fine to remove a single voice line ("Die like your mother did!") in a fictional game about fictional creatures killing other fictional creatures just because "well, it can be a bad experience for this one person that complained about it", then I have no faith in such a flimsy developer that can be this easily peer-pressured -- and thus, cannot, in good faith, recommend the game. [/strike]
I bought this game because of Asmongold.

I played the hell out of the demo version and was chomping at the bit for the EA release.  Obviously, I've spent most of my time diving into the game instead of praising the Devs for releasing a more finished product than some recent "AAA" games.  This game is great if you enjoy the genre.

That's not to say there aren't some blemishes: hit boxes/detection don't necessarily feel consistent: specially with exploder enemies or wasps in 3rd Biome, some starting weapons are clearly better for survival than others and some weapon balancing is very much needed to bring them up to viable options (looking at you mini shock towers).

The game is still worth the price of entry, even moreso when on sale.

I'm digging up what these devs are putting down.

This is not the action roguelike you're looking for. This game doesn't respect your time, gets very grindy, and doesn't offer nearly as much variety as games like Vampire Survivors, which costs less than half as much as this game.

DRG: Survivor is plagued with terrible voice acting, uninteresting progression, and unforgivably flawed balance.

If you love the same voice lines being repeated over and over, in nothing more than a slight pitch shift between characters, then you'll love this game, otherwise, you'll hate it.

If you love your meta-progression costs to increase exponentially to the point where farming resources for another mere 1% incremental upgrade becomes nigh on pointless about 20 hours into the experience, then you'll love this game, otherwise, you'll hate it.

If you love the idea of different characters and their classes being completely gated out of higher difficulty runs because their weapons literally don't do enough damage against the most basic of mobs before you're inevitably overwhelmed due to the amount of damage the game demands versus what it provides for you, then you'll love this game, otherwise, you'll hate it.

Don't be fooled by the early access tag, this game is feature complete and the development direction is very clear.

This game is so bad, that any curiosity I had to buy the main Deep Rock Galactic game has been killed. If they can ruin the most basic principles of a survivorlike/action roguelike then I'll not waste even more money on any other representation of this franchise under their development ethos.

tldr; Avoid like the plague, buy 3 copies of Vampire Survivors instead.

Never played a game in this genre before so not going to compare it to anything but here's some initial comments after 5 hours.

[b]Positives[/b]

+ The game is very fun
+ A very polish early access ("EA") game
+ So many different gun and perk combinations - seems endless already and I have no doubt they will keep building on this
+ Gameplay loop is enjoyable although it can get repetitive
+ The sounds and voicelines are great
+ Incredible value for the pricetag

[b]Negatives[/b]

- The first available class is the Scout.  It's very basic and I actually found it quite boring to begin with (while I was learning the game) and this is probably off-putting for new players.  Ironically, it's now my favourite class.
- Enemy variety is quite low - particularly the end-boss - but this is expected for an EA game and no doubt will be built on
- The robot companion needs a lot of work.  I believe this has been confirmed on the roadmap already.
- No tutorial and explanation of various different mechanics, in particular the effect of each elemental attack and the importance of mining.  Overclocking is a big part of the late-game as well that isn't explained at all.

Overall, absolutely loving it.  Recommended.

And repeat. It felt like I was playing one of those fake mobile game ads that has the Deep Rock Galactic name on it.

Sorry for my harshness.  I do not recommend the game at this current state,  just play the original Deep Rock Galactic.

This is not DRG. This does not play anything like DRG (even things that could be). The best features of DRG (tricky mining, mobility, meaningful co-op) do not translate to this game.

It uses DRG as a setting and it sort of works, but mechanically it has very little to offer. At the moment upgrades (both in-run and permanent) and boring and linear (damage, fire rate, reload speed, piercing and XP) without exception. The 2 things that set it apart from a sea of other survivor games (mining and DRG weapons) aren't interesting enough at the moment to offset an otherwise generic base.

I suspect people only like it because it's DRG and the Ghost Ship Games are a great dev team. This game is not developed by Ghost Ship Games, just published by their branch. 
I.e. if it was "Mining survivors" by exact same studio it'll be sitting at ~60-70%.

Have a look at [b]Swarm Grinder[/b]. 
Same genre with mining and drop pods (so adjacent theme). It still has balance issues, but that games attempted to push the boundaries. This one doesn't.

As an Early Access "beta" game, a lot might yet change, so don't lose hope!  But right now, I can't recommend this highly anticipated game.  

If you were like me and were very excited for a DRG skinned survival game, That's exactly what this is.  But in it's current form, it doesn't scale well.  Most of the upgrades are actually useless.  And though they sound exciting and helpful, they will hurt the players chance of survival. In other words, the devs are have created a game which half of the content should be strictly avoided.  That's bad.

Currently the winning (and seemingly only) strategy is to focus exclusively on 18th level upgrades, trying to maximize DPS with gold and nitra drop pods, making a "bunker" until the the elite shows up, and then kiting the entire mob until you kill it, farming EXP. At Hazard 4, your entire run will hinge on RNG giving you the right upgrades and you knowing not to run into corners.  At Hazard 5 you need to be an elite player with the blessing of god.

"Survivor" games are simple by nature, which often have clear winning strategies, and clear losing ones, and a lot of content in between.  The RNG fight for good outcomes and player skill have a lot more nuance than this, including ways to turn the RNG in your favor, and accepting certain risks for early/mid game strategy to benefit or hurt your endgame.  That's just not possible here. You are a glass cannon with a pickaxe.  Your foes are all bullet sponges who eat rocks for a living. Life is hell.  

But worst of all, No beer, and no Steve!

Jilted difficullty aside, the game is plagued with a number of other aspects in desperate need of refinement. Unfortunate starting weapons, delayed pickup of new weapons, prolonged level-up grinds, some punishing dive requirements, and a frustrating cadence all suck potential out of the game, especially for new players.  

If you level up certain guns to their final form, the game is a cakewalk.  But they take away your pickaxe early on and you are forced to continue mining with your forehead.  So getting to that point is just a chore. This game is a chore.  

If you need me, I'll be at the bar.

Did not encounter any major bugs (heh) but did see a few times where mobs, including mini bosses got randomly stuck and refused to move from 1 spot. Somehow the supply drop messed up their pathing.

Gameplay wise- The game rushes you thru each stage too fast. Does not give you any time to actually enjoy the game. Drop-pod leaving after only 30sec is way too fast as well. No time to finish a 2nd objective (if you havent finished it during the run).. or collect some exp on the ground... you just have go straight for the pod or  gameover.
Overall the game just makes you feel stressed from start of finish. they should slow it down a bit, and give more time to get to the pod.

RNG factor is also bigger than most similar game in the genre. You get outscale and outswarmed in this game way too fast if you dont get a bunch of high tier upgrades early on (mostly in higher difficulties)

Also lacks stuff like manual aim. Some weapons are outright unusable without this feature. Trying to aim manually makes you walk in the direction of the mobs, which often results in taking a lot of dmg. But that is the only to hit mobs with some weapons.

And honestly, overall the weapons are not well balanced either. There are a few which are insanely good, but not even available on every class it seems... which in turn also makes some of the classes significantly worse.

If they can fix some of this stuff, would definitely make it more enjoyable.

DRG: Survivor is an interesting choice of direction for the IP, but a stunningly natural one. The original game (in which I have 250+ hours) thrived on the feeling of beating back hundreds of murderous bugs and scraping by in an environment that, more than anything else, wants you dead.
Survivor, then, is a game that thrives on the feeling of beating back thousands of murderous bugs, so let's start with the positives.
[list]
	[*]The modelling work is fantastic. The game's visual style is distinct, but reminiscent of DRG in just the right way. The only visual assets reused that I noticed were menu icons.
	[*] Digging is a lot of fun, if a little bit slow. The ability to mine bunkers into walls and abandon them as soon as you get overwhelmed is great, and it's a blast to design your own near-misses with death.
	[*]Performance is rock-solid on my rig (R5 5600G, RTX2070S, 16GB RAM). It's easy to make a game like this run terribly - even Vampire Survivors chugs towards the end - but DRG:S is a smooth experience the whole way through.[*]The core of the game itself is fun - this is not a total indictment against the game, and if it seems up your street you should pick it up and give it a go. Early Access means that the title gets some leeway, and in 12 months I think it'll be great.
[/list]
With those things said, here are the things I don't like about the game right now, and hope that they will be addressed.
[list]
	[*]The final boss is pretty terrible, and there's only one so you always know what you'll be fighting. An enormous hitbox with an extremely telegraphed lunge attack that deals a huge amount of damage leads to one of three outcomes in my experience:
	[list]
		[*]A fairly easy (see: boring) fight where you kite the boss around the stage until it's dead
		[*]"What the hell!? I got trapped by bugs and couldn't move!"
		[*]"Goddammit, I didn't react to the telegraph fast enough and my move speed was too low so I got one-shot..."
	[/list]
	[*]The game feels content-padded to the Nth degree.
	Overclocks are unlocked once a weapon reaches level 12, which takes quite a long time, and they aren't even unlocked for the run you're on. Without overclocks, runs feel wasted or overly difficult, and losing a run right before you unlock the overclocks for a weapon feels awful.
	[*]The stat upgrades are fairly boring percentage increases in stats. I get that we need something to spend our mined minerals on, but these get expensive really fast and, honestly, aren't enjoyable to grind for.
	[*]The content in the game in places feels somewhat uncreative. 
	[list]
		[*]Overclocks themselves are generally uncreative stat boosts. The few that aren't are great fun; I'd like to see the devs get a lot crazier with these.
		[*]Artifacts suffer the same fate as overclocks. Not massively exciting, though the potential is obvious for cool combos if slightly reworked.
	[/list]
	[*]Voicelines are mostly reused from DRG, and I personally noticed some wonky audio mixing between each one. This one isn't a deal breaker at all, but later in the game's early access life it would be nice for it to get its own unique set of lines to really set the atmosphere apart from DRG.
[/list]

All in all, I can't recommend this game in its early access launch state. However, GSG are great developers for DRG original, and I have to imagine they'll guide this game well as its publisher. This is one to put on your wishlist and come back in 2025 - I'm pretty certain it'll be great by then.

Really enjoying this. I'm not a huge player of what I suppose is the "roguelite arena survival" genre but this one has me hooked. It has DRG's charm, nice graphics, and I love the added intractability with the map that mining offers you versus similar titles in the genre which generally consist of completely open fields.

I will say that I have a few complaints though. 

First off, unlocking overclocks sucks. Any run you dedicate to leveling up a new weapon to 12 is basically thrown as a loss because of how powerful overclocks are. Perhaps once you hit 12 on a new gun, you get to pick 2 OC's from the 6/12 pool for it, then proceed to level it up further to 18 during that same run if you want. As it stands, the current system discourages experimentation which is really kind of the point of this genre. 

Lvl 18 Overclocks in general are a bit too strong, IMO. The correct way to play seems to just giga pump one weapon and pick up utility in all other slots. Basically any weapon can carry a run with a lvl 18 OC, but that means you're either pumping your starter or the weapon you get at lvl 5, as the lvl 15 weapon comes too late and the lvl 25 is always just a wash. Feels weird/bad to have 2 to 3 weapon slots every run that are just there because you have to pick something. Maybe this is a personal playstyle issue but it seems worse in every scenario to level up multiple guns halfway rather than cranking an early acquired gun to lvl 18.

WASD controls are rough for a lot of the "shoots in facing direction" weapons. An option for mouse turning would be nice. Playing on controller is fine though, and is what I've been doing since my first run with the Warthog.

That said, positive overall and I am optimistic about this game's future.

DRG fan here (500+hrs). As of now, I cant recommend this game. Its extremely simple, only moving around. Will update as the game evolves

In it's current state, it's OK. I do like how elements from the original game, DRG (my beloved) have been well-translated to this, including the iconic "V" to "Rock and Stone!". However, most autoshooters play to a sort of power-fantasy endgame, where your cumulative upgrades ultimately make you feel nearly immortal, and doing big gobs of damage all over the screen. Games like 20 minutes till Dawn execute this perfectly. DRG Survivor attempts to do this via the unstable overclocks unlocked at lvl 18, but they simply aren't powerful enough to play to that power-fantasy endgame. Sure, they're good. But they're almost never GREAT because enemies feel tanky regardless of how many damage mods you stack. In addition to that, non-overclock upgrades rarely feel impactful, even as they stack into the lategame, and the only powerup drop in the game at this point is the magnet, which is excessively rare. Lastly, the rogue-lite elements (permanent upgrades between runs) lack impact as well, and are limited to minor buffs to our character, with increasingly scaled costs. I'd personally like to see upgrades both for our character, and for Bosco, to add more rogue-lite elements and (perhaps) make our decisions between rounds feel like they have more meaning. Ultimately this game gets a thumbs up from me, but not because of its current state. I'm sure that the devs will make improvements here and there, and I anticipate the finished product will be a far better experience, but as I said in the beginning, this game is OK for now.

DRG: Survivor has the potential to become an even greater game, especially since it's an Early Access title.

Right now it feels.. weird to play. There's a weird balance of over- and underpowered weapons. Most of the upgrades are simply "increase stat X", only a handful really change up the weapon or the gameplay.

Personally I do not like the idea of having to level up a weapon to 12 in order to unlock overclocks for the next run. It kind of forces you to deal with a weapon in its 'weak' state combined with the fact that the in-game upgrades don't have much variety.

The difficulty progression can be overwhelming. If your weapons don't pack a punch (namely because you don't get good upgrades or you don't have overclocks unlocked) you spend most of your time clinging for survival.
If you do end up with good upgrades it is usually towards the end of the dive where the game is pretty much already over.

The final boss is.. boring. It walks and jumps towards you. If you have OP weapons you are pretty much done. If you happen to be cornered when it jumps to you it may end your run.

I like the mining system, but it's overshadowed by overwhelming swarms and the limited terrain. Enemies also have a tendency to hide behind the walls and pretty much get a sneaky hit on you.

I believe most of the issues can be fixed simply if upgrades are treated differently, but as it is right now my runs are split up into "I have good weapons, easy run" and "I simply cannot keep up with the swarms".

I still think the game is relatively fun, but you might want to grab it during a sale for now.

Dude.

They were able to merge Vampire Survivors with OG Deep Rock Galactic.

9 hours straight in the first sitting and its not even its launch build, they definitely nailed it with this one.

It's currently difficult in ways that aren't fun and don't have interesting challenges/any way to deal with them.

Small bugs can be completely hidden behind terrain due to the 3d camera.

Drop pod timer can be impossible to meet due to terrain/swarm positioning and you have no control over even when it will come down.

Swarms can spawn very close completely cornering you. Even though you know when swarms will come you don't have much control over where you are when they do.

The boss at the end of each level requires perfect dodging, but the terrain doesn't necessarily allow for it.

Lots of the mission-specific unlocks depend heavily on RNG during a run.

Personally, I much prefer Deep Rock Galactic...over this Survivor version.
I prefer to reload when I want to, shoot when I want to, and to plan tactics with my own decisions in mind.
Yeah, I know people say a game like this, an auto-shooter, takes skill...so does DRG.  Just a different sort, and a different sort of person enjoys auto-shootes.
I'm not one of them.

currently, DRG survivor feels the most watered down, slowest and least impactful survivor out there, with meta progression thats both a slog and in such small amounts you can rarely tell it's making a difference, the gunner feels like the only character than can actually survive a full dive but thats only if you get an above average run, 2 of the 6 elements (acid and fire) can't be told apart from each other in any obvious way, as appose to cold which slows and has a chance to freeze, electric which arcs between nearby enemies and plasma which bounces between enemies, in mission upgrades can range from 2% movement speed (common rarity) to 40% status affect dmg (legendary), leveling is done in such a way that unless you focus almost entirely on one of the 4 weapons you can have equipped in one run then theres no chance you're getting it to it's last overclock level, if at all if you happen to be unlucky with the upgrade RNG or can't survive that long and to even let a weapon equip overclocks you have to get it to lvl 12 in a single run when you first unlock it, which is harder than it might sound since you dont unlock the overclocks for that gun in the same run, so you're better off doing a haz 1 mission to get it to lvl 12 and then die cause of the poor meta progression theres no point it continuing plus the underpowered weapon will very likely not get you through the boss unless you really really stack upgrades or manage to get another weapon to max lvl, theres more I could point out but I'll stop here for the sake of a semi short review and because I dont think the other aspects are that important to overall game quality.

in short meta progression is near pointless, upgrades dont feel impactful until you get *some* overclocks. unlocking new weapons and character variants is a chore and so is unlocking overclocks for said weapons, out of the 5 difficulties even has 2 and 3 feel impossible unless you get good RNG/enemy spawns/weapons
overall I dont want to seem to harsh but this has to be the worst survivor type game out there, theres a reason vampire survivors basically invented this genre

if you like Deep Rock Galactic and also fancy auto shooters like Vampire Survivors or Brotato, the you will love this game.

It adds to this emerging genre with a lot of content already, themed around Deep Rock Galactic. The base game loop reflects that of the game its based off of, but in a more concentrated format.

Fully playable and enjoyable in early access. A  perfect match for the SteamDeck and other similar handhelds.

---

With that said, there are some things I would like to see changed or at least have the option of modifying.

1. The end timer is wayy too short. I get we aren't supposed to meander around after completing a "floor" to collect everything, but 30 seconds if you're already massively kiting is nary enough. I've lost runs just because I was forced to run through a horde to try and make it to the drop-pod in time and ended up just dying from damage (expected).
I would like to see it changed from 30 seconds to 45 seconds or a flat 60 seconds.

2. There currently exists some balancing issues with some of the weapons. Namely, the "beam" weapons can be pretty under-powered unless you focus level them. But then you get to the late-game and that's the only high-leveled weapon(s) you have. This might not be an issue per-say but rather the intended outcome of not choosing a more balanced set of weapons. In one instance, I had fully upgraded flamethrower, sludge cannon, and flame turrets. I could not kill enemies fast enough around me and ended up getting swarmed.
The only reason I bring up this is the possibility of more interesting build choices.
With that said, this isn't necessarily a stop-gap that needs to be fixed. Maybe running beam weapons is supposed to be more challenging?

3. A few bugs and issues I've encountered so far.
 - On controller, you can begin moving immediately after regaining control from the pod. On keyboard, you have to release the keys and repress them to start moving.
- Some performance issues that bring the Steamdeck down a little, which drains the battery. This is to be expected with the sheer volume of entities and models in the world, especially towards the end-game. However, it would be nice (and probably already planned) to incorporate some changes to allow for lower-end systems and handhelds to gain better performance.
- You can glitch the exit countdown and stay on a floor indefinitely. No doubt will be fixed.
- Due to how floors are generated, sometimes there are single-tile crevasses you can get hung up on while fleeing enemies that isn't obvious why you stopped moving. If these lie within a cluster of rock, it's even worse.

4. Some of the upgrades seem to be just negative overall. Maybe this isn't the case due to never actually picking them, or perhaps there are unique synergies I'm missing out on. I'm not saying that every upgrade should be positive in every way, but it would be better to follow the same kind of design principals that Deep Rock Galactic follows of upgrades having interesting trade-offs.

---

A Gem Among Roguelites

Having spent countless hours plumbing the depths of alien worlds, blasting bugs, and bringing home loot with my crew of jolly space dwarves in 2020’s excellent Deep Rock Galactic, I was curious how the experience would translate to a single-player, top-down approach in Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor. Let me tell you—it translates brilliantly!

Familiar Yet Fresh: Survivor retains the heart of the original while offering a refreshing twist. As one of four distinct classes armed with auto-firing weapons, you deploy into a hostile environment to squash endless insectoid enemies. But here’s the unique angle: mining. You’ll need to dig up gold and nitra to buy upgrades, harvest rare minerals for permanent unlocks, and rush to collect specific resources on each floor for bonus objectives.

Good Vibes: From energetic dialogue barks to the bombastic soundtrack, Survivor delivers on those good vibes. It’s a subculture of its own within multiplayer co-op, and there are nods to the community and player-made memes that show this spin-off was thoughtfully put together.

Reloads Matter: Survivor introduces reloading to the genre. Since you can’t trigger a reload manually, you must keep a careful eye on your ammo bars. Reloads add an interesting dimension to crafting builds. Prioritizing reload time upgrades becomes crucial for tough runs.

Gunner Glory: As a Gunner, mowing down hordes of bugs with a torrent of lead from multiple nozzles never gets old. But now, reload management adds depth. It’s the difference between being a walking death machine and getting overwhelmed.
Satisfying Sound Effects: The sound effects of smashing bugs and rocks give off a sense of accomplishment. Every swing of the pickaxe reverberates with purpose.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a mashup between Vampire Survivors style game and DRG. I am a fan of both of these games but I think it fails at both styles. It is trying to be something new but taking wrong lessons. I think all my gripes with the game can be resolved but I don't think the developer is going to change the direction of the game. 

Visual presentation is great but the game has visibility issues, some mission side objectives are obscured by terrain (you can still see on minimap). XP orbs are too bright and can obscure some small enemies.

Upgrades would be OK except you can't have overclocks unless you upgrade weapon to level 12 in one dive before. This is artificial game length padding and very annoying.

Another problem is how you finish the level, because if you kill enemies too fast you will have to end it too soon to gather enough nitra/gold to upgrade weapons. It punishes you for killing enemies too fast. Levels are generated so if you don’t find resources in the first few minutes (RNG on top of RNG) then you will have a hard time finding them later. This is also why mining speed is the most important upgrade (another RNG).

This would be fine if enemies were arriving in waves but they are just arriving constantly so killing them faster will not work and will spawn bosses faster. You have to remember that you can't avoid shooting bosses other than just running away so again you need mining speed. 

All of this is frustrating and has nothing to do with difficulty, but everything with not giving you enough control over your actions. I cannot recommend the game at this time.

It's an excellent survivor that I loved during its demo version.

The version currently offered adds levels, allows you to play other classes, test other weapons... In short, it adds content.

The content offered is well provided for a game in alpha, and I am convinced that it will continue to expand, be refined, and offer more synergies and builds.

The level design is successful. Each biome has its own atmosphere, impossible to confuse them.
I think it is possible to push the work a little further and make them even more different from each other, both visually and technically.

Events specific to each biome and difficulty would be a blessing.

The only real problem with the game at the moment is its speed of completing objectives. The bar fills up too quickly and it is impossible to take advantage of the objectives and your build. I want my dwarf to have time to dig, to harvest, and to find himself in very tense moments because he is stingy.

I also hope that other types of waves, monsters or events related to filler will complete the whole thing.

The game has a format that would allow it to be adapted to different playing times, solo or multiplayer. I would definitely see the arrival of an express mode (which would rather resemble the current version (improved, of course)), a normal mode and a long mode.
Endless is yet another kettle of fish and has been announced for the future.

A great thing, in any case, the spirit of Deep Rock is there. I hope it remains Deep Rock rather than a copy of another survivor: after all, I work hard to be rewarded with a sandwich and a beer.

TLDR: Its addicting and has a lot of potential!

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a survivor-like game based on the DRG original universe. However, unlike many other survivor-likes, this game does not let you boost your stats to the point where your choices don't matter and you can just stand in the middle of the map AFK for minutes or hours. In DRG:S you need to conciously navigate the map to mine resources and stay ahead of the game if you want to complete your objectives and progress, which I think makes this game more challenging and unique than other games of the same genre.
Very easy and enjoyable game.

This is what you want to see from early access game. The level of polish is beyond expectation. Gameplay wise, it's more addicting than (red) sugar. Flows perfectly, pretty much self-explanatory, you always want to go for yet another "last" run.

Got a small grudge with visuals though. While mostly perfect, the clutter can become real. Bugs sneak up on you through burning/acid surfaces mixed up with several explosions and hundreds of XP orbs lying around. Not to mention when a bugger gets you from behind a rock without a chance of being spotted because of the POV. Maybe highlight obscured enemies or add some transparency options for player's effects?

Also, flying enemies hit boxes are far from intuitive.

And please oh please let us use the mouse to control our dwarves. It's much harder to position yourself perfectly using WASD (and some weapons just don't work without proper positioning).

Visually - AWESOME
Gameplay - SPECTACULAR
Digging/mining mechanics - GROUND BREAKING (pun intended)

General feel of the game is REALLY REALLY GOOD (certainly worth the money)
-------------------------------------------------------------
What could use some attention:
1) Events - cool but little variety. same stuff over and over again. Art. drop could be random out of 4-5 little objectives instead of 1. Secondary objective could be virtually anything...
2) Enemies - cool but again, no surprises, Variety from run to run would be welcome.
3) Characters/classes - feels shallow, there is very little difference (impact on the game) between classes, most of class specifics is worth few lvl-up bonuses and limited gun set you will be choosing from.
4) Each class mod run different wepons - but for some reason they are not listed anywhere... learning by doing.
5) Artifacts could be made more impactful. Few % dodge chance or reload speed ain't magic.
6) Talent/skill tree - flat % bonuses (boring)
7) Shop economy - meh, incremental impact on the game, you basically buy few lvl-ups if you mined enough of gold or red gold.
8) Game modes - NONE, just 3 maps with 5 difficulty levels.
9) Looks like pretty cool base for a multiplayer (PvP, Coop PvE)

All in all game is great, just seem to me like slightly underutilized potential. I'd love to see developement direction towards Nordic Ashes: Survivors of Ragnarok with multiple levels of character, equipement and talent tree complexity. Idea is great, engine works super smooth. This Game is (for me) an absolute disappointment.
On the Surface Level... the game is true to the Lore of DRG. But DRG-Survivor is sadly one of those games, where the Developer didn’t understand why Vampire Survivors was so successful.

Some points come to mind:
Balanced RNG
Clever Positioning to mow down the hordes of Evil.
Progression Systems that value the lifetime of the consumer.
Lots of varieties of Core Classes
Lots of varieties to build up your virtual Barbie or Ken.
The “Carrot” to keep you positively hooked.
That's a few of my opinions, what makes the Vampire Survivor Genre so much fun to play

DRGS has none of these!

The Game is (in my opinion) an unbalanced Mess. 
That will raise his ugly Head a few Hours in.
Best Example:
The Dreadnought Boss has a JUMP - Attack without telegraphing his intentions where he wants to land… (on the player thou..)
YOU can’t Kite him because you fire in the front direction… 
He is faster than you…
So If you turn around to show him yours truly Gatling Gun…
nah
He is on to you in a millisecond, or he jumps into your face,,, 

Other weird design decisions (again, my opinion):
The Stage Phases progress way too fast for completing your Mission in one go.

The Store Credits must be mined… without any marker via HUD or a Mini Map. .
Because all is going too fast… your Progression turns into a Grind fest…

Mining minerals and stuff… is much, much  slower than normal Rocks. In later stages, you can’t mine anymore the stuff you need, because the bugs are humping you… combined with the Front-Firing Arc. a death sentence.

In later Stages the bugs get faster and faster… faster than you… Elite Bugs rushing through the Rocks, like a hot Knife through Butter… and because there is no Kiting… Death awaits…

During the Eye-Candy, you can't see near Bugs, in a Game of Positioning, deadly.

Weapons are locked behind a Level Gate. Every Dwarf gets 4 of them… very fast, you have seen all there is in the “Charles Heston little Gun Shop” Department.

Also, not much variation in the Artifacts, Items, Equipment and so forth. After 2–3 Hours, you have seen everything.

The procedural generated Map can lead you into a Cul-de-sac. Followed by: “A swarm is approaching… “Game over Man, Game Over”. 

After 4 Hours of Gameplay:
The DigDug System is a very good thought of the Developer
Sadly, hindered by the “Slow Mining of Minerals” Decision.
The Price is good!

In my Book, DRG feels rushed, unbalanced, not Fun! 
The Progression System would get Korean Pro Grinders angry… too much grind…
It feels not like an Early Access Game… more like a Proof-of-Concept, Early Alpha Version of what may come to DRGS.

60/100

What would in my Opinion benefit the Game:
Twin stick Mechanic like in Soulstone Survivor.
Forced Reload Button, for the Swarm Warning. (Even as an Update Artifact!)
Kiting, see Twin stick.
Dodge Roll, if you want to keep the “Jump Attack”
Better Mission System
Better paced Levels… we are Miners, not Troopers on Klendathu
Better UI / HUD Elements to let the Gamer grasp the Situation better.
Outlined Bugs if they get near you
Telegraphed Attacks and other QoL improvements.

Alternatives:
Soulstone Survivors
Vampire Survivors.

Pretty bare bones at the moment, but a VERY solid foundation for what should be a great game. DRG Survivors adds onto the new "Survivor" genre through the addition of base DRG's core mechanics, most prominently  digging, which adds a new level of setpiece based mechanics and strategy that works great. 

I'm not sure if this was worth the $13.50 I paid for it, as I will keep playing it as it gets developed, enjoying new content and mechanics as they get added. I expect I will get my money's worth. This early version already got me more than halfway there with over 8 hours of enjoyment before it started to feel same-y.

[h1]TLDR; Not Fun[/h1]
On paper, this game seems very interesting, but after playing for hours, its boring. (current patch: Hotfix 0.2.241d)
However, I'm curious on how the DRG weapons are implemented, so I'm playing for more hours to unlock the remaining weapons, which sad to say at the moment, its not rewarding. For those who care, the meta progression is awefully stingy and not worth the time for late-game.

Also, I played enough survivor-like games to figure out that this early access is NOT designed with the overpowered-endgame-build roguelike experience, which is the final straw for my negative review.

EDIT: Currently the late-game experience is terrible, weapons unlocked after rank 12 are underwhelming, having bad stats or overall the same mechanic. Also, the balancing is off on hazard 5, maybe more contents in future will help, but as of now, its purposely made to be impossible to push players away from full completion, early access or not, its disgusting for completionist.

[h2]More Rants[/h2]
- first, why no shield?
- need encylopedia page for unlocked weapon info (for overclocks as well, see next)
- overclocks should NOT be locked behind 12-levels (maybe unlocks entry in encyclopedia instead)
- unstable overclocks should be more drastic (like boomerang collect XP, this one good) for an impactful build
- different weapons don't have special synergy
- hazard 5 is impossible, calling it "challenge to skillful player" won't change the fact that its just bad level design
- DoT damage is too low, investing upgrade into these has no meaning, should either scales better with each upgrade, or mechanically change it to have distinct effects (like % based, amplify damage, etc)
- no loadout customization or random events to make interesting gameplay (although there's [spoiler]golden lootbug[/spoiler])
- lootbug should not be immune to weapon damage or explosion
- personally, I prefer spending resources to unlock weapon instead of grinding each class
- or, meta progression for each weapon, potentially unlocks overclock at the end (could be a nice goal for grinding)
- it seemed that once everything maxed, overflowing resources are useless (but during run, I still need to mine them for XP)

[h2]Personal Prefences/Issues[/h2]
- I'm sad to discover that flamethrower spins instead of shooting forward
- Gunner's minigun shooting forward is okay, but useless while mining (please make it do some mining, or start cooldown when not shooting)
- Engineer's shotgun should not auto-shoot when there's no target in front (but its working great when converted into plasma)
- [strike]Gunner's LeadBurster stuck above wall, causing it to miss[/strike] (fixed)
- Most grenades, should explode faster or upon impact, currently it always missed the target due to the delay
- I'm very upset that Breach Cutter [spoiler]shoots balls[/spoiler] and does not pierce through wall
- Autocannon is like a scuffed assault rifle, NGL
- Smart Rifle is dumb, target-locking is way too slow (i doubt can be improved with upgrades)
- Deepcore PGL (the grenade launcher) deals too little damage and too slow, and, the explosion SFX with smoke is blocking vision
- Impact Axe is awesome, BUT, it sometimes pushes enemies towards the player
At first I thought this game generates far lower dopamine than Vampire Survivor, then I figured out you can just approach exploding bugs to make them explode.
Rocking it

Its just not that good right now, not that its terrible but it's missing a ton of little things from the original game that gave that game it's reputation. The boss is one of the most basic boring bosses, even for a dreadnought; all it does is walk to you and sometimes do a jump attack that isn't always that avoidable in specific situations. the upgrades don't really change your shots in any way, all they do is do +% stat effects barring some extremely rare upgrades/final overclocks. After trying Vampire Survivors and having played Goobies its obvious that this is just some lack luster half baked idea of something that should be cool in theory but the devs lacked an understanding in the core components of what made those games fun in the first place.

Played the demo to death when it was first available and had a good time knowing that nothing was final.
It's in early access now so I'm still lenient, but I'm also disappointed with it's current state.

-No Miner's Manual, figured this would be like the first thing they would add.
-Aiming on weapons suck, especially throwables. Get used to being chased by a swarm 100 times over and your weapons to target the fresh solitary grunt spawning off screen.
-Poor weapon balance, especially with the higher hazards the weak weapons will end up feeling even weaker.
-Item pools fill with trash fast. Most classes share weapons, so the more you unlock trash the more your choices will be filled with trash. Requiring you to dump all your gold hoping the reroll doesn't just give you the same exact selection. For artifacts you're basically screwed if you get trash because no rerolls.
-Pacing is terrible which gets very obvious in higher hazards where it just shoots out bullet sponges that if you can't kill fast enough will eventually just out grow you.
-Unlocks/upgrades are incredibly sluggish and grueling to go through with the game feeling incredibly stale.

Super Disappointing.

I came in as a big fan of both Deep Rock and Vampire Survivor like games but it unfortunately feels very underwhelming.
The key problem is the pacing and balance feel very off. Enemies get incredibly bullet spongy, with many of the weapons needing re-balancing to make them even viable. Levels end up being a slog of kiting a big blob of bugs around the map as you plink away at them while trying to do mission objectives and snag resources. Outside of exploding bugs and spitters all the enemies feel the same, just with slightly different health pools.
Upgrades are mostly disappointing minor stat upgrades that make numbers go up. I never feel like I am putting together a build, just choosing whatever gives the best bonus. Overclocks are boring and do little to spice up gameplay. Permanent upgrades are a boring grind for minor % bonuses. It all feels like a lot of grinding for a slow trickle of underwhelming rewards. 

The good news is all of this is definitely fixable, but right now I would recommend waiting on this to see how it cooks. There is a decent foundation for a game here, but right now the balancing and pacing of it makes it not very fun to play.

If you like DRG, get it.
If you like "Survivor" games, get it.
If you like dwarves, get it.
Heck, if you like Roguelites, get it.
If you don't like these, you're clearly a leaf lover so you need to make changes to your life. Get it.

On a serious note, it's definitely one of the best in genre.
There are four classes with their different loadouts (different starting weapon and bonuses), multiple biomes with their own small kinks\ a bunch of different weapons and overclocks (special bonus or bonus/penalty combos you unlock at certain levels that can really change the way the weapon works)

So there is a lot of variety and more is already announced. And of course - you have to unlock all! There are also difficulty levels so you can test your mettle at higher levels while you unlock permanent bonuses like a roguelike.

Seriously. Get it.
More importantly: ROCK AND STONE!!

The game is very fun and hooks you with the big numbers getting bigger. 

There is a lot of questionable balancing, but its version 1 of early access so that's to be expected (although the recon scout feedback from the beta several months ago seemingly went ignored). I very much hope that the developers take a good look at the data they get from players. 

The Zhukovs, for example, are just okay to supplement your existing build. However, when they are your starting weapon (recon scout) they feel downright anemic as your sole damage dealer. Most of the time, 75% of the damage is wasted due to bugs clumping up in a single pack. 

Attempting the Hazard 4 Crystalline Caverns challenge of "Reach (level) 55 as recon scout" is an absolutely miserable experience. You can try it countless times and get maybe to the beginning of stage 3 at the most, on average. Then you try it as gunner and reach the dreadnaught stage on your first try with considerably less effort. Yeah, it's that kind of funky (un)balance. (That's not to say either of these are balanced correctly, but the requirement is specifically scout, and that's just not happening)

But like I said, it's version 1 of early access. There is plentiful time to listen to feedback and make balance changes accordingly.

I give this little game a 7 out of 10. I wanted to give a 9, I really did.
Things I loved about:
- The game is damn fun. To a point that it can be quite addicting.
- No bs or whatever. Straight into the action as soon as you load it.
- Graphics are great, the whole contrast of colors and scenes is quite pleasing.
- Easy to learn and quite forgiving if you make a mistake.

Things I believe could be improved:
- CO-OP in this game is going to be a massive change! I can honestly imagine players laughing their asses off playing with their friends.
- Game play is too linear. All the levels feel the same. Level 5 is somehow empty; mining gold and nitra at this level feels "meh" regardless of what you do.
- Boss mechanics are very easy to learn. Some unknown behavior to it might be a nice touch.
- Game being too linear it only allows you to focus on certain things, whether you want it or not (depending on what buffs or wpns u got). The wpns you get are pretty much RNG and you never know which build you gonna end up with. I am not saying this should be changed, but...perhaps if the actual level or biome you are playing on requires different thinking compared to others; most likely it will make the game more diverse.
- Minor thing, but when you choose a buff or new wpn, the outline of what is selected is a bit faint. I cant remember how many times I've chosen the wrong stuff because of this. It automatically selects one for you. Let us choose it instead. Make it more visible.
- Perhaps a level that you don't know if it is going to be a 5min lvl or a 30 min lvl. 
- Mini games like "you want that supply? Allright you got to farm first X o Y amount of resources or mobs". The reward being quite appealing in order to make that effort and sacrifice.

Can think of a bunch of stuff.
Overall the game is great, feels nice, quite familiar to "certain" mobile games out there.
For a casual type like of player, this little game is awesome, highly recommended.
It truly has the whole DRG vibe to it.
I've had some pretty good time playing it and I'm sure it will improve to something more polished.

Cons:

Early levels on higher hazards are extremely difficult for characters that requires levels for good weapons.

Health, Movement, Crit. chance, and Crit. Damage are all you need to level. (Nothing else feels like it matters)

For now play for fun, don't touch hazard 4 or 5 unless going for completion. It's easier to farm mats on lower hazards.

It's almost as if every mechanic present in this game was carefully adjusted to provide the most tedious and unfun experience imaginable. 
Allow me to elaborate:
1) Unlocking overclocks for a weapon is only possible on the next run (weakens a new player, unfun, grindy)
2) The drop pod timer is too strict (creates tension but causes frustration in most cases)
3) The hitboxes on some bugs - especially the Dreadnought - feel wrong.
4) The bugs' attacks deal a LOT of damage (fine with me, but 3) makes taking damage feel cheap)
5) Only one of four classes is available from the start
6) The game collects a mountain of data from your PC, opting in does nothing, everything about you has already been stolen.
7) Inability to manually aim your weapons
8) Grenades and other throwables work very poorly and most of the time end up away from the horde, IF ONLY I WAS ABLE TO AIM
9) The meta progression is awful and boring
10) Unrelated to the game itself, but the foul aura of toxic positivity emanating from the community is infuriating.
11) Again, not a criticism, but a hub of sorts would be nice.


What I DID enjoy:
1) Variety of weapons (along with some new ones)
2) Tanky enemies and their sheer numbers
3) All the eye-catching audiovisual fluff every game in this genre has
4) All the classes I've unlocked so far have been very neat in terms of shaking up the playstyle.

TL;DR: This feels like an in-house concept that somehow made its way to Steam. I sincerely hope that the game will get better over time, yet for this to happen a handful of core mechanics have to be reworked. 
P.S: Fingers crossed, Rogue Core won't be as undercooked.

[b] Objective: survive, OR WE WILL SEND ANOTHER DWARF [/b]
That's the shortest way to describe this game! Yet, it gives hell of satisfaction!
While initially the game may seem a bit monotonous, as you unlock other characters, upgrades and perks, the gameplay becomes more entertaining!

[b] Few tips for the beginners: [/b]

- [u] focus on upgrading new weapons first [/u] , so as to unlock overclocks (you may be surprised as how much they can improve gameplay)

- [u] use terrain to your advantage [/u] so as not to get caught by multi-directional flow of enemies during swarm events (eg. dig tunnels to channel enemies or prepare escape route)

- [u] supply-pods can take-out large enemies [/u] which will help you to get rid of mini-bosses and stronger enemies fast (so sometimes it is worth leaving them drop-ready for when you should need extra impact dmg)

- [u] acheivements unlock new supply-pod perks [/u] some of which will buff your health-regen or dmg significantly

- [u] scrap unwanted overclocks [/u] to keep the slots free for better ones as you level-up your gun (there is no actual limit to upgrading weapon mid-game and scrapping gives you rare or legendary weapon buff as compensation for overclock)

- [u] mid-run focus either on elemental builds or kinetic [/u] in order to make best use of the overall dmg boosts (many weapons can switch damage types with overclocks)

- [u] SHORT ELEMENT SUMMARY: [/u] plasma = bounce / electric = dmg buff & stun / fire = high dmg over time / sludge = slow & dmg over time

Deep Rock Galactic Survivor (DRGS) is an excellent addition to the rogue auto shooter genre and a welcome implementation of DRG aesthetics. Your mileage may vary depending on the DRG source material, but what stands apart is the way the four classes engage in distinct ways with amusing builds of powerups and unlocked artifacts. Variations and ramping challenges reward the steady investment of "permanent" perks for your classes, making DRGS a contender into "just one more run" hall of fame. With a transparent road map for future development its your choice when to snag a copy, but rest assured, the game is solid for fans of the genre and/or DRG.

The game is fun at first but it will fall off rather quickly as everything in this game is too similar and becoming boring after a while. Also some aspects or challenges in this game feel almost impossible and become very annoying after a while, for example there's a map where you have to mine 150 "nitra", some red stone and I tried over 20 times but it is just not possible if you don't get the luckiest random map layout 5 levels in a row. And noone want's to play that damn map over and over again just to achieve that.

Also there's sidequests in every level, collecting a certain amount of mushrooms (12), blue stones (20) or flowers (6) will give you extra nitra and gold. Somehow if you get unlucky, you have to collect these flowers and it is like 10 times more difficult than the other two types, so much that I don't even try to find them anymore.
Other comparable games feel so satisfying that you can't wait to start the next level, but here you sometimes have to force yourself to, because it can be frustrating at times and at the end of each mission your kinda glad it's over.
On top of that, most of the challenges you have to achieve to make progress include playing a class, a build or a weapon that you just don't want to play. You can't pick your favorite build and weapon to play because doing that you'll always be stuck and not be able to make progresss at all.

You never feel like you are ahead, you are always behind always running, never making progress except for a little bit. In survivor games you get to a point to where you break past that and start doing more damage and gaining ground, you never get that in DRG:S. It hasn't felt fun the entire 5hrs I've played, its just a chore to run, try to get the gold/nitra before you get overrun and just run. This is a running/mining simulator and not so much a survivor game. If you enjoy games like Nordic, Vampire Survivor, Soulstone, 20 Mins, etc  you will not enjoy this.

Classes are not balanced, weapons are the same unless you get a specific build you will not win. Almost all of the upgrades you get from the supply beacon are just worthless and don't make any actual difference. They should put the overclocks in the drops or something.

Meta upgrades are holy crap expensive, you get 2-4 of most upgrade mats per 4 level run. Right now I'm seeing upgrades that require 60...80...100 of each material? Holy. That is going to take an unreal amount of time. Seems extremely out of balance.

I even went so far as to edit my save to give me enough credits and materials to buy every single meta upgrade, and it still feels like a losing battle, I just can't recommend this game as it stands, its not balanced and it just doesn't feel fun at any point. I want to like it, I love the original game, Rock and Stone!, but I just can't get behind this attempt.

Auto-shooter that scratches a Dwarven itch that I didn't know I had. It plays fine on KBM but is much more comfortable on a controller.

Each class feels very unique with their own strategies for success. Each biome offers just enough differences and environmental challenges to keep it interesting. The weapons are varied and fun to use, with a couple of exceptions.

RNG on the powerups keeps each play varied enough to keep it interesting and challenging.

I only wish for two features: multiplayer and a way to carry forward your progression when you beat a biome without dying.

TL;DR: The game is fantastic and worth every penny.  Heck it's worth a lot more than what they are charging for it.

They somehow made a game that can keep you engaged while literally playing with one single thumbstick.  No, really, the whole game... One thumbstick.

The keyboard control felt a bit janky, like it wasn't moving at correct angles.  I tried on a controller and it was smooth as butter.  I'm sure the keyboard controls will be worked out later on in the early access.

As far as content goes, there's not a ton right now.  There's only 3 maps with multiple difficulties.  Again, the game has just come to early access and I'm sure more content will be added over time.  As far as the account progression, there's a ton to unlock, and the classes all feel very unique and have playstyles that differ enough from each other to make them feel like their own thing.  

The game is more challenging than some of the other VS-Style games I've played.  The game can be very unforgiving, and recovering from a mistake can take some time and thinking on your feet.  

Overall if they continue development with their current vision in mind, and add an "infinite mode" later on, this game is gonna slap way harder than it already is.  

What are you doing still reading this?  It's like 8 bucks right now.  You should be playing, not reading my rambling review.

Game is early access but is already fun with A LOT planned for the very near future. It can be a bit difficult when you first start off as you have no progression buffs yet, and no weapons unlocked along with their over clocks upgrades. But once you start playing more things begin to open up and the fun really begins. Just stick with it, this game is not instant gratification and full unlocks at the first play.  But it does start to really get a bit easier on the first tier of difficultly after about 2 hours of gameplay and a few unlocks. You have to actually play which pushes you a bit to play and try things you may not usually do. And I was happily surprised with 1 of the classes i thought i wouldn't play much. 

I keep finding new combos of weapons and upgrades that shocked me how well they can do after i had them marked as useless. And some of the weapons are down right hilariously OP when you get them maxed out with just the right perks and over clocks during a run.  So far most weapons I see have a purpose although there are few duds that just don't work to well for this type of game and its current balance. And some only work well if you get lucky with certain perks during a run (yes some RNG is involved in this game but overall not bad). 

Check out "The Road Ahead" post for what is planned in the next few months. Even with Early Access tag the game plays so much better than other Early Access games, and this company has a great record with other games of theirs I played and the community in their games is usually really good and they are responsive to the customers and what is coming up.  Last the game is priced well and not a 50 dollar money grab so I would recommend picking it up now at the nice on sale price.

Already got my money worth in a time when most games fall way short so this is a nice relief from that feeling.
