The difficulty in the levels are well thought out its worth a shot playing this game. some classes are not that nice and some are good. Class guns need more balancing and maybe needs to be rebalanced. Maybe the devs can get some inspiration in borderlands on gun designs. 

The game doesnt have modifiers that scale with difficulty like most rougelike games. It doesnt have a way to reroll it into the map like what POE can do in the map modifiers. Also can add a merchant on the run like what POE does on its sanctum.

Ive enjoyed many bullet heaven games like Vampire Survivors, Nordic Ashes, Brotato, Soulstone Survivors, Halls of Torment, Death Must Die, Bio Prototype, and Spellbook Demonslayers.

DRGS has a lot of good things going for it but it also is in that Early Access stage where a lot of features present in other games are missing. 

The good parts:
Fun DRG theme that if you love DRG you will enjoy the dwarf setting and flavor.
Weapon variety is nice and does feel fun to kill hordes of bugs.
Mining Mechanic allows great moments of rushing to get away from a huge horde of bugs to get to a safer area, as well as gathering the resources for meta upgrades like in regular DRG.
Class system is nice to give the existing 4 dwarves some variety, as there are 3 specializations per class allowing for 12 different starting play styles. 
The 5 levels per dive and the shop afterward are very reminiscent of Nordic Ashes as they are very similar in that regard.
Secondary objectives like in regular DRG are present. Collect Morkite, Apoca Bloom, and Boolo Caps are the only ones in the game at this moment. Perhaps some kind of Aquarq or other objective may be added in the future.
Analytics opt out. Very nice to see.

The Bad:
Given it is early access, like I said before many other features present in other games in this genre are not present. Banish, Skip, Sealing meta upgrades are not present. Only Rolling is present at the moment. 
Weapon upgrades and stats are not clearly explained at first glance. How much does a reload speed upgrade exactly affect your reload speed? You only find out in the weapon stats after you pick the upgrade. Soulstone and Nordic Ashes both have this feature to show you exactly what your upgrade does before you pick it.
There is no key rebinding in the game at this moment. I recommend playing with a controller as you really only need the left thumbstick and the face buttons.
DRGs also lacks a feeling of screen clearing godlike power that other games in the genre allow you to have. Maybe that's a me problem and I haven't progressed far enough to hit some kind of upgrade that lets you do that, but at this moment in my playtime I have not gotten that far yet. I do use overclocks as well, just to clear that up.

Verdict:
DRGS has a lot of potential to be a great Bulet Heaven game with more updates in the years to come, hopefully bringing more QOL features and upgrades to smooth out the rough edges. It's fun and I would recommended it on sale in its current state, but waiting for updates is also a fine idea as well.

Hungrily, mercilessly, and at an ever increasing pace, you plod through the ecosystem that lived at peace...
   ...until you arrived.
  Corporately driven lust brings Deep Rock Galactic, in all of it's brilliant glory, to the land of the bugs once again in search of that sweet, sweet dirt. And they're going to shit in the mouths of any indigenous species that gets in their way. 
  Brilliant, and at and an endlessly increasing pace, you plod through caves, destroying bugs, getting stronger with every death. And upgrade. 
  Incredibly satisfying, and at this price, it needs to be in your library.

This is one of the nicest looking vampire survivor clones out there.  The Deep Rock galactic theme works well for it and it gets challenging.   There are quite a few things that will need to be addressed before it is ready for 1.0 but as an EA option it's nice. 
I especially like:
1. The digging theme works well
2. The specializations having targeted drop types is fun
3. The Deep Rock Theme actually improves this type of game by making it a race the feel like it makes sense.
4. The loop they have on each level is nicely laid out.

These are what I would like to see

1. More enemy types (basic, elite and bosses)
2. More Biomes and balance out the ones that are there (I feel the 3rd is easier than the 2nd)
3.  Some pacing changes would be nice. The game quickly becomes a grind (long before you reach the hardest levels)
4. The 4 classes make sense for the theme but more specializations would be nice, I'd especially like some tied to achievements rather than just playing a class over and over again.
5. More event types as you progress (beyond swarm and drop pod) maybe at higher difficulties.
6. More persistent unlocks would be nice.  Maybe some class customization options (like choose extra crit, speed, or dig) after specialization load out,  pick a few weapons that wont drop in a run.

It's almost like the developer has never played any other games in the genre. Progress is by inches and you'd have to sink dozens of hours to feel any sense of meaningful gains. It's incredibly disappointing considering the value of the IP involved.

So far this has been a pretty fantastic experience.  I love this developer due to their flagship effort and all of the additional free content they add to it to keep players coming back for more and Survivor seems to have been crafted with the same attention to detail.  It's very challenging, at least for me, and I've not yet been able to sack the first deep dive's Dreadnought, but after unlocking the driller finally I can see a path to victory.  Ironic that in this DRG game the scout is at a slight disadvantage on completing objectives.  You can tell there is real depth (lol) to the weapons and upgrades similar to the DRG but you have to re-aquaint yourself with these Survivor versions, as they operate in different ways.  I like that you can jump into the game quickly and jump out (or get kicked out, in my case) and it doesn't force you to stay in game any longer than you want to.  Very high replayabilitiy here as the unlocks are getting very interesting and you want to see how they impact your runs.  I highly recommend this game for any Vampire Survivor player or DRG player that wants to play a challenging, well crafted game, with great characters and personality.

Hello all, I would first like to say that I am a casual gamer. When I play I generally do it for fun and not for 'a challenge' however I have about 1400+ hours on the normal DRG and generally play Haz3. With that being said, survivor is a new style of game I am unfamiliar with and it does have a learning curve to it. Essentially this is a single stick shooter / time survival game akin to 'vampire survivors' which I have never played. It does give me tower defense feels as well with the mining mechanic. 

Biomes are similar to the regular DRG series and most of your time is spend kiting enemies around while collecting XP in order to level up and earn weapon slots, artifacts, and mining minerals in order to spend them on 'upgrades' which are essentially permanent buffs. 

Upgrades (permanent buffs) can become quite expensive so you will largely find yourself farming haz1/haz2 missions for minerals as those are the most manageable. Haz3 you can still farm but Haz4 is virtually useless as the spawns are too large and too fast to focus on anything but survival. Upgrades seem useful in Haz1/2/3 but do not pack a punch at Haz4/5. 

During each mission run, you are leveling up, and each time you will see a menu to upgrade your weapon, improve mining speed, movement speed, health, etc. Some are common, uncommon, rare, epic, and legendary. It is largely luck based and you can also reroll using gold if needed. How you do during your runs largely depends on the upgrades you use. I think I have my permanent luck buff upgraded but it still seems like I receive a lot of common upgrade options rather than more epic or legendary. Again, this will affect how well your mission goes and if you win or lose. 

Artifacts are also small buffs that arrive via supply pods that drop during each round of a mission. There are 5 rounds with the final one ending with a battle against a Dreadnought. Most need to be unlocked via simple assignments such as 'collect 250 gold', etc. Again, artifacts seem to help at the lower levels but Haz4/5 they do not pack much punch. 

Overclocks can be earned for your weapons but you must first unlock the weapon, then unlock each weapon's overclock by leveling the weapon to 12, and then you can finally use the overclocks. Some are better than others and you will find what works best. 

Class Mods for the dwarves are unlocked as you level up as well, and you will find some are more useful than others. I find myself using Recon Scout and Foreman Driller most of the time as they have a reasonable movement/dodge/mining speed though the armor grease artifact does help dodge/mitigate some damage done by bugs, though I still feel all dwarves should have some inherent dodge capability even if it was 10%. 

Additional thoughts on the current build that I as a casual gamer would like to see implemented as it can be daunting for some. 
- Lower damage done by bugs as it seems quite high.
- Weapons (even with overclocks) can seem ineffective at Haz4/5. 
- Haz4 can be manageable at times but it still seems there are too frequent spawns, and your weapons, upgrades and artifacts do not seem to pack a punch to mitigate the waves of enemies
- Once you take on the Elite threat at the end of each level, Haz4/5 in particular it seems the threat level increases way too fast, and the waves just keep coming. It seems unmanageable especially in the earlier stages (1,2).
- Perhaps change when you unlock each weapon in order to mitigate this? Unlock 2nd weapon slot at 5, 3rd slot at 10, 4th slot at 20? 3rd is currently 15 and 4th is currently 25. 
- Default Movement speed / Mining speed seem extremely slow at the start, perhaps 50% increase? The only dwarf that seems capable of mining is the Foreman Driller at higher levels. 

With that being said, the game is very polished for an early access title, and the graphics are amazing. I realize that in it's current build things will need some balancing but overall I have been enjoying myself even though I find the higher hazard difficulties frustrating. I hope that they end up aligning the hazard levels more in line with DRG so that we casual gamers can take full advantage of what the game has to offer and not find ourselves frustrated at not being able to 'complete' the game as it were. Thanks!

It's good! The digging, objectives and multiple stages per run make this feel unique in the Survivor space.

Individual levels are smaller than others in the genre, but with more focused objectives. You'll have side objectives and resources to gather, which will keep you moving and exploring around the level - digging paths as you go. 
Being able to dig through the environment enables you to set up choke points and set up escape paths for yourself.
After finishing your main objective, you'll need to head to the drop pod pretty quickly (30s) before being moved to the next stage - so you'll want to finish gathering/side objectives before this. This adds some risk/reward factor as you can try to quickly grab what you can at the risk of outright failing the run by missing the drop pod.

Overall definitely a solid foundation with a lot of potential, at a reasonable price point. I had fun with it as is, but do look forward to seeing what future updates bring. I think many DRG objective types, mechanics and enemies will transfer over nicely, and with some tweaks to the combat (and potentially upgrades for Bosco/BET-C being added) I'll be very happy.

This is a very fun game that does not extremely punish you for not being able to complete a level, making the focus of the early game to really get to know your class and figure out the mechanics, what is a good level up perk/weapon unlock and what is not. It will be a bit of a struggle at first but as your characters get access to new weapons, upgrades, and perks that you unlock for all characters after you leave the level, it becomes easier but you need a focused build to complete the maps. 

As you progress, you unlock newer, more challenging levels with new hazards that you need to account for, keeping you on your toes at all times. 

Tips: 
- Use terrain to create pinch points and barriers between you and the bugs
- You have a decent sized health bar, use it (don't be afraid to take a few hits) to escape bad situations and remember roughly where the health stones are on the map for a much better experience
- Try to circle back around areas you were in previously to collect precious XP from those bugs you killed.
- Use your characters strengths! At character selection, they let you know what your character is good at and is noticed more early game till you can buy upgrades to help with run speed, mining speed, XP gain, etc. etc.

👾 As someone who's not usually a fan of bullet hells or roguelikes, "Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor" has been a delightful surprise! 🎮 I've been hooked on the Deep Rock Galactic universe since its first foray into the first-person survival genre, and this latest installment is a perfect addition to the lore.

🚀 The premise is simple yet thrilling: dive deep and survive waves of relentless alien bugs using a vast arsenal of weapons. But, oh, it's so much more than that! The game is exceptionally accessible, making it easy to jump in but hard to put down. 🎉

🔫 The progression system is where "Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor" truly shines. There's a plethora of weapons and overclocks to unlock, not to mention the satisfying meta progression that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. It's a game that respects your time and investment, offering loads of content and excitement. 💥

💰 I've spent more money on games that offered far less amusement. The value here is undeniable. Plus, the developers' commitment to supporting their games without additional costs is commendable. It's a business model that deserves support, especially from the younger gaming crowd. 👍

🐛 In conclusion, whether you're a veteran of the genre or a newcomer, "Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor" offers a compelling, action-packed experience that's easy to pick up but offers deep (pun intended) and rewarding gameplay. Highly recommend it to anyone looking for a blast of fun! 💣

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

[b] Review After 100% Achievements [/b]

If you are a fan of the survival roguelike genre then you’ll enjoy your time with this game! Despite being in early access, I ran into no problems throughout my time obtaining all achievements and doing many, many runs. You can expect your character to start out fairly weak in your initial couple runs but as you upgrade your stats and weapons, you really start seeing progression. There are a ton of weapons you can unlock by completing challenges and leveling up characters. There are currently three biomes (maps) that you can play, each with different hazard levels (difficulties) to challenge you as you boost your character’s stats. Overclocking your weapon is a sick feature that helps push you to deeper stages in the run while also customizing the weapon to your playstyle. I know in their content roadmap, more artifact airdrops are in the works as well as new maps to play which will be great. There is a ton of content that Funday Games wants to keep adding to the game so it will be cool to see it develop over the coming months. The achievements were fun to obtain, with you having to do dedicated runs to obtain one or two at a time. Overall it was a great experience, the only grindy achievement was the ”Big Spender” achievement, but I just threw on some Youtube and kept doing run after run. Great game for a great price, and it stays true the Deep Rock Galactic theme by having you focus on mining resources while managing the hordes of enemies around you. Can’t wait to see what is added in the future!

I review the game negatively at first but after spending more time with it, things are moving along much more smoothly.

Pros:
Cheap
Unique playstyle compared to other reverse bullet hell games (digging, drop pod, extraction etc.)
Each class/subclass offers unique gameplay and attributes/passive
A lot of interesting weapons with (some) fun overclock upgrades
A lot of things to aim for (subclass, weapon, overclock, artifact unlocks)
Runs well so far for an EA game

Cons:
Start out slow - scout with their starting scrappy weapon is quite weak, makes you want to pull your hair out
Demand that you upgrade your main weapon to max out 3 overclock asap or you'll get overwhelmed early
Many overclocks are just basic stat boost - less interesting and game changing compared to original DRG
No unique skills for each class (no zip line, grappling hook, platform etc.)
Balance still needs adjustment - if you have poor luck the first 2 stages, might as well give up

Even with all the issues, for just 9 bucks I can see myself returning to the game over and over for a few runs each day. With more contents in the roadmap, time will tell how this game turns out.

This is a great adaptation of the Survivor genre.

If you have played Vampire Survivors you should have a good idea of what to expect here. Implementing mining and resource collecting for in match upgrades is a new element and works so well in DRGS. This game can be difficult and painfully unforgiving in the early stages of your experience with this game. But rest assured you will be moving towards permanent upgrades which will make your proceeding play throughs just that much more tolerable. Eventually you will you will reach god status and breeze through the opening stage and then be introduced to a new stage and new playable characters. And this is the cycle of survivor games and it feels so good here with DRGS.

Absolutely worth the price. Its not the best auto-shooter, but its pretty good. Its got all the playful charm of the parent game, using a lot of the same voice lines, with good understanding of consistency in themes and play.

Plus, its in early access and already has more content and stability than some fully released auto-shooters I paid more for. 

Definitely recommend if you like auto-shooters, and if you like DRG, that's gravy.

Very fun vampire survivors autoshooter with the fun part of mining as well. It really makes you feel like ROCK AND STONE'ING. The only downsides I feel are not helping the gameplay loop is balancing...This is in early access so I expect them to change some things but here is my problems...
First off the Exploder bugs need some kind of ring that shows up when they get too close or a visual indicator, it is too dam annoying when you get hit for like 2.5x the normal dmg of bugs from them and there are tons of visual effects covering the screen from explosions or blending into the bug mosh pit or the lava level, impossible to see them and then sometimes it feels like they explode instantly near you with no warning. Maybe change when you kill them it has the same visual warning they explode as well, instead of instant because there is no way to tell what their hp is and it is hard enough keeping track of all the bugs around you.
Secondly, HAZ 1 and 2 are are too hard...they are beginning levels not start playing tryhard or well I got screwed on upgrade rng so now I hit like a wet noodle so I guess I will get overrun (consistently). I mean I am even going hard min/maxing time spent mining and killing while exploring the map to get secondary done and I am still losing quite a bit. It is too dam aggravating when that happens ON LEVEL 1 and 2, Haz 3 I would expect it to start being hard like in the original game. I would probably fix this by increasing the exp gain and very slightly increase all damage giving you faster access to good gear to make it fair. I mean most starting bugs should just be one shot-able and then slowly get more hp or something.
Overall a great game though, I am enjoying it besides the bs that sometimes happens like with exploders or level generation making a weird plateau making it impossible to get around a swarm sometimes.

This game should be more fun than it is. The overclocks are mundane, you constantly have to run from the bugs, because they are always too strong (while having to stay still to mine), but most unforgivably, the game balance is off. You have to play and fail, over and over, to build up the meta, so you can survive longer next time.

It's a bit of a slog, but it needn't be. Hopefully, it just needs some tweaks. For example, I wish each level boss dropped a magnet, so the player auto-picked up all the XP on the level, as you don't have enough time to pick it up once the 30-seconds-to-get-out timer starts. Also, the post-boss rush back to extraction needs to be easier. I've killed the final boss THEN died more often than I have killed the final boss and got back for extraction. 

The game this mimics, Vampire Survivors, was fun, because you won often, but by the skin of your teeth, and in lots of different ways. Here, you just die, over and over again, gradually accruing points to give you X percent more hitpoints, or do Y percent more damage. Do this often enough, you will finally get to a point where you have enough hitpoints to survive, and your damage output is enough to win. Unsatisfying.

This is most definitely a game in alpha and I cannot recommend it for the veteran Deep Rock player. There's not actually that many new lines, at least ones that pop up often, and the gameplay is a significantly shallower version of Vampire Survivor. IT feels like a cheaper mobile game using Deep Rock skins.
One of the biggest criticisms I have is that IT DOESN'T MATTER WHICH WAY YOU'RE FACING, at least for weapons. Your dwarf can shoot right out of his bumhole while mining in the complete opposite direction. Vampire Survivor is actually a bit better in that some weapons, knives, etc actually fire in the direction you're facing. Just feels like fairly brainless gameplay.
I'm optimistic that this will improve, but for now I'm going back to Vampire Survivor for my roguelite fix, which is entirely free on mobile.

A lot of fun for it's price point, especially for the cost. However, some serious balancing needs to be done. Gear balance is all over the place, some stuff is really good some of it is borderline unusable (to be expected from early access to be fair) Movement speed buffs are way under powered, and the game is currently way too hard. Haz 1 is basically impossible to clear until you have a good few hours or more of upgrades, which feels really bad in practice. Nothing like getting swarmed to death where there's nothing you could've done. The game also has no upper limit on enemy spawns, so you can easily end up in a situation where (thanks to the 30 second time limit on the pod) you beat the boss and then die trying to get to the pod because there's actually 500 enemies blocking your path with no time to kite them out of the way... or die to the boss itself because you have nowhere to go to dodge its attack. 
The targeting AI is also horrific, grenades are pretty well unusable thanks to the AI cherry picking random stragglers instead of aiming for crowds, and unless your gun has specific targeting rules getting it on the target you want is a rough time.
All that said, the game is VERY fun, has that great Deep Rock aesthetic and sound, and is pretty addicting. A bit more content and some SERIOUS balancing, and there's something very special here, especially for the price tag.

About twelve hours in and the game has kept me entertained for most of the way. It’s a grinder, but there’s enough upgrading, leveling and character progression to keep you entertained during the grind. One thing that differentiates itself from similar games is that bug behavior and movements are different each round. So, most of your success is from your map movement and ability to upgrade, dodge, mine and strategize with the map. Purchased this as a way to step away from all of the FPS games and try something different. So far I haven’t regretted my purchase and will probably grind out the next few maps to finish the game.

[22 hr update] SO ADDICTIVE!!! The BEST Survivor-like. Funday Games has expertly adapted the Deep Rock Galactic themes and mechanics. Faithful to DRG with fun bullet-heaven versions of the weapons familiar to DRG regulars. These ARE DEFINITELY the best versions of DRG weapons. I find myself playing even those that I've completely shelved in DRG-proper.

The deep-dive mechanic (in this case, complete 5 mine levels to succeed at a run) gives a clear objective for each run, with various random goals tossed in. DRG Survivor improves on survivor-likes by giving you meaningful early run gameplay = mining! Time-pressure on each stage provides delicious tension between maxing XP and mining or surviving to the next stage. Cumulative unlockable buffs typical of a rogue-lite - love the inclusion of the mineral market!

I still hate that failed runs = minimal progress. [Here is where I mentioned the minor bugs I'd encountered at 9 hrs, but which are now fixed!] As a DRG fan, I'd have given this 2 stars just for being DRG. Compelling gameplay, great theme execution, I'm at 4.5/5 and leaning toward full marks. Now if only I could get that 500 gold in one run!!!

Its insane to me that this game is in early access, its very polished and I rarely come across any bugs. If you like this genre then you'll like this game. I'm excited for the future of this game and for a good price, you're getting a good amount of content. A good buy IMO.

I'm a proud EA Supporter of DRG (Windows PlayAnywhere version) and based on the awesome experience I've had with that ride over the past several years, becoming a supporter of their newest Dwarf-based release was a no-brainer.

If you like Diablo's perspective, Vampire Survivors' grind-pickup-upgrade-bullet heaven cycle, and DRG's mining features, aesthetic and attitude, then you will absolutely love this title - even in EA.

The basics are there: you get dropped down onto each planet at level 1 (I'm not sure how this is explained lorewise, maybe some initiative from the Corporation), mine for materials to upgrade, carry out company objectives, and then slay the big baddy while fighting off occasional swarms of creepy crawlies. Then get back to your dropship with your loot before the time runs out. DRG fans will find this second nature.

Either finish all of the depths at the point or die trying. Once you do, you can return to enjoy your new unlocks or spend your hard-mined materials to upgrade your Dwarf.

I put in several hours on my first night and find myself returning. I can't wait to see what the full roadmap will contain (inter-level quests with huge rewards, new relics, a way to define your own starting kit?!)

Keep it up, GSG!

TL;DR, build diversity is discouraged, success is HEAVILY reliant on RNG, the pace is too rushed which takes away enjoyment/ease of mining or exploring.  An important thing to remember with auto-shooter survival games - they're fun when you succeed, not when you die repeatedly to level.

Things that can be immediately fixed - 
• Decrease the blast radius for exploding bugs.
• Increase drop pod timers to 1min, let us loot!
• Increase Nitra/Gold spawns or fix the mechanism that places them, they are 
  sometimes non-existent.
• SLOW DOWN the stage timer, don't weigh kills so heavy that you get 3x swarms at once.
• Fix/remove lava - you shouldn't have to stand in lava to mine important 
  resources or clear a supply pod LZ...
• Unlock overclocks WHILE you're playing the weapon for the 1st time.  It's not fun leveling a 
  weapon that you can't make useful just to die and use it again.
• Power-ups need adjusting - weapon leveling should be separate from all other power-ups.  Power-ups are too slow for how one-dimensional they are when weapon levels are thrown in with stat increases.
• Late game boss swarms are out of control, you get overrun too fast.
• Buff overclocks, 25% firerate/reload is a joke and can be done with a couple power-ups.

There's a lot of work to be done with this.  They're clearly going for Vampire Survivors (VS) + DRG, but they're not quite there as far as the balance between progression:difficulty (over 100 hours of Vampire Survivors here).  There's too much resetting/dying just to slowly progress vs. a game like Vampire Survivors that nailed waves and farming a map before ending the match.  Enemy burst damage is too punishing, you can go from full health to dead in your final match, just by being in the wrong place at the wrong time.  For a wave-based survival game with rounds lasting this long, you shouldn't be able to drop instantly - the blast radius on the explosion bugs needs some adjusting...  Though I marked this as not recommended, it's VERY close to being a decent game, but this seems like alpha, definitely not beta and certainly not 'early access' (not sure why we replaced beta with early access).  I'll continue to support these guys, but there's a lot of polishing ahead.

Only 3 maps, 4 characters, it gets stale pretty quickly.  No clear definitions on currency/xp earned in different maps/hazard levels.  I'll try to edit this as I play, but off the bat VS provides easier roaming/movement and more satisfying/more power-ups.  This game is trying too hard to remain tit-for-tat with DRG but that's not exactly going to work in this type of gameplay - they need to mix things up.  It feels like the overall design of this game, was 'repeatedly fail to win' rather than 'succeed to win' which is arguably less fun.  A game like VS keeps you hooked with wanting to experiment with unique power-ups/characters that perform very unique actions, whereas this game is trying to just paste in items from a FPS which do not translate over to an auto-shooter in the same exciting way 'magical' power-ups would.  You get some guns that shoot in different directions, and can increase damage, fire rate, critical damage, etc.  Nothing really exciting there.  But it can work - if you're going to stick to less-exciting power-ups/items, you really need to emphasize the mining aspect of the game.

Some classes are outright useless despite intended purpose - the juggernaut for Gunner for example.  This gains weapon damage when getting hit, and it stacks/runs out, so you're clearly meant to be a tank that gets hit for damage boost (especially with the short weapon range).  This is countered by "higher" armor which is laughably minuscule and becomes worthless on anything hazard 3+. It seems some classes were 'built' outside of actual gameplay and never tested.

The power-ups in general need some serious work - everything is way too one dimensional.  In my opinion, either weapon level ups should be in a separate mechanic than stat power-ups, or leveling needs to be quicker (or rounds need to be longer).  The reason I say this, is the game seems to revolve around overclocks and leveling weapons, however you're LUCKY to get 2 weapons max leveled in a dive - this is not very fun and very one dimensional.  I think of VS where you can (and are encouraged to) max out every weapon you have, and evolve every single one before a match ends.  Then, I think of this game where in a dive you're only going to max 2 weapons yet we're given 4?  You never feel like you're building a REAL build in this game, you're just rushing to max level 1 weapon which in turn results in ignoring all the other stat power-ups.  This game would be way more fun if we could actually get all 4 weapons max leveled, while also enjoying passive power-ups.  Ultimately, the power-up system is very vanilla, there's no nuance to it, and it's extremely one dimensional - pick a primary weapon, choose those power-ups every time they appear, ignore all else.

The game's design seemingly contradicts itself at times.  It appears they're going for a more grind/farm heavy VS gameplay, yet they rush you WAY more than a game like VS that lets you really take your time and get your character built up in each round.  You get swarms while swarms are still active, you get no time to actually mine yet they're urging you to mine for between-stage power ups but rush the end stage objective on you and keep hammering you with swarms preventing you from doing so, then when you're at the final objective they keep powering up the remaining enemies, again, rushing you to complete it.  For example, if you build up a really powerful character early in the round, you'll mow down swarms and while doing so, it progresses the round and throws you into the next swarm, then it's over - you won't have any time to farm anything if you're accidentally TOO strong...I literally hit 3 swarms without moving from 1 spot before because I made my character too strong, then I was at the end of the round, fun.  When it's finally over, your drop pod timers are insanely short, what was the reason for this?  There are way too many farming/mining elements to the gameplay for how much they're rushing you, it doesn't feel good, I don't feel like I'm able to enjoy powering up my build at a reasonable pace.

I've finally been able to make SLIGHT progress, and unfortunately it only highlights more negatives within this game.  To really become powerful and complete higher hazard levels, you have to focus on ONLY 1 weapon from the very beginning.  This means you have to rely on RNG to give you power-ups for just that 1 weapon and if you don't have enough gold to re-roll or don't get lucky with the power-ups, only getting upgrades for your secondary, you will fall behind and will not be able to get the overclocks required for completing later stages and might as well quit/start over (not to mention you can get screwed on overclocks and have to salvage, i.e. quit the run).  This not only discourages build diversity, but it heavily leans into the RNG aspect.  Basically if you don't level 1 weapon quick enough, you will fall behind the progression requirements.  In a game like VS, I've had horrible RNG yet can still pull through and get a build suitable for beating the stage halfway through - in this game, if you get bad RNG a couple times, you may as well just restart.  Ultimately, the progression in this game is starting to feel more like a chore and less enjoyable with each death.  My interest is slowly waning and they're not doing enough to keep me hooked.

Well after 24 hours I'm calling it quits at hazard 3.  This is just not fun at this point, grinding the same maps, same characters, same stale weapons, getting halfway through just to die to some bad positioning and over-swarms (and mostly explosion bugs - for real, fix these).  I'll check in after it releases, but hopefully they listen to the negative reviews and make proper adjustments.

Fortunately, this game has seen some success with Funday Games and Ghost Ship Publishing pulling roughly a cool $2 million USD in revenue —on a conservative estimate— in a week. Because of this the future looks more promising. Currently, thrifty spenders should heed the negative reviews, since there are plenty of valid criticisms of the build depth and enemy variety in a genre which has been around for awhile now. 

That being said, there is a good amount of polish and improvement from the demo version they released previously. Much like the game its spinning off from, the crown jewel of DRG:S is the level generation and manipulation. You essentially are given a small board with randomized hazards, blockades, and mineral deposits that you need to weave through a growing horde of bugs trailing you like a game of Snake. The game has a much tighter and frantic pace than Halls of Torment or Vampire Survivors due to this tighter, arena-like level design and that feels great. The audio and visuals are also a pretty big step up compared to most survivor games and it runs solid on a Ryzen 1800X and RX 6600. The smaller scope as it stands currently also seems to keep it from approaching near unplayable frame dips like Halls of Torment end-game has succumbed to.

As for things I'd like addressed aside from the obvious, the added arsenal to the dwarves that isn't present in the main game is actually pretty cool, but I hope they take another leap for the survivor genre and add movement specialties that are present from the utility slots of the co-op horde shooter. Essentially, expect a grappling hook, expect repellant or spongy platforms that synergizes with grenade launcher hopping, ziplines to travel over obstacles or avoid hits from smaller grunts... The driller is actually great as is, good job.

Dynamic environmental effects like sandstorm and seismic activity would also be great to see. Don't forget the ice stalactites — which are present in Halls of Torment.

The way they prevented the meta progression from being able to refund points I'm not a HUGE fan of, either. I hope they follow the genre norm of allowing you to mix and match the meta elements at will as they unlock through your career point/resource total. Halls of Torment's loot system is a good thing to take reference from. The ideal way to progress through the game currently is to prioritize xp gain, since many of the hazard unlock challenges require reaching weapon level milestones which are fairly dependent on chance to attain, even if you start with the weapon required to level. The idea being that while you may not survive the run due to being caught off guard or backed into a corner, you will have at least checked off the weapon level challenge - this is also how overclocks are unlocked (which can't be immediately used in that run in-game, another annoying delaying tactic currently present).

In short game feels good to play. Maybe it released into early access a little too early content wise, but there's more potential given the good launch. I'd maybe recommend Halls of Torment or Vampire survivors as your introduction to the genre, since they have more compelling build opportunities and learning curves currently, but if you want another survivor game for your collection and love DRG, this is a solid buy at $10. I look forward to giving feedback/ideas on the game and making it into one of the "required" survivor games you need to play, given its unique premise and toolset.

I love this survival genre, and one thing that happens in every other game is that eventually you just get cornered. This game is different because that just isn't the case(most of the time). In terms of a Bullet Heaven/Survivor-like style game, DRG: Survivor comes so close to scratching that niche and easily having me sink 100's of hours into.

Main gripe with the game boils down to the ludicrously short round lengths. Within the span of 5 minutes you have :
1. Primary objective (General survivor-like gameplay loop of kill/kite/level)
2. Secondary Objective (Varying fetch quests which force you too explore/mine)
3. Supply Pod (Random capture zone which you need to mine/clear)
4. Mining for resources (Gold/Nitra currency for in between stage purchasing and varying minerals needed for post run upgrades)
You rinse/repeat 5 times before fighting the final boss which is a massive health sponge that if you don't dodge its windup, will easily 2/3 shot you. The general lack of hit box transparency makes the game feel extremely unfair (Final Boss pounce, exploding enemies AoE, static map hazard mobs attacks, shooters, etc...) when you're entire screen is filled with mobs while keeping track of the various other objectives needed to progress the game. With short runs, conflicting progression elements, and general grind elements, DRG: Survivor comes out to feel fairly frustrating.

I came to play a DRG : SURVIVOR. Expecting a DRG set dressed Survivor-clone, not a Hades on Max Torment in the second difficultly modifier. Post game upgrades are linear while the costs are exponential, forcing you be in a constant struggle with which maps drop which minerals for a certain upgrade you want. And if your early game RNG isn't on point with in run upgrades, you will quickly be out scaled be mobs by the third stage if you aren't completing every single objective.

The game is still in Early Access, but difficulty and certain quality of life features that survivor-likes have seem to be vacant from this title. Some suggestions : 
1. Re-balance Hazard levels/scaling : Hazard 1 is decently challenging for an early account, one with little to no post game upgrades, but I shouldn't be needing to already grind for these upgrades in Hazard 2-3.
2. Tweak in game events : This game genre isn't popular for its speed run category. Either lengthen time between events to give the player ample time to prepare for the upcoming events or add a downtime phase to give the same effect.
3. Increase Invulnerability Frames upon taking damage or add a Dodge Roll in the form of a jet boost.
4. Don't lock other classes behind account level : Either make them base choices, keeping their overclock/class augments needing dedicated playtime to access, or if you want to keep them as earnable characters akin to other survivor-likes, tie them to a achievement befitting that class. (I.E "400% attack speed to unlock Gunner")
5. Reroll/Banish system : Make rerolls their own currency you can play around with, instead of costing gold, a currency you need for post game progression or in run upgrades. Make them their own post game upgrade or tie their amount to upgrades akin to Vampire Survivor. Likewise with Banishes and make these systems work with overclocks.
6. Multiplayer : The most demanding of the requests which would solve a lot of the issues. Following the balance of DRG, tie difficulty to the amount of players currently in run, toss modifiers into the the game for the solo-sadists, and the demanding action economy of DRG: Survivor is all but mediated.

At the time of writing: it's alright. 

Mining and resource collecting puts a nice, but small, spin on the Vampire Survivor formula. You always have something to do and there's a lot of moment to moment planning. Good stuff. 

A lot of people are talking about the balance, which is indeed iffy, and the lack of content. I'm pretty confident they will fix the balance and add more content. That being said, the game has some problems that are a bit more baked-in, such as the isometric perspective. On all three stages currently available it frequently hides enemies behind terrain, and on the 3rd stage Hollow Bough, I found myself frequently taking damage because the dark brown of the map blended together with the black used to signify impassible pits. The 3D look is nice, but is nothing but a drawback when it comes to gameplay. 

A smaller problem is also the amount of grinding you need to do: a new weapon needs to be used and upgraded in a underpowered state before you unlock the ability to make it powerful. What makes this even worse is if the run ends before you managed to sink enough upgrades into it to make the unlock, then you just played a underpowered run for no reason. This feels bad and I can not see any reason for it other than to pad playtime, which is not something a 10 EUR game should care about. 

It's still a thumbs up because there's clearly enough good stuff here to justify 10 EUR. Just don't expect it to be the same kind of home-run normal DRG is, at least not yet.

I think this is a wonderful entry into the kinda vampire survivor genre, DRG:S isnt trying to re'invent the concept of this kind of enemy hell gradual power creep progression game play, but for me it does put a wonderful spin on it.

The Visuals, lighting and aesthetic are absolutely delightful to look at. (God i love looking at magma core)
The Weapon visuals, effects, and particles all look great, and while later in the game it can get really cluttered with both the amount of enemies and weapon effects going on, if you know the vampire survivor genre its no less cluttered than other similar games and you learn to love it.

The mining is an absolute joy and satisfying, i love watching the Glyphid's walk around the environment to try to get to you, or the bigger enemy's dig through it themselves. Mining minerals is delightful and mining tunnels to funnel enemies or panic dig in an attempt to escape getting surrounded is a wonderful rush.

The enemy variety is fine, plenty of things to kill and nothing super annoying to absolutely body you out of nowhere, if your getting surrounded you can feel it happening and usually find a means of getting out. Also bating exploders and chaining them to kill hoards is my favorite pastime now :)

I think the weapons of DRG have been implemented wonderfully, and while at time of writing i think i only have a little over half the weapons unlocked they are all a pleasure to use. While some of them feel similar each other or are a little hard to get the feeling of at first they all have their place, and the Overclock system floored my expectation from the beta and are a highlight when you max them out.

The classes have also been implemented really well, each having 3 sub classes with different buffs and starting weapons for good variety, and depending on which class you choose will depend on the guns you'll find in game with some periodic overlap (Foreman driller FOR THE WIN LEMMI DIGGY DIGGY HOLE)

Progression is gradual, yeah at first a 5-10% buff to something doesn't feel like its helping too much, but stack that buff 8 times and get better buffs ranging from 25% to 50% and stack that even further with Overclocks that range from a bit better to KILL EVERYTHING and your 3 other weapons that you're also overclocking and upgrading, oooooooh things gonna get EXPONENTIAL IN HERE! The meta progression is fine if a little slow, though the Ore Store from DRG is clever and gives a use to unused gold, personally i like it, it compliments the "in round progression" rather than being the main focus.

The end of match boss fights are fine, if you're high enough level and got a good build they're nothing to worry about, though so far its been the same boss at the end of every mission, id probably ask to have other variants, basically the same but with different attack sets to set them apart from the current one. But as it stands the boss endings are just fine if a bit repetitive after the 5th go at them.

Personally I hope this game gets a number of updates for quality of life fix's like the boss's, but realistically if they said this game was finished, i think it has enough to be 100% worth the 10$. And while there's an argument that Vampire survivors is only 5$ "Why buy this when you can just get that", that's fair and a completely reasonable argument I personally have both because I feel they're different enough to justify owning them both, and upfront, 10$ is pretty good for the playtime you'll have with this game, and I would personally still buy this game 7 times over than buy "Skull and Bones"

This looks like a survivor game.  But its not.  It's a clicker game made to look like a survivor game.  The limited weapons, meaningless upgrades and rinse and repeat levels mean you don't get that "class build" fun, or "weapon synergy", or rapid progression to "god mode" in the face of overwhelming enemies.  Everything is dialled down to make this a visually appealing  clicker game.  What's more, I think this was done on purpose.  I feel like everything the developers added to the survivor formula was to turn it into a repeatable/incremental grind to fit with the ethos of Deep Rock Galactic.  Problem is, on the way, they took the fun out of it.  Let us be clear, this game isn't just grindy, its a grind mechanic built on a grind mechanic built on yet another grind mechanic.  Its a clicker.  I hope they have a proper rethink and re-invent this game during early access.  Do not buy until then as its 20 mins of fun at best.

Disclaimer: Did not receive this game for free, do not know why it states this.

Game starts off great and has a tier difficulty 1-5 that you progressively unlock as you play. Game really starts to show its early access issues by tier 3+ difficulty where there are balance issues.

The warthog shotgun weapon does not autotarget nearby enemies like every other weapon does which is a very strange design choice considering how small and how much maneuvering you need to do in this game. It's an extremely frustrating experiencing using this weapon while playing with a keyboard because aiming is done exclusively with WASD - very frustrating. The strategy seems to be to build a tunnel choke point and just stand there and blast in front of you with this specific weapon once you get your character into a decent position but then if you have enemies that are flying or a flying elite it negates this strategy.

I would say vampire survivors is a much less frustrating game to play simply because there is no mining nodes in vampire survivors. Imagine vampire survivors where you have to stop and mine a node for a few seconds in order to make your weapons stronger, that's basically the game. When you fail a run in vampire survivors its because of bad RNG which happens in any roguelite, when you fail a run in this game its because it wasn't properly playtested.

Example:
Progression is tied to mining nodes in the game which give XP to level weapons but also gives gold/nitrate which you spend on upgrades, so you NEED to mine these to make your weapon stronger but you can't mine and fire at the same time with certain weapons that require WASD aim (warthog shotgun) So if you start kiting enemies or build a tunnel choke point, either the flying guys destroy you because you can't aim properly with WASD in a confined space or you kill everything too fast and end up with no gold/nitrate for upgrades between levels which you will not be able to progress forward on. This is because the faster you kill enemies the faster the boss is spawned for that level and enemies become stronger once the boss has spawned. Once the boss dies the level ends and you only have 30 seconds to board the drill before the next level. 

It's vampire survivors with mining on a "timed" level, if you can imagine vampire survivors where you need to stop to mine a node for a few seconds in order to get stronger. It doesn't really work at higher difficulty levels, sounds good on paper though.

What they should have done here was after the boss dies enemies continue to get stronger but you can board when you want (level doesn't end after 30 seconds) which would give you a chance to mine nodes that you've missed since the game has forced you to abandon them because you needed to kite - or you simply killed everything too fast because the game didn't allow you to mine (same difference). I think they did this as a nod to the original deep rock galactic game since that game had timed levels, but in this case it just doesn't work.

It was negative before, because it crashed often after dozens of plays.
I got angry, it was making me mad.
I cursed developers and I got banned.
And I found that this game is an early access.
Crashes reminded me nightmares of 'Diablo IV, MW III', it might be a trauma. Because they just crashed like Hell and I screamed a lot, it was too painful.
'Oh, why does this happen to me?'
I checked my system again, also the BIOS, reassembled some parts, ran 3DMark.
I found some people told about overclocking features caused crashes. I thought 'Oh, is this ASUS Performance Enhancement?' But it's on by default, also 'Intel Adaptive Boost Technology' is on by default.
I was just using default settings for my motherboard, because it must be fine, it is usually fine with defaults for most systems.
I tried to turn off one of them and checked my system again and again one by one.
I think 'ASUS Performance Enhancement' causes crashes for some games. It's my conclusion.
It's been just some hours testing, for now, at the moment, games didn't crash on my system. But I didn't try 'Diablo IV, MW III' yet, because I lost will to play those games, they were nightmares, I screamed many times when I encountered unacceptable crashes, I got tired and I feel sorry and I wonder why ASUS set BIOS like that. It just made me furious too much day by day and month by month.
I poured out my feelings and it caused troubles, problems, it damaged people.
Ah, how will ASUS think about this? Why, just why did they turn in on by default? My time, energy wasted too much, it wasted my life.
I hope there will not be many crashes again, really, because I've experienced enough, too many, a huge amount of numbers. It's OK to crash sometimes, it's acceptable, every game has errors, bugs, but not too many.
So, this game is enjoyable, playable, I found ways to enjoy this game, I could beat Dreadnaughts.
Highly recommend its super fun, great graphics, visuals and lots of guns/upgrades.

The fundamental problem is everything feels "the same".

The classes all feel "the same".
The weapons all feel "the same".

This game has great bones, but it's 1-2 years from prime time, and it's something you'll get EXTREMELY bored of very quickly if you play it now.

Seems to be higher effort than you average Survivors clones that keeps getting printed nowadays (yes I do know that VS didn't invent the genre, I just can't be bothered to remember the names of older games or invent a better name for it, sue me)
Mining is an actual mechanic that you can use to your advantage, build for and is integral to both character and global upgrades, and a game of this genre with destructable environment is really a breath of fresh air.
Dwarbs have a lot of voicelines some of which I can't remember from DRG.
I like the art direction, which doesn't surprise me since DRG had a great one to begin with.
Same great soundtrack as DRG.
Pretty challenging so far early in the game, but doesn't feel straight out unfair, and I'm still on the low hazards. I reckon you will snowball really hard later on, but for now the balance between difficulty and straight up murder fun is pretty gamn good.

The only drawbacks I can think of is perhaps weapon variety might not satisfy some people, but so far it looks like weapons are not class locked and you can mix and match them freely no matter which class you choose to play, which expands the build variety (upon playing further I don't think that's the case for all weapons, some seems to be cross class while others are class specific). And bosco is pretty damn boring, they really should add Bosco specific upgrades and weapons which would also solve the potential weapon variety issue. 

Overall, for a price they're asking, this is a no brainer, the game already delivers and I'm looking forward to see what it might become if it gets properly updated.

The game has a lot of potential. The core mechanics are fun, I love mining and killing bugs. But the game's progression system and difficulty needs some tweaking.

Most of the meta progression is tied to mining special ores you can find on each map. These materials do not give any immediate progression for your run making it a risk to mine. (It ends up affecting the flow btw, but that's another subject). This is not really a problem in hazard 1, you can mine a good amount without sacrificing your run. But once you naturally reach hazard 2, the difficulty ramps up so fast, you have absolutely no time to farm the meta materials. Your only choice is to grind the easy difficulty until you're strong enough for hazard 2 which is not fun at all. One solution would be to add some run effect to the materials.

The second thing is weapon overclock. As you level weapon in a run, they will periodically give you a choice for a powerful overclock modification. The thing is when you first unlock a new weapon, it won't have the overclock available until you level it to 12+ in a run. And this overclock being so powerful, there is almost no way to succeed a hazard 2+ run without it. So what ends up happening is every time you unlock a new weapon you are forced to run a easy hazard 1 run, hope you get to choose that weapon and level it to 12 without the fun mods. You have to do this for every single weapon you unlock otherwise you just cannot progress. This is unnecessary grind just for the sake of it and sucks all the fun from the game. This limitation should just be removed from entirely. 

Another minor things is some monsters are just over-tuned. On the third planet for example, there are some bugs that can fly AND run faster than you. There is almost no tactics to defeat those, other than running in circle and hoping not to get overwhelmed. Also, some monsters are so spongy your only strategy is to hope your weapon AI targets the "bomb bugs" to make the horde explode. It almost makes it feel like weapon upgrades are irrelevant as long as you can target those. I would like to have better agency on what is happening and not rely so much on luck. Tuning down the bomb damage and decreasing the health of some monster would be a good solution to this.

EXCELLENT game. Whether you're brand new to the top-down genre or a veteran player (PoE, Diablo, etc.), this game is for you. Barrier to entry is low, while the depth and challenge that the game offers is definitely there, without making you feel overwhelmed by it. The game has near endless replay-ability with every single run you attempt being different from the last in one way or another.

Deep Rock Survivor is brilliant.  Clever game design makes this far better than the game on which it’s based.  You can herd the swarm and farm it like a resource.  You use the terrain as a corral and can fashion it but chipping away tunnels through it.  Some of the things you mine help you immediately, others help you in the current session and others still, help you push forwards in the meta-game.  The frequency and efficacy of rewards in the meta-game motivate you to have one more go.  What’s more, every time you play, you get a good deal further than you did last time.  This game is really well put together and balanced.  Highly recommended.

Yes, it's a 'survivor' game. Yes, it's not as detailed/unique as the 20 other swarm/survivor games, but, it's fun and it is a new take. Is it better than Vampire Survivors ? not yet. It needs a little bit of tweaking to the formula / meta for it to be as simple and dynamically difficult, especially because it relies on stats to offset ramping difficulty waves and gear/tech tree options. As do most of the swarm/survivor games.

I'd expect there to be a few surprises added, but it's still early in development. If it goes live as it is, I don't think it would be worth the money in comparison. It needs a bit more flavour / tuning for the Meta. As it is, it's playable, but it could be improved as you gain access to new characters, new unlocks, etc. 

Having unlocked the 4 class types, they're uniquely fragile, and very different survivability. You can figure it out yourself... but the game strategy/meta is very rough. There's room to improve the meta, but It's enough for 20 hours of gameplay. You'll fail 5/10 runs if you don't have a good strat, and there's an upper limit on skill/tech. Unlocks are needed to gain the better gear to execute the chain/stacking of status/crit effects. It's very rough. But that's kind of the fun. 

20 hours in, you'll probably be looking for things to finish rather than enjoy the game, but YMMV. There's room to add more in the future, so I hope they add more features and improve the game.

Reasons being the Scout class and its skills/upgrades is OP compared to the others. There isn't even a comparison. Also, the upgrades you do get, gets tedious very quickly (i.e + weapon damage/fire rate/crit rate). There also isn't much of a choice when getting new weapon slots, as some weapons, like the throwable bomb is infinitely better than the boomerang or any other upgrade. 

Levels are too short and enemy variety is lacking as well, which makes it become quite boring after a few hours. I guess the game is still in early access, but there's only 3 levels so far + a few difficulty modes. This game needs 30+ unique levels, each with different mechanics and ways to complete the level. At the moment, each level feels exactly the same as the one before it, so it becomes a boring slog. 

I don't think I can recommend this at its current state as it only provides 4-5 hours of original content, after that it's more of the same every time you play. I'd give it a 6 months to a year before recommending it and that's IF they actually add new content that's worth my time.

So, the good :
 - The graphics are really good (imo) for the genre and I like the artstyle.
 - The mining and objectives are a nice addition and add some strategy to the gameplay
 - Every progression system is pretty cool.

The bad :
 - Aiming abilities should be a thing, or at least being able to direct them for all weapons.
 - Meta progression is incredibly slow/unimpactful. Every point should be at the very least noticeable.
 - Upgrades are unoriginal and the values don't match the genre of the game. It's not an MMORPG, it's THE genre where upgrades should be the most impactful. e.g. 2% movespeed is a talent in an MMO, not an upgrade in an auto shooter.
 - Weapons feel pretty bland, especially since upgrades are unoriginal and unimpactful.
 - Overclocks are what regular upgrades should basically be.
 - Best way to dispatch a swarm is actually not your own weapons, but making enemies suicide and take out a big part of the swarm with their explosion
To summarize the bad : Every upgrade is too unorignal/unimpactful for a genre whose only goal is to grow to insane power levels within a run, only matched by even crazier enemies.

Overall I feel like the game did an amazing job porting the DRG theme and adapting all mechanics to suit the auto shooter genre, showing great potential, but the moment to moment gameplay is not great.
I don't really want to play more currently, but I feel like the foundation is there to make it an amazing game. Devs probably already have, but should really take a good look at Soulstone Survivors to see how cool a game with basic upgrades can be.

Really enjoying this as someone who's found these RBH games quickly becoming a favorite genre. Graphics are gorgeous & the gameplay loop pretty fantastic & certainly gets you hooked. The addition of mining as you play adds a wonderful new dimension to the genre.
As far as criticisms go, I have 2 & the first may rectify itself as I pour more time into the game or once it leaves early access & that first is in the upgrades, which are, by all means, SOLID, but aren't as inspired as the mining mechanic.
The second is in the maps. The one thing that RBHs offer you a sense of control over are in trusting your surroundings. Some may limit you in some way, say a limited vertical or horizontal border, but it's the one thing you tend to grasp firmly and can trust.
Here, it's not the walls you can mine thru, but rather the random dropoffs that act as barriers that can suddenly put an end to a great run when you make one bad choice in which way to head with a horde nipping at your heels. Perhaps, over playthrus, this will grow on me as part of DRGS' charm & world, but atm, it serves more as a sense of frustration. With my 2 faves being Vampire Survivors & Army of Ruin, perhaps I've grown too accustomed to open maps, or at least ones with limited barriers fencing me in.
But, DRGS is quickly becoming one of my faves in the genre, and these 2 small sticking points are ones others should be aware of before heading underground with our group of space dwarves.

An excellent Survivors-like / bullet heaven game that captures a totally different feeling from everything else in the genre, whereas in other games in the genre the end-game tends to be a cakewalk with all of your overpowered weapons, DRG Survivor is an active struggle on the player's part throughout the entire run, and it really makes it feel like all of your decisions throughout your run matter. A lot.
The meta progression also feels great, I think it strikes the perfect middle ground between Vampire Survivors (it eventually trivializes the game) and Brotato (a complete lack of meta progression).

Only real downside to the game is a lack of co-op play, which is something that the original DRG embraces as its main way to play.

As of 21/02/24, this is a playable Vampire Survivors copy, but not a particularly good one. Weapon overclocks, this games version of Weapon Evolves, are decent, but minimalistic and nowhere near as satisfying as in VS or other VS copies. Graphics and sounds are OK, but the feed hitback isnt as satisfying as VS and a lot of the assets have been 1:1 copy pasted from Deep Rock Galactic, kinda lazy tbh. While there are three different maps, the way the maps playout is pretty much always the same and it gets repetitive and boring very quickly. The worst part about this game is probably the balancing of the Hazard 4 difficulty & its challenges. It has nothing to do with knowledge or skill, and everything with RNG. Bad supply drop spot thats covered by too many rocks? Restart run. Get wrong item from Supply Drop? Restart run. Not enough Loot Bugs spawn, or Nitra spawns in awkward locations at the edges of the map? Restart run. Dont get enough good High Rarity Skills? Restart run. Maybe they can fix some of these issues but as of now I would put this VS clone towards the bottom of the VS clones I've tried so far.

This game used to be fun and relaxing, and after people posting [i]tons[/i] of good feedback, devs decided they'll change it to a stressful slog, while ignoring most of the feedback. Can't honestly recommend it at its current state, it's like 5 steps back compared to the public test from months ago.

The game sped up five-fold compared to the public test, which makes you fight against the timer rather than do anything else. The damage to enemy health&speed&numbers balance has been so skewed even hazard 1 difficulty feels unfair and needlessly stressful. The grind has been made mandatory and necessary. The incredibly fun mechanic of chaining enemy explosions has been nerfed.

Meanwhile, nothing has been done to make the game more accessible, visual clutter at later stages is still an issue, and the weapon/enemy/map variety is incredibly lackluster and uninspired, not to say non-existent when it comes to enemies, and mostly graphic when it comes to maps.

There is still hope for this game, but the development priorities and design philosophy need to be carefully but seriously reconsidered.

Reminds me a lot of the original Deep Rock Galactic, it's a good concept, a great early access, and with the possibilities that this can go are nearly endless. I would recommend this game to anyone, but keep in mind there are a few issues, not many in bugs but rather game play.

Suggestions?
More game modes, pleaseeee more game modes, there's only 1 game mode and its kill elite, kill elite again, kill it two more times and then kill the big baddie! This gets boring, fast. If anything, I would say play though the original DRG, and understand the various game mode types. You have 'oil' extraction, minehead platform mode, normal mining, escorting, repair minehead, and dreadnought hunt with various other modes like deep mining.

Another idea is to have an ability to have a survival mode, and add endless expanse, the grid is quite small, not a lot of space to move in.

Finally, I would recommend to have players to move at their own pace. What I mean by this is, when I kill the Elite, I should have the ability to continue the fight, or call in a drop pod. Currently, its once it is defeated, it's over, no time to collect or mine, just move on and you're done.

Oh and also, add Multiplayer if possible...

Regardless of all of the suggestions, there is a lot to work with here, and it has a lot of potential! DRG was a masterpiece, this game has A LOT to fill, yet also has a good source of lore and reusable assets that would fit in perfectly in here.

I truly and genuinely love this game, I have 6.9 hours currently, in two sessions of this game and I'm going to build up quite a bit more I promise you.

The game is fairly well balanced, with few weapons that I've experienced so far that seem like 'bad' choices.
The end boss is difficult, but once you get the hang of it doable.

I've heard complaints about this game and its mechanics, but whenever I actually looked into them they weren't actually valid. For instance I hear Asmongold complained at length about the fact that different styles of gameplay exist. (I haven't watched the full video, but I did skip through it, and he does make complaints about that subject, to what extent though I can't say.)
My friend tells me that his point was that he didn't like that the gunner has to look at the enemies to kill them, and arguesthat every class should have omni-directional firing.

But in my opinion the Scout is the most boring class, The Scout's gameplay is what I would consider genre generic gameplay, it's the same that you'd experience in something like Vampire Survivors for example, and that's why the scout is the first class. it's recognisable and easy to pick up regardless of whether you're a veteran or a new player. However the other classes focus on diversifying the gameplay, with each having a different and unique style and feel.
What this means is that this game really shines by make each class feel like a different experience, but not a worse experience.

For instance in my opinion from best to worst class you have Gunner>Engineer>Driller>Scout

>The Gunner's mechanics are very target orientated, you lose the ability to target everything in order to fire in a medium cone centered on your front, this means you can't fire at enemies while running which was Asmongold's issue but if you build him right you never need to run, everything in front of you dies. Swarms be damned, I fire more bullets than your species has members. 

>The Engineer is the play-easy class, effectively not needing to try very hard to get far because he can just throw around stationary auto-turrets, and have around 4 of them at once in my experience, Whenever you upgrade them they are no longer stationary, so you just have 4 auto turrets following you around while you mind your own business, any other weapons or artefacts you get in addition are a bonus but not very needed as the turrets are almost enough on their own.

>The Driller is a close-range class where the close-range is optional, obviously it does work better at close range but I managed to complete a run where I spent 100% of my time looking for ores to mine, basically their primary weapon is a pistol that shoots straight backwards. it's not powerful but it is consistent, this is the class that I find it's most important to choose the right weapons at the right times, however whenever you can easily rapid fire high-explosive grenades out your back ain't nothing getting close enough to disturb your gold fever.

>The Scout is a generic class, simply put just like in many games of this genre you can run, and it'll shoot generally around you. This means you don't need to worry about any advanced gameplay like timing, distance or radius, you just need to worry about positioning and escape routes. The scout does seem to fall off faster than the other classes but I'm also certain that changes based on what additional weapons you unlock. I'd say due to the early game power of the scout it has the potential to be the most powerful class if you can get and level the right weapons. But the gameplay isn't very complicated, or deep and there's a low skill entry for this class.

Now just because I am genuinely enjoying the game doesn't mean I don't see room for improvement, it is an early access game and there's certain to be changes to come.
>First off some visual detail but before you leave in the ship I think it'd be neat if APD-B317 was shown being loaded into the ship, or followed the ship into the hole. As of right now it just kind of sits there, and it's almost like the AI just turned off. it just kind of feels unfinished, like the devs didn't know what to do at this point.
That said, >>Early Access game<< and this polish was not required so it's completely understandable that it's not in the game, but it is something that every player will experience every time they play, so I think it's important to mention.

>Second off enemies in the game are divided into three categories: Crawlers, Flyers, and Stationary. The issue with this however is that there's not really any variety within these groups as every enemy is just "Crawler who also:" with there being an exploding one, and a ranged one. But other than that there isn't much variety.
I'd suggest adding in Unique enemies with a smaller spawn rate, make Praetorians that will use their radiation breath, or create areas of radiation to restrict player movement, Mactera uniques may have the ability to fly into the sky, and descend at another location of the map, making it difficult to predict where they'll be.
Grunts and slashers may have unique forms that move slightly faster, or which have the ability to jump similar to the dreadnought, and the spitter uniques may have the ability to break walls with their spit, attacking you from areas you haven't mined out and making tunnels for the other Glyphids to chase you through.
Additionally unique lootbugs may drop sugar red, or rarely an upgrade / magnet.

I am certain that i haven't experienced the full extent of the game just yet, but this is something that I want to already be in it in later stages, or would like to be added at some point. Just rare uniques that can turn runs on their head, and threaten to force a more creative approach to situations.

>Third off I'd recommend adding more terrain variety, right now whilst the world is filled it's feeling like a tutorial for each of the environment types. for instance in the magmatic levels you have... magma... Who could have seen that coming? But joking aside adding background details like destroyed and torn apart M.U.L.E.s, shut down escape pods, and stationary turrets with small amounts of ammo can liven up the experience. Additionally I'd recommend adding mining explosives that can be found rarely in levels, allowing you to pick up say a barrel that looks similar to a oxygen tank, and then with left click, or space bar your dwarf can lob it, the explosive detonating on impact. You could have voicelines like "For Karl!" or "Take That!", or "Is this where all the Flintlocke's goin'?"
Finally on that note also adding in terrain, or structures of rival companies which would also leave the possibility for the rival of some waves to be the units from rival companies, which in turn could have ranged abilities causing the player to have to go on the offensive instead of the defensive playstyle that's generic in this genre.

>Fourth off this is a small detail, but it would be nice to have some level of customisability, it doesn't need to be anything big but it is a massive factor of DRG so it'd be nice to see it in DRG:S, now because the model is so small I'm thinking having two player customisation options, and the majority of customisation being based around the APD-B317 and ship.
For the dwarf: having a hat/helmet customisation, and an armour customisation because those would be the easiest things to see from the player's perspective.
The APD-B317 customisation is obvious as I think we all need a Cyber Ninja watching our backs.
However I also thing customising the drop ship visually, by changing colour and minor aspects like the lighting, type of drill it has and perhaps visual cosmetics around it would be nice.
A really simple cosmetic that would be amazing to see in the game would be like how irl race cars have company logos on them, but with the beers.

This review is written as for patch "Hotfix 0.2.146d".
As a early access game it definitely needs more polishing, for example weapons need better balance and waves feel too rushed, more importantly the weapon overclock unlock system is not fun to play (see [i][b]Note[/b][/i]).
If you are a fan of the original game I would recommend this game at its current state.
If you are just a fan of the Vampire Survivors genre I would suggest waiting a bit longer for this game to become more polished.
===
[i][b]Note[/b]: "overclocks" are upgrades for your weapons. They (mostly) make your weapons more powerful but the overclocks for a certain weapon can only be obtained after you have leveled it to level 12 once. For that run you cannot unlock the overclocks. This basically makes that a "sacrificial run" where you cannot win because your weapon is weak without overclocks. In my experience that is deeply unsatisfying and this unlock system needs a rework.[/i]
