I cannot recommend this game as is. There are multiple things wrong with it. I will be comparing Deep Rock Galactic Survivor (DRGS) to Vampire Survivors (VS) often as that is probably the game that launched this genre of game. 

1. The maps and dives are too similar to each other. The waves are always the same, in the same order, at the same time. VS has the same order of waves at the same times, but each map has different enemies that act differently. Sure, each one has enemies that fill the same role such as bats, floating skulls, and dust elementals, but they look different, act different, and spawn different. In DRGS you have like 5 or 6 different enemies, stronger versions of those enemies, and boss versions of those enemies and they all spawn in large groups and take the shortest path directly to you, on all three maps, in all five difficulties. And the “gimmicks” with each map are minor annoyances at best, and the floor layout is spawned the same way. VS has wide open maps, thin horizontal, thin vertical, wide open with large obstacles, and things in-between. There is no incentive to choose a different map in DRGS. VS’s maps have different difficulties, different enemies, and unique items on the ground that you can pick up for free. 

2. Weapons and upgrades are not balanced. There are weapons that are 100% better than others and there are weapons that are 100% worse than others. While certain weapons in VS are better than others, all of them are viable without having to get a very specific build and very specific upgrades. The weapon I have the biggest gripe about is the turret that the engineer starts with on his basic kit. You have to stand still to deploy it. The engineer throws it away from himself to deploy it. The turret targets the enemy closest to it itself. Every single time I stop moving to deploy turrets, a bug gets close enough to attack me. Every single time the turret gets deployed, the closest enemy to it is not the one attacking me, and with how few immunity frames you get after taking damage, I continue to get hurt. So I start moving to get away from the bugs, but I am also running away from my turret so it can no longer target the enemies closest to me. I also can no longer place a new turret because I am moving. Do you see what the problem is here? You need incredibly specific high tier upgrades in order to make the turrets viable.  And its over clocks are just as useless as it is. You can have the turret follow you at about a 50 yard distance, or you can have it’s bullets break walls which I don’t feel like I need to explain that one, or you can have the turret blow up at the end of it’s life doing very minimal damage that has harsh ramping and a miniscule AOE, or you can get a generic one like changing its damage type or a low increase in stats. It is important to note that the upgrades for the weapons are random both in stat increase and amount of the increase. I have died because the upgrades I got were for the wrong stat or were too low. I have seen VS like games pull off random upgrades, namely Soulstone Survivors. But VS offers the same stat increase for each level of its weapons, and instead offers the general stat increases as separate items that can also be leveled. 

3. The different characters are too similar. Each class and sub-class have different stat boosts and abilities that are minimal, useless, and sometimes even detrimental. Each class is also limited to specific weapons and start with one specific weapon. And like I said previously, some of them suck. VP characters each start with a specific weapon, but are open to get any other weapon in the game and any other item in the game. 

I got distracted while writing this so I forgot exactly what else I was going to say but I think this covers the most of it. There is not enough variation between maps and characters, and weapons and upgrades are not balanced. I also recommend reading other reviews as some of them also cover other annoyances. Basically, DO NOT GET THIS GAME YET. It certainly could be fixed, but it is not currently

I want to start by saying I've enjoyed this game a lot, almost loved it but with that said what this is missing isn't a lot and the early access period seems to have fixed a lot of issues i had with the game feeling a bit bland and repetitive.

The unlock system is maybe a bit restrained but i can see how it encourages a lot more play through looking for new gun combinations; So the way it works is you find a new gun then you need to upgrade 12 times before it unlocks the "tier'd" augment system on them so every 5 or so i think it is unlocks a big "fires more waves, or reload speed 100% faster, or becomes "x" damage type. 

Now the issue with this is mainly that COOL I FOUND THIS NEW GUN! but... i cant really play it until after I've finished a run with it hitting 12 upgrades, which means that you really cant get the most out of it by a considerable margin AND you may not even get to the 12 unlocks if you found it late enough into a run, so that feels a bit bad at times.

The maps can become a bit boring and needs expansion, after 20+ hours of game-play its just the same thing over and over, area "x size" always square and go around perimeter until i then work my way into the middle, rinse repeat, the biomes are cool and quite different and i can see this being expanded on quite easily but we need triangle maps or long maps... anything... a square every time is just to simple to follow.

The amount of upgrades and weapon types is quite rich, they feel quite different from each other and would allow for a lot more variants from game to game.

All in all i want to give this a 7/10 and can see it become a 9/10. Its solid and you wont feel like you've wasted your money or time!

Not a whole lot to say. It's a fun roguelike set in the universe of DRG. 

The core gameplay is fun, there is a lot of variety between runs, and it's also quite polished for an early access game. It's priced very well for what you get. Rock and Stone!

The purely move based mechanics put me off for a moment, but after getting used to it leads to a fairly relaxed sense of gameplay. Focusing more on your ability to safely path around, and deal with waves of mobs, split between gathering resources both for progressing and loot; as well as those juicy piles of XP orbs..
Each class also offers a unique approach to each dive with their own specific weapons and stats. Allowing a variety of builds for all and bolstering the replay-value esque' game design we all come to love with roguelikes.
The enemy variety is admittedly a bit same-ey but it doesn't really matter all that much, their numbers and position poses much more of a threat. Leading to a fun game of cat and mouse when it comes to manipulating their pathing, especially with regards to the destructible terrain. 
All in all if you enjoy movement based auto shooters and deep rock galactic, this game is a love letter to them both and at quite a reasonable price. 
9/10

So far there are many things i don't like, i feel kinda bad for giving it a thumbs down, i hope to see things change because it genuinely looks like it could be a fun game. I'll list everything here i like or don't like as feedback.

Pros:
+ Addicting, even if it's way too grindy, it makes you come back.
+ 'Early Access', so (hopefully) a lot more content coming, looking forward to it.
+ The way you have to mine resources to buy upgrades in the menu is a fun mechanic.
+ Account/dwarf level is a neat progression system. (i wish dwarf level would increase their stats)
+ Vibe/theme of the game they are going for is cool and on point.
+ Weapons feel unique and they got nice effects.
+ Sound effects and music is good.
+ Many viable builds, lots of fun gun and overclock combinations.
+ Unique voicelines for most interactions. (ie. 1 unique line at least for almost every gunpick)

Mid:
+- Game's first 5-8 hours are fine, but the repetitiveness and grindiness becomes way too apparent.
+- Unlocking more artifacts dilutes the choice pool and you can't reroll them (a reroll implementation for maybe 10 Nitre?), you are forced to pick useless artifacts, and some can brick your run.
+- Menu upgrades don't have a refund button, so if you misclick, well the resources you spent for it are gone.
+- Games end too fast (~20 mins), by the time you feel powerful, you are killing the boss and the dive ends, there's no power fantasy and it is a "survivors bullet hell" game, an infinite mode or longer dives are needed. (10 stages in a dive perhaps?)
+- There are voicelines for a lot of interactions, but they are mostly 1 liners, these voicelines are funny for the first, maybe 1 hour, then it becomes very repetitive. (can we get a only dwarf voice toggle on-off)
+- The price... It's cheap but it could've been cheaper since Vampire Survivors just offers way more (and offered more at launch) than this game and is 5 Euros cheaper.

Cons:
- Biggest negative for me is that there's not enough sandbox feel to it until you literally grind out every weapon to lvl 12 to then be able to use their overclock capabilities, and even then you are REQUIRED to do hazard objectives to unlock more hazard levels/difficulties, no relief, you are chasing objectives all the time.
- Side objectives which reward you with 30 gold in each dive every stage also add to this, and there's only 3 of them. The 'Collect 12 Boolo Cap' one is unrewarding and too time consuming.
- Biome/hazard objectives that require you to level a specific gun to X levels. There's no way of checking which gun what class uses, so you either trial and error in-game or have to look it up online it.
- The way of unlocking overclock for weapons is clearly just time padding, don't like it.
- Enemies are way too spongy, movement feels very sluggish, luck doesn't seem to have enough effect, levelling speed falls off pretty quick.
- The 30s timer after killing the elite/boss either needs to get increased or just scrapped entirely, let the player scale as long as they want and can in the final stage of the dive at least, more risk/reward and longer games.
- Levels are too short and there's not enough time to do things. (it might be intentional, although i am not a fan of it)
- Movement speed and Mining speed upgrades in the menu start at +2 each upgrade, but after 5 upgrades into them they become +1 and the upgrades become more expensive. (why not just keep the +2s?)
- 3 biomes/maps only, 1 boss, few elites and only a handful of enemy types.
- Each biome has 5 difficulties (called 'Hazard levels') which you have to unlock, but these difficulties only add a health, damage and quanitity multiplier to enemies, and reuses enemy types rather than adding new ones, not a fun design, i'd prefer if there were new and reused enemies at the same time.

Edit1: Added a few more thoughts and rewrote/thought through some negatives as i progressed more through the game.

The best part of the Survivor like genre is starting weak and ending up obliterating everything on screen. this game doesn't give you that. it only gives it you when the exploding enemies kill everything for you. you don't get to be a badass all you get to do is struggle to fight the enemies and the swarms kill themselves when they blow themselves up.

Weapon balancing & Spectacle: by balanced i mean the weapons that are just bad choices need to be WAY better and all the weapons i think need more impact. Vampire survivors is fun because you can end the game with 12 spinning lasers of death and 5 other weapons doing equally rediculous things. the subata pistol ends the game with 2 bullets instead of one firing out your arse. you see the difference? which would you rather see. i do understand this game has limits because its not pixel art and has DRG universe designs. but this isn't a survivors-like game.

This game is great, i do like it but guys i don't want to spend several hours+ grinding the meta progression so i can actually have a fun experience. honestly this game doesn't need any major changes but that makes the small things so annoying. 

Boss fight: So the boss you fight right at the end is completely different from everything until that point as it can jump to you no matter how fast you are or where you are which has killed me nearly every single run i do. this ruins any fun i have as if i want to play stationary with he engineer's turrets suddenly i'm 2 shot by that guy and can't stop to put down turrets. the enemies don't stop spawns all around you either. i already have destructible terrain blocking half the map and the enemies fill the rest of the gaps so where the hell are you meant to go? to the main menu i guess because thats where i went until my 8th time dying where i went to my desktop because it was no longer any fun to die to the boss at the end, the boss can only kill you with this one attack btw even though in the main game he has a fire ball and everything which i assume were not included for a good reason. 

Enemies: so when i play the original game a can can kill a regular mob in a couple of bullets. in this game its more like in 5 or 6 bullets. for the bigger enemies its even worse everything is a bullet sponge but unless you have maxed out meta progression which i don't i can almost never fight them to a standstill. i spent 5 hours and only got about 7 meta upgrades because i never have time to mine for materials.

In the end i'm still going to play it because its good but dying feels bad in this game and the meta progression is too slow for my liking i'll edit/remove this review if i change my mind after playing longer. i can't see me liking this unless the boss can't just jump on me and kill me instantly though. games like this are supposed to make you feel like a badass not a weakling who can hold off an army but die in 2 hits when the boss comes.

UPDATE 1: 10hours in now and i can say some of the issues i have are less pronounced mostly i figured out you HAVE to mine a big arena for the boss so you can move and stuff. however i will make it clear that the second and third biomes are genuinely AWFUL i don't even go on them anymore because the combat is built so that you have to run away but the stage is filled with obstructions and ranged enemies that spawn in the dozens, i have about 20% of the upgrades i HAVE to run away constantly and die immediately if i can't funnel a swarm. This genre started because of a casual game you didn't need to sweat the crap out of and i can honestly say hazard 2 is god damn difficult and it took me 10 hours of grinding to get 20% of the upgrades if the difficulty doesn't change the rate of progression needs to. i like this game but if i want to feel powerful i need to grind for dozens of hours which is exactly the opposite of how these games are supposed to make you feel. 

The last thing i will say is the weapons are by no means balanced and having to pick them and get them to level 12 is a stupid mechanic that i fail to do most of the time because my weapons are so weak i can't do anything unless i choose to upgrade the ones i already have overclocks for which means i can get 1 weapon to 12 never 2 that's IF i manage to win a run when i need to use 12 upgrade points on a sometimes completely useless weapon. some weapons are good from lvl 1 and some are useless even at 12. the Gunners minigun for example having it shoot only in the area in front of the player in a game thats designed for you to always be running away is really REALLY annoying and makes it by far the worst character starting out. i think this is the enemies fault and not the weapon because you can't even use forward firing weapons to carve a path through enemies because they are so tanky.
It's just such a fun and addicting little game. I don't know what else to say. ROCK AND STONE!
Game is awesome

At the current state, one of the weakest examples of a bullet-heaven/auto-shooter/Survivor-like game on the market.
Meta progression is slow and barely felt in gameplay, the difference between starting a run and finishing a run isn't that large, you don't go from a nobody to a bullet-spewing god, you go from dwarf with gun overwhelmed by bugs to dwarf with four guns overwhelmed by bugs. Upgrades you get are random, meaning you can go the entire game without seeing a rare or better upgrade for the weapon you've designated as your main weapon for the run, and better rarity upgrades are extremely meaningful, as one lucky legendary means not taking five common upgrades (aka, five levelups that constitute a very substantial amount of levels you get in total). Weapons vary wildly, with a notable amount of them requiring careful movement and positioning when combined with the extremely tanky mobs, the mining system, random placement of turrets around you when you stand still, kiting enemies just right, triggering exploding mobs to clear area and other bugs - ideas that while appealing are not implemented cohesively. You need to mine facing rocks, but (some of) your guns also shoot toward where you're looking. You need to always keep moving since you cannot hold down an area reliably even when doing the greediest micro-optimizations that hundreds of hours in the series and multiple 100%-d games have taught you, but a lot of the map slows you down ever more thanks to the mining mechanic. You need to constantly stay ahead of the bugs with upgrades, but the map has a linear, constant progression ending with the area boss, where the only time you would theoretically be able to extend the time on a map is by delaying, yet killing the boss often cannot be avoided reliably due to the way guns target, and an extremely punishing drop-pod mechanic where you might have around 5 seconds to finish up something in the area you were when the boss died before being forced to rush to exit the map, being conscious of possible terrain RNG, movement enhancing upgrade luck you've had and the possibility of bug swarms between you and said drop-pod, or you auto-lose the mission. It feels bad when bugs rush you and there is no way to efficiently clear them to farm levels as fast as possible, mining feels bad since you often are dealing unoptimal DPS depending on your loadout, it feels bad when given all these issues of being forced to move, being unable to screenclear almost whatsoever even with perfect build choice and adequate RNG and no magnets spawning make you leave all the experience you've theoretically obtained on the ground since the drop-pod is waiting, and it feels bad when you're entirely at the mercy of RNG regarding upgrades, with rerolling of upgrades being the same currency you use to upgrade yourself between rounds of a dive and none of the tools of shaping upgrades present, such as not picking the "entry" upgrade to a tree (at best - don't pick up a structure or an elemental weapon when you're doing kinetic projectiles so you don't dillute your non-weapon pool) your build isn't interested in or the myriad of potions in Halls of Torment. The best weapons often do not rely anything but their targeting AI and line of sight to be good so the best pick is obvious almost every time, overclocking the guns - with the trailer promising "dramatically changing the weapon's behaviour and giving you an edge in combat" and the reality being often "give the weapon another damage type, meaning it synergizes less with your kit now and floods your passive pool with more things that don't level up your gun nor benefit your entire arsenal" - is terrible, and it's a shame it's advertised as the most impactful change to your gameplay given you even need to use the weapon semi-successfully without those overclocks first to even be able to overclock them in further runs. Most upgrades are numerical changes to the formula of "X shots of Y damage per Z time, after a given amount of shots wait N time", which are fine filler, but that's all there is to upgrades - pray the one that's purple or yellow when you get a level is damage or reload speed, not crit damage when you've yet to see a crit chance or fire rate on a shotgun with two shells in it. Even when fully utilizing every possible avenue of making yourself better the game gives you, the end result is "you're not completely overwhelmed by the bugs just yet", there's never the screen-clearing untouchable win-state of god run ends of other games, just "you picked up just about enough damage to not be overwhelmed by trash while fighting the boss, good job, 5 runs like that and you can have your 2% mining speed upgrade!". The game is careful to never let you get too strong, one of the main draws of having a god run in these types of games.
Not much here for fans of the survivors genre, rather another dwarf game for the DRG enjoyers - the can of paint, grindy nature of progression and the feeling of a hostile (randomly generated) world you're never entirely conquering being reminiscent. There are much better survivor titles in the 10 bucks range, although it definitely looks nice, and has potential if the training wheels were taken off and we could actually have meaningful win-states, better functioning upgrade and weapon-usage systems with a larger impact and less feelbad moments during gameplay. I don't regret my time, there's definitely potential here, but currently it's not really delivering what I look for in these games.

Overall, I like this game, but it has some serious flaws to it that are fairly frustrating.

This game does a great job of putting you on the edge of your seat, and forces you to make the best out of a bad situation. The game looks and feels great. From getting xp, to causing a massive chain reaction explosion, to just mining as the driller has a really satisfying feel to it. The classes feel different so that it actually changes the play style. Missions aren't too long and in the beginning there are frequent unlocks.

I have 4 main issues with this game.
The first and second issues basically go hand in hand, and that is the case of the difficulty and the meta progression. Unlocking a new hazard level basically always feels like the level is impossible to clear until you progress to a certain meta level. This is frustrating because it feels like player agency is taken away and you are simply forced to keep trying until you eventually reach a threshold where it's even possible to win. 

The third issue I have is that the progress bar for each individual mission feels like it punishes you for doing well. In order to succeed in this game, you must mine for resources while fighting hordes of bugs, pretty classic DRG gameplay. However, the progress bar which spawns the boss of the stage goes faster the more bugs you kill, which when it's sending swarm after swarm, causes it to spawn the boss too quickly in my opinion. You might not think that's a big problem, but if the boss is left alive for too long, the alien horde increases in power very quickly, forcing you to kill the boss and leave as fast as possible. In later stages on higher hazard levels, this happens too quickly for you to mine for the resources you need.

The fourth issue is with the guns. Some of them are just so much better than the others that it basically pigeonholes you into picking the same or at least similar load out every time. Another problem arises because of this, which is that the guns you can get are picked randomly from a pool of choices. You can reroll this, but it costs resources. Similarly, the overclocks seem imbalanced in the same way as the guns, but these you cannot reroll, so if you don't get what you want, too bad. 

It might be a surprise that I still gave this game a positive review, but it's still very fun regardless of these issues. I also trust the producers and have faith in them that they will make favorable changes to this game. That along with the low price point gets them a positive from me, and I am mostly hopeful that they read similar reviews to see what people like/don't like.

Great Game.  If you like the Vampire Survivor "Garlic-Like's" style you will love this game.

The characters are varied. The unlock system is great.

The only real negative is the balance issues between tier 2 and tier 3.  Tier 2 is now incredibly easy, and tier 3 is incredibly hard. The amount it takes now to upgrade my characters would be so much grinding tier 2 that this is the first time in 18 hours ive felt myself slowing down on wanting to play it.  I guess 18 hours to hit a wall is still pretty good though.

In it's current state with it's current amount of content if I had to choose to purchase or not again I would wait for a few more updates. It's a good price, but I would still wait for more to come out the game could use some beefing.

Couple things to note:

- not actually dev'd by Ghost Ship games or the people who made DRG (Made by Funday Games)
- this is the team that made "Subway Surfer" on iOS and "Don't DIE in the West" on Steam

Positives:

- Damn fun for the first few hours, I was immediately hooked to the gameplay loop of mine/shoot/loot/level
- Aesthetic is very nice and obviously the same as Ghost Ship Games: DRG
- Visually pleasing, not too busy, and generally fun to try and catch everything on the screen
- The upgrades are straight forward, easy to understand/select, and fun
- The weapons are straight forward, easy to use, and fun
- The enemies are obviously similar to DRG, but not exactly the same making for a new learning curve though only slightly different
- Aspects of the level designs and aesthetics are fun and engaging
- The passive upgrades you upgrade before any dives are similar to the in-game upgrades. Easy to understand, not unachievable but not incredibly easy to level, and somewhat effective (I feel like upgrading in the menu does actually make a tangible impact on my in-game play)

Negatives:

- Bosses are not a challenge in any way in terms of mechanics - I only ever die to my health being too low before the fights began or to not having enough DPS to finish the fights quickly (Up to Haz 2)
- Upgrades feel good at a certain point, but then as you ramp and build into your run/build, the run ends because you've beat the mission - (Even your character says "That's great for my build" or something like that, but your build isn't even a build until the very end of the final mission)
- Mining feels weird and is sometimes inconsistent/random - there is no real value in mining unless convenient
- Shooting is just the most odd mechanic in this game, several guns shoot where you are facing only and often times are shooting rocks or the supply pod instead of enemies (directional shooting pls)
- Electric is the clear defined meta of this game as most other options struggle with healthy crowd control (make fire more viable)
- The supply drop is fun but it would be nice to see more upgrade options, I would even prefer there not to be good things every time, more of a mixed bag of Low and High tier items as the upgrades per level are
- More upgrade varieties would be great


There is not much that I feel needs to change, the game is pretty spot on but just missing a few core pieces that could make it go from a C+ to B game to an A-A+ game. A few updates, maybe beef up the level or game mode options, honestly increase the spawns of the mobs too. All very easy fixes and they are working with a great publisher who likes to listen to its playerbase.

There are walls to dig through, side objectives to complete, and a bunch of other gimmicks that I have to grind through, all while trying to survive and beat the stage. It really sucks that I have to literally die just to get upgrades like overclocks for my weapons. Which are the upgrades that give the weapon a boost, but they are locked until you level up the weapon to twelve and either die or beat the stage. Its like there are so many things to do in this game that it has an identity crisis on what its supposed to be. Remember Vampire survivors where you literally just move around or stand still while the bullets kill the enemies. Well DRG: Survive is exactly like that except that there way too many things to do at the same time. It also forces you to stand still in situations where you have to be constantly moving. Like the Gunners minigun only facing one direction. You have to stand still and aim the cone of fire at the bugs for it to be effective. 

I played a bunch of these survivor like games, and this one just really confuses and frustrates me

I would just pass on this game, or wait for a couple of months until the rebalance everything, if the devs are even going to do that in the first place.

All right, let's dive right in.

Just like in Deep Rock Galactic, DRG: Survivor puts the player in the work boots of a dwarf miner on a distant alien planet. Players must complete a series of objectives (ranging from collecting X amount of minerals and securing supply drops to killing bosses) so they can descend into the next layer of the level - all while surviving a relentless alien onslaught. Each mission has 5 layers, each getting progressively harder than the last, and on higher hazard levels, the missions prove to be quite difficult.

This is a very addictive game and even though the concept is straightforward, the execution is amazing - which makes for a highly entertaining experience. The voice acting and sound design is on point, and the isometric-style camera angle gives this game a nostalgic kind of aesthetic (it reminds me of the old StarCraft, Outlive, and Diablo games) while still delivering stunning environments and creatures to the player.

If this is what the game is like in early access, I can only imagine what might come next - and I'm excited for it!

Few things are as satisfying as mowing down wave after wave of bug-like aliens, but if there was one thing that would make that even more fun - it would be if we could do that with friends! I imagine that scaling the difficulty and balancing everything for that would be a challenge, but one that would undoubtedly position DRG: Survivor as one of the best games of the year.

Normally I wait until the game leaves Early Access before I leave a review, especially a negative one. However the recent patch showed these devs are truly out of touch with their player base and I legitimately regret investing and trusting in them at this point. https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2321470/view/6636686753338579730

"Removed the Dwarf voice line "Die like your mother did" because we think it's out of place and don't want to remind some players of tragic events in their life when they want to relax with a video game. We might add a voice line filter in options down the line if enough people want it."

They are rightfully getting roasted for this absurd censorship of an iconic DRG voice line. The dwarf isn't even referring to the player's mother, but to the bug's mother. What, are we unable to insult the bug hoards now? What about people with arachnophobia who are seriously stressed out and frightened by spiders, even digital ones? Because this game has giant yellow spiders that explode. And i made this post that was swiftly removed: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3164976224 The mods are doing overtime with damage control. And they are removing other topics criticizing this move.

They also locked this thread giving legit criticism: https://steamcommunity.com/app/2321470/discussions/0/6292161380826562223/
"The fact that you believe nobody even notices what they say just highlights how little this should matter to you anyone else it doesnt effect." That's not a reason to lock valid criticism.

Not just the censorship, but the game is also horribly unbalanced. it takes a long time of grinding the first difficulty of the first level before you can really start to beat the other difficulties. This is exacerbated by the fact that you must first level a weapon to 12 before you can even start using the powerful and absolutely necessary overclocks on that weapon in future runs. There's a pinned tips page that helps you play which I already did all of them, and the game is still very difficult, especially on higher difficulties where enemies will often outscale your damage if you haven't been lucky with the rng powerups. And I'm not the only one complaining here either.

So with both of these things in mind I decided I needed to leave a negative review now so other people know what's going on, and to wait until the devs fix these issues, if they fix them. If they do I will change and update this review. But for now stay away.

I was very worried that this game would feel like a cringe spin-off that just rips DRG assets and doesn't get how DRG is supposed to feel.

I am pleased to say that this is absolutely not the case. Funday Games nailed it. It feels like a DRG game.

It's not PERFECT yet, I would definitely like to see some gameplay tweaks (the timer appearing after you kill the boss and the boss itself appearing after you kill enough enemies discourages you from killing enemies, which sucks) and more variety in upgrades (particularly more "synergies" and "builds" being possible), but they have managed the hardest part. I'm sure all these tweaks will come in time.

For how low the game is priced, I definitely recommend it for any DRG fan for a taste of something different.

This is a 'gem'of a Roguelite Spin-off in the Deep Rock Galactic universe...after 50 hours of gameplay at time of writing, here are my thoughts...

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is an absolute blast, delivering a near-flawless translation of the core Deep Rock Galactic experience into the endlessly replayable roguelite format. Funday Games has outdone themselves, creating a spin-off that stands confidently on its own while honoring the spirit of the original.

At its heart, Survivor exemplifies the addictive roguelite formula. Each run offers a fresh challenge, with procedurally generated levels ensuring no two experiences are alike. You're always on the move, blasting hordes of Glyphids, mining valuable minerals, and scrambling to stay ahead of the encroaching swarms. The combat is incredibly smooth and responsive, echoing the high-octane action of its predecessor. Each of the four classes (Driller, Engineer, Gunner, and Scout) provides a unique playstyle and powerful abilities. Seeing how far you can push yourself under relentless pressure will have you saying "just one more round!" long into the night.

From unique weapons and class-specific upgrades to potent artifacts and game-changing perks, Survivor is brimming with creative choices and a sense of tactical depth. There's a joy in experimenting with loadouts, discovering the insane synergies between upgrades, and adapting strategies with each new item you find. Survivor doesn't hold back with content either; there are tons of unlockables to keep you coming back for more, ensuring a rewarding progression system that motivates you to try out different playstyles.

Presentation is essentially flawless....despite the huge hordes of bugs, complete with their reflections on crystals, and some fantastic particle effects, the game keeps up pace and runs smoothly, with minimal loading times. The instant access to pause the game via the Right Mouse Button, with an overview of your current build, keeps you in the game as often and as quickly as you like. 

If you're a fan of Deep Rock Galactic or simply love a well-crafted roguelite, Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a must-play.  With its smooth combat, creative upgrades, and deep progression, it's a captivating spin-off that delivers everything fans could hope for in this fresh format. Now, I have 3 more achievements for a clean-sweep...something I never do with Steam games!

I know it was less than $10 but it's not really worth it in this pre-alpha state.  

There are core aspects of the game that need addressed, and SHOULD have been addressed before this game was put on sale.  It doesn't feel like a game that was even playtested, or if it was, it was play tested by an IGN reviewer.

Balance doesn't exist.  This wouldn't matter if there weren't missions/quests in the game that direct you to play a certain way.  Most builds are not viable.  Many weapons shouldn't even be touched.  There are upgrades in the game that even the legendary version is worse than the common option of a different upgrade.

Also, there's no co-op or multiplayer.  That's kind of the very core of DRG, this game should have had that running before even releasing it to the public.  

So maybe if you are okay with playing this 6-12 months from now, it's worth it at this price under the assumption they will fix the issues.  If they do not fix the issues, this game will never be anything buy a DRG branded cash grab.

Uggg...this really hurts posting this for such a game franchise but sadly as hyped as I was for this...this isn't good. I was talking with a friend and sadly the best way to explain this game without you having to read the rest of the review is, [i]Son, we have Deep Rock Galactic at home and this game is shown[/i]. 

Sure I get it, this game is in Early Access I KNOW, sure I know it's a Vampire Survivors like, but I love Vampire Survivors.
If you have stuck around let me just get to the meat as to why not recommend. Again this pains me so much but basically the 3 pillars of why Deep Rock is fun is that it's [b]fun with friends[/b], obviously it's a [b]mining game so that's really fun and interesting[/b] and there is [b]vast customisation with very different characters[/b]. 
At least most of these pillars or really, all 3 don't continue in this game. Firstly massive red flag, this game is single player, sure I get it fun and probably cheaper to make but really most probably the chaos with your friends is why most people play Deep Rock. Second if you don't have friends and you really are a dwarf then mining is your thing so that's why you play Deep Rock...yeah none of that here. No controls, just WASD so move and the dwarf does everything automatically, yes like Vampire Survivors but come on maybe let me click my mouse for that at least? Ok let's not do that ignore what I said but still let me enjoy my mining, let me see gold and go ouuu yes! Not every time I see gold or Nitra or anything else I'm like god no, I'm gonna get slowed down and this endless never ending swarm will kill me! Please I don't want to see anymore minerals. 
Lastly the customisation, so this was the ehh sorta, it's here but not really. You can technically customise your build and get the gunner, scout weapons and grenades so what...is the point of the other classes really? Not much, minor things like the scout can move faster...yey, no grapple btw cause why have something that cools down for lets say 30 seconds and uses something other than WASD make the game more fun and original? No Gunner shield cause again same reason as stated before. It's just painful. So many obvious things where missed...and I can't think of a reason why. It really feels like a chore than just having fun with Deep Rock again and it makes me very sad. It's just a worse Vampire Survivors like with a Deep Rock skin and that's it.
Hey, at least I can click V and Rock and Stone...alone.

Aside from the fact that this game looks nice and is  a DRG spin-off, I wouldn't recommend it as it is now.

1. [u]Balancing and progression[/u]
The balancing in this game after the first few hours get to feel slow and repetitive, as you have to meticulously grind in order to get universal upgrades for stats and dwarfs. Progression does not feel rewarding, it takes to long for how much you get and gets worse with time, with the game getting boring/frustrating quickly.


2.[u] Weapon functionality and Gameplay [/u]

This is probably what I dislike most about this game. The way weapons function makes 0 sense to me. No weapons in this game require you to aim, and the way the weapons themselves shoot does not make sense for how gameplay works with fighting the bugs. The game quickly devolves into trying to work around how your weapons do not function effectively with how you want them to, the biggest offender being the flamethrower which spins slowly in a circle (often times not hitting anything) instead of targeting the bugs. [b]You are at the mercy of how your weapon aims.[/b] Along with mainly boring % upgrades, there isn't much in the way of creativity or skill in fighting the bugs. Just running, mining and choosing the upgrade with the biggest %.


[u]Conclusion:[/u] The game has too much unrewarding grind. The gameplay feels repetitive and frustrating when it comes to how swarms function in respective to how weapons work. Gameplay as a whole feels un-engaging with the feeling of skill not being present at all, just running and mining to escape while fighting against how weapons work, instead of the bugs.

Final Stage - Get hunted by bugs. (survival its optional)

It's just kinda bad in its current state.
It's hard to see the effects of a 2% increase to firing speed when your gun is already a pea-shooter with no damage. 
It's hard to fight a boss when the game feels it's appropriate to fill the level with hundreds of enemies to go with him, as well as making them harder to kill as time goes on, which makes the boss harder to kill in return.
It seems pointless to pick an overclock ability for your gun when the options are "Electric" and "Acid" when the game doesn't even bother telling you what either of those effects does.
The meta-progression is a slog with most of the effects you can boost just feeling like filler.
The classes and what makes them special feels inconsistent and their starter weapons feel very underwhelming.
The reload system absolutely kill this game for me. Not only can you never really choose what to shoot at (outside of simply standing closest to the thing you want to kill), but now there will be times when all your guns are reloading, and you're just standing in a crowded hallway like a dumbass waiting for a timer to tick down to start dealing damage again.

When your main competition in this genre is a game like Vampire Survivor, who has already mastered this formula, it seems strange to try to re-invent the wheel in such a way where I wish I was playing a different game.
This game is DRG in name alone, and has little to do with the game whose name it's piggy-backing on. The characters just throw out recycled lines from DRG, the weapons all feel underpowered and situational, and the setting could be any other generic sci-fi scenario and it wouldn't change the game one bit.
The game is missing what makes DRG special. Teamplay, frantic gun-play, creative builds and charming environments, enemy variety and setting are all missing from this game. It just feels like a missed opportunity to make a game that actually explores the DRG universe further through story or any actual coherent lore.

While it is right now not as good as either DRG or Vampire Survivors, it is full of potential. The digging mechanic is fun as is digging out supply pods and doing secondary objectives. We can only hope we will get more missions in the future instead of just taking out dreadnoughts and maybe more outlandish weapons, since a lot of them right now are just shooty-shooty-ratatat, but all in all it is already quite enjoyable. And the traversal tools of all the classes are missing as well right now.

A few words of warning: 
1. the game starts really slow and lackluster, but keep on playing (and dying) and the more interesting stuff is unlocked and possible builds start to slowly emerge.
2. the game is quite hard and unforgiving, but remember that while it has a mission objective, it is still mainly a "survivors" type game and getting over the finish line will not happen often.

It's just lacking something so far.. It's almost there however and I strongly believe this thumbs down will turn on its head by the time they've had a few patches out. As it is now the game feels a bit over-balanced, almost none of the weapons feel fun to use and the progression paths are uninteresting on most of them, along with extremely tedious stat upgrades after missions where you get things like "2% mining speed" after a 30min run, feels a bit too slow. This along with every end-boss being the same and the missions being generally quite uninteresting. Lots of whining but there are general glimpses of greatness here as well. The mining addition is a fresh breath of air for the genre and I wish they would double down on this even harder, I think there are a thousand more ways they could explore to make it more central to the game play loop. For now its not really worth it if you are a big fan of the genre as there are too many competitors that just do the same thing but better, but hopefully in a years time this will stand shoulder to shoulder with the greats, fingers crossed.

I want to like this game, and maybe I will with the future releases. Right now, I don't think that it's a good game, for me at least.

1. There is no sense of mystery. All possible unlocks are visible, albeit it's not clear what the unlock conditions are (you can access them, but it's a pain).
2. It's not DRG in terms of look, feel and gameplay. Sure, it's a different genre, but the art style is too different, the guns are just nominally similar, so are dwarves. The feeling of large unknown, and you being opressed is not there either, the game is well lit and levels are absolutely tiny.

As a survivors-like, it fails on many points as well. One key for me was how jarring the pacing feels, it's okay, but it's just too rushed, you have no time to appreciate your upgrades at all.

Side objectives are really half-baked, to the point where I would prefer that they did not exist. You can't always achieve them, and then you just feel bad for wasted effort knowing there's little you could have done differently.

Main objectives are mixed for me, the level-to-level objective with a miniboss is okay, but it's too simplistic, as you can kill it by dropping the pod on it every time. It just feels like going through the motions, that's the by far easiest and best way to do it, and it sucks all the fun and variety out.

The core objective at the end of the run is better in a sense, but also worse. You can take something like 50% hp off the boss with the pod, but I had runs where I could simply not get at the boss. That is - my guns would mow down everything else, but refuse to target the boss.

Finally, the whole extraction thing feels horrible. In DRG it feels like a victory run, like you're the hero escaping after a successful mission and the game does everything it can to help you get there generally. In here, you have 30s, and it's just enough in most cases, sometimes it forces you to run through the mobs and get hit just to make it in time. It's a punishment quite frankly.

After playing the game for a bit, I can say that I have no excitement towards it at all. It's a polished piece of work that is less good than most of the indie titles out there.

The survivors genre of games isn't the deepest most complext genre, but this game plays in the space quite well. It's competently made, even while in early access. The mining aspect adds an interesting level of tactics to the genre. Overall, I like it. It's a good time killer, as games of this genre should be.

Pretty good, I die a lot more to map generation than I do mistakes of my own making though. For example when a pod drops too far away for me to physically reach in time thanks to ravines or red vines in the way. Ammo box is nice but because of the 30 second timer I never take it unless it pops up on the last stage. Pickled nitra is a death sentence so I have never taken it since there's no way to get rid of nitra on the last stage, you need to get super lucky with movement speed to have a shot generally speaking. I've played a lot of DRG and a lot of these Survivor type games and that 30 second timer doesn't really fit either of them. I can count on one hand the amount of times I've been left behind by the pod without being downed on DRG and all of them were because of my friends trolling me, and I can't think of any other Survivor type game with a death timer rather than a victory timer and I'm not 100% sure what that mechanic being so harsh adds to the game. Either remove or allow us to circumvent impassable terrain, improve the pod's location choosing or extend the timer and it'll be fine. Losing can be fun, being left behind is literally never fun and should only be used as a super last resort if the player's really cheesing the stage mechanics.

Having managed to complete all 3 biome goals for hazard 1-3 maps, and 2 of each for hazard 4 maps, I can say this game has sublime balancing. If you were to ask me what my favorite class is, I can't answer that. Because they are all phenomenal in different ways. 4 main classes (12 total subclasses) are all amazing and those biome goals want you to use specific classes / loadouts. 

It's also a reverse difficulty game. It's easy to fall behind the curve and struggle to survive in latter phases, but I found the gameplay loop to be a nice session -- typically up to 30 minutes if you get all the way through, and you'll die lots especially trying to push those boundaries by not killing the boss right away.

At first I thought the scout was a crappy class, but after levelling up other classes, going back to the scout was pretty impressive. Seems like every weapon no matter how bad it seems becomes very powerful by level 18. 

For example, in hazard 4 hollow bough, you need to acquire 600 gold in a single run. That's a lot! It also wants you to level the subata rear firing machine gun to level 25. I hated the subata as it makes for a difficult start. So the driller foreman starts with it, and also has a perk that lets you mine 50% faster once you get going. There is an artefact that gives you a chance of gaining gold when mining any rock. So that's the plan. Get that perk early (luck), and mine the crap out of everything. I haven't pulled it off yet, but did complete the dive and got subata to 25. Once it hit 18, it became impressively powerful, like a tailgun on a B17 bomber.

The harder the hazard level, the faster you level up, but also the faster the levels complete because progress is tied to kills. Once you get a weapon to level 18, you can really go toe to toe against most waves and get that sweet leveling machine rolling.

I'm really enjoying this game. I don't know if multiplayer is coming, but I imagine that would add a lot. I am also impressed how you just move with the left stick. No aim, no fire button. The only time you press a button is to select a perk. 

On the downside, I find the UI is laggy despite the game being paused, and more than once I accidentally chose the wrong perk.

It's still fun to play but very imbalanced and grindy right now.

This game is a mixed bag. It's really fun, and a great game to just pick up, play for an hour or two, and go about your day. And I highly recommend it to any fan of Deep Rock Galactic. It looks really good, is fairly smooth, etc.

As an auto-shooter, though, I'd say it's just average in its current state- slow progression, heavy emphasis on laborious grinding, limited maps, overpowered and bullet-spongey enemies, etc. I know it's still Early Access, so there's time to add things, but as of right now I'd say wait for a sale/for more content if you want to pick the game up.

All in all, though, it's a great game, and I really appreciate the devs putting so much care and effort into this game. They should be proud of such a good product!

This game is a solid choice for fans of DRG and survival games. Despite its imperfections, it delivers engaging gameplay that merges DRG's elements with survival mechanics. However, the late game could benefit from additional features to maintain player interest, as the experience tends to wane past hazard level 3, I lack the incentive to play past that. Considering it's still in early access, the game is fairly decent.

I've played a lot of VS-like titles. VS, Rogue Genesia, Death Must Die, Halls of Torment, Project Lazarus, Soulstone Survivors... all are better games. Every one.

Besides the IP (which I am aware of, but not an ardent fan of), this game simply has good graphics. There is nothing within the confines of the Survivor-like sub-genre that DRG:S does as well as, let alone better than, any of the titles I listed.

At their core, Survivor-like titles can be summarized as taking the 100+ hours it takes to reach max level in an ARPG like Diablo or PoE and condensing them down to 15-20 minute bite-sized chunks of power fantasy wish fulfillment badassery. You go from a weakling to a god in a few minutes. It's intoxicating and, above all else, fun af.

DRG:S does not seem to understand that. There is, no matter what you do, no moment at which you feel more powerful than you did the moment before. Heck, it's SUPREMELY easy to become LESS powerful when you make a choice, because of the way the game scales itself and the fact that effectively NONE of the weapons synchronize or synergize with one another. There are, at its core, SO many poor design decisions (within the confines of this sub-genre) that are baffling to me.

Weapons, despite mostly being guns and variations thereof, cannot be aimed. You are wasting ammo and damage output when you pick many of them. They have idiotic limitations like "only shoots ahead of you" or "throws randomly in a direction" that you will, at least half the time, have a weapon equipped that is unsuitable for what you need.

The weapons cannot be manually reloaded. That means you will often find yourself in a situation where your weapons simply are not available to you when you need them most. (And good luck if they don't shoot where you NEED them to shoot.)

Besides that, the weapons do not synergize. There are no wild combinations or effects that make any decision more meaningful than another. It's just +Damage or +Crit Chance. No, Fire weapon + Acid weapon = special Napalm damage. Nothing works together. Some weapons are outright horrendous choices that actively harm your ability to kill enemies. It sucks. (And what do effects DO? What is the difference between acid and fire? Plasma and electricity? No clue. Game doesn't explaining itself.)

The enemies scale at such a degree that if you do not prioritize damage, you will get overwhelmed. Period. Once the boss spawns, enemy swarms scale in size, number, and HP every 30 seconds (or so it seems) to a degree that makes it essentially impossible to overcome the odds. Count on it. It WILL happen to you. It's just a matter of how much you can put up with it.

The mining mechanic is a neat idea, but woefully misused. By placing the player on a fixed map (instead of the endlessly scrolling ones that are common in S-likes), you can AND WILL run into scenarios where you corner yourself by no fault of your own. The game does not telegraph or inform you of the map's size or limitations before you discover it yourself and remove the fog of war. But that can only happen if you wander, which means you're not managing objectives, which means you're wasting opportunities to progress the meta-upgrades (which are lame and uninspired). It also means you need to abandon collecting XP gems because if you're mining, you're not killing bugs. You'll have maneuverability, but have too many bugs to kill. If you try and kill them, you're not mining, which means you're unable to maneuver when needed.

My suggestion(s):

1) Allow players to aim and reload their guns. This would be the most important and most effective way of changing the balance of the game. Period. It looks and feels like it should be a twin-stick shooter variant of the S-like formula. Embrace it. Lean into it. The other systems at play do NOT afford a fun experience if it's simply an auto-attack style game. Which ties into...

2) Make the auto-attack be a secondary fire mode for every weapon. Take cues from Death Must Die, a more traditional ARPG-like spin on the formula that lets players choose, and actively change, whether they auto-attack or manually attack. But make it a per-weapon choice. Maybe I want the acid spitter to be spinning around me as I secure a drop. But when I'm mining a path, I want to ensure it's spitting behind me. Let me make that choice. Maybe I want the microwave emitter thing to auto-shoot to my left because that's where the swarm is approaching from, but maybe I want it ahead of me because that's where I want the path to be cleared. Let ME choose that. Let ME aim my armaments. (Do you know how rarely I need the shotgun shooting RIGHT in front of me?? Rarely ever. Know what is in front of me a lot? Rock and stone. Because I'm mining. What good is having a shotgun that is idling as I look at a stone wall when there is a literal planet's worth of nasty space bugs crawling up my ass? Oh, I can turn around and feed them some lead, sure. But then I'm actively NOT doing what I WANT to be doing, which is mining myself a path to escape the buggers. It's diametrically opposed design decisions like that that just boggle the mind.)

3) Allow for one of two things: either allow weapons to be combined to create all new bug killing monstrosities in-run (the way VS combines powers) or keep giving us new weapon choices every few levels (the way Soulstone Survivors continues to allow you to swap your choices). The last thing I want to find out in the middle of an otherwise good run is that I just picked a bad weapon. So let me rectify that mistake by still giving me the chance to pick a new one later. Maybe drop weapon caches the way the artifacts drop. Or let me pay currency to grab a new weapon during a level up. Something. As it stands, it is far FAR too easy to cripple your run because so many of the weapons just outright suck to have equipped, but you don't know that until you use them, and then it's too late. You may as well die right away because your run is ruined. There's no overcoming choosing a bad weapon and no way to make that weapon different or more effective in a way that matters.

4) Make the map endless. Just have the materials spawn randomly as-is, but let us go wherever we feel we need to. The vines and tougher rocks and stuff, that's fine. Nice little speed bumps. But actively putting us on platforms that limit maneuverability is far FAR too limiting when the heat gets turned up. And it will.

5) GET RID OF THE TIMER. Why the F are we forced to suicide run at the end of every level to finish things? If I just survived the boss and completed my objectives, I WANT THE SPOILS OF MY EFFORTS. Period. I want to be rewarded with mountains of XP, not punished with a lower health bar going into the next stage because I had to brute force suicide run to get to the ramp, which then means I'm spending gold on health and not upgrades to actively make myself stronger. And that's only even possible IF I managed to sneak in enough mining of loot bugs and upgrade materials while managing all the other crap in a given stage.

5b) If you won't get rid of the timer, then ALWAYS have the boss drop a magnet. Always. Again, I WANT THE REWARDS FOR OVERCOMING THE ODDS YOU'VE STACKED AGAINST ME. I DO NOT WANT TO BE PUNISHED AND FEEL LIKE I'M MISSING OUT.

Until the team decides what they want DRG:S to truly be, either a simplistic ode to a better-designed game with the same IP or a truly great entry in an emerging genre, this game isn't worth your time or money. There are better, cheaper options available. My recommendation isn't just not to play it. It's to seek a better game in the genre like VS, Halls of Torment, or Death Must Die if you are interested in it. Those are the objectively best entries in the genre I have experience with. I know there are more. Interested? Go find them. They are likely better thought out than DRG:S is. It's really hard to misunderstand what makes a genre of games fun worse than the DRG:S team has here.

The game is fun for the first few hours, but the progression starts to feel slow and tedious. The lack of weapon synergies and boss variations starts to become noticeable. The progression feels like it was designed to pad content by making you rerun the same maps to get minor upgrades. Locking overclocks behind level 12 means that you need to run a weak build that will likely result in a loss before you can attempt with a build that could work.
Funny quick game, worthy successor to DRG

EDIT 3: They released a new patch! Did they fix the softlocks? No. Did they fix drop pod falling off the map, ruining your run at the last 20 seconds? No. Did they remove the "Die like your mother did" voiceline from the original game, because it's offensive? Yes they did. In a game where you shoot other living creatures with guns, cook and burn them alive, electrocute them and poison them. In a game where you commit genocide for profit. They removed a war cry. These developers are a joke.

Bland, slow, and ultimately not satisfying - which is the only thing you could go for in a survivors-like game. It doesn't bring anything new to the table that we haven't seen, and it does all the usual stuff worse than any alternative. Hitboxes are unpredictable and not properly communicated, upgrades are low-impact, music and SFX are muffled and distant (not even correctly spatial), hitting an enemy is like hitting a curtain, enemy variety is low, UI is clunky.

And no amount of rocks and stones is going to be enough to overcome this.

You might want to check out Swarm Grinder instead, which DRG:S has suspiciously [i]a lot[/i] in common with.

EDIT: Eighteen hours later, and it doesn't get any better. All runs feel the same. There's no synergies you can make. It's all about how much you've previously grinded for permanent upgrades. No matter which weapon upgrades you choose during a run, the way you move and approach enemies is exactly the same. It's a miracle indeed - they've managed to make a bad game when all the hard work had already been done for them: they had all the lore and flavor pre-built, and survivors-like is the easiest dаmned genre to nail. You just need to make it fun.

It's funny how none of the positive reviews have anything good to say about the game. It's all just memes and ASCII art of compressed gold (which isn't even in the game).

EDIT 2: There's also a bunch of bugs with softlocks. Also the last stage sometimes doesn't load (it just shows Loading... screen without really doing anything, which I suspect is a softlock as well). So it's not just a bland game, it's also bad software.

I think there's a simple fix to the odd pacing that can happen in this game. Stages are often hard to pace because secondary objectives can be really spread out, and bugs slow your progress around the map big time. Besides balance tweaks that I'm not smart enough to suggest, here's the simple solution:

AFTER DEFEATING THE BOSS, LET US CALL IN THE DROP POD

AND ADD BONUS XP BASED ON STAGE CLEAR TIME

With these two changes, I think the game would be vastly improved.
Want to go for the secondary objective and risk the bugs getting so strong they could overwhelm you? Go for it.
Want to focus the boss so hard and get that sweet supply drop insta kill so you can clear the stage in record time, getting some bonus XP? Do it.

In the state of progression right now, all the wrong things feel rushed. Drop pod timer being the biggest issue. It doesn't feel good that killing the stage boss quickly is only BAD for you. That should not be the case in a game like this. If anything, let us decide when we progress, because gameplay says, "get strong fast" and then penalizes you for doing just that

This is my review for launch. This is an early access game so there will be updates.

What I like: 
+ A variety of different characters and weapons, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.
+ A strong variety of weapons, class mods, and relics to work towards at launch.
+ Price ($9 at launch)

What I don't like:
- The enemies scale in difficulty too high early on. Even Tier 3 (out of 5 tiers of difficulty) is incredibly difficult without the right RNG drops.
- The levels feel too short. My suggestion is four longer levels instead of 5 short ones.

I'm indifferent about the upgrades shop. It is a grind, but the rewards are very powerful.

Will I keep playing it?  Yes, to get my money's worth, when I feel like something stupid.
Is it fun?  Reasonably so.
Do I recommend you buy it?  No, at least not yet.
Why:
CHEAP.  It's honestly just a farmed-out, crappy bullet-hell roguelike engine with all the DRG assets slapped onto it.  I've played a couple hours and not seen anything unique yet.  The DRG folk could have done so much better than this.
NO MULTIPLAYER.  Honestly I was so certain it would include this that I bought it out of hand, and copies for my friends, before seeing it was single player.  Cooperative multiplayer is the heart of DRG and this is a travesty.  I have two friends who get motion sickness from 3D games and I thought this would finally make some of the character of the DRG universe available to them.

This game starts out quite addicting in the early levels/hazards but falls off and gets agitating the more you get into the harder levels. The selection of weapons is pulled from the og DRG which is nice but feels weak when it comes to descriptions and variety. At the harder levels it becomes agitating to balance secondary objectives and kiting enemies (which can be quite fast for some instances to the point its unfair) and the exploder bugs can become extremely annoying and will often ruin a run. When you get hit with multiple at a time, say goodbye to your health because you can be hit by SEVERAL at a time if they all explode at once (each doing up to 30 dmg). The ending boss also has a somewhat predictable attack (which does half health damage for most characters) but in some pregen maps it becomes IMPOSSIBLE to dodge and no matter how powerful you are its a game breaker. This game is hard to love but hard to hate and I hope EA will get better in the near future.

EDIT:
After playing for some more time Ill list some specific pros and cons that I'm talking about

PROS:
Credit and Material system for perma-upgrades presents a nice long term game play loop which is enjoyable at first

Lots of weapon variety

Classic lines from OG DRG are still enjoyable and they've added a few extra lines

Good potential for a casual gaming experience

CONS:
Harder levels become very tight when trying to balance secondary objectives and kiting enemies to gather the xp they drop. It becomes a decision of either focus on collecting the secondaries or actually leveling up to get powerful.

(currently) Single Boss type which has an unforgiving damage output and will often end a run in the clustered pre-gen maps

XP is primarily (other than mining) gained by killing enemies and retrieving the xp they drop which in the harder levels becomes very difficult when some enemies go faster and some slower which makes kiting nearly impossible in some levels

Magnets (which retrieve all xp in the map) are dropped once in a blue moon (in my experience) *this could be solved by supply drops acting as an automatic magnet when you clear them*

Weapons variety is good but some weapons are downright just not useful to pickup compared to others, assuming this will be fixed in future updates (minigun is awful at the beginning stages)

Mining is interesting and is often a good strat to escape and direct hordes but special veins feel a little too cumbersome to mine, especially when upgrades are more useful for damage vs minig speed. Hopefully in updates they decrease the total hits needed to mine them because it becomes impossible to get precious minerals at later stages when you're being swarmed constantly and enemies hit even harder

A common complaint I've seen is that the game is too hard - the people saying this are either unfamilar with the genre or haven't put a bare minimum amount of time into the game (or both). You need to unlock upgrades by completing milestones over the course of multiple runs to be able to take on further stages, and thus by design will 'fail' your first couple dives before you have the equipment necessary to take on huge hordes and lots of elites. It only takes around half an hour to unlock adequate equipment to complete the first difficulty tier. Unlocking something or multiple somethings in a run is a win in and of itself. This is on par with other survivor games that I have played like Vampire Survivors or Boneraiser Minions.

Pros: 
- [b]Unique biome features[/b] you can take advantage of to quell the swarm of glyphids, such as exploding plants in Magma Core, and regrowing brush in Hollow Bough.
- [b]Altering navigatable paths[/b] and choke points by mining.
- [b]Risk versus reward[/b] for attaining materials for meta upgrades during a run. It feels great to get away with training a horde around to finally mine some Croppa. 
- [b]Large arsenal[/b] of weapons. 
- [b]Price[/b]. Game is cheap! 
- [b]Satisfying to make bugs go splat[/b], especially with the beefed up upgrades after you unlock a lot of things.

Cons: 
- [b]Limited upgrade variety[/b]. Different status effects are cool but a lot of the overclocks are just dps increases. Would be nice to see the unique overclocks from the original Deep Rock Galactic in the future.
- [b]Class identity[/b]. Currently only the Driller has a unique traversal tool in his first subclass, being able to mine faster with his drills. It would be great if other class had traversal tools. Maybe allow the Scout to grapple over chasms, Engineer to platform hazardous ground, and Gunner to set up ziplines for faster traversal. 
- [b]Run length[/b]. A won run only lasts 15 minutes or so, which often makes it so you only get to experience a full build for the last couple minutes. I would love to see an option to loop after completing a run to continue playing - with more dense hordes and way more elite enemies to continue the challenge.
- [b]Limited content[/b]. While the arsenal is huge, the environments and objectives you can use them in/against are not, at a total of 3 unique biomes and 6 objectives (including side objectives).

The vast majority of the negative reviews for this game boil down to "game is too hard".  But that is exactly why this is the best vampiresurvivoslike so far.  The vast majority of the other titles boil down to find the OP combo and then roflstomp the map with it.  

This game has way more nuanced balance than that and will keep you on your toes the whole time.  Even if you do get really lucky on powerups you still have to play well to win.  Also, all these games have a metaprogression "grind" to them but it feels way less grindy when you are constantly trying to overcome the next challenge (hazard level).  This game does this beautifully well as it will take you quite a while to work through the 5 hazard levels in the 3 different biomes.  

So in summary if you want a casual game where you just walk around the map clicking and can win easily then you won't like this game.  But if you actually want a game where you have to concentrate, make correct decisions, and maneuver your character well to win then you will enjoy this game so much more than its predecessors.

The first hour is awful. You will feel like it's unfair, too hard, unbalanced. You will struggle to make it past Floor 2 out of 5 on the easiest level and won't have any other classes, guns, biomes available to even try. The meta-progression upgrades will feel too small to make a difference. I was there. After 1-2 hours, I was watching my time and considering a refund.

Then it clicks. Then you're getting to Floor 4 instead, or making it to the Dreadnaught on Floor 5 and working out how to dodge his lunge attacks. You're getting overclocks on guns. You're getting new artifacts for Supply Pods. You're getting access to other classes. Then you get your first Dreadnaught kill. And it's all coming together and you understand now. 

Now you're hooked. One more run. One more Goal to achieve. One more upgrade tier to unlock. One new gun to get to 12 for overclocks. One new artifact to try out. All of a sudden, it works. And you're glad you pushed through the first couple hours.

I've played all the classic survivors: Vampire Survivors, Brotato, Halls of Torment, 20 Minutes Till Dawn, etc.

This is one of the first survivor games where I get bored after 1 run and need to stop:
- The weapons and upgrades are very bland (damage up, fire rate up, reload speed up, etc)
- The artifacts (items you get) also are very boring and meaningless
- The upgrades you buy between runs are so expensive and scale so poorly

However, the WORST offender to me is, before you unlock special upgrades for weapons (which makes them usable, not strong, USABLE), you have to upgrade them to level 12 in a single run. Basically, this means your weapons are useless the first run(s) with them and its such a counterintuitive mechanic because you HAVE to upgrade them, but doing so gimp your progress for the current run. Whoever thought this was a good idea, eat shit.

Overall, this game runs well and is pretty. But as a survivor experience, the devs have no idea what makes a great bullet heaven experience, a great bullet heaven experience..
I love the game, but I won't recommend something made by developers who cave at the SLIGHTEST chance that someone is offended by something and start to remove content like iconic voice lines.
This is a 10$ game. For 10$ is this a good game? Hell yes!

Before reading just know I whole heartedly recommend this game. It's an extremely good game, especially for early access... but is it perfect, no, it definitely needs improvement. For how small the price is, it's definitely worth it.

Levelling is slow, gameplay is repetitive and stages consist of 4 areas which is basically easy, medium, hard and hard with a boss at the end.

This is early access so it would be nice to see a few changes, for example magnets have a very low drop rate. It'd be good to see luck also affect drop rates (with more drop items added ofcourse)... although on another note high% luck doesn't exactly give you good loot either, majority of the time you get common when levelling up.

Stage timing is basically locked at the rounds, the boss always stays with the hordes you need to kill to level up. It's easy to complete a dive with level 50 or below characters if you just focus on a single gun. If you focus on multiple, you'll simply end up dying on the second area. It's almost a mix of too hard if you want to have fun versus extremely easy to ace the game if you play it the boring meta way.

Endless rounds? - Could be a cool implementation idea, would definitely solve the lacklustre base gameplay, however, with the options for guns, enemies etc after 30 minutes you'd get bored as there's no challenge. 

Challenges - Currently 3 challeneges per map plus the random collect 20 x, 12 x, 6 x... same things same amount blah blah blah, It;d be nice to have extra challenges maybe a challenge menu (could be implemented into the milestones?) daily, weekly, monthly challenges. DRG is a mining game, community mining challenges, mine 1mil morkanite?

Skins -Yes yes, I know, fuck skins, but they add personalisation like when you got to change the colour of your neons in NFS back in the day. Anyway, the gold supported skin is activated via Settings > 3rd tick box. However, it would be nice to see an actual skin customisation menu. Don't forget this doesn't have to be as in depth as something like fortnite, apex or character customisation in games like black desert etc. It'd just be nice to change the look of your character (a bit like DRG) and also how enemies look since each stage and area has the same enemies. Would also be cool to see some bullet animation, electric colours?

Minerals - Gold extremely common, nitre not so common, pearls etc rare.

Market - Could be cool to see this change on a day by day basis instead of it being a flat rate of 400 buy 200 sell

Achievements - Again, it'd be nice to see the steam achievements line up with the milestones in game, there are many more milestones in comparison. Also a tracking feature?

Maps - I really hope they release more than 3 maps for this game. Understand there's more than one hazard level but I think everyone would love more than 3.
