Game Rating: PG (Mild Violence)

GENRE: Action, Early Access

RELEASE DATE: 14 Feb, 2024

I watched Asmongold playing this game and, although I was not a fan of Vampire:Survivor whenever I'd seen it played, and so I avoided it, there was something "spectacular" about the gameplay I was watching.

I felt I "had to" buy it. I hoped I was not making a mistake. For the current price, I cannot imagine anyone at least "trying" this title. The value is definitely there.

So far, I have no complaints. DRG: Survivor feels like that perfect "power fantasy" type of experience one may look for in reading manga/watching anime like One Punch Man and My Hero Academia, or playing games like God of War and Warframe.

Every time I'm in the midst of a run, and I unlock some uber (Legendary) upgrade, or deal an unsightly amount of damage, decimating thousands of "bugs" (they're also referred to as aliens) in this heist-like mine adventure where I try to get in, genocide, and get out, as efficiently as possible - at every level, I can't help but feel the game has especially capitalized upon one virtue of action entertainment: "Spectacle."

I love some of the deeper levels of customization that are available.

Choosing between elemental and kinetic damage, between status and crit, between specializing in a damage-type, or specializing in weapon-types (all of which synergize with different characters/classes), I feel as though there's always a reason to choose a particular class and go for a specific build.

Currently, I do not feel compelled to "get that same build I did before" with a particular class, which is excellent, as that sort of compulsion where there seems to be "no better/as effective/nowhere near comparable" build for a character bogs down gameplay and lends toward the feelings of monotomy that have me unceremoniously abandoning roguelite/roguelike games like this, or in other genres/genre blends.

I am definitely curious to see how they deepen the gameplay, seeing whether the stats, guns, and upgrades can get zanier, more creative, become more impactful/aweinspiring, and have higher ceilings that aren't merely "higher" but have a sense of weight to them that makes purchasing more powerful choices meaningful, rather than the trite and foregone circumstance of "I'm choosing this more powerful buff because the game is more difficult now and I'm facing more powerful foes."

In other words, that sense of "earning" the spectacle, the progression, and the loot is a fine line, and it breaks whenever every choice/a substantial set of choices becomes generic, weightless, and/or hopelessly routine.

Where I am in progression, I currently feel a bit "stuck" and am resorting to replaying older levels to grind for resources so I can advance in my overworld progression tiers and, hopefully, become powerful enough to take on some of the ever more challenging "Hazards" (higher difficulty runs) of which there are 5 tiers of Hazard per Biome (there are three biomes currently).

The grind aspects of games are the parts that have always typically made me a "one and done" type of player in MMOs/MMORPGs as the monotony weighs heavy on me before long.

The "nuance" of such experiences dries up and the "game" starts to feel like a payless job. That sort of effect is something that gatekeeps such games into becoming the prime choice for only the hardiest, most hardcore fans who relish the gameplay loop's grind plateau.

I personally cannot find my way into that mindset. If I can recommend anything, the developers of DRG: Survivor may want to consider implementing systems to rid the onset of "grind" that many games engender to keep up the fun for players who are not party to that toll.

One such recommendation I can suggest is using the resource system as a means of modifying certain options in-game. For instance, some of the resources that go toward overworld progression can be used to reroll certain options with effects that spending gold does not provide. This would be essential, especially when overworld progression is either maxed out, or is in a period of stagnation where upgrades are getting expensive. One thing I criticize with certain games is how particular resources one routinely grinds for become obsolete, or altogether useless, due to progression (becoming too powerful), migration (resources are no longer viable in a new region), or longevity of the game (newer resources are more favored than the older sets/varieties). DRG: Survivor can keep the soul of its progression alive by gradually shifting "why" one is grinding for the resources, as opposed to funneling them all into one system that will eventually cap out.

Unfortunately, I can see the end of the game coming up, somewhat. Once every weapon/mod/artifact is unlocked, and every biome is complete, I don't see a reason to come back to this as the gameplay loop has this one game mode it currently features in, and nothing besides that. At the very least, a "survival" mode would be nice, to see how long one can survive and overcome waves of "bugs".

I see other players are hungry for a co-op mode. I don't know if that was present in the prior rendition of this game, but I can see that happening if the levels expands, with a gameplay shift in a mode that resembles more of either a survival game, or a team vs. team vs. team dynamic, where cooperation becomes key.

Destiny released a mode where it's P vs. P vs. E (player versus player versus environment), where players' teams compete through their successes against the environment. That sort of mode could be excellent with this gameplay.

Anyway, I ultimately love this game and am looking forward to seeing how this shapes up through its early access offering. Much love, and luck, to the developers. You have a special game here and I am thrilled to have bought it.

So, take this as an objective review from a guy who loves bullet-hell.

First of all, the game is really really fun. Even in its current state, you can spend many hours having fun and trying out new things. Even though it is in early access, I do believe it has good content to keep you busy for a good while. I liked how they added new things/mechanics to the genre which is always a plus and on top of all of this, the game's graphics are sweet.

Secondly, if you take a look at all the negative reviews, they are either bad players crying about something so that it gets removed OR they say the game lacks content and variety etc. Guys, it is an early access game that just literally got released. And has any of you seen the roadmap- like hello? It is a good thing to point out the missing elements, suggesting improvements etc. but giving a thumbs down? C'mon..

[spoiler] ALSO, the avg playtime of negative reviews is around 5 hr. There are only a handful of them being 20+ or 30+ at the time of writing this review [/spoiler]

Thirdly, the content. As you can tell from the About section, there are 4 dwarves, each dwarf has classes and starting weapons. You combine 3 more weapons from the choices you are given into a 4-weapon kit. You kill monsters, you level up, you pick upgrades for your character and for the weapons. The weapons get powerful upgrades once you reach certain checkpoints called overclocks. Pretty standard, solid bullet-hell foundation. You also get side quests to pick up flowers and stuff, which reward you with exp and gold. Additionally, you can dig resources off the map by just simply walking and/or while running away from monsters, which adds a good layer of depth to the gameplay.

Now, here are my humble suggestions:

[list]
    [*]More bosses
    [*]More artifacts
    [*]More overclocks
    [*]More dwarves
    [*]More classes
    [*]More biomes
    [*]...
[/list]

Wait, they have all that in the roadmap- How 'bout dat.

On a srs note: it would be really nice to have things like Banish and Lock for the level-up upgrades to simply remove them from the pool or lock one in to pick up for the next level up.

Keep up the great work guys, looking forward to the updates! 
[spoiler] Especially to the BOSCO 2.0 update becuz idrk what that robot dude's doin'  [/spoiler]

Edit1: Seeing stats for the artifacts at the end of the round be great too. Just as we see the dmg dealt by each weapon, people might want to see how much healing/exp/resources they got from each artifact

Long time fan of Deep Rock Galactic and have been eagerly awaiting this after immensely enjoying the demo.

Survivor is rough around the edges and has some growing pains to get through but overall shows a lot of promise. Designed with a faster pace in mind and keeping the pressure on so you have minimal time to think and react to incoming threats Survivor feels different from the obvious inspiration that is Vampire Survivors. Stages are tight and advance quickly as you kill more and more glyphids The longer you take to complete the objective for that stage the more difficult the glyphids get to kill.

Adapting elements from Galactic feels like a natural fit so far though options do feel a bit on the limited side. Overclocks, secondary objectives, various weapons, and minerals make a return filling out various roles you'd expect for each. There's even a few new types of weapons here which I hope give some inspiration for Galactic. I particularly enjoy going full construct with the Engineer freeing me up to focus on mining and resource gathering.

Enemy variety and stage objectives are the same across all three available maps and those don't offer too much variety from one to the next minus map specific features which don't do a whole lot to change up gameplay. Hopefully future updates will add more spic to this and help give each map a more unique identity along with enemies to change up tactics and stage hazards.

Upgrades can feel a bit bland at times too mostly relying on improving reload time, damage output, and rate of fire with a few dwarf specific upgrades tossed in like movement speed, mining rate, armor, and health. Overclocks do a great job at changing up how weapons play and tactics employed with them. One such example is turrets can be mobile, explode when expired, or you can get an additional charge to place down more turrets. Really hoping we see overclocks play a bigger role. 

Overall it's a fun experience for the price being asked. Gameplay definitely feels more focused on pick up and play for shorter sessions than other auto shooters but I appreciate the more fast paced nature of this. Unlike other games I always feel that sense of pressure and needing to plan ahead so I know where to go and how to deal with the endless swarms thirst for dwarf blood.

I'm hoping that because this is early access, my feedback will reach but I never really know if it ever does. Despite being mostly negative, I still am enjoying the game. It's a Good autoshooter survivorlike and for ten dollars of recognizing it's partially early access support, it's not a bad deal. In this review I'm being extremely critical because I'm a big fan of the genre, and I'm simply disappointed that it doesn't feel like much of a unique take on the genre is coming from Funday. If you're looking to get into the genre, I would start with other games first unless you're a big fan of DRG already.

+ Visuals are nice and clean, animations are satisfying and I'm impressed at how much can be rendered at 165fps consistently without issue. 

+ Guns are *generally* fun and game play as a whole scratches that itch that's supposed to be scratched in this genre.

+ I actually like that the stages are on the shorter side; it would make sense for duration to scale with higher hazards but I think it's a unique take to have this level-based system and I like that you're discouraged from infinitely kiting excessively kiting as a whole. 

+ Emphasis on really enjoying the level-system. I love playing certain floors in different ways and having to weight pros and cons to resources I choose to collect, when I'm collecting them vs fighting, etc.. I think that alone is what kept me playing.

> I see multiple comments about its difficulty, but I've dumped a lot of hours into the genre so I'm not encountering that as much. I will say, when I'm not playing a class with armor I feel like the damage of hits is a little wild.

> This is extremely true to the DRG universe, HOWEVER a part of me feels disappointment from that, too. It's hard to call it reused assets, but on the same token I wish something new was being imagined. Extension of the universe rather than reiterating what we already know. I may feel differently if I was already more in-love with the DRG universe as is, so it's definitely subjective, but I think it could have been more creative and it seems a little late to change this :(

- Progression at large is somewhat miserable. My biggest complaint, is that in order to fully "realize" a weapon, you need to upgrade it to level 12 in a single run to unlock its overclocks. When you successfully do that in the run, nothing happens- you don't even get to choose a single overclock. You just have this basic weapon with a bunch of bland stat upgrades that usually falls off in end-game, because you're not getting any of those powerful overclock effects. This creates a cycle early on quickly where it feels like you're often signing a run off to its death to attempt to stretch your luck and unlock overclocks for two weapons to actually enjoy those weapons in future runs and the game as a whole. If you're not doing that and taking a run seriously, you're constantly feeling conflicted between pursuing a stronger build and growing a weapon you have overclocks unlocked for and progressing to unlocking a gun's overclock's. If you're lucky, you're strong enough to do both and hail-mary spare gold for once your primary weapon is level 18.

On the topic of progression at large, mining unique materials is also not exciting or interesting. The material requirements are only existent on two upgrades, and the requirements jump so high you're certainly not upgrading your stats in meaningful ways. You usually do whatever's available, you can't focus stats that you find valuable or synergize with weapons you like or tend to use without being drastically inefficient. There's nothing else to spend it on; no way to improve or augment bosco, the way you interact with drop pods and supply pods, brewery, etc.

- Progression within a run is also not that interesting, everything is just reload speed/fire rate/damage, and guns aren't designed in a way to uniquely take advantage of these stats for the most part. You're usually just taking the highest rarity, and you're sometimes left with no agency on actually becoming powerful i.e being constantly offered reload speed for a weapon with already low reload speed, regardless of rarity. There's seldom upgrades for things that increase things like clip size, bullet quantity bullet spread, ability to pierce, bullet size, their reach, etc... Everything unique is restricted to overclocking, which as mentioned, is a pain to progress. And even so, a lot of overclocks are just extreme shifts in the aforementioned stats, nothing that remarkably changes gameplay or makes a weapon unique.

- There's not a lot of satisfaction in weapons and it's difficult to discern their individual impacts, all kinetic guns are gold bullets or silver pellets, so if you get any that overlap their individual impacts quickly get lost. This can also be a problem with the fire weapons, although I'd general say the status effect applying weapons are ALL more exciting to use simply because their visual impact is far more robust.

- Enemies are all mostly the same, you don't play around almost any of them in a unique or different way. The loop of using supply pods and detonators to take out swarms or elites got old incredibly fast, and that's all there is to do. They don't have targeters on explosions or the dreadnought's attacks, so it can feel a little difficult to understand when you're reliably hit or not hit.

Review in progress: After maybe 4-5 hours in the demo and as a fan of the genre I was super excited for this.  Playing early access, I loved the first hour, then it tapered off quite a bit- the first bit suffers a bit until you unlock overclocking and move past the first biome's initial 5 levels.

Once you've done that, it picks back up again, but I do think some - particularly more casual players - may disengage at that point.

I think for new players it could use a little more early-game introduction.  Compared to other games in the genre the exploding mobs aren't quite as obvious at first, and the distinction between red sugar and nitra (or really any other ores) could be more apparent.

That boss (and also the exploding mobs) I think also point to something that's fairly common that isn't present here, which is ground indicators. One can argue whether that's good or bad, but it certainly raises the difficulty somewhat comparatively. Even stopping to lure the Dreadnought into jumps, I'm struggling a little bit to guess its timing and precise destination; moreso when I do have to stay on the move due to swarms.

I also agree with some of the other comments that at least the gunner and the scout maybe aren't -quite- different enough as the first two classes you unpack. Conversely the engineer does change things up a bit, partly because you want to lean into using your turrets effectively. I've unlocked the fourth but haven't played it.


Pros:
-Some people noted it as a con, but I think the game's strength IS that it's constantly forcing you to decide whether to focus on fighting, mining, escaping, scouting, collecting. You kind of need all of those, and there are consequences to picking right or wrong, and you will inevitably die (probably many times) trying to get in just one more tap on a node.  If you don't enjoy constantly pivoting between those, and staying on your toes doing it, you probably won't like this game. It's just too fundamental to what it's trying to do imo.
-All in all - with some caveats - I think the general approach to the map is a good feature for the genre, and particularly the destructibility changing your options but I think there's still room to polish.

Cons:
-Gameplay loop is super shiny at first, but does start to wear thin a little bit until it picks back up again when you start getting more unlocks.
-If current tuning stays as is, I think they'll lose a lot of casual and even above-average players after the novelty wears off.
-Overclocking could unlock sooner
-Once in a while the map design is just kinda dumb. You won't constantly find yourself stranded on a peninsula during a swarm surge (or worse, swarm + dreadnought) but if you play long enough it's going to happen eventually. 
-Early game weapon options could be wider, and there's really not great weapon synergy compared to a number of other games in the genre.  I can live with it, but it's not a selling point.

On that point I think they either need to smooth out some of the oddities, or perhaps add some landmarks for wayfinding.  I generally navigate space IRL and in games very well, but I do find the samey RNG and color palette of the maps a bit too numbing.

Overall (at 6-7 hours) for a grade at this point I'd say 7.5/10, and imo worth the price. I think my favorite moment so far was picking a cosmetic weapon upgrade and the scout saying "I love wasting my money on cosmetics!"  Perhaps coincidence but it felt like a not-so-subtle jab at some other games.
Really fun roguelite and beautiful graphics. I really enjoy the terrain mechanic in this genre

feedback:
[list]
[*]much, much larger maps to better utilize the unique mining mechanic 
[*]co op
[*]classes with a stronger identity that provide perks that upgrades can't easily replace, preferably with level scaling
[*]unlock conditions being more clear for additional classes
[*]reworked and balanced weapons, including overclocks and evolutions. some weapons sluggishly target monsters
[*]many more stages, and additional modifiers to challenge said stages (endless mode, boss rush, etc)
[*]way more bosses that preferably don't rely on a non-illuminated charge ability
[*]a more robust, deeper upgrade tree that affects the player dramatically more without requiring a huge grind for each milestone
[*]stronger, more immediately impactful builds. players are too weak for this subgenre of game. should you ever piece together a powerful build, there's little to no time left to enjoy it.
[/list]

I am very pleased to see the progress made since the initial release of the demo. The new biomes create nice variety both in visuals and gameplay, and having all four classes available provides a lot more game to sink your teeth into.

What's going particularly well?
- good visuals, nice to look at
- gameplay feels good, the difficulty is well-tuned. swarms can be overwhelming, but become manageable as you find tricks and strategies to manage them.
- the weapons are well-implemented, both those from DRG and the new ones created just for this game. They are interesting and reasonably distinct from one another, despite there being quite a few.


What would I like to see change?
- I think the artifact system could use some more attention. Many of the boosts they provide are not particularly interesting, just increasing a stat conditionally or providing a small reward for some game action (finding extra gold while mining, for instance). It's not bad to have simple buffs available, but it feels like there's an opportunity here to make the gameplay deeper. The artifacts that give you buffs for standing still are an example of something a little more interesting, since they encouraged me to change the way I was playing. More stuff like that would be nice.

- I would also like to see some more variety among the weapon overclocks. Despite there being so many weapons in total, you have access to a limited pool depending on the class you're playing. The upgrades you get each level only increase your stats, so your four weapons and their OC's are the only strongly significant decisions you make in each run. It's not so bad that every run of a particular class feels totally the same, but there's not as much variety as I would like. Some of the OC's do cool things, but many times you get one that's just more damage and reload speed or something, which isn't really any different than the basic upgrades you're getting every level.

- The structure/pacing of missions could be more flexible. Currently the cadence of action from one run to the next is always very similar. It's an autoshooter, so you can't ever stop killing bugs. And since killing bugs is what advances the mission, no matter what you're doing you're making progress. And the end of a level is a hard limit, since the pod comes automatically and if you miss it it's game over. This means that each mission is always just about as long as the last one, finished at about the same character level. It would be nice if there was more variety to the pacing, and more variety to the objectives each level too. Maybe some of the machine events from DRG could inspire additional objectives and challenges to encounter. Maybe we could trigger the pod manually, rather than being forced to move on to the next level immediately.


Overall, the game is fun and polished enough to feel worth the price, despite not being done yet. It looks and feels great to play, and my biggest complaint is just that there's not more of it. All the game needs is some more variety and build depth/options. If Funday continues to add content of a similar quality to what's here already, then this already very good game will become incredible.

So yeah, still can't reccomend this game, I hope there was something between yes and no because its not a bad game, the annoyances just make it so I don't feel I can reccomend it.

Consider this a "maybe."
There's a lot of cool ideas here but the problem is the core loop doesn't lend itself to interesting builds. 
The mining is a great mechanic and I enjoy the level based structure. I also enjoy how there's a massive variety of weapons and they all have augments when upgraded.
The issue is that none of the upgrades really lean into any specific type of build outside of maybe damage types, and even then it's minor. In other Survivors games you can make fun builds around say landing crits and the upgrades would empower that build (health on crit, crits explode, etc. etc.). This lends itself to experimentation and lets you try to min/max a specific playstyle.
DRG:S's upgrades are almost entirely just raising stats a small percentage without any real synergy. It's dull and doesn't feel rewarding. 
I do think they could fix this. The core is great, it's mostly just the upgrades that suck. By tweaking this system I think this could be a fairly unique survivors clone with it's other mechanics. Sadly, as is the game gets boring pretty quick and upgrades are extremely grindy. 
So yeah, maybe after a few updates it'll be ready to rock and stone, but for now I don't think it's worth the asking price when stuff like Halls of Torment exist.

I'm going to give this a positive review on launch in Early Access, based on the presentation and the fact that the core game is fun enough to take interest. That said, you should know what to expect from the game and the genre that it emulates, and depending on your expectations, you should maybe wait until it comes along a little further. For $10 ($9 at launch), it's not bad. However, it is clearly not a "finished game", it's not buggy (for me at least no crashes), there's probably about 20-40 hours of grindy gameplay to unlock everything there is to see, but all of the areas for improvement means you'll probably want to be willing to reset your progress to fully enjoy the final retail version of the game.
The visuals are good, very faithful to the designs of the original DRG game, sound design is decent, many familiar voice call-outs and new lines using the same voice actors, same or similar pulsing soundtrack as swarms come in.
Many of the weapons feel underwhelming at first but upgrading and learning how to use them effectively is part of it, the other part is that some of them do just kinda suck.
This game does not have multiplayer, is not a twin-stick shooter, and would probably be better if it did have both, but it does not advertise itself as such. It is a spin-off in a currently fashionable vein of the "Survivor" auto-shooter, which are all mindless timesinks with periodic dopamine hits for unlocking something or other each run, so you should go in expecting that, for now.
In summary, looks nice, plays fine, currently low on content and shallow meta, but fun as long as you are unlocking stuff. It does have the bare essence of DRG, hopefully it can be shaped into something that sets it apart from the generic autoshooter.

One of the blandest, most boring VS games I've ever played. The maps are tiny, filled with crap. They fill the screen with exploding mobs. The power ups are absolute trash. Have these devs ever played a survivor game? Nothing is powerful. You run like a fool around kting super-sponge mobs around and get cornered continuously. You can't kill anything because every power up is garbage. Where are the cool weapons? 
A pistol or a rifle? What? Where are the flame throwers, AoE? Anything at all that is actually interesting? Why does the smallest trash mob take 4-5 shots to kill when it should be one? You do not get powerful in the game, not in the first 5 hours at least and that's all I can stomach.

The grind is ridiculous too. You finally unlock a new character and ...he is basically the same but walks slower and has better armor. Boring. Boring. Boring. A 'legendary' power up is 50% reload time? lol.

Speaking of which, a bullet hell where you are running away all the time and waiting for your weapons to reload. What? In a bullet hell, my idiot dwarf is standing there doing literally nothing as a horde comes in to kill him. Fire your gun FFS! Oops, gotta spend what, 15 levels putting points into nothing but reload speed until you fire more than once in a while. Slow, sluggish. Boring.

30 seconds to escape! Dumbest idea ever. I just killed a boss, loot explodes, but if I stay to clear trash and get it i die(?) /facepalm. Question for the devs: why can't I just go to the pod when ready? Why are you constantly harassing and shoving me to the next thing? Just let players play for goodness sake, get off my back with the endless hoards and timers and 'mobs get stronger' for some reason.

I thought with some unlocks the game would improve but it's just boring to play. I have felt not once a  moment of excitement with my 4+ hours trying. Most boring survivor power ups I ever saw. 

The whole 'take damage because your pixel touched theirs' thing is really old now too. New games do it much better. Look at Soul Survivors for example. The mobs actually have to attack and hit you to score damage, you can dodge at last second, it adds a feeling of skill and responsiveness. This is just lazy, touch mobs get hurt crap. 

No dodge, no sprint, no jump, no jet pack, no mobility whatsoever just adds to the sluggish, slow ultimately boring survivor game on the market. Looks pretty though.

This is a neat spin-off of Deep Rock Galactic. It's a game about danger, darkness, and Dwarves where you control a Dwarven survivor that has various mining objectives. There are swarms of giant alien insects that impede your mining prospects at every turn. Thankfully, the mining company you work for provides you the right tools to help you get the job done. Like other survivor genre games, difficulty increases with each passing second. You'll need to upgrade your Dwarf just to make it back alive to the space rig, where you spend the precious minerals you collect in your runs on everything a growing Dwarf needs. Something special about DRG: Survivor compared to other games in the genre is that your survivor can tear up the level terrain and carve out strategic pathways through the levels to get as many minerals as you like. Just try not to get too greedy, or you'll join your fallen coworkers in short order.

Easily the best auto shooter in the vampire survivor's genre. And it's only in early access at the time of this review. Amazing. If you like the genre, you will love this take on it. Well done to the devs for making a spinoff that is actually incredible. Rock and stone!!

I'm a big fan of Vampire Survivors style games, and this one checks pretty much all the boxes. However, this is not the type of VS-like where at a point in time you feel like an indestructible god. It is always challenging, even after you have all four of your weapon slots filled. This is not necessarily a bad thing, however, as it has been able to hold my attention for multiple playthroughs with much more ease than other games of its ilk.

In addition, there are multiple unlocks to pursue, aside from new classes and new weapons, you also have to level up each weapon to 12 in order to unlock the "Overclocks" which are basically modifications for each weapon that makes them more powerful, more interesting, or more useful, depending on the overclock.

If you like Vampire Survivors and similar games, then you should definitely give DRG: Survivor a shot.

Another addicting survivor game but this time we can rock and stone.

It's vampire survivors with DRG branding slapped on top and some minor terrain deformation.

The problem is I already have VS, I've had it for a couple years now and DRGS offers very, very, little to an already stale formula. Yes there is mining, being able to tunnel through rock and mine minerals is a nice side objective in addition to the usual kiting activities. But it's not enough.

This bullet heaven or whatever the genre is called nowadays has plenty of games in it and they have all iterated upon VS in some way. Be it including strafing or full on manual shooting and reloading. DRGS has only brought with it the ability to hump the walls to get some extra resources. Yes you can tunnel past a horde in the short term but the "islands" of rock you chew through are never really big enough for this to be a significant strategy. Guns feel bland and ineffective for the genre they are in too, with many having incredibly cumbersome firing patterns and long reloads that feel punishing when you have no control over them. Upgrades likewise feel boring, outside of overclocks all you are getting is simple % stat changes. 15% damage, 10% reload. You don't ever feel strong, merely that you are at best keeping pace. In fact a lot of the overclocks themselves are also just basic modifiers but bigger, very few actually change how you might play the game, a stark contrast from DRG where even balanced overclocks can significantly shake up a weapon.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the fact this game actually has some challenge and I wish we could get swarms as big and omnipresent in DRG itself.

Which really is the crux of what I don't like about this game, it doesn't feel like a DRG spinoff. It feels too much like an inferior version of VS with a superficial gimmick tacked on. 
You aren't getting lost in caves, because they are always just small rectangles with a few small islands of digable rock or small impassable pits dotted about. 
You aren't doing various mining and industry tasks, all you have is clearing waves until a boss spawns then killing it so you can move to the next rectangular arena. The best you get is mining some morkite occasionally.
You aren't using creative weapons to kill bugs and in fact have no direct control over them at all.

The game feels agonisingly passive in how you play it. You kite bugs, hump walls and choose between 3 basic % buffs to one of your guns every few seconds. I hope eventually they do actually try to make this game be a little more interactive and a lot more like it's big brother as a true spinoff rather than a clone of an already existing game. But I had these same complaints back when the demo came out and practically nothing has changed between that and early access. 

Just buy vampire survivors instead, it's cheaper and has more content.

Still needs plenty of work and polish. All great fun up until haz 3-4. Then your success 100% depends on having good rng throughout the entire run, get a good weapon and get upgrades for said weapon. The entire screen just becomes an undodgeable clusterfuck at that point too, most of the trash is slow to kill, almost every wave is a swarm, you got shooters as trash, you got spines in the ground everywhere and those big static ground worms shooting even more shit.
Leveling up is boring since there's pretty much 0 chance you get anything interesting, many of the overclock mods are really boring plain stats that are the same as getting 2 rare level up perks. Progressing feels like a boring chore with a ~5% success rate.

Fairly well polished for a early access game, recommend to wishlist at the very minimum

So first off It's a bit of a unique hybrid mix between survivors and roguelike but a bigger emphasis on roguelike over the typical survivors, keep that in mind everyone before jumping in thinking its as easy as vampire survivors, its definitely not as you reach haz 4/5

Pros
Meta progression upgrades, even the aesthetics are awesome, definitely looks and feels like DRG with the maps, weapons and voiceovers you'll find a sense of comfort and familiarity from DRG itself.

Cons

Mid
-Hazard difficulty spike from 3 into 4-5 is insane, could need an adjustment
-Weapons - some shine on its own, some are outright garbage unlike DRG where all are viable, and some need overclocks to shine. Examples - certain fixed directional weapons

Major
-Very Roguelike, unlucky spawns or lack of proper artifacts for some challenges ex. mining x amount of gold/nitra make it difficult/impossible to complete - good fix would be set amount of spawns until challenge is complete, bigger map or infinite scroll map(bigger map would fit DRG theme over inf scroll).
-Overclock - locking its fine for progression, but having it locked until you complete it then only getting access to it the next run is a buzzkill.

Minor
-Hazard difficulty spikes feel off 1-3 are fine but the jump to 4-5 feels like an absolute struggle.
-Lack of variety for overclocks, would love to see clean, more balanced and more unstable.
-Upgrades during run progression - lack oof/feel redundant especially when you start maxing out meta progress and the lack of a banish option, reroll is fine but it still triggering if you have bad RNG somehow get similar options within multiple rerolls
-Map spawn variety - Hollow Bough horrible offender, feels like only 3 variants spawn and they are all obnoxiously difficult 
Crystalline Caverns and Magma Core are excellent and balanced in comparison.
edit
-Boss - almost forgot just nitpicking, only 1 dreadnought type so far, and it only leaps, would like to see more variants and move sets.

"Bugs"

-No crashing yet, but chain reaction explosions and sudden spawn of exp and despawn of corpses trigger micro lag/stuttering/freezing which is terrifying for the run. Surprisingly no desync run ending-deaths.
-Some throwable grenades get stuck over unmined terrain and effectively do zero damage even bugs are in splash radius.
-Drop pod ramp can bug out and prevent access - triggering a game over as it leaves without you. (I've experienced both ways, one via diagonal orientation prevented me moving onto the ramp at the tip of edge, and the other being the ramp didn't pull me in like it does on some runs, and yes the green arrows disappeared meaning you are in range when far enough on ramp.)

Probably a few more i forgot note down, but honestly nothing too notable.

Overall though, while its still early access and needs a bit more polishing and tweaking i "dig" it
needs more time cooking as all early access do, but its been enjoyable so far, looking forward to future updates especially overclocks and map variety from DRG universe.

Misc
-Would love a roadmap to see what's being worked on next
-Optional Co-op - I wouldn't mind this but the game is perfectly fine on singleplayer as well.

will probably update as early access progresses

Great game.

The thing I love about these games is the moment you find an overpowered build or weapon combo and for one run you feel invincible, but I've not been able to find anything in Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor that is really comparable to the experiences I've found in other games. 

I have to say the art and audio are top tier for this genre. When measured against Vampire Survivors or really any other similar game, this one stands out. Nothing looks cheap and everything fits into the Deep Rock Galactic world. 

My main issue is progression. You level up during your run and choose upgrades as you go. After your run you bring gems and credits back to exchange for permanent upgrades. After 12 hours I've gotten absolutely sick of seeing the same upgrades for fire rate, mining speed, reload... It's the same handful of minor stat upgrades for every weapon and none of them feel significant. The majority of the weapon evolutions are also simply stat boosts for fire rate, damage, reload, or an option to change damage type. There are a few interesting ones but they are a rarity. There is no unlock I'm dying to get, there is no upgrade that feels like it's worthwhile to work towards. 

Lastly, the most heinous thing this game does is forget that this genre is about the 1 in 20 runs where the stars align and you get the perfect drops for an unstoppable build. That's the whole point. After this long with the game I still feel like I'm just barely getting out alive on almost every run. Maybe that's a part of the original game they felt it was important to include here, but where are the weapon combos? Where are the upgrades that are so amazing you suddenly ditch your whole strategy to focus on optimizing a new exciting item?

I feel like I got my money's worth from a $10 game but the pace of progression and bland, underpowered experience make this game a real slog. You can find a little bit of fun here, but I was honestly surprised how quickly this one soured for me.

I have to mirror the other negative reviews here, it has the potential to be fun, but the feeling of being constantly underpowered feels a bit like a slog. Additionally to that mining minerals feels far too slow unless your dumping everything on mining speed, which makes you even More underpowered for the next stage. The End boss fight is sadly kinda underwhelming, spamming the same attack that two hits you basically always.

Lots of room to improve, and I am hoping I can change this into a positive review upon release.

Pros: 
- The game is well priced, definitely feels like I got my money's worth. 
- Love the artstyle 
- Sound design is really good , so many of the weapons/enemies sound distinct which helps sort through the chaos. 
- Early on, progression is very fast and feels rewarding to play. 

Cons:
- Higher hazard levels are not balanced very well, hazard 3+ becomes a total slog to get through. The enemies are so strong and numerous that it feels almost luck-based. 
- Class/weapon balance needs tweaking. Driller feels almost pointless sometimes and gunner feels incredibly strong. Some weapons are must-picks (warthog, minigun) where others are must avoids (thunderbird drones, leadbursters).  
- Later on, progression is very slow and feels repetitive. 

Overall , the game is really fun for the first few hours and definitely worth a try. But it needs serious work for long-term enjoyment.

The game felt a bit slow in the beginning compared to Vampire Survivors. But after playing it for a bit longer, I am just as hooked as with Vampires. The focus is just a bit different. It is less of a reverse bullet hell as with vampires, but more about making decisions and strategic play when considering to focus mining over killing or vice versa and when deciding on weapon builds.

The game can certainly use some more work when it comes to content diversity, but in an excellent state for a just started early access and less than 10€. And knowing how the devs treat Deep Rock Galctic, I am fairly optimistic, that this game will receive a lot of more love. Main things that I hope for are more content and more diversity in enemies/levels and possibly a couch coop mode like with vampire survivors at some point. I think some of the weapon upgrades could also use a bit more tweaking too. And the bosses certainly need more diverstiy. They are currently a one-trick-pony.

I read some reviews about people saying that the upgrades don't have enough impact. And in the first few hours, I felt the same. But once you unlock overclocks and put three of those in a weapon, this can drastically change. I ran around with a sniper boosted to insane crit damage levels and overclocks that basically made it a one-shot-all-shotgun. I killed the final boss in just a few seconds on Haz3. The weapon changed so much due to the overclocks.

I also love how the weapons and classes can have very strong upgrade synergies. I played a gunner variant that shoots additional bullets every 100 shots and skilled everything on attack speed and crit chance and damage. I also only selected weapons with lots of bullets per second. It absolutely shredded through hordes of enemies. 

Overall, the game starts out a bit slow at first (also because overclocks have to be unloced per weapon first). But once a few hours in, I cannot stop playing and want to try another build idea. It is in an excellent state for an early access game and costs not much more than my daily lunch. If the devs treat this game with as much love as the regular DRG, this game can become an excellent one when it has its full release one day.

This is an excellent translation of Deep Rock Galactic in early access form.

Clearly the game needs more levels, more bosses and boss mechanics, more enemy types, weapons etc.

Takes about 5h to unlock all the characters and complete each of the levels, probably 10h - 20h to fully complete the content available on all difficulties, though its a little light on content and game mechanics its going to get repetitive and a bit boring at around the 10h mark.

Ghost Ship has done a great job constantly adding content to Deep Rock over time, so I would expect this will be a proper Early Access title with proper developer support moving into release 1.0, especially as this game essentially cross promotes Deep Rock core game quite effectively.

The core mechanics are fun, the visual style, audio, controls and performance are all excellent, just a little light on content, which feels like a true representation of an Early Access title vs feeling like you are Beta testing a buggy mess.

So why 90% and not 100%?
This game screams for multiplayer PVE. I get that it isn't the first choice given how the game is currently balanced but Deep Rock has never been a solo experience! It would take a bunch of changes and time, which may not be in the cards for this game, but if it ever does get added then this moves into a firm #1 in the genre.

I did enjoy DRG Survivor demo, so I'm not 100% sure what's happened. But over time the main game has just got more and more frustrating to play. I think the problem is twofold to me:

Pacing - DRG Survivor felt a bit slower paced? you had the ability to somewhat control your run as by the end you could delay and spend some time levelling up, as long as you could manage to keep an ever strengthening horde at bay that is, but it was up to you. I get the feeling each round might be shorter than it was in the demo now too? Could just be me.

Class balance - Driller mains feel incredibly weak, while in theory it should scale to amazing by the way you can keep adding more beams, they do almost no damage to start with, so it goes from terrible to almost passable - never to the level of pure destruction you can get out of a gunner or scout with the only a little luck in your OCs. Amazing OC luck with Driller gets you to ... roughly passable.

Anyway yes I kind of like the game but it is so frustrating at the moment to play.

[hr][/hr]
[b]Basic Gameplay Loop[/b]
Basic loop is select your character, pick one of its load-out sets, choose a map, select the difficulty (hazard level) and load into the run.

A run is 5 maps. 5th map will have a boss. Maps are not big and are half filled with rocks/ore that cannot be traversed until mined. Being next to something that needs mined will automatically start mining it. There are ~7 ores that are used as currency for in-run (temporary) and out-of-run (permanent) upgrades.

Your weapons fire automatically when enemies are within range and line-of-sight. Killing enemies (and other actions, based on upgrades) drops XP orbs and you pick them up to collect it. When you level up, you get 3 upgrade options you can choose from for free. These are generally damage, reload speed, or fire rate for one weapon or a weapon type (e.g. all, projectile, cold). At certain levels you also unlock one of 2 RNG new weapons - at 25 you get your 4th and final weapon.

After each map, you go to the store, which is just several upgrade options that you use one of two currencies to buy as many as you want or can afford. All upgrade screens can be re-rolled using a currency.

As is standard with the genre, new items are unlocked by completing "Milestones". Milestones in this game generally involve hitting a player/class/weapon level or by collecting  a given amount of an ore.

[b]Review[/b]
This is an uninspired, genre-chasing, RNG-heavy, waste of time, cash grab.

Lots of balancing issues - clear winners and losers. There was obviously no baseline that the devs calculated out and aimed for. Since they can't even bother to simulate their own game, it is no surprise that the RNG systems are not handled well, either. Doesn't really feel fun from the start. Constantly oppressive. This is not a sit back and chill game until you are well into the mid-game. Seems to be one of those "it gets fun after 20 hours" games, unfortunately.

Maps are way too small. The "5 map with boss on 5th" pattern was boring by the 3rd run. Too easy to get cornered, especially during a "randomly" occurring swarm. Suicide-bomber enemies suck in all games, but worse here due to their excessive speed of exploding, with a barely perceptible shaking beforehand, and no apparent distance-based damage falloff. Oh, and they often come in packs so a single pack can 1-shot you.

RNG BS restricting progression is not content. RNG is not gameplay. They need to do a much better job. They need to steal more from other good games. "Winning" feels like random chance, instead of skill and strategy. Permanent upgrades you get outside of a run are more important for completing a run than skill. Everything must be in perfect balance or the run is not fun. There is no reason to have MMO-style rarity for upgrades.

Map/hazard unlock objectives are not presented in a logical order for normal completion. Upgrades and unlocks need re-balanced across the board. Map objectives are boring, don't add any real variety to the core loop, feel like they force you to rush through maps, and just don't add anything relevant or fun. Artifacts are worth more used as Rods from God than as exciting upgrades. Reload speed is too powerful, meaning the base reload speeds are oppressively slow.

Too much of the map area is blocked off and requires mining to clear - this is a majorly significant difficulty spike from similar games, where most of the play area is open space. Mining doesn't feel anywhere near rewarding enough given the time and risk (and upgrades) it takes. Base mining speed is oppressive and doesn't feel good until upgraded to +50%. Map/objective timers are oppressive. Enemy spawn points and rates are oppressive.

Weapons are boring, unimaginative, and rarely help provide agency to the player. Virtually all upgrades are simple stat changes. Having multiple rarities for each stat upgrade adds more useless RNG into the mix. It's pointless and does nothing to add to the fun. Many of the "overclocks" (after hitting certain upgrade levels, you get super upgrades) have negative attributes tied to them, which is not fun.

Runs feel too fast. A baseline of 25+ levels is not enough for the amount of trash RNG you can run into. XP orbs are significantly more difficult to retrieve than in most games in the genre. The combination of movement speed, timers, and oppressive enemies will force you to leave a significant amount of XP on the floor when you leave the map.

Games are supposed to be fun, but I've written "oppressive" way too many times for that to have any application to this game.

If you enjoy games such as Vampire Survivors or Soulstone Survivors, then you will be right at home with this title. If you are tired of these types of games, this will get you excited again. Let me explain. 

The game does not have tutorials or directions - yes, you have to figure things out just like in Deep Rock. However, there are three main mechanics to be aware of:

1. Mining - You have to run and collect minerals like gold to meet not only the level missions, but you need that gold to pay for permanent upgrades you apply after each run completes. 

2. Firepower - The second mechanic, one more common to other games in the genre but not the same as Deep Rock is doing - you have to modify your loadout each time you level up. You also will do this between missions in your run. Once you finish the map's objectives, the resources you collected fund your hunger for weapons or other mechanic upgrades. 

3. Mission Objectives - These will be things like "collect 20 bits of gold" or "upgrade X gun to Y level" and once you finish, you unlock something new that will show up in your games. There are a ton of things you can unlock. Even being in EA - I feel in my time with the game I barely unlocked anything. 

Perfect Steam Deck game - and this will be an obsession for years to come. This is a game that is played over a long time as the upgrades do not come cheap or easy to obtain. You have to work at it, but the game is a lot of fun, so you will love to put in the time. 

If you are on the fence but the game and play one round. If you hate it, return it. You will have to stick with things just like in Deep Rock - that game also requires you to play over a long time and slowly opens up with more and more options, guns, and skills, and this game does the same.
The funnest top-down type of whatever-you-want-call-these-types-of-games I've ever played, and in the theme of DRG to boot. It's incredibly inexpensive as well at $11-- less than the cost of lunch.

After playing vampire survivors:

-You are always just surviving, never really feels like you are able to stand and fight anything.

-The limited map size is not conducive to the survivor type game IMO.

-The upgrades/weapons feel weak, no real huge power spikes other than penetrating bullets.

-The dreadnought is way too strong in this current iteration, honestly just not fun at all when I know I'm coming up to it.

-Vampire survivors has a much more chill feeling, and constantly has you looking for the next upgrade, this just feels stressful for wimpy rewards in comparison.

-The pace is all over the place, nothing happens in the first 30 seconds. As soon as one swarm spawns you've got too many things going on and not enough time to actually get to where you want to be and you end up leaving way too much when you have 30 seconds to get to the drop-pod.

That being said this is still early access, I love the devs so they get my $10 either way, and DRG is the perfect setting for a survivor type game.


At the moment I wouldn't recommend it. We'll see how the final product looks.

I've enjoyed many hours in Deep Rock Galactic, and while the theme/franchise is strong in this game (albeit mainly to reuse of concepts/assets), it doesn't perform well enough for a positive review at the moment.

As many other reviews point out, this game suffers from highly questionable decisions such as disabling overclocks (the thing that makes weapons fun and unique) until you've leveled a weapon to 12. Some weapons/upgrades feel downright poor compared to most other options, and it can be tough to "pick yourself out of" bad rng.

It's a shame since the experience itself has potential. Perhaps check in on this one after it's been through a few iterations in EA.

1. Kill count enemy wave progression is a mistake. You end up making games shorter by investing in metaprogression and at the same time you earn less metaprogression currency because you don't have enough time to run around and mine minerals. Trying to NOT KILL enemies in order to buy yourself enough time to mine kills the fun of the game.
2.  Difficulty scaling is just stupid. Hazard 1 without metaprogression is way harder than Hazard 5 with metaprogression.
3. While general game flow feels fine you don't get enough time to feel yourself powerful by the end of the run but at the same time you don't feel pressured to keep doing pretty much anything.
4. Nitra and gold offering the same upgrades as level ups is just not satisfying.

[i] Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor [/i] is a fun, fast paced, and kind of brainless game that's easy to pick up and play if you've got some time to kill. Being an early access title, however, the game definitely feels lacking in some aspects: in particular, the game currently only has one boss that becomes quite boring once you learn its attacks. That said, there's clearly a lot of potential here, and I'm confident the rough patches this game has will get some polish in the future. In the meantime, [i] Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor [/i] still has a lot to enjoy. Rock and Stone!

The game is fun for the first few hours. but quickly burns out due to lack of content and weapon synergies. There clear takes and passes in terms of both weapons and artifacts. The meta progression is as you'd expect but a slog to get through and feels more like content padding rather than an exciting mechanic that makes you powerful the more you invest into it.

The weaponry feels very underwhelming and with a lack of banning, builds are left completely to RNG whether you get something that will help take you to the end or not. Classes take eons to level through and provide access to only new weapons, no other bonuses that would make dedicating time into them more engaging/exciting. 

All in all this could be a great game if the devs take time to properly balance both progression and weapon stats.

Hopefully it gets patched soon and I would change the recommendation.

It definitely needs more boss variety, co-op, and changes to the classes to make them fit niches. I also feel like even haz 1 is way overtuned, given that the game can go up to haz 5. If you don't pick specific weapon combos and get a set of upgrades, you're probably going to fail at the boss.

The pacing was much better in the demo, this needs work. Weapons are not synergistic and class bonuses are either marginally useful or terrible. Being unable to aim guns other than have them shoot the way you're moving sucks, especially for Lead Storm, making them effectively useless vs Dreads. Enemies spawn too quickly in final stage, giving literally no paths, forcing you to focus on mining speeds to clear a way, but wasting mods on mining means less damage and bugs never stop spawning. A vicious cycle that desperately needs tweaking. This is from Haz 3 playing pretty optimized builds, I'm guessing it only gets worse at higher difficulties.

I can see the potential, but a few things could be bettered. There is no way to see the full extent of your minimap, i.e. like Diablo. I find the grinding fun, but I also think the ore chunks (jadiz, bismor etc.) take slightly too long to mine through. Plus I think the stat upgrades don't feel like they do much. The upgrade isn't quite worth what you're spending on it. 

But other than that, I suppose it's not too bad. Rock and Stone, brothers

As a fan of both DRG and Vampire Survivors, I think this game shows potential, but is not worth it in its current state. Variety is at a bare minimum, upgrades are very basic and offer much to be desired, and its lacking what makes Vampire Suvivors such a great type of game..... the GOD LIKE feeling you can achieve if you make the right build. Almost 10 hours, and probably 50+ runs and there is never a time where you feel like your hitting the sweet spot, where its challenging but your doing awesome. Your always on the run, always 1 bad mining spot away from death. Some enemies are just meaty and take soooooo much time to kill. And the maps in this game have edges, or ends. So in a pinch you cant keep running away, you will hit a dead end. 

And the sidequests it gives you are occasionally borderline impossible. It will give you a side quest like "Gather Morkite" it will only place 2 or 3 morkite veins on the map, meaning unless you are JUST looking for morkite, its impossible to gather enough before the mission ends. Many times i've burned my way through 1/2 of the map, dont have enough of the side quest item, and am now faced with this decision. I can either:
1. Run back where i've killed waves and waves of enemies to gather exp that they have dropped, so I can level up, the only possible way i'll survive future waves. 
Or
2. Explore the other half of the map, finding the side quest items, but abandoning all the exp the enemies have dropped.

TL;DR: If you like VS/VS-like games and you like DRG, you should not hesitate to get this game. If you like VS, but you have not played DRG, you will probably still like this game, but while staying true to the DRG source material, this game has a few differences. Differences that I feel make it better than just a DRG skin over the exact same VS game play.

I read through a bunch of reviews before I purchased this game. After spending some time with this game, I think the negative reviews I saw were from people that are not familiar with DRG.

- The mining mechanic here is great and can be used to your advantage to funnel your enemies and make strategic decisions about how to exit an area.
- Yes, the enemies are a little spongy, especially early on, but it makes the mechanic above all the more useful
- Look, this isn't VS. Just like in DRG, the goal is to complete your mission and GTFO. The longer you stay, the harder it gets, especially after your tunnels are gone from explosions, etc. The tunneling aspect is a big reason why you WANT to change the floor. If you consider all the floors in their entirety, then a run is just as long as VS, if not longer. The people complaining about short levels have not done a completed run. You go through multiple floors and then fight the boss. I guarantee that anyone complaining about level length have not spent much time with the game.
- The miner quips are great, especially if you like DRG. You can turn them off if you want. 

They made a great bullet hell game and remained true to all the DRG elements. It really is a fantastic game and it sells for less than $10.

I WANT to love this game, but it wont let me.
It looks and sounds great, handles nicely.
Game loop is short, which I like but with almost no meaningful progression.
Most weapons feel about as effective as throwing gravel, barring a few that feel actively unpleasant to use. Some of this may get sorted since damage feels profoundly lopsided in the bugs direction.
Right now just feels like grinding up levels to unlock weapons that aren't fun.
And I know games use more complicated calculations in the background to get to actual bonuses but whats on the card to whats actually applied feel particularly egregious.
All that being said it's got a lot of promise and I'm hopeful some bugs get worked out I'm going to keep checking on this to see how its coming along.

what I don't like:
- the meta progression is kinda meh. You don't really get interesting upgrades. Just a very slow 1% bonus per upgrade for a long grind

I was really looking forward to this one but can't recommended it in its current state. 

- The classes have very minor differences. 
- There are no builds (you can change a weapon's damage type; it does almost nothing). Every else is %attribute goes up.
- There is a weapon overclock system like in DRG but the effects are boring (just number changes) and you need to essentially waste a run to unlock the overclock system on a weapon by weapon basis. 
- The difficulty is weird for a survivor type game. You are swarmed by enemies that spawn relentlessly but are given no effective tools to deal with them (see also: no builds). You are encouraged to run and mine paths through the walls to stay ahead of them (which is cool and unique in this genre) but the maps are tiny and eventually you have nowhere to run, enemies are all around you and you don't have the means to make a path (because there is no aiming your weapons so you are at the mercy of the rng. Also, again, no builds).
- It's neither a relaxing 'low effort, number go up' nor a 'super skill based, agonize over every choice' type of game. Maybe it changes after 20 more hours of unlocking minor 2% buffs to movement or whatever, but i don't really care to find out.
- The final boss is agressively dull. It has one (1) attack pattern, deals entirely too much damage and it doesn't interact with you or your character in any significant way. Are you scout or driller? Doesn't matter it's the same fight either way. See also: no builds.
- The DRG setting feels like a coat of paint. 

In short, this is a VERY early access game. Keep that in mind before you buy it.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivors is the brand-new installment in the DRG series. It takes inspiration from Vampire Survivors and adds its own DRG twist on it- with overclocks, an addictive gameplay loop, the eye candy that is the art style, and the unique builds, you will play for hours because of reasons both good and bad. 
I will be very lenient with my opinions since this game released a couple days ago, AND is in Early Access.

This game... This game is pretty fun. It doesn't hold a candle to its parent game at the time of writing this, but it is a very good time nonetheless. It has a lot of the traits that the original game did. Charm? Check. Addictive gameplay? Check. (more on the gameplay later.) A good art style? Check! I love how the game looks, and the cute twists and alternate designs on the monsters are executed well. It almost makes you forget that you bash lead into their skulls in the original game.

So how is the gameplay? If you've played Vampire Survivors before, you know how this goes. Dwarf shoots at buggy, buggy die, die give you blue thing, get enough of blue thing and you level up, allowing you to upgrade yourself or get new weapons for your character. The loop consists of:
-start
-kill buggy, as mentioned above
-kill enough buggy and you get swarm
-after swarm, you get beacon which you need to clear a specific area for it to land. I don't have a negative or positive opinion about this part.
-more buggy killing
-big boss
-kill big boss
-oh noes, you have 30 seconds to return to the drop pod!
-get in
-go deeper into the mines of Hoxxes
After each return, you can spend the Nitra and Gold that you have found on your way to get even more upgrades. This is a nice alternative for the late-game where leveling up is hard.
There are also artifacts, which are like the items from Risk of Rain and the sequel and the Risk of Rain remaster, if you have played any of those games. They provide a specific benefit.
Remember how, at the very start of the review, I mentioned overclocks? You can get them when you have a specific amount of upgrades for one weapon. Overclocks are for that one weapon respectively, and are specially designed for that one weapon to improve your loadout. There's also the hazard system, but I don't think I need to go into too much detail about that. It just adds a risk-reward system, just like in DRG.

However, behind all of this lies some bad things about the game. First of all, the unbalanced overclock level could have been lessened by 2-3 levels. After a while, getting levels becomes tough, just like Vampire Survivors; the game DRG: Survivor was inspired by. And there's no problem with this, but I feel like those extra 2-3 levels feel like padding. There are also no cosmetics, something that I ABSOLUTELY ADORED in the original game. Now, it just feels like I'm playing as the same guy as everybody else instead of getting my own drip. (dlc cosmetics are cool though) Also? No beer. Tsk tsk. I don't know how it can fit into the game, but add it. PLEASE. Also, we need more original voicelines. This is an issue I also had when I played through the playtest.
In conclusion, game has flaws but is a fun time.

Definitely not recommending this game as of this date the game is horribly unbalanced at hazard 4 above unless God gives you the ultimate RNG and get your weapons overclocked early on the stage. You will enjoy most of ur time playing this game at low hazards.

-Hazard 4 above-
-Mobs are way too tanky for no reason and you don't even get the payoff because most of the time the EXP you get at killing those tanky mobs are little to none and sometimes you can't even get the EXP shards coz you're either low health fighting the consecutive swarms while getting to the drop pod. by the end you're gonna get triggered as to the amount of EXP shards you left on the stage.
-Mining is way too slow and is a pain on high hazard stages because you're either too busy fighting consecutive swarms or getting the EXP shards of said swarm which can take the whole duration of the stage because again they are too tanky for no reason especially on the earlier stages of the map where you have no upgrades and overclocks to your weapons.
-Drop pods need to be longer or let players make the choice as to when to move on to the next stage. Really infuriating as to how many resources you can miss whether EXP Shards or rocks.
-Needs a lot more movement artifacts/items, characters are too slow imo (except the scout ofc)
-Some weapons are utter dogshit like those cryo drones and electro, the only good drone is the viper because they actually follow the enemy, seems like an odd choice in design the 2 former drones you need to manually place your character to make them hit the enemy but even if they hit for like a poot of damage.
-Leveling takes way too much time.
-The main upgrades that they give you are small at max levels. idk why they are too stingy with the numbers to the buffs they give (16% mining speed and 24 exp% at max level) like bro thats nothing.
Overall, I can recommend this game if you only play at low hazards. Lot of potential once they fixed the balance at hazard 4  above, only viable way to clear is with scouts with cryo zhukovs (which you need to pray to RNG gods to get those overclocks). The way it is now the only consistent character for high hazards are scouts other you need a lot more resources and good rolls to be even viable at that stage of the game.

I'm only on Hazard level 3 and already feeling like I don't want to progress anymore because it feels meaningless and tedious. Most upgrades are +% damage, +% fire rate, +% reload time reduction etc. (BORING!)

Then you get the cooler things like the overclocks which actually change damage types (No in game description of what damage types actually do though, whats the difference between fire and acid dots? Not a clue!) and a few of them add/change functionality of a weapon (FUN!).

At the moment there seem to be 3 maps that have the same end boss, same enemy types and only differ visually except for the first map having some breakable crystals, the second map having a bit of lava on the ground that hurts you if you walk on it and the third map having annoying vines blocking your path.

Meta progression also seems meh, mining is kinda fun and gives you something to hunt for on the maps, but spending a couple of runs worth of minerals on "+1% crit chance" doesn't feel very fun either.

My tip is to hold off on this game for 6 months or so and see if they've turned it around, because right now there are both better and cheaper alternatives out there.
Awesome little game. very addicting. Don't notice any flaws. pretty polished. Some weapons are much weaker than others.

A bit too difficult, but it's fun. Hazard 1 (easiest difficulty) feels like I can never outscale the enemy.

The stages could last twice as long too. Drop pod should be a minute. What this feels like is Hyper mode from Vampire Survivors.
I want to take it easy and obliterate my enemy when I choose hazard 1. I tried hazard 2 and it feels the same as hazard 1. There should be a clear difference.

Also unlocking weapons and then having to unlock overclocks is so bad I'm probably not going to play until that is addressed AKA the system removed. I don't want to waste 20 minutes forcing myself to get a weapon to overclock level or praying to RNGesus that I can do at least one weapon in a run. The issue more or less is Legendary +50% DMG to all weapons or common 10% fire rate to shotgun that doesn't even work with fire rate, you have to take the fire rate...
Rather than forcing to grind for overclocks, why didn't you do the same treatment as secondary objectives that you unlock them for all weapons/classes? Hell, make hazard 1 easier and if the player reaches the final stage, unlock them for that class. Make the overclocks themselves a drop like in DRG and make them absolutely nuts. There is no reason to keep things balanced, let people absolutely destroy hazard 6 with cheese if they want to. Just like in vampire survivors.


Other than that, the game is incredibly fun and has potential, The classes and weapons are distinct and fun to play.

Deep Rock Galactic Survivor is a spin-off of the original co-op game Deep Rock Galactic. It's an auto-shooter like Vampire Survivors or Brotato, but with its own unique elements. Thanks to the abilities of the dwarves, you can collect materials and tunnel through rocks to escape from hordes of enemies. The game is highly addictive and allows you to unlock upgrades to reach further each time. It has been released as early access and will continue to evolve in the coming months. Many hours of fun for less than 10€.
So far it's great! It keeps the DRG spirit but we really need Multiplayer on this! It will send this game into the stratosphere!

Like getting the choice between a legendary and 2 uncommons. Feels pointless. Sad, that most choices are like this. 

The Character customization also feels pointless. You have to unlock everything step by step, cant really play your favorite build or character because of the damn mission objectives. 

the upgrades for character stats are also pointless, because the most efficient strategy is to spread your ressources evenly, so you get the most stats. Since you are able to unlock every upgrade, no choice matters for the gameplay; everyone ends up with the same stats, there is no "playstyle". 
I hope they add more real choices into the game and get rid of forced "play this" "play that". Especially in a game that is supposed to revolve around strategic choice.
Also. Having players choose between reload speed, damage and fire rate ALL THE TIME is not interesting either. there is always a mathematically superior choice and i wont sit here with my calculator to optimize my damage.

Game is still early access, so i hope they improve it. As it is you can get 12h out of it until it gets boring; already worth the price though

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a roguelite game that puts you in the boots of a space dwarf who works for a mining company. You have to explore alien caves, fight off hordes of bugs, and collect resources to upgrade your weapons and abilities. The game is a single-player, top-down version of the original Deep Rock Galactic, but it retains the charm, humor, and action of its predecessor.

I bought this game at 10% off on Steam, and I have played more than 6 hours so far. I have to say, this game is a blast. It has good learning curves, good graphics, good mechanics, and good weapons. The game is challenging but rewarding, and it never gets boring. There are four classes to choose from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. My favorite class is the Gunner, who can unleash a torrent of bullets from multiple guns. My favorite weapon is the Zhukov NUK17 level 18 overcloks, which has spiral ammo that can shred through enemies.

The game is still in Early Access, but it is already very polished and fun. The developers are constantly updating the game with new features, bug fixes, and improvements. The game also has a lot of references and nods to the original Deep Rock Galactic and its community, which makes it feel like a part of the same universe. The game also has a great soundtrack, voice acting, and sound effects that add to the immersion and atmosphere.

One of the best aspects of the game is the mining mechanic, which allows you to dig through the terrain and create your own paths and strategies. You can also collect different resources and power-ups that can help you survive and upgrade your gear. The game has different biomes that offer different challenges and environments. The Crystalline Caverns are the easiest biome, with no vegetation and useless crystals. The Magma Core is filled with molten lava and exploding plants. The Hollow Bough has vines that can block your way or regenerate over time. You can read more about the biomes in these articles: Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor Biomes Guide, Deep Rock Galactic Survivors Biomes - Full Beginners Guide.

The game also has a larva biome that is not yet available, but it looks very promising. It will feature a dark and slimy environment with larva sacs and acid pools. You can see a preview of the larva biome in this video: Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor Preview - Diving Into a New Genre.

The game has no bugs, everything is smooth. Well, except for the alien bugs, but I slayed them all with my awesome weapons. The game has a good balance between difficulty and fun, and it always keeps you on your toes. You have to be quick and smart to complete the objectives, kill the bosses, and reach the drop pod before it leaves you behind.

If you are a fan of Deep Rock Galactic, or if you like roguelite games in general, I highly recommend you to buy and play Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor. It is a game that will keep you entertained for hours, and make you feel like a badass space dwarf. Rock and stone, alone!

The game is really fun! It seamlessly translates DRG into a survivor-like experience. However, there are some key areas that require fixing:

1. Both Weapon Upgrades and Artifacts lack depth and effectiveness. they're just bland overall.

2. The four characters are a bit too similar, they are mainly differentiated by their weapons and a small buff. For instance, the miner has a 20% mining speed bonus, which seems very insufficient. Increasing it to 50% would justify the "Miner" title compared to other characters.

3. Visibility of projectiles isn't the best, especially in darker environments.

4. More bosses, biomes, and weapons are needed, the game currently feels somewhat limited (understandable considering its Early Access status).

5. The permanent upgrades system is too expensive. Adjusting the cost or adding a respec option would help a lot. currently it's definitely more grindy that it needs to be.

Despite these issues, I trust the developers to address them and refine the game into something great. They've already laid a strong foundation; now it's all about adding more content and lots of polishing.

Noticeably still in early access.
I have played DRG since it was in beta, and this game has a totally different feel: I constantly feel very weak.
All the upgrades you buy don't feel to have a significant impact on actually killing the damage spongey-enemies any faster. To me, your guns do not feel satisfying, because they have barely any impact. 
The only reliable way to deal with big groups of enemies is to lure the exploders into self-detonating. Or using the resupply pod to oneshot the boss. When something like this becomes a key strategy, that feels like imbalanced design.

At Haz1, it feels far too damage-spongey. Haz1, in DRG, is the difficulty level where you can fool around not being productive half the time and still be 100% sure you'll complete the mission.

I don't recommend this game in its current state as a polished product, but I will definitely be keeping an eye out until it improves. It has potential, but does not currently fulfil the fantasay autoshooters generally fulfil. 
I am aware it is early access. DRG in Beta was much better balanced than this though, even back when the gunner didn't have his shield yet.

Also, a nitpick: each of the songs used in DRG, actually have a signal function, they indicate a specific phase of the game. It throws me off how in DRG Survivor, the soundtrack of big waves, or for dreadnoughts, or the rush to the escape pod, are played interchangeably and without a reason.
