It's fun, and the mining mechanic is a nice twist to this type of games and it stays to the core DRG gameplay.
It's short and engaging but challenging.

You can, however, tell that it is an early access game. 
Below are some things that bug me/should be changed and I think everyone would benefit from these:

1. why is it that after you unlock overclocks in a run you can't use them in that run and need a new run to be able to add overclocks is beyond me...

2. the game offers little to no instruction on how any of the stats/resources/weapons work. As someone who played DRG I think I got things pretty quickly but I can imagine if you have no experience with any of those it can be quite daunting. Especially stats - since each game seems to have their own definition of how crit/status works and so on.

3. weapons that shoot ONLY in a specific direction are bad. They should be made to shoot where the cursor is and it should be a toggle in the menu if you want to auto shoot or click shoot. Because of this. some weapons are barely usable and some are so much better than others. This feels like the kind of thing that should not have been in the game at all...

BONUS:

4. Not adding multiplayer is a big miss given how awesome DRG is because of a multiplayer.

5. They should add an endless arena style run, or king of the hill style, where you can manipulate the map (through mining) to survive as long as you can.

5. More customisation... imagine if they let us use skin packs, at least for dwarves, that we bought in DRG.... It would promote cross play, feel that your investments are worth it, entice people to invest... easy win for everyone.
Very Fun, needs more bosses, but with this being in early access I'm confident the game will improve over time. Coop would be a cool addition as well.

This game has potential, however, it is just too grindy, to the point where it is almost annoying and a little too repetitive. It is hard to make any sort of progress since the levels are too short (especially the first stage) so you're going into the next stage under-powered, which makes it more difficult as it is. The upgrades don't really feel like they're worth it or like they make any sort of difference. Leveling up is slow. There is a lot more worth mentioning, but it is pretty much all explained in depth in everybody else's reviews. I do, however, find the game to be addicting despite the current state that it is in. And it is fun, but can turn into a frustrating experience an hour or so in.

I understand that this game is in early access, I just feel it is worth noting said things. I would recommend it to a DRG fan, who does not really mind the difficulty, progression, etc. however, if you are looking for something that is and feels more like Vampire Survivors, then this probably is not the game for you in the current state that it is in. I may continue playing it to see if it grows on me, but I may just refund it completely.

1. Bosses variation per biome.

What is required to unlock certain stuff?

Maybe engineers passive is faster reload for turrets. Scout has movement speed etc.

I just hope this continues to evolve.

If I had to describe this game in one word it would be potential. At it's current state this game has uninspired items and achievements, too much fast paced game play, and a boss that's too hard. I think it would be nice if there were achievements that encouraged you to look around and do side-objectives, maybe to unlock each character you need to find them on the first stage of each level and then do their quest like: needing to help Gunner kill a elite bug in the first zone, collecting 3 sentry spots for engineer in the lava area, and finding and giving driller an aquak. I'd like it if you needed to press or hold down a button to call in the drop pod instead of it just arriving instantly, or at least have a lot more time to go into the drop pod. I hate it when I have to drop everything and leave without completing the side objective or having to leave the minerals, I also don't like it when I have to charge through a hoard of bugs just to leave on time. With the bossfight I might sound like I'm just bad at the game but it would be nice if the boss accidentally trampled the other bugs so there's not just a giant swarm of bugs on top of a boss chasing me at once. The boss' jump attack isn't well telegraphed, maybe a red marker to indicate where the attack is going to land, I also hate how the attack is damage in a straight line and not an area around where the boss lands, it just feels like bull when the boss deals a third of your health or worse kills you because it flew over your head. That being said there are some things I like about this game, I like the diversity of the weapons and how they can impact how you play the game, I like being able to bait out explore explosions to make them clear out the other bugs, and I like how you need to do achievements to unlock stuff. There's a lot of room for improvement in this game and I really hope that the devs take my and the other player's feedback to help improve and grow upon this game's mechanics and gameplay

Take what works, don't shoe horn garbage in that doesn't. Don't re-pace the game. Don't re-scale the difficulty. Don't add irritation factors to slow things down.

Example: all powerups should feels *incredible* instead of *a compromise to nothing.* We shouldn't be building three different engines, we should be accentuating the fun factors. Most power ups are "make an irritating feature with bad base stats (movement, mining, damage, reloading, whatever) less intrusive." Yikes.

Great potential and a unique gameplay style compared to other "survivor" games but the balancing right now is completely screwed.

- Weapons basically have no AOE, clearing swarms feel tedious and unfun rather than giving you a sense of power. You are relying on the exploding monsters do deal majority of the damage rather than your own weapons.

- Upgrades feel generic and not impactful. Its just damage, reload speed, crit, firing rate. You are limited to 4 weapons and none of the upgrades are things that morphs your experience from game to game and make each run feel different. There is not much variety in weapon choice or upgrade choice.

- Pacing is too fast, you will often have swarms spawning within 30s of each other and just overwhelm you too soon into the run, made worse by having literally no AOE to clear them.

- Side objectives are too scattered / take too long, made worse with the too fast pacing. Good luck getting 20 Morkite if the 2 clusters that exist decide to spawn on separate corners of the map. You will sit there for 10s mining a single chunk of it while enemies swarm you. 

Right now rather than starting weak and growing to become OP, you start weak and stay weak. The most useful weapon to clear enemies is not your guns but the exploding monsters and the supply drop pod because your weapons have no AOE and no damage.

They need to add more sources of pierce / aoe into the game, stretch out each stage so you arent getting swarms and bosses back to back, increase the density of ores in the map.

If they made this a coop experience though, that would be VERY fun.

At this point I've played 8 or 9 "VS clones" or reverse bullet hell games.  This is one of the most unique and innovative of them.  Faster paced and more concentrated gameplay than many of the titles in this genre yet with lots of opportunities to level up and make your build.  Each run consists of 5 quick levels reminiscent of Deep Dives (with breaks in between to spend gold and nitra resources on run specific upgrades).

Visually, audibly and thematically this game absolutely captures a DRG run in VS style (albeit a solo run, complete with Bosco providing a bit of support).  The classes, resources, levels and even upgrade system will be familiar to DRG employees.  Most of the weapons will be too, and although some new weapons appear or operate in a different fashion than expected they nonetheless are very creative translations of DRG weapons into VS.

This is undeniably a good game with many innovative approaches to the genre, but it does still have some flaws that will need further work to make it great.  The game is grindy (all VS clones are), but particularly in the early game the grind is going to turn off some players who come from DRG but aren't that familiar with survivor style gameplay.  I'd definitely like to see faster early game progression as it takes quite a few runs with only one class, one map, and one difficulty unlocked before you start to get into the real flow of the game (it gets better after that though there will always be moments in this type of game where progression gets grindy again).  Hazard levels take forever to unlock and until you do you can easily get bored of playing the same three maps on hazard 1 over and over (even if more maps are coming I'd still like to see this scale better).

While the weapons are pretty well balanced atm (relatively speaking), there will always be disparities between weapons in this type of game but it's important none of them feel completely useless and I've yet to have a run that feels like I lost because I couldn't get a decent weapon (Poor build synergy will always be a thing though).  However the upgrades don't feel particularly well balanced.  More specifically the costs for the various upgrades need balancing, some stats scale well or are more valuable and should be more costly whereas others scale poorly, have low value but cost the same.

My last complaint for the moment and maybe my biggest one is how short the timer at the end of each level is to get to the droppod, you've only got 30 seconds.  Considering you're usually still fighting many bugs and have lots of XP gems and other resources you'd like to pick up it's really not enough time, I've failed many runs by watching the drop pod door close in my face and leave me behind.  I don't mind this as a mechanic over all but it should be more time on the clock to finish things up.

The game might need a slightly lower beginning difficulty, I'm experienced at these types of games but many that come from DRG to here won't be and may give up on the game fast with the current intro difficulty.

WHERE IS MULTIPLAYER

(Also where is my ability to use cosmetics that already exist for the dorfs)

Gripes aside, excellent game: it's a well polished vampire survivors-like made with the Deep Rock Galactic stuff, and it's lavishly attentive to details.

That special level between relaxing and tense that can make a game impossible to put down. Hectic, fast, explosive, but satisfying and playable in little bite sized bursts.

You'll see a lot of reviews comparing this to Vampire Survivor, and that's because it is absolutely that kind of game. The biggest difference is the terrain: clusters and walls of rock make the map more elaborate to navigate but what's really fun is that you can DIG through it. This adds a whole new dimension to a Vampire Survivor game. Your split moment decisions aren't just "do i dodge the enemies this way, or risk it to get that exp?" anymore, but now include "do I hole up in here and bunker, do I have time to dig an escape route through here, do I have time to mine this, do I want to leave this wall alone so it continues to block bugs until I use it as an escape route later?" Really makes it stand out.

The weapons are fantastic and each is unique in an impactful way that makes you adjust your playstyle. You have some that do singular damage, some that do AOE, some that target the closest, some the highest HP, and some only work in certain directions (Minigun is great when you need to get from point A to point B and all bugs in between must DIE, but the Subata is good for covering your back while you mine). The sentry guns are my fave (you can upgrade them with little tank treads!!). The basic upgrades are okay, but the Overclocks are where things get interesting (well, usually. Some of them are more of the same +damage or +reload speed, but I'm betting they're going to add more cool Overclocks later. Game is in early access, at time of writing)

It is grindy though. I've played 32 hours and still haven't unlocked all the weapons. I have mixed feelings about that.

But, I've sunk dozens of hours in because it really is that fun. And I can only picture the game getting better yet as they get feedback from the Early Access period. For a 10$ price tag, value has already been met. Recommended.

Certainly been seeing some people split on the current state of the game. Keep in mind that this game is currently being labeled as "Early Access" and things are likely going to change in the future.

I really am enjoying my time with this game. Each class has their own starting weapons and passives which do enhance the ways they have to play the game. Scouts are usually able to move super fast, gunners are tanky, engineers can play super passively, and drillers can make mining efficient. There is JUST enough to make each class stand out and each feel fun to play as.

Runs start off slow but they ESCALATE FAST. They consist of five stages; four normal stages and then one where you arrive at a boss level. The boss is extremely tanky, fast, and a challenge to see if your build is strong. It's a solid gameplay loop. Things can feel overwhelming, in a good way. It keeps you focused on the enemy types, your builds, how to plan a route, etc. It has been a very fun time.

HOWEVER...

There is certainly a bit of padding here that feels unnecessary.
I'm not a fan of how you must reach a certain level with a gun in a run before overclocks are available for it. 
Classes and their starting weapons? That makes sense. However, currently, you must get a weapon to a high enough level in one run, and then you can start overclocking in the NEXT one. 

There are also PERMANENT upgrades. Your first few runs will likely result in you dying on the first 1-3 stages due to not having upgrades. I'm not a fan of this system- at least not with how it is implemented currently. It feels like the only real difference between hazard levels is what levels you need to have purchased with the in-game resources you gathered.

It also feels impossible by design to win your first run, even if you are skilled enough for these two reasons alone.

For $10 I still think this is worth a buy, even moreso if they expand on this game. I've already got 10 hours in this game and that's a solid deal for a game that's in early access. Just... be prepared to die, a lot. 

Ghost Ship have done a wonderful job with Deep Rock Galactic and listening to the community for changes with their game while it was in development. I have confidence that they'll iron out the issues related to balancing and/or game play in due time.

It's very hard for me to give a negative review because I really do love what this game wants so badly to be, and I love DRG and the guys that made it, but in its current state, I simply can't recommend it (DISCLAIMER: Yes, I know it's in Early Access and is subject to change, this review reflects my thoughts of the game in its current state at launch.)

1. Stages are too short, and leveling is too slow.  
The enemies are already pretty bullet-spongy at the start, getting momentum in the beginning can be difficult.  Since leveling seems rather slow, it can be very hard to get your weapons powerful enough to feel like you're all that powerful against the bugs unless you get really lucky with some legendary upgrades.  Going for secondary objectives is basically necessary, since the gold and XP you get are essential to upgrading enough to survive, but when you're locked into the same spot on the map because you can't kill fast enough to move, and can't gain ground to collect XP, it becomes nearly impossible sometimes to complete secondaries when they're spread out so far.  Eventually you get your footing if you don't die first, but by that time, the boss is dead, you only have half the secondary objective items, and now you have 30 seconds to fight through a horde that is still probably stronger than you.
I'm not a game designer, so I don't know the nuances of creating game balance, but this can be fixed one of two ways in my opinion.  The first is to make levels longer or give the player the option to really extend the duration somehow, the first stage especially is over so quickly, you're forced to go into the second stage rather underpowered.  The second is to make XP gain faster, letting players become more powerful just a little quicker would be really nice, especially since you can carry 4 weapons, and each has 18 levels to essentially get to its full power, and in my time playing, I've barely been able to get above level 54.  If each overclock came at every 5 levels (5, 10, 15), it would feel a lot more balanced in my opinion.  In games like Vampire Survivors, maxing out your entire loadout IS an option, it takes time and planning, but you're rewarded with a very powerful character in the end.  In this game, you have to choose a single weapon to work on maxing out, as it simply isn't possible to max another when you're overclocking other weapons to make them competitive at all and picking general upgrades so you're more survivable.  I'm not asking that you go into the last stage completely overpowered, but I would like to see it more feasible to be at level 60 or so by the time you come into the final stage, that would give more flexibility in building both your guns and your character, along with the possibility of having 2 guns maxed out or very close to it.  If enemies need to be scaled up in the final stage to compensate, then so be it, but players want to feel powerful by the time they're in the endgame.  What is fun in a Rougelike is feeling very powerful in relation to an enemy who still feels like a threat, when every moment feels like a struggle against them, it's just not very fun.

2.  Meta progression and character leveling is a torturous slog of a grind right now.
Collecting XP, credits, and materials for meta progression is painfully slow, by the time you get to Hazard 3, you basically are soft-locked in progression because upgrading your base stats is extremely expensive in relation to how quickly you get the things to afford it, and when stats are being upgraded by 1-2% after 2 hours of gathering materials to buy the upgrade, it hardly feels satisfying or worth it.  Each class also upgrades very slowly, making new weapon unlocks take multiple full runs between them.  Unlocking overclocks on weapons doesn't feel like too much of an issue in its current state, but getting it to level 12 (and surviving long enough to do it) is kinda tedious.  Base weapons with no overclocks are pretty underwhelming.  Nerfing yourself and dedicating a run to using a weak gun to unlock the overclocks just isn't very fun IMO, but at least you only have to do it once as long as you balance the diminishing returns of leveling the locked gun with actually useful upgrades to your stats and other guns.

Please understand, I REALLY want to recommend this game, at its core, it's still very fun.  I'm being hard on it because I care, and I really want to see the devs turn it into something truly incredible.  Once they work out some of the kinks in the balance, I will be sure to update this to a glowing recommendation, they just gotta get there first.

I genuinely don't get what the negative reviews are saying, and it seems like the only positive reviews are just from people who like the game because it's DRG. So I would like to give some genuine praise to this game and refute some of the claims the negative reviews make.

1 "The game doesn't have much content": OF COURSE THE GAME DOESN'T HAVE MUCH CONTENT, IT JUST RELEASED INTO EARLY ACCESS.

2 I'm not going to value your opinions if you have only played the game for TWO HOURS

3 "The upgrades don't feel powerful": This is the statement I understand the least, have these people even unlocked overclocks? I agree that the normal upgrades feel a bit weak, but they're just meant to be stepping stones to the overclocks. 

4 "The gameplay doesn't feel satisfying": I find the gameplay very satisfying. the exploder chain reactions clearing entire swarms, one shotting elites with resupply pods, picking up a magnet and getting six levels at once, I find all of these some of the most satisfying things in any game I've ever played. 

 I think DRG Survivor is a very fun game that does have its flaws, but also has a lot of potential to become something great.

(if you did write a negative review I don't mean to offend you, I just disagree with your opinion)
 
Edit.  Hi everyone. I really didn't expect this to blow up. Thank you for everything, ROCK AND STONE! After reading the replies I feel the need to clarify one of the points I made. The statement I made about needing more than two hours to have an opinion was not my best: when I wrote that part I was angry that people were saying bad things about a game and franchise that I like. However, I still think there is some truth in that statement: two hours is more than enough for a first impression, and it's fine to write a review about a first impression, I just don't agree with people writing extensive reviews of the entire game based solely on other people's reviews and a first impression.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor tries to take on the infamous Vampire Survivors type of gameplay, and it's just OK. Yeah, yeah, Rock and Stone!

It's a shame, but I wouldn't recommend DRG: Survivor as of yet to anyone who isn't a fan of the main game.
I played Vampire Survivors, Brotato, Death Must Die, and Halls of Torment, and I'd recommend each of those games in a heartbeat. DRG: S is not there (yet). If you've played all of those games already and need a new fix, DRG: S could be for you for at least a couple of hours.

While it captures the look and feel of the original Deep Rock Galactic, Survivor lacks in variety, and every run feels more or less the same. In each stage, you'll mine for gold, nitra, and other resources, fighting off huge waves of bugs while waiting for a special Elite Bug to spawn. If you manage to kill it, it's off to the next stage. The classes offer little to no diversity besides the starting weapon and some minor bonuses which can be compensated for after one or two level-ups in a run, turning the class distinctions obsolete in the blink of an eye.

But I guess there is still room for improvement. Adding new types of enemies from the main game, for example. Also, the main menu could use an overhaul. I would like to see a bar, a dancefloor, stuff like that where I'd equip cosmetics I found in a run. Oh yeah, cosmetics! They aren't in this game. DRG has a ton of things you can find during a mission, so I'd say it's part of the charm. And this feature is missing in DRG: S.

Well, I hope things get better in the next couple of months. Do it!

It is a hordelike, just to set some gameplay expectations so, youll spend all your time moving around and consuming power-ups. That being said, I find the following gameplay mechanics amazing compared with other games of this kind:

- Having to choose between powerups(weapon upgrades X status upgrades) gave a good twist in the game since you cant spend too much of your upgrades in the status ones that will give you specific element damage, crit chance/damage, mining speed because youll be a jack of all trades but master of none. 
- The weapon specific updates are amazing, and combined with class-specific weapons make the gameplay a lot fun
- Having to choose between a weapon specific upgrade that is rare for example, and a status upgrade that is epic or legendary makes this game really fun
- Having to deal with mining, completing the level mission, dealing with mobs adds another layer of complexity on this type of game
- Having to also choose between mining ores that are used only on the current run(nitra and gold) or going straight for the ores that give you permanent stats updates is also a nice gameplay mechanic.

So far so good, no crashes or artifacts on this game. Will play more :)

It's a fun little game so far, but that's all it is. I'm not recommending it, even though I know the devs could turn this game into something great if they give it even a tenth of the love and dedication they have given DRG. I want to believe in the it, though, and I'll amend this review based on future updates.

Currently, DRG:S feels like a half-finished mobile or browser-based game. This is a game about mining ore and shooting bugs, and all you do is run into rocks to mine them while shooting at the same time without pressing any buttons. The gameplay is fairly bland.  Enemy AI is extremely basic, and this goes especially for the final boss of the dive. In order to beat the game you shouldn't necessarily level your weapons, but mainly your mining and movement speed, so you can kite the boss around forever. Everything else is secondary. Differences between various elite enemies are also minimal.

Another weird part for me is the loadout system. The fact that I still get Scout weapon upgrades when I'm on a Gunner run, for example, takes away some of the uniqueness the classes have in DRG. And even the class "bonuses" lose their edge after a few levels.

I will say that DRG:S looks nice and despite its flaws, it's a nice way to waste some time and decompress after a long day. 

TL;DR: As much as I love DRG, and as excited as I was for this game to come out, DRG:S feels more like a mobile game with the same assets and voice lines as the original. Your mileage may vary, buy at your own risk.

I really wish there was a middle ground between like and dislike. It has very good bones, very solid gameplay when you get into it. But I don't like it. Not yet, anyways.

 Many of the systems seem to throw you to and fro. Collect, but don't collect too much or the waves will get too strong because of a hidden timer. Call down a drop pod so you can get strong items, but if it lands on the elite you need to kill you've got 30 seconds to gtfo or you lose. 
So collect, but not too much. At the higher levels you are actively punished for having a strong build as the level elite will die fast and you cannot get as many resources, leading to a lack of upgrades, allowing the difficulty curve to overtake you.  (One could argue this is the design. One could also argue using a spiked bat for pleasure is a good time.) I don't feel like I am throwing hands with hordes. I feel like a phantom usher is shoving me from level to level and spitting on me when I try to deviate.
Some of the weapons need buffs, and bad. It isn't that you cant break away from the difficulty curve, its just some weapons you start with kneecap you before both they and the usher spit on you again. 
Last big erk, secondary objectives should give nitra too. Simple as. 
As soon as they fix the flow of this game it will be PRIME. I think increasing most of the "you lose, idiot" timers should help and a few buffs will do the body good. Keep an eye on it, and keep your mind open to it.

With around 8 hours in the game so far I can highly recommend this game. If you have played any other games in the survivor genre this will scratch that itch. 

Ive seen quite a few reviews saying the classes and weapons lack variety and depth but I disagree. Each class Has a different starter ability as well as a very unique set of weapons. I do agree the abilities to set each class apart are fairly bland and do not add much. In some cases you can just earn up to it within the run. For example the scout only starts with 10% extra movement speed and +20 health. 

You can easily earn this mid run. What sets each class apart are the weapon types. For example the driller has several different Flame and acid type weapons while the driller starts with Mini turrets that you will have to strategically place in the right place by standing where you would like. 

You can unlock and overclock for them later on to allow them to dynamically follow you around.   

As of now the game definitely does lack content as it only has 3 biomes and one game mode. It could use an endless mode as right when you start to feel strong you kill the boss and the run ends. I would also like more boss variety, Possibly making the boss random each time you reach the end of a run to create a sense of suspense. 

as well as different bosses the higher you reach in hazard level. 

On a final note it may just be a skill issue on my part but past hazard level 3 I find almost impossible and I think could use some tuning. Overall For $10 even if this game was never to receive an update again, id still recommend it.

A very good Vampire Survivors inspired roguelike with a lot of issues. The early grind both during missions and for total progression is a slog. 30 second escape timer is not enough time to finish up collecting XP and minerals. Some weapons and artifacts are useless and basically force you into a meta build if you want any hope of successfully finishing the mission. Forcing you to max a new weapon once to unlock overclocks for later builds also holes you into maxing a bad weapon for that run, so might as well restart once that weapon is maxed. Still a fun game with some interesting mechanics though.
Great time killer.

I'm both a DRG fanboy, and a VS fanboy, and sadly this game isn't approaching the goodness of either at this point.  Two classes are outright bad (looking at you, Driller and Engineer) with frustratingly little kill power, even deep into a run.  I've only had 1 or 2 builds that have ever really "popped" in any way, like in normal VS-style games, and even then there wasn't any real satisfaction when it happened.  I think most VS-like players would agree this is a pretty big issue that needs some attention.  VS and its ilk are so highly lauded because there's normally a"WHOA!" moment when you pick up a combo of abilities that synergize together and give you that feeling that you no longer fear the enemies, instead they're regretting the coding that forces them to approach YOU.  

To be quick-ish, It needs more variety in the level-up AND overarching perks you buy with minerals.  Some of the overclocks are interesting and insta-grabs, but most are meh.  I really like the weapon selection, but the class/loadout perks are pretty meager as well.  I would also like another mission type or two to bring it more inline with DRG and mix it up a little, though I like the biome variation and how the biomes beyond the first have their own environmental hazards.  

End of the day, this is an EA and needs some more work under the hood before I switch my review to positive.  However, I really hope it continues to develop and make the right moves, just like DRG did.  II look forward to the day I can switch up the direction of this thumb.

Amazing rogue-like with more [i]depth[/i] (bazinga) than you would think. The only two things that stop me from absolutely playing this non-stop are lack of multiplayer and variety of boss stages. The game [b]just[/b] came out, so I'm going to hold out hope that both of these are added in the future, but even as is, the graphics, gameplay loop, and mechanics are all extremely fun. It's worth trying out all the different classes and you'll find that the ones you might not enjoy at first, will feel much better later after you get some more upgrades and try them again. 

For me, the gunner felt a bit weak starting off compared to scout, but after upgrades and unlocking some overclocks (the bullet penetration on minigun....dayum), he just becomes a machine of death.

While building up your stuff though, I would recommend the engineer. The constructs put out great damage and status effects can help keep you safe in the early game.

The driller's base passive is really great for farming ore (go figure) and although the weapon he starts with is pretty crap, you can overclock it to give your other weapons a massive boost (I like a mix of constructs and projectiles for consistent damage).

I think the best part of this game is learning how to use the terrain to your advantage. The enemy AI will always try to go around if there isn't a direct way to you, so you can drill straight into a wall and leave a sliver left to the outside and setup a bottleneck, then if things get dicey you're pulling the swarm to your front so you can always escape out the back in an instant. 

Overall, really fun game. I really hope they add multiplayer in the future for the longevity of the game, maybe some events and stuff. It really depends on how far the devs want to take it, but I could see this game potentially being around for a long time if they wanted to do the work. If it stays single player, it'll still be a fun game for a month and worth the money.

Can't recommend this game in its current state. 

The game is far too difficult and fast paced to be fun. You always feel weak and even with upgrades the mobs continue to easily outpace you. Even 12 hours in, all 3 waves of enemies in a level will be alive at once because I can't kill even the first wave before the second and third arrive. Unlike vampire survivors where most weapons and combinations make you stronger, in this game the options that actually make you strong are very rare and not intuitive. If you just build for fun, you will almost always be so weak you can't even finish a level. 

The game also bizarrely does not give you enough time to do all the things it tasks you with. If you farm nitra and gold, you miss out on experience and levels and upgrades. If you do secondary missions, you miss out on both of the aforementioned. If you kill enemies and collect their exp to get strong, you miss out on nitra and gold and secondary missions. Every path you take feels bad because you are missing out on ways to progress. On top of that, you have to fail runs to unlock overclocks for weapons. Weapons are not viable without overclocks yet the game asks you to throw away sometimes multiple runs praying for rng to give you the weapon you want to unlock OCs for and then praying it gives you the upgrades to get it to lvl 12. I still have not been able to unlock them for multiple weapons despite actively trying to. 

It also feels very bad to not be able to get experience for killing enemies. You have to manually pick it up, but the map is so covered in bugs that most of the experience is completely lost and huge amounts of power and progression will just stay on the level until you lose it all by being forced to move to the next one. 

Overall, the game needs a lot of improvement.

[h3]Deep Rock Galactic [strike]Survivor[/strike] Simulator[/h3]

Welcome to the Deep Rock Galactic acquisition program, where you will be introduced to the wealth and [strike]dangers[/strike] adventures that’s what working for Deep Rock Galactic is all about.

But of course this program comes with all the benefits of any simulation software, such as, but not limited to:
- Shooting while mining minerals
- Automatic aiming (assistance)
- Unlimited ammunition
- No fall damage
- Drop pods always landing on ‘accessible’ locations
- No distraction from (or need for) [strike]friends[/strike] colleagues
- Looking better than Real Life Galactic*
- More weapons than are actually available at Deep Rock Galactic**

[i]*Debatable.[/i]
[i]**Dual flamethrowers finally included.[/i]

Have you ever been in an survivor or mining mood, but never liked mining cubes or shooting pixels? Here is your chance for a more realistic experience. The excavating mechanic really adds some depth to the genre and decision making. Dig your own [strike]path[/strike] tunnel to success!

And as a bonus for showing off your survival prowess you could be selected to join an ever expanding and prosperous Galactic Corporation. So sign up now! And before you know it, you might be bonding with strangers over one of the premium selection of beverages in the Abyss Bar after a long and exciting deep dive.

Green beards will be a thing of the past.
Rock and stone, future miners!

Progression is too slow and the longer you play the more it becomes boring. This game is not much different then Vampire Survivor. Vampire Survivor has a near perfect progression and keeps the player engaged the entire time. They do this by giving you access to many different combinations of characters, items and stat increases. The randomness decreases in VS as you play given how many re-rolls and passes you get. This game's progression is hindered by only having 4 characters and a set amount of weapons that each character can use (thus locking you out of some given what character you play). This makes the progression much slower and duller as you are forced to use characters and weapon combos you may not like. This happens in VS, but not nearly as much. You have to grind each of the 4 characters in game for a long time to unlock all their weapons and profiles (this is the main complaint, make this faster, it's so dumb how many replays you go through). I've played 21hrs and  don't really feel like I've unlocked anything really cool or fun to keep me hooked playing. I did not expect this to be a 40hr+ game and I don't really think it should be. If the devs want the game to last 40hrs+, add more characters, profiles, weapons, have a game mode+ or dlc. I like my vampire survivor clones because they are fast and addicting. This is long and drawn out for no real reason. Plus, god give us multiple bosses, one is not enough and so boring, strategy becomes stale given the repetition.

If you enjoyed Vampire Survivors... wait, no. This game is on completely different level.
I think Vampire Survivors on steroids is an understatement. 
Basic idea is the same, you walk around, your character auto shoots enemies. 
But...
There are a few really cool mechanics, kinda new for this genre, like procedurally generated environment. You can dig out resourced that you will use in this run, but also different ones that are spent for permanent upgrades. 
You can destroy rocks to escape yourself from swarms but also help yourself out to fight enemies in corridors instead of open area. 
A looot of items, weapons, what is already surprising for a game which is still in Early Access.
Unique level up system, which allows you to upgrade weapons in different ways each run. 
Rogue-lite + "vampire survivors"-like game, definitely worth a try. 
9/10 for sure and I am looking forward to future updates and extra content!

I am a big fan on the survivor genre of games, and this is the worst one I've played. I feel that the developers completely miss what makes these kinds of games great - which is progression.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor simply doesn't have a good progression system. Almost nothing in the game feels rewarding. Most of the weapons are bland and doesn't significantly affect the gameplay enough. The upgrades are bland (mostly % increases). The continuous progression between levels are equally boring.

Rock and Stone!
You play a dwarf that mine rock and kill bugs.

[h2] Needs Improvement [/h2]
[h3] The Good [/h3]
There's a lot that this game does well, weapons + classes feel unique and interesting, feedback for enemies and pickups is satisfying, hit-boxes are fair and the unique aspect of the dives from DRG combined with mine-able terrain/collectables and explode-able enemies that you can manually detonate makes this game stand out design wise from it's other survivor like counterparts.

[h3] Needs Work [/h3]
I'm a huge fan of the design and progression of DRG, so there was a lot of that I was hoping to see in this game, mainly:
[list]
[*] Interesting map generation and sub objectives - DRG has a wide variety of sub objectives and natural cave features that make every run unique and engaging, even with the 3 map types the levels in this game feel very repetitive and uninteresting.
[*] Satisfying progression for weapons and characters: the stat increases you get feel very unsatisfying and don't really customise how you play. Overlocks are fun but you basically get them all for free once you've played + levelled with a weapon once. There's definitely a lot of room for improvement here.
[*] Better bosses + elites: I'd rather than have a action packed fight with lots of dodging than a tanky turtle that crawls towards me and occasionally leaps at me.
[*] Weapon slot design: Currently at hazard 3 I find myself prioritising overclocks for sheer power, which means I often have 2 guns severely under levelled and basically just there more for aesthetics than use. This might be less of a problem on higher hazards I'm not sure.
[*] Cosmetics: not really a must have but I'd love it if they brought some unlockable cosmetics from DRG here.
[/list]

[h3] TLDR [/h3]
Gameplay is good, but map design and progression need work to feel satisfying.

Great spin on the survivor format. It looks and feels very "Deep Rock". I was impressed at how useful the digging mechanic is as a survival tool. The main negative I have with the game so far is the variety of upgrades. Most of the time you are choosing between basic stat increases. You do eventually unlock some more interesting options (like increasing your damage by 1% for every 5 gold you have), but I'd like to see more cool upgrades available earlier. The progression path for weapons is also a little annoying - i.e., you need to level weapons to 12 in order to unlock their overclocks, but you can't use them until subsequent matches, so the initial levelling of said weapon is just a pointless grind.
Overall though, the game is definitely fun, and definitely worth the low asking price in my opinion.

For its price, is just great.

Many people complain about the lack of aiming, but it is actually a specific design choice, since different weapons have different aiming strategy or shooting pattern. And this adds a layer of strategy in your gun choice.

Another common complain regards the need to level up a weapon in a run before having access to its overclocks, but also this mechanic to me its fine. Make it necessary for you to first do a couple of runs with a weapon and learn how to use it, before giving you access to more advanced options. It makes sense in terms of lore, in terms of gameplay, and it feels rewarding.

There are things to fix and for sure it needs more content. For example, the final boss is always the same and is quite boring.
But for a Early Access game, it is just fine. And the price is completely fair!

Disclaimer:  I like the game enough to keep playing it through till the end, because I love VS-like and roguelikes, but they need to do better here.  I think we all had high expectations for this, and to me, it just doesn't live up to many of them.

Seems like mostly fan service unless they make major improvement.  
- Severe lack of content. 3 maps doesn't cut it at this stage in these games.  Playing just to unlock harder versions is not fun.  Where's the secret objectives and other events to open other areas and other ways to play?
- Most of the weapons within the same class don't really feel much different.  IE Gunner.  OK great, I got a new weapon.  It mostly feels like there's just another stream of bullets in there.
- Same thing happens on every mission with nothing to discover.  Sames bosses.  Same hordes.  Barely any addition of new enemies.  
- Side missions with collecting are pointless. Yes, ok, you get some gold and such.  That's it.  These should flow into some other improvement aspect of the game.  Also they shouldn't have a limit.  Right now, for example, you have to collect 6 flowers, but there's a bunch more you could get.  Just make it a sliding reward based on how many you can get.  
- Add more achievements. LOTS more achievements.  And make many of them skill based feats, not "Collect 2000 gold".  It's fine to have these, but give us ones to actually strive for.
- Needs more relics.  More effects that drastically change how you play that run.  There's just not enough here. 
- Unique events or other triggerable things to do?  Again, we want more variety, more things to consider, more options to squish bugs, and more builds to play with.  
- Other game modes please?  Like a non-timed map? Something?

Apologies ahead of time if I missed something that I mentioned they should have, that they actually do.  But these are my first impressions getting through the game to Hazard 3 on the maps.
Buy it, play it. Regretting your life choices is a problem for future you.

The game has an OK starting point.  Biggest problem is half the guns are directional based and when part of the core game play is moving around and trying to mine resources it makes the directional guns feel inferior to the auto target ones due to either: standing at a rock to mine or trying to angle yourself so the gun will still fire while mining.  It wouldn't be as bad if the directional guns did more damage to compensate but most of them feel underwhelming to use and take considerably more level ups to make them passable.  I would wait to purchase until most of the guns are adjusted.

After playing 8.5 hours of the early access release (as well as 15.6 hours of the demo and 340+hours of the main DRG game), I would have to say I do see the potential of this game but it does lack in several areas and it does take a few hours to get enough upgrades to get the ball rolling.

The main things that I think the game feels "off":
1. The classes - Unlike in the main game, this is not (up to) 4 player co-op, this is just a single player experience. Much like in DRG, each class has their niches. However, being single player only does highlight the power imbalance between classes.

The classes do play the same (in terms of the core gameplay) as there are no mobility tools like the zipline or grappling hook in the main DRG game, instead the game introduces subclasses with different starting weapons and a unique perk. However, in my opinion, some are just better than the others.

Since the mining mechanic is useful for making your own path through the terrain on top of getting your gold and nitra (which you need to buy upgrades and/or heal between stages, as well as rerolling), you want to prioritize mining minerals in the early game as it gives exp. As driller has innate mining speed increased, his early game seems much easier, as well as doing "throwaway runs" just to get minerals like jadiz, umanite, enor pearls, etc.

The classes also share some weapons with each other so the only thing separating them are the subclasses' unique buffs and slightly different stats (e,g, scout has more crit dmg, gunner more health, driller more mining speed and engineer has increased xp gain.)

2. The weapons - The variety is nice, a lot of returning weapons from DRG as well as some new ones introduced in this game. HOWEVER, unlocking the overlocks of the weapons require you to take the weapon to lvl 12 in a run first, and then you can get overclocks on subsequent runs at lvl 6,12,18 (18 being an unstable overclock which are gamechangers). This is not a good design choice imo as it basically forces you to do a few sacrifice runs just to unlock the overclocks for each weapon. In my many hours of playtime, I would say 10 levels per stages is the average, but when you level up, you also get other important upgrades, such as CRIT rate and dmg, health mining and movement speed, pickup range, etc. You also get additional weapons at lvl 5,15 and 25. So getting lvl ups for the weapon you want is inconsistent. (If they would just make it so you can get the overclocks on a weapon without spending a run unlocking it, a big part of this issue could be solved......... I do understand that this may be the developer's choice to get the player used to the weapon before giving them free reign but 12 lvls is just abit too high in my opinion)

Basically you rarely get the chance to get more than 1 weapon to lvl 18 to feel the power for long, because usually by that time you will be at the last stage. Perhaps the early access version's scaling is a bit harder than in the demo but that might just be a placebo as I have 100% the demo but not done so yet for the early access.

Overall, the gameplay loop is fun but shallow, considering other "survivor-like" games allow you to have a proper build by the end and enjoy the power fantasy, DRG survivors seems like they want to preserve the feel of DRG more than leaning more into the survivor like gameplay. I look forward to more enemy variety and if the developers would take more creative liberties and try more new ideas as it seems the association with the main DRG game is a detriment rather than enhancing the gameplay. I believe this game achieves what it sets out to do but could definitely use more content and polish to make this game truely stand on its own.

I would give this game neutral if possible but after playing it a bit more, I would say it leans more towards recommend than not.

I really really want to like the game, but I sadly cant.

The Good:
* Visually the game is amazing, great environments and great animations. I really like to see a Survivor-Type game made with budget. I wish you could see the different weapons shooting from your character though.
* Music is good, sound is great, voicelines make the game feel more alive.
* The walls and the mining add another layer of complexity which is very welcome.
* Nice enemy density. Its always fun to have to deal with a big horde of enemies.
* The different missions with different maps and different difficulties are great and would keep me engaged BUT:

The Bad:
* The worst part is by far the upgrade/level-up system. All upgrades, and I mean every single one, are basically just minor stat increases in a very blant way. Builds basically don't exist. You just take whatever increases your damage-output the most at this moment. Just take a short look at Brotato and its item variety. This is not just a problem in this game, this shit is especially common in Triple-A games these days, where upgrades are just like +10% damage. Booooring.
* Even more limiting is that upgrades have a rarity on them, so mostly they take away the freedom of choosing an upgrade because you usually want the upgrade with higher rarity that give you that tiny bit more damage. In the shop its fine since higher tier upgrades cost more gold, so theres a trade-off, but the level-up reward screen is an illusion of choice.
* Overclocks could have helped with creating interesting builds but most overlocks are also pretty bland, rarely game changing. And having to unlock overclocks first is just annoying. Theres better ways of doing meta progression than wasting runs for unlocks.
* I could be wrong on that but It also feels like your build doesn't even matter because killing big hordes of enemies mostly revolves about creating chain reactions with exploders...
* The permanent upgrades that you buy with the meta currency are just boring stat boosters too.

The game has alot of potential, and I hope the devs make the best out of this early access.

Showing promise during its early access phase, this game holds particular appeal for fans of the Deep Rock series. Yet, it tends to veer towards excessive difficulty, potentially alienating some players. While leveling up, the rewards lack the satisfying dopamine rush characteristic of many other roguelites. Additionally, the initial level proves more challenging than desired for a game of this genre. Adding to these observations, it's worth noting that the first level's end boss presents an undue challenge for a game of this nature. In comparison, several bullet hell survivors offer a more balanced and finely tuned gameplay experience, underscoring an opportunity for refinement in difficulty scaling and design.

I was super excited for this game, I love a lot of the horde-survival/rogue-like genre. Other than looking great, DRG: Survivor is not a great entry in the genre. 
The weapons are all too similar, upgrades and overclocks are just small stat increases. There are virtually no movement mechanics. 
There are no synergies of items to leverage for interesting builds. Weapons have huge reload times yet the time-to-kill is long even when your weapons are up.

The game ramps enemies in count and strength faster than you can level, so you mostly don't get to fully explore many of the levels. 

Short of grinding out base stat upgrades for dozens of hours, you have no chance to snowball. Maybe the higher Haz levels will provide an xp/difficulty ramp that makes them actually more fun to play, but no way I am going to put in another 20-30 hours of grinding to find out.

Right now in this form, it's a huge disappointment and probably the least fun of any entry in this genre I've tried. Hope the devs see the feedback and do something to build out some fun.

Funday is off to a great start on changing the formula while keeping the aesthetics of Deep Rock Galactic. The classes feel unique, the progression is straightforward (if lackluster on the Overclock side currently), and the maps are interesting.

For an early access game, its surprisingly stable. Performance could be optimized for lower end machines, but I've not encountered anything gamebreaking or any hard crashing (maybe a minor visual bug but kinda hard with all the visual clutter).

I think that the remaining biomes, new sub objectives, and other enemies from DRG proper should be introduced in the future, and maybe some weapons and overclock modifiers could be exported the other way. I love the idea of the shock gates and the flame turrets, and would love to see them in the original IP.

This is my new favorite survivors game, and it's not even close. There's so much more going on in the environment than other survivors games but it all fits together cohesively. There are mission objectives, resources to mine, supply drops and of course the ever-present horde of bugs. You can focus more on mining or more on killing bugs and it's fun to switch between the two. The weapon builds and overclocks are great and require you to focus on upgrading certain weapons over others. 

The bug horde is meant to be a constant threat that has to be managed, this is where deep-rock-galactic-survivor departs from other survivors games. The bug horde path-finds to the player based on what is presently on the screen, this allows you to funnel the bugs through chokepoints and plan escape routes when they get too close. It's a really interesting and sort of unexpected aspect of this game that I really like. Some people are put off by the fact that you can't just click your mouse and destroy everything on the screen, but it's really important that the game is designed this way so that the mining mechanic works with the combat, and it's what sets this game apart.

A glaring issue right now is the fact that there is a single boss fight at the end of each Biome and it's exactly the same. Not sure the developers were thinking here. There is a good amount of content and polish in this game already, so why not at the very least have an alternate boss model with different attack pattern? The game also is in need of more "supply-drop" power-ups (these are passive buffs that can change your build) because right now there are only about a dozen and you end up getting the same ones over and over again.

This game is about as satisfying as... Wrestling a greased pig? 

Upgrades — the ones you get from levelling up during a dive, AND the meta ones you purchase on the main menu — just feel like they do nothing and have no variety or synergy, what [i]should[/i] be fodder enemies are way too tanky, and I'm pretty sure said enemies also scale their stats each level, ultimately obsoleting the already awful upgrades.

I know it's early access, but it feels like the game has somehow progressed backwards from the previous demo. It's like the people who're developing this game took one look at the Vampire Survivors' store page, saw the hordes of enemies and the upgrades, and used that for inspiration without ever considering or studying what made [i]that[/i] game so satisfying.

Here's hoping that I'm not the only person whose mind immediately goes to “DRG spin-off = automatically good and immune to all criticism.” You're all consoomers.

I know the game is still in its Pre full release form, but i think after 10-11 hours i can give a decent review of what i have seen and played so far plus a few suggestions for the Dev's.

Positives: sooooo fun! shooting and watching bugs blow up is just as fun as DRG if not more so!  Excellent arrange of weapons to choose from between the different classes and sub-classes!  Graphics are top-notch and i haven't had any crazy graphical issues/clipping that messed with gameplay at all. The random spawn of levels is awesome as well. This is by far the best $10 game you could buy!

Negatives: Really none, i cant find anything that completely turns me off from the game or is so annoying id call it a negative.

Suggestions: i do have a list of things that are geared towards new players and maybe you guys are implementing some stuff since it is pre-release.
1. A short tutorial - maybe a 3 level with an elite at the end? i knew what things like nitra/gold did, the different minerals (ebony pearl, jadiz etc.) were for because i played DRG, but i have seen others who ignore all of it because they didn't know they were for buying upgrades between rounds or for the permanent upgrades. Also explaining that getting a weapon to level 12 unlocks the overclocks that are essentially to progress.. i actually didn't know that until i was about 2-3 hours in and "accidentally" unlocked one.
2. Maybe adding in that when you hover your cursor over the different class/sub classes it could tell you how to unlock them.  It took me a bit of looking through the menu's to figure it out.
3. Different end boss types!
4. More biomes! DRG has like 10 =P
5. Longer mission time.. it does seem like sometimes each level is just a bit too fast.
6. The only graphical issue i have had and it was pretty rare was sometimes the Dreadnaught would hit me and it i really felt like i was not in the hit box/radius to be hit by him jumping.  Maybe i suck at dodging! but sometimes it felt a little inconsistent.
EDIT: I'm not sure if its a bug or not but sometimes when i get hit while im mining my character slows down.. like he loses all run speed bonus and is noticeably slower. its caused me to die to the dreadnought as well as almost miss leaving a level a few times.  Seems to happen about once a run, but if it happens on say level 2 the "debuff" disappears when you start level 3.

All in all excellent game id highly recommend and would give a 7.8/10 for now!

Fun as hell!

Your favorite DRG dwarves in a single player bullet heaven roguelite.

I see people comparing to other, similar ones, and while it shares a lot with those other ones, being in the same genre, after 8hrs of play, here's my observation:

It's fun.  Weapon choices matter.  Powerup choices matter as well.  Time matters quite a lot.
Wrong weapon choices can end your run at the last level, or any of the earlier bosses.

Like in the OG DRG game, the bugs spawn in ever increasing waves.  So it's a good idea to clear a level rather quickly, BUT you want to get that tasty gold, and nitra to power up between levels.  Powering up between levels can be critical as well.

The mechanics are kind of similar to Yet Another Zombie Survivors, where you need to balance the weapons of the other teammate.

Here you'll be balancing area effect, environmental, mining speed, etc.

The unique thing here, is that 90% of the time, you'll be weaker than the bug horde.  Even if you end up squashing a wave, if you take too much time, eventually the next wave will overwhelm you as the bugs get stronger and stronger.

This is where it's important to have some weapons that can damage bosses fast.   I've had runs where I've only had forward facing weapons, and just couldn't do enough damage to the boss since I'm always running from it.

A bit of strategy is called for, and different dwarves have slightly different loudouts that do affect gameplay.

The first few games you play are basically impossible to win as meta progress on guns themselves are necessary to give them any flair. Not having them evolve mid game seems like poor design decision that I hope they remedy before release. It's unfun having to level a gun to max level on base mechanics, especially since with the limited game time I don't even expect to max 2 weapons on most characters(The XP Engineer being the outlier). 

The game itself is quite fun with the destructible terrain, collectible goals, and the cheesing with the drop pod. That last part did however make the game terribly easy from what I've played so far. I think it not being a co-op game is odd considering the base this spinoff comes from but at the same time I can see the difficulty in trying to balance a Survivor game with multiple players. 

With some polish and revisiting core mechanics of the game I totally see this being flipped to a thumbs up but for now I'm bored of it within a few hours and leveling guns to ACTUALLY level guns is not my cup of tea. Oh, and it would probably make the game far too easy but allowing mouse targeting on the "In front of Character" weapons would feel so much nicer. I hate mining when I've got the shotgun/railgun, I just ignore that aspect of the game til I get a second weapon(And I don't focus on leveling them because they feel so clunky).

This game has one very simple feature that sets it apart from the rest in its genre. The ability to dig through walls and create your own path while collecting some valuables in said walls. Other games may have little/no incentive to move around despite moving being the only active thing you do in these games. Vampire Survivors? Yeah let me go pick up that Empty Tome upgrade by holding left for 5 mins, I'll get there eventually. DRG: Survivors? Ooo, piece of candy... Ooo piece of candy... Ooo piece of candy. Not to mention that some enemies will try to path around walls while others will path through it and destroy them. Use that to either prevent them from getting too close until you're ready to create an opening or even use their own digging to help you mine the gold you need for the next upgrade/reroll.

I will, however, point out the glaring flaw with this game has over other similar games. No "unique" synergies at all. VS has weapon fusions, 20 Minutes 'til Dawn has upgrade paths, nothing but stats in this game that [i]maybe[/i] affect more than one weapon that you have. Major upgrades (overclocks) only come every 6 levels and can sometimes be something special like adding elemental damage, or maybe it's just a stat boost for that weapon alone... Not as much variety in this game as others.

For those looking for meta-progression I might recommend a different game though. Based on the number of "Milestones" as this game calls them (the unlockables between sessions) I bet you easily run out of them before ever reaching the highest difficulty. There are still upgrades that act as permanent stat boosts which look like they may take longer to fill out though so maybe that's a consolation for you. 

For now though, the core gameplay loop is enough to keep me entertained throughout the entirety of a run. Will try to come back here to update if they ever add new content to address these issues, or if I run out of content before then.

DRG: survivor is an auto shooter that plays similarly to others in the genre while adding in terrain that has to be played around.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[h3]+ Core game play plays extremely well[/h3] creates an addicting game play loop, currently each run has 5 stages that are on a timer till the boss spawns once the boss spawns the bugs will occasionally be buffed until the boss is defeated 
[h3]+ Graphics / art style are great [/h3] this is the first auto shooter i have seen in 3d over 2d
[h3]+ Mining[/h3] lets you escape the alien horde when cornered but also forces you to make a choice to fight or mine for resources for upgrades

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[h3]- Content [/h3] very few variations in aliens, maps, artifacts, this will probably be fixed in the future since the game just came out but its important to note at this time
[h3]- tank controls [/h3] for weapons that are directional it can be difficult angling your weapon to shoot the horde coming towards you, 
[h3]- milestones [/h3] milestones currently mix the completed milestones with the incomplete ones making it harder to track what you have left to do. this isnt a huge issues right now but could become a problem when the game has more content


overall the game is great and i look forward to future updates

It's a fun twist to a vampire survivor formula: being able to make your own path on a map by mining minerals. I really liked the visuals, your character and operators' voicelines, and especially exploding bugs which you can trick into destroying the whole horde following you.

But, while I've been having a moderately fun experience with the game, it was gradually ruined by balance and technical issues:
1.  You have to upgrade each weapon to a lvl 12 to unlock its' overclocking. I can't imagine going into vampire survivors and collecting each weapon to a certain lvl so that the game would let me evolve this weapon in the NEXT run. The game loop   turns into this: unlock new weapon - start next run on the lowest difficulty - hope that new weapon will appear in your weapon selection on lvl 5 - 15 - 25 - click on every upgrade for this weapon until it's lvl 12 - repeat for every weapon you find in the game.
2. Right now there's not much to do in terms of sidequests. You've got to collect/mine 6 to 20 things every round and find an airdrop when you reach the middle of each round. That's all. Oh, and kill the big bug  at the end of the round.
3. The most disappointing thing that made me write this review: I've lost my savefile after power outage. I've played two sessions and everything was erased. It wasn't that much playtime, about 3.5 hours, but because of the first point I don't want to restart my progression cause it's so tedious. I did find a guide that suggested editing the config file, but every weapon has a UUID, and I don't know where to find them, and don't remember all the weapons that I've unlocked, nor do I have any motivation to search for this info.
HARD,BUT FUNN

I love the survivor genre and was thinking many of the negative reviews were made by people that might not "get" what the genre is about. Having played the game, I can definitely say the meta progression is terribly slow. I also think the criticism some others have said about explosive bugs being THE way to do damage is correct. 

All this being said, the core game loop is enjoyable. I can see the design choice was meant to mimic the FEEL of Deep Rock and it definitely does that. The relentless tide chases you from point A to B as you desperately try to mine resources before they catch up to you. Nailed it. However, I think the devs leaned in on this a little too hard. It never feels like any choice  makes a significant difference. This is the essence of the genre. You have to feel like the decisions you make affect the game play. Otherwise, the game play feels way to shallow to warrant your time. There is definitely a great addition to the survivor genre here. I just hope the devs can see the difference between nail biting challenge and nihilistic tedium.

I love Deep Rock Galactic and Ghost Ship Games but it needs a lot of work. 

The game play is mainly running around gathering materials, doing objectives and running AWAY from hordes of enemies, so imagine my confusion when they decided to make certain weapons ONLY shoot in front of you or behind you.... This is stupid and honestly should be changed to at least fire towards the cursor/mouse.

Things I would like to see changed:
1. 30 Second window to leave makes it so much more rushed for legitimately zero reason, I've lost several runs because it throws the pod in some insane location and while there is still a horde chasing me, sometimes the horde is also ON the drop ship, which results in a loss because you literally cannot enter the ship due to the enemies damaging you and killing you, sometimes it spawns the ship SO DAMN FAR its not possible to get there without movement speed increases, on floor 1.
2. Weapons only firing in set directions. Not single one of these weapons do I like using, I don't like the Minigun, the Warthog or the Subata. I don't like any of them, they all feel significantly worse to use than any of the automatic aim weapons. (If it was cursor based they would actually be useful in comparison to the auto aim weapons.) 
3. The amount of environmental hazards gets actually completely ridiculous the moment you go to the Magma Core, it goes from ZERO hazards to THREE DIFFERENT ONES. Which aren't too bad one at a time, but having them on Floor 1 is just annoying, especially since the Stabber Vines shouldn't/can't be in the Magma Core. 

I want to see this game succeed, and I'm sure it will, even if these changes don't happen, but I think the game would be far more enjoyable if these changes were made.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivors is an absolute blast so far. It borrows a lot from Deep Rock Galactic and converts it neatly into a Vampire Survivors style game. The visuals are great and match the same attractive look of Deep Rock which is beautifully paired with many of DRG's awesome soundtracks. I haven't encountered any bugs so far and the customization is varied and suits both budget and high-end machines.
The game play is, of course, what this game is about and it follows a 5 stage dive format with the mission types being limited at the moment (with more on the way among other things). You start by leaving the drop pod to mine (yes, mining is a very important part of the game play loop similar to DRG) and kill Glyphids to level up and collect upgrades for your dwarf and arsenal. As the mission progresses, swarms will attack, a supply pod will arrive to give you an artifact, and an elite must be killed to trigger the escape pod. This is repeated for stages 1 through 4 then the final stage you face a Dreadnaught to achieve victory. Mix in randomly generated areas to explore, 4 classes to play, 3 biomes to weather, and a truckload of things to unlock or upgrade, and you will begin losing track of the time.
Highly recommend to anyone, even more so to fans of DRG, Vampire Survivors, or Halls of Torment.
ROCK AND STONE, TO THE BONE.

Weapons/gear upgrades are incremental damage up/reload speed upgrades. Overclock upgrades do not augment the gameplay much. Unlike other survivor games, no weapon synergies/combinations. Annoying that you have to get 12 upgrades of a weapon, to unlock the overclock upgrades for the NEXT run. Never feel strong enough to face the horde. Almost always running away from the horde. Constantly have to use the explosive bug to help clear the bugs rather than my weapons. Especially weapons that only shoot in front of you (e.g., Minigun) Feels bad to leave so much EXP behind after beating the floor's elite mob due to the 30 second timer to go to the next floor or lose. Only 1 boss which is trivialised by moving not in a straight line.

Better than I thought, I love everything about deep rock and I love vampire survivors so it was already a great mix. The gameplay twists of the objectives and mining really add to how you move around a level. The inter-level upgrades are also really sweet.

This is a thumbs sideways for sure. I'm hoping the early access will lead to a very fleshed out game, but I have some faith. Quick rundown:

Pros:
1. Respectable price.
2. Generally fun bullet heaven.
3. DRG dwarves and audio.
4. Painful but addictive.

Cons:
1. Having to use dry runs to obtain overclocks.
2. Mini-gun forward-facing requirement; you'll rarely be fast enough to shoot the Dreadnought for any meaningful amount of time.
3. The amount of time given to reach the drop pod after the stage boss is killed; without movement speed bonuses and/or a clear path, you can be shut out of completing the stage.

Because of the low price and the potential for future improvements, you probably won't regret buying this, even if it's just a day or two of initial addiction. I'll be watching these updates closely.

Game is ok, you need to manage time and can't do everything each stage which is fine but difficulty needs to be adjusted. The start is difficult even for someone with a lot of genre experience which leads to slow resource acquisition, slow upgrading and unlocks and just a grind overall. Some obvious balance issues aswell. 

It's actually a problem with the genre as a whole that has unmitigated powercreep the more you play making gameplay duller instead of making the game more challenging the more you play. Wish someone actually did something about that. Ease a player into the mechanics and then apply difficulty as they gain upgrades and unlock new stuff.

This is the typical unbalanced experience we see in the genre that's excused by being "hardcore" when in reality the devs just haven't paid adequate attention to the balancing of the initial 10 hours of the game at all and made it unneccessarily hostile to the player.

Meh. This is very uninspired. The mining aspect is a nice addition to the genre as it gives you a secondary focus and you are constantly choosing between trying to mine and live / lvl. That said, the guns are not very fun. The only class that really stands out is the engineer, as it is the only one that offers a real variance in play-style. The upgrades are mostly boring stats except for the overclocks. There is no need combining of weapons or anything like that. There is also no larger metagame outside of incremental stat unlocks. The three biomes are very similar, and most maps are small. Same boss in all three. Same mission progression in all three. Same mini-objectives in all three. No ability to explore and discover. It isn't bad, it just isn't as good as other offerings in the genre. Halls of Torment has better scaling and systems. Death must die has better power fantasy and variance. Vampire Survivors has better everything. The one standout DRG:S has is the graphics fidelity, which looks nice, is easy to read on screen, and never has slow down. 

Also, do yourself a favor and mutre the game after the first run. You will never hear anything new again.

TLDR: Is good for few runs but i would wait how it shapes in the future.

Now for bigger review. there is a lot to like and dislike about this game. 
i would also like to give some feedback and ideas to devs who may read this.

i believe the biggest problem the game have is that it looks like DRG, it plays similar enough to DRG and yet it lack it distinguishing features. It is its biggest strength but also its biggest weakness.

[h2] Characters [h2]
You have beautiful formula for making distinct characters, why did you not use it here?
You can basically collect experience from 2 sources, combat and objectives[ores, collectables].
so why does every character play the same, why are they not on sliding scale between these 2 progressions?

Why doesn't scout have grapple hook, allowing him to quickly navigate map and collect resources?
Why does driller mine only as fast as the other dwarfs? Or give him melee drill attack. Or make some walls unpassable that only driller can mine.
Why not give a gunner his shield, which would also fix his inability to shoot back with gatling gun?
And what about engineer? why does ho not have ability to build walls, for example? you give him static turrets that would benefit from terrain control.
There is a formula in DRG where every character is distinct and plays differently, and yet its lack in this game is all the more grating. 

[h2] Level design [h2]
I will be honest, the caves are just boring. And i don't mean distinct biomes, that is nice idea and i would like to see more of them in the future. But the algorithm that generates the caves could use some work to make them more interesting, Right now, they are just rectangle with some holes here and there but that's it.
Also why don't we have a map? looking for dropped magnet is a pain and as they are rather rare, it feels bad to pick them up at the start of the level and to abandon them if you are unable or don't have time to find them at the end. 

[h2] Gameplay [h2]
Now this one is hard to judge. i like the concept, i like how difficult it feels but right now. Yet i also feel like there is no chance at victory and that sucks. Even at hazard 2 with good half of the meta-progression, i have problem killing the juggernaut. the problem is not the big bug, i would kill it with time, problem is that i drown under all the adds and there is nothing i can do.
The game would also benefit from more secondary missions and final stages.

Also some aspect are very questionable. 
Like the guns that only shoot forwards in a game where you need to run away from bugs? And you cant shoot anything when you decide to mine? i would understand if we could selectively choose to aim like in other game, but without it, it add a lot of difficulty just hitting something you need to hit.
Or the uncleanness of some aspect. how is the experience and gold determined? do i gain more on higher hazard?
Also the horde mechanic feels redundant. you are already attacked by horde, now there is more? so what do i do? if i am strong, i will just shoot them anyway, if i am weak, i will just run anyway. at later stages, i could not tell you if the horde is happening or not. it should feel more distinct, yet with the current balancing, it does not.
fun

A pretty fun survivor-like game with a neat mining mechanic. It IS in early access and has much room for improvement, but for 9 bucks it's great so far!

Improvements I could see made:
-more variety of weapons/effects
-weapons having their own graphics on the character
-outlined enemies or certain enemies if they are hard to see/behind a walls etc.
