Great game, great price! Had loads of fun unlocking stuff and making builds. 

Pros: 
- many viable builds, at least at difficulty 1 to 3 (havent played higher difficulties yet)
- classes and subclasses offer different playstyles
- weapon modifications (overclocks) can really change the fundamentals of a weapon, offering unique advantages and combos
- levels feel really different with unique map features. Not just visual

Cons: 
- My game crashes from time to time (although I haven't found many others reporting this)
- Lost all my progression after one such crash

Even though I'm salty about losing all my progression, the  game itself is great and I can't wait to see what's coming in the future!

As many have stated, the game currently suffers from lack of balance and an efficient character progress. 

1. You HAVE to rely on swarm exploders to clear out the swarm. Your weapons do not deal enough damage/do not have AOE. Because of this you never feel like the upgrades you receive do anything.
2. There is not enough time during a stage to complete side quests/mine minerals for character progression. Swarms occur too fast and once you kill the boss, you have to rush to the pod. Also if you do finish side quests/mine minerals, you end up grinding a few hours just to get +1% crit chance or +1% move speed as your character progression... 
3. There is no proper class distinction. Upgrades are the same for most weapons. Similar weapons are offered to most classes, until hours into the game when you finally begin to unlock some more. As of now, I never paid attention if I was playing as an engineer or a driller, because they are all very similar. 
4. Randomly generated maps add a lot of bad RNG into the game. On some maps, you can get a ton of resources and a nice layout. On some maps, you will run around only encountering boolo caps before actually finding some resources...but you're already half way through the stage and there are 3 swarms...

I am a fan of DRG. I love the game! And I want to love this game as well. However...as far as auto-battlers go...this is mediocre at best in its current state. I will revisit in the future.

I don't like the weapons, things that work get diluted by things that don't when you unlock them later on. I never felt as powerful as I did when I first unlocked the Gunner. Get those two rapid fire pistols that fire in an X and the mirror that fires in + and you effectively have made Garlic in those other games. Nuisance enemies get cleared out quick. But then you get grenades and gadgets that deal fire damage, over time. Or electrical damage, over time. Why is electrical damage over time? If I got struck by lightning I doubt it's going to kill me 3 days from when I got struck. 

The map design,  I don't like that the game is broken up into 5 mini-maps. Feels bad to get moving and rolling and before you know it, it's time to leave. You feel rushed, constantly. You have to leave a lot behind and it just feels awful. This map system exists in Brotato and it doesn't feel as bad, but that's because all your loot comes with you after. Perhaps make the drop pod drill thing be a magnet when it leaves it just sucks up everything on the ground for you. 

Otherwise though, it's still a YES from me. Being fresh into Early Access, and from a franchise I feel can be trusted to improve and shoot for a fully fledged out game a year from now.

In the large field of Vampire Survivor inspired games, there are quite a few good ideas, especially mining and weapon overclocks (major upgrade every 6 per level upgrades upgrading the specific weapon). In the case of overclocks, while they can change the guns significantly, most don't, and the rest of the upgrades you get also are not interesting. 3% crit chance? 4% reload speed? Both leave me wishing I got interesting upgrades instead. Some of the weapons, especially the shotgun is very frustrating to use on MnK. The different specializations and miners don't feel different, you get a different passives, between stat adjustments or minor effects, like having your weapons start off closer to their first overclock (ie real upgrade). I should also add that most of the real changing upgrades are locked behind the very last overclock slot for a weapon, so you're more likely to get an overclock that is relatively simple for the majority of the run.
I don't want this to come off as trashing the game either, I do plan on coming back (and hopefully changing my recommendation to positive upon future updates releasing.

Great game! Let me explain: 

There are many complaints about the conflicting fact that you both need to mine materials while also being almost pushed out of the level, AND on top of that you also need to put your time into farming for XP, at the start I also felt like this was a weakness. However; the more I played, nearly 16 hours in, I realize that there is a good balance between all of the priorities. After some time, which the 2 hour reviewers have not gotten to, is after getting more upgrades, and ESPECIALLY overclocks, Im able to split all of the priorities evenly throughout the run.

This here is another gripe many have, not feeling strong enough. Again, the start of the game is meant to be difficult, if you have very little play time, you have very little progress on your account. I feel like im overpowered now at this point.

Content is lacking slightly but of COURSE it is, this is an early access game as of right now. I have run into zero bugs, and no gameplay is clunky which is the normal now not only for early access games but many triple A games.

If you like DRG either way, you will love it because it stays close to the original game with characters, weapons, voice lines, bugs, etc..

**Edit** One thing I did want to mention is that bosses are very easy to cheese due to simply running circle around it.. 

Cant wait to see what else they add! Hopefully more boss variety as well as mission variety.

I think I have enough hours to form a review of this game,
and I will start by saying that this game is great!

It has the Deep Rock charm you know and love but with a "Survivors" twist. As it stands right now it has enough content to justify the price tag. I feel some others are judging it too harshly and while they aren't wrong in some aspects the game can still improve over time from updates and more content drops. Each class actually has quite the unique set of play-styles if you build right and tinker with specific setups. The Mining aspect of the game is a nice little bonus to acquire materials and take advantage of traversing the map. The enemy variety becomes more difficult to manage on higher hazard modes which is nice over just a health and damage increase. Lastly, the weapons/upgrades and grinding for overclocks does actually feel pretty rewarding and allows you to tackle the higher difficulties just like in the main deep rock game. Overall, it pretty much is a fresh take on Deep Rock and if you do like the survivor genre it is a worthy game to give a try, you won't be disappointed! 


Now,
if the developers are reading this, I have a suggestion for the class system to make them even more unique and mimic  mechanics/abilities that Deep Rock Galactic has.
- Give the Scout a grapple that can be used to cross gaps and allows for a nice escape tool!
- This is an odd one given a zip-line would just be like a worse version of grapple so...I think the Gunner should have a tag/mark system that rewards for focusing specific enemies and allows Bosco to unload artillery on targeted enemy.
- Give the Engineer a platform tool that allows for blocking pathways and pushing bugs to specific pathways.
- Give the Driller a drill overpower mode that when active allows you to not take damage from the front and do quick burst/mine damage for a short amount of time.

All of these of course would be either limited use or on long cooldowns to balance out the amazing advantages they would give you. That's all I have for now, I will update if things change as my playtime increases, Rock and Stone!

- Meta Progression is slow and boring. Yay another 2% damage increase or 4% pickup radius...
- Overclocks are underwhelming and the fact that you usually have to waste a run to even get them is ridiculous. Like, 25% more damage and reload speed? That's like two levels worth of upgrades and you get about 40+ levels per run or more. 
- Artifacts are the only thing so far that seem to actually affect the way you play your run in a meaningful way. And even then, there's only a few that do that. And you can't reroll them either for some reason
- You NEVER feel overpowered. In a rogue-lite, that's the most satisfying thing, finding a fun combo that makes you feel strong. That doesn't happen here. The  most satisfying and powerful way of clearing enemies is when an exploding enemy makes a chain reaction with other exploding enemies. Why can't YOUR BUILD do that instead of it being in every wave by default, making whatever build  you chose kind of meaningless? 
- Characters do not feel very different. The driller for instance starts with +20% mining speed. You can get that from ONE upgrade. All the characters are just a few upgrades away from each other. Sucblasses are sometimes unique but rarely affect the way you play.

Some things I would like to see:
- More unique weapons or weapon synergies
- Better upgrades. Small stat increases are just boring if that's all there is. What about On-Crit modifiers or element combinations, different mining bonuses other than just speed and resources
- Make the characters more unique
- I hate the overclocking unlock mechanic. Just change it or make the overclocks available on the run you level the weapon
- MORE INTERESTING OVERCLOCKS. With a few exceptions, they are bland and boring and don't change the way you play at all. 
- Just less boring please! The core idea is fun and unique enough to give this life

Before I write my actual review: It is not a bad game.

But I will list my reason why I am giving it a no below:

With the mining aspect it gives the VS-like genre a new USP. If a swarm becomes too much you can simply dig yourself a tunnel to escape. Other than that you will also find ore to buy upgrades between layers.
However, due to having to mine for upgrades and level up myself by defeating enemies I am constantly torn between "should I go boom boom enemies" or "should I rock and stone". 
When you first load into the game you can already see which upgrades you can potentially buy after each game. For me this simply meant that if I collect minerals during the game I can then use them in that screen. I did not expect the minerals to be essential during each run itself as well, so I didn't mine any in my first.
Another aspect which feels wonky are the upgrades themselves. Besides that they are very basic now (eg. "do 10% more damage with this weapon) which I don't mind much it is hard to tell how impactful they are. Other than go for the rare or epic upgrade I don't see a reason to go for other upgrades besides damage, mining speed and reload speed.
Last but not least the weapon upgrade milestones you can unlock. I really like the idea of choosing upgrades for specific weapons which then can unlock special milestones on them depending on how many upgrades that weapon has. What I am missing is an overview which upgrades I already chose so I can better choose which milestone I want.
In general am I missing numbers in this game, I want to know how which upgrade affects which weapon or myself in what way. Currently it's missing that bit of structure for me.

For an early access game it nailed the basics of what an VS-like is, and I'll gladly update this review when it gets polished some more. :)

The Star Wars Holiday Special of Deep Rock Galactic. Sure, all your favorite characters are here, but the adventures and charm of the things that made you love them are absent. The core of DRG is the cooperative layering of strengths and weaknesses among the classes. This single-player outing that plays like a phone game doesn't allow for that, so every character you can possibly play has some weakness you can't overcome until you grind, grind, grind the universal upgrades out. While I was playing I just couldn't help but think that even a solo DRG with trusty Boscoe was a more rewarding experience, but a much better option, just play DRG with four randos. By some miracle normal DRG has one of the least-toxic communities in all of videogamedom. If you can't find a passable, playable group for some mid-tier DRG go to your bathroom, find the mirror, and there's your problem. If this goes on sale for say, $5, maybe pick it up and play it at the office on a low-end machine. At $9 it's a solid meh.

The positives : Mining is fun. I like mining through the walls. I like acquiring resources throughout the run. Unfortunately these resources feel awful anyways.

--------------The Issues----------------

First of all - getting in the drop pod within 30 seconds OR DEATH is just about the worst gaming mechanic I have ever seen. You beat the boss? That's too bad, if you can't run through the horde of enemies without dying you die anyways! There's no increased difficulty to the drop pod, it's merely death.

The weapons? Remember when you played BTD5 and every tower was useless at the beginning besides the one you used? This game has the same problematic trope, but there is no paywall to justify it. 

The upgrades? Imagine creating a game this far after vampire survivors, with so little customization. No duo powers, those are even in mobile games! There's crit, damage, attack speed, reload time, and duration. That's it!

Even for early access, this is just a game with nice graphics based on dwarves looking to suck your wallet.
The only good bug is a dead bug.

Highly recommend this game for the price. Even if you haven't played Deep Rock Galactic (what are you doing, go play it) this game is quite polished and addicting. The game is a solo auto-shooter roguelike (ala Vampire Survivors) built beautifully in the world of DRG. Complete challenges during your runs, and mine minerals to receive permanent upgrades that will help you survive further in your following runs.

My only slight complaint is that there don't seem to be many (if any) unique voice lines to this game. They are copy-and-pasted from DRG, which isn't a big deal but you'd think they could record some new ones since this is a completely separate game. I've heard that the game isn't very long at the moment, but it was just released in EA and the time it takes you to complete all available levels will vary. I just completed my first dive after 3.5 hours, so I still have a long way to go, which seems like plenty of playtime for a $10 game.

TL;DR: If you like the auto-shooter subgenre of roguelikes (like Vampire Survivors), this is a great game to play. Even if you haven't played Deep Rock Galactic. But seriously, go play that as well.

I absolutely recommend this survivor game, I have put in about 300 or so hours into Deep Rock Galactic and this brings me the nostalgic feeling I got from the Dwarven voice lines in DRG. Great first 4 hours

PROS

Great production values. Destructable terrain makes every run a little different and creates some fun tactical options. The end-level timer rush also creates a fun bit of mad-dash to complete the level.

The core gameplay loop has good tension. You have to balance the opportunity to mine (upgrades) or kill (XP).

CONS

The meta of this game is pure linear stats grind. As soon as you level up enough to clear Tier 1, starting Tier 2 is like starting the game all over. You are back at the bottom, dying quickly, and just grinding tiny little stat increases to eventually get stronger. First time through this was fine, second time through its all the same, you just suck again, on the same levels. Hamster wheel stuff.

Weapon and equipment / skill synergies are almost non-existent. There should be way more benefits to certain combos of weapons and other augments to make builds interesting. Brotato and VampSurv did this really well.

4 main characters classes, with 3 subclasses. But the sub-classes just have tiny stats differences and starting weapon but it doesn't add much to the strategy because your build is a matter of random chance. 

It would definitely help if the game let you control your builds during a run. At the very least "bespoke build" mode should be an option and give the player control if they want it.

Game also needs more flashy fun stuff and wacky effects during a level clear. Like Vamp Survivors had disco gold mode, crazy light shows, temporary insanity triggers, etc. Things like that would make the runs more varied and fun.

VERDICT

Worth about 10 hours of play time at this point. Expanded meta, build control, weapon synergies, and more glitzy random events during levels would make this game an ace.
Oh yes!

Definitely rough around the edges and in need of a lot more content and some pretty serious rebalancing, but it's fun. Brutal and unforgiving, but fun. Would love to see some more biomes, and for them to have more going on than simply being increasingly difficult to navigate, which on that note, Hollow Bough should probably go back to the drawing board.

I haven't played long enough yet to unlock too terribly much, but the weapon upgrades all seem to be... more or less identical. Reload speed, fire rate, damage. Seems to be the case for just about everything, and I feel like there needs to be some more uniqueness to them so that they have more of their own identities - much like they do in the original DRG. Overclocks definitely need some more creative ideas as well, as most of them seem to just be a couple of weapon upgrades packaged together, which isn't very interesting or even impactful.

For 9 or 10 bucks? Sure. But I feel like the game needs a fair bit more to it before it really lives up to its namesake.

Currently i think the game is fun but i do think it is a bit rough as well...

As a quick overview for the game currently (2/17/24)

The game in itself is a survival based title with some roguelike elements for your playthroughs.

There is meta progression as well for the game to work on as you go along for those that may want to know that.

Overall a run is comprised of picking a character ( 4 currently; you start with just the one unlocked ). Every character has a starting theme or loadout; with more you can unlock over time as you go along. The starting weapon and class traits with said loadout can add some variation to your runs.

When starting your dropped into a Biome ( Map ) to begin your run. In the map your surrounded by randomly generated rock layouts and enemy spawn points. You can break the rocks by moving into them with varying levels of time needed to break some ( resource based ones take longer ). Within the map you will have rocks that grant resources for your run to use on upgrades or resources that are used after for your meta progression upgrades.
The goal on the maps are generally to kill monsters until the final Elite appears to kill and you can complete that floor to move on to the next. Each run has 5 Floors to do to fully complete the map your on.

More difficulty levels exist as you make progression towards map goals that are shown when viewing the biome you wish to complete or play on. The goals always include completing the map and 2 set goals often tied to collecting a resource or using a certain type of gun.

There is a varity of ways to increase your strength while doing your runs. You have weapon upgrades & relics you can earn on each floor of a map if you want to go for it ( involves clearing a set marker on the map and holding the position for like 5 seconds or so? ). One facet of the weapons is unique upgrades called overclocks but are not unlocked by default. Once unlocking a new weapon; the game will require you to level it up fully in a run to unlock the overclock ability. ( Note- is currently not a feature players care for right now as it seem like double dipping to use a weapon fully ).

Between floors you will get a shop to spend your resources on for upgrades and you do have re-rolls by default by using in game gold during your runs.

As for the meta progression at the title screen; you are able to sell un-needed or wanted resources or buy wanted ones for cash ( meta progressions are tied to cash you get from runs and the resources tied to various upgrades )

Overall the game is enjoyable but will say it is challenging from the jump ( nice for some..annoying for others ). Given this is more of a survival game..its not inheriently intended to be played as a traditional Roguelike to farm a map for exp and resource as enemies will outpace you in most instances. The enemies get stronger at the end of floors infinately until you beat the Elite for that floor. So for those maybe wanting a power fantasy of wiping a map with overwhelming strength..you may be a bit dissapointed. 
All in all its a fun title and does need some balancing and tweaking to things and it should turn out well as the foundation is definately there.

Personal notes..the only real issues ive noticed performance wise is bad stuttering when the screen gets heavy enemy wise ( I run a 3080TI for reference sake and a higher end CPU ). Also one bug thats only happened once where the map failed to load properly but seems rare at best and simply re-started the run.

Gameplay is great so far. There are some balancing issues that need to be addressed but for the most part I'm having fun with it. Hollow Bough (Haz 1) has been the biggest Challenge to complete a dive so far and took me quite a few tries to do so. The rush to the Drop Pod is either an easy path or completely blocked by a horde of bugs. Looking forward to the future Updates!

After playing for a while, I say this game is severely undercooked and needs to go to back into the oven. It's not fun. Compared to other Vampire Survivor-likes, most of the time you can do nothing else but run around like a bitch. There is almost never a moment where you can stand back against the horde, just run run run. You never feel powerful.

All weapons, with some exceptions of the primary weapon of the first class specs, hit like a wet noodle, and even investing significant effort into upgrading them does nothing. "Overclocks" are underwhelming most of the time, with some exceptions. A lot of the artifacts/gear from supply crates is not very impactful, although then there are some pieces unlocked later that are good. You either get them, or you will struggle (and probably die early into the run). 

Nonexistent level design so far. 3 biomes, they change a bit, but you always do the same. 5 stages, with the same boss in the last stage. Every single stage is the same. You run around for a minute gathering resources, after that "a sWaRm Is cOmiNg" and you run away from it for the rest of the stage, trying to clear the supply crate area and stand still long enough so it drops down. Variety of enemies is also nonexistent. 5 models of bugs get old really quickly, compared to hundreds of different enemies in Vampire Survivors. Sure, in there a lot of them are just stock images from bought assets, but the main issue is seeing lack of any progress. Brown bug, red bug, blue bug, big angry flying bug with a health bar, shit shit shit, run!

There is too little information. You don't know exactly what element types do, you just guess it from gameplay, but the exact mechanics remain hidden. How is the damage for each element calculated? How much damage is from the initial hit and how much from the DoT? The weapon details don't tell. If I upgrade damage of a fire weapon, does the bonus translate to higher fire dot? Plasma type is really just a single bounce from the wall? Weak and pointless. Nobody knows. I don't want to go scour a wiki for this, put the information into the game.
HP bar is only on the toughest enemies, so you have no idea how well you are doing. They either die, or don't, and they form impenetrable wall you have to run away from. Highest weapon damage seems to be on the weirdest places. You are telling me this stupid fire grenade I didn't upgrade at all scored regularly millions of damage, while the gun I upgraded from the start did barely a million? Weird.

Mining is only fun to a point when in higher hazard levels the horde is on your ass and you wish the game rolled you a legendary Mining Speed upgrade or two. Then it's just frustrating.

Rock and stone? More like "sweat and frustration". I will give it a year before trying again, right now I regret my purchase.

In its current state, this game is prohibitively hard. It throws as many enemies at you as Vampire Survivors does, but adds a reload mechanic that can see you stop attacking, which lowers your DPS drastically. Finishing a level will [u] require [/u] you to die, upgrade your character, and restart it - otherwise, you simply won't have the DPS, scaling, or health to do so. 

You can overclock weapons, but doing so requires them to be upgraded to level 12 in one run, which would be fine, but beating a level requires an incredibly strong build, which requires overclocks - which means you'll need minimum one run to level a weapon to level 12 (and that's if you get lucky enough to get upgrades for it, which aren't guaranteed by the looks of it), and only in the [i] next [/i] run will those overclocks be able to be used - this means a guaranteed forced one death minimum on the first stage to the final boss, because you just won't have enough DPS to get through otherwise. 

Speaking of the bosses... well, the first level's boss has two attacks, which is one more than many other enemies. All enemies will move towards the player to hit them - classic Survivors gameplay - and some will do other things like blow up or spit slow moving projectiles. The first level's boss has two attacks consisting of moving towards the player at alarming speeds, or to jump in their direction. The issue(s) with this is that this jump goes incredibly far, tracks the player to a high degree, and the boss deals a significant amount of damage to the player, often in the ball park of 4~ hits to kill a scout, the first playable character (who you are forced to make your first few runs with). You can dodge these jumps fairly consistently if your play field is open, which... it is not. Your play field is full of hundreds of enemies walking at you, and walls that need to be mined away. They are mined slowly unless you take the mining speed upgrades, which leave less for damage upgrades, which means you can kill the hordes slower... it's a vicious loop made difficult to navigate by poor balancing. The mining is an innovation on the genre fit for the Deep Rock name, but it also adds an entirely new dimension (hah) to the balance that leaves players floundering for necessary upgrades. You simply never feel strong, and the game never reaches the highs that Vampire Survivors does for its celebration of killing thousands of enemies with ease. 

Did you have to die in Vampire Survivors? Sure, eventually, to the literal personification of death, but that just acted as a level timer - and even then you could kill death if you built well enough - but the final enemies here are just... bigger bugs. Completing a run in Vampire Survivors also counted when you were killed, because for most players, that would be their end. In Deep Rock Galactic Survivor, if you cannot kill the final boss, you've failed a run and your pity prize is the scant few upgrade crystals you've collected along the way. This key difference leads to a massive disparity in run quality between Deep Rock, and Vampire. In the latter, you lead a string of victories to grow stronger and better, unlocking new items and beating new and exciting enemies. In the former, you're scrabbling for whatever chance you can to try and last as long as possible to try and gather enough materials that the next run might matter a little more.

I suppose it's more faithful to the "Survivor" part of the title, but it's not why a lot of us play the genre. In its current state, the game is fun and well made, but ultimately frustrating and poorly balanced. As someone who has sunk countless hours into both Deep Rock Galactic (on ps4) and Vampire Survivors (on switch), this doesn't capture the wanton slaughter of either, and feels like an attempt to make a very hard game without an understanding of why it's being made. I can't recommend it until a thorough balance patch takes place.

But after that, be it due to upgrades that carry over, new unlockables or just general game knowledge, your power grows exponentially. 
I am pretty sure it took me less than 10 tries to finally beat the final boss Dreadnought, which the first 3-4 times I reached felt like it was impossible to beat.

Tl;dr: If you find the theme (DRG) interesting, and enjoy Vampire Survivors, give this game a try, I am sure there is a lot of fun to be had, as I have already.

Another Vampire Survivors Like game.

I wasn't convinced on the purchase from the comments and game footage, but after purchasing I've been pleasantly surprised.

It really comes down to tuning.  The power progression curve feels quite good.  You start of weak, but you rarely get to a point that you feel disgustingly overpowered.  You do feel an increase in power though, and with the randomness of upgrades you can have quite a bit of variety in bad to good runs.

The additional mechanic of mining is great.  I think this leans in to what this game is offering that it does better than any other one I've played so far:  It provides multiple objectives for you to choose between, and there is a depth of skill in how you use your weapons and upgrades to make a run more efficient.

As other reviewers have noted, the fact that you don't really get to the point of blowing up the whole screen while afking can be a drawback for some people.  For me I think that you have to pay attention the whole time makes it a more engaging game.

Very excited to see what they add to this one throughout the EA period.

As Steam continues to be flooded with (Vampire-)Survivor-likes or Horde-Shooter, Bullet-Hells/Heavens or whatever you want to call them, 
these games tend to get pretty stale after the fourty-nine thousand six hundred and seventy-fifth instalment, with only a handful worthy of being called 'exceptions'. This one, at least for me, is one of them.

Just like its older sibling [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/548430/Deep_Rock_Galactic] Deep Rock Galactic[/url], the gameplay revolves around the mining mechanic, namely the destructible walls. e.g. Do you choose to dig straight through the wall, giving you an extra emergency exit; do you leave it intact, making it harder for enemies to reach you, but forcing you to take a longer route with potentially new dangers; or do you try the risky route that leads to that [i]very profitable-looking [b]vein of gold[/b][/i] that ends in the corner of the map, with the only way out being a massive cave wall? [i](Always remember, Kids: [u]when mining, some of your weapons may not function and your movement is significantly slowed down[/u]!)[/i]

In my opinion, the game requires you to make more decisions that can have a lasting effect on the course of the round than other representatives of this genre, in which it mostly comes down to a simple [i]"do I still have enough HP to continue firing away or should I run away and heal".[/i]

Having a great time at the moment, although it is not all just [i]ore veins and beer[/i].
It certainly needs some polishing (btw: great name for a Publisher Studio in Poland. Somebody write that down), but as it's only been out for a few days and is as early access as you can get, let's give the devs at Funday some time rather than abandoning this gem right away. I'm looking forward to the updates while still having fun :)

Player damage always feels behind no matter how you build, you take a moment to mine, you get overwhelmed by the outrageous amount of non stop bugs. On the flip side, focus on bugs you end up with hardly any resources for upgrades. Could be fun but needs a lot of work imo. In the meantime, go play brotato.

Hello there fellow person looking at comments for reviews to see if its worth buying.

Felt like commenting to lighten the mood because I am not quite sure where the negative comments are coming from.

This game does what most rogue-likes do and adds a couple mining elements to give you a little something extra to do.
Ignore the negative reviews, the game isn't impossible or poorly balanced or FAR too boring, its just very key to focus on a weapon to get the "overclock" abilities and those are what make the game fun which you may not get them quickly into the game as you need to focus on a weapon till you upgraded it 12 times so then your NEXT run you get access to the overclock abilities. I have had plenty of success so far and some really fun runs.

Now not all weapons are made equal obviously but using the right passive with the right weapons is crucial. Each miner has 3 passive starting abilities/stat load outs and you have enough weapons that have their couple different overclock options, minimum 6+ per weapon. Some might overlap as far as buffs but I haven't experienced it yet. As some do focus on powering the weapons strengths OR making its weaknesses not as bad so you can find a build one way or another. I understand where people are coming from saying the weapons aren't VERY innovative but i mean its sticking with its theme quite well and has plenty to keep you interested. You have your turret builds, your elemental builds, your high rate of fire builds, ur low rate of fire high damage builds, gernade/throwables builds, and all sorts of things inbetween. And changing the elements of the weapons highly effects the way they interact with the enviroment its NOT just a "scales with elemental modifiers" perk. 
 I would pay double the price they are asking for this game and still be happy. So its a very fair price.

Played a good few Roguelite's by now as i'm sure many who have found this review have, and I have to say... This game, considering its in very early access, is really solid and a real blast. So many different weapons and combinations alongside the choices of 4 characters who each have up to 3 different builds they can use, gives the game a lot of variety and build choice. All weapons (even if at first they seem bad) can become godlike and disgusting combinations can be made.

The game also has some unique features as well as those we've seen many times before in the Roguelite genre, such as a near fully destructible terrain + mining for currency which allows for a very different playstyle compared to the usual dodging mechanic formula from a lot of other games. 

Features I would like to see added to flesh out the game a bit more...
- An endless mode sometimes you just have that great, fun build going and the game is over all too soon.
- A boss rush mode for that true adrenaline rush.
- More weapons, overclocks, love what they have, would love even more to mess around with.
- More unique boss enemies, currently only one.
- More permanent upgrades as well as higher difficulties to counterbalance them (such as +1 base gold/nitra from mining would be really fun to take builds even further).
- Just more fun. Game is great and roguelites for me are all about just kicking back for a bit and having nothing but fun absolutely blasting through massive hordes of enemies and chasing those epic and legendary powers.

Again, considering this is early access, I can currently and confidently say that the only way is up for this game at the moment and I myself am eagerly awaiting future content updates and to see where the development of this game goes, highly recommend giving it a try. Can't wait to see more for this game.

Unsure why the game needs to be in early access, I don't see much of a difference between the play test and the current state of the game, there's 2 extra maps and 3 extra characters. I am enjoying the game right now, though it's very unforgiving and they made it harder then the play test. I would not recommend it unless you really like Deep Rock Galactic AND you really like the rogue-like genre. It would be nice if Steam had a neutral review, this review would sit nicely there.

I remember Hazard 1 and maybe even 2 being pretty easy, but enjoyable once you got a feel for the game. But in this final version Hazard 1 was hard for me as I am not a highly skilled player. There is no I-frame or anything like that when you get hit you get hit a lot. You are dealing with swarms so when taking any damage its easy to be taken out while still at half health as you will be hit by many attacks each dealing 5-10% damage. I found i often got cornered with no chance of success. bugs on all sides my guns barley doing anything to them and no ability to try and run through and eat some damage, as running through more than 6 bugs is fatal. The time to get to the drop pod is also way to short. Its not really possible to run through the enemies so it took me often 15-20 seconds to find a path the the pod when i was ready for the boss to die. If the boss died while i was just trying to survive. That got much harder to make. I don't know why you cannot get a little breather when you have so many other things in the mission to do, at least in Hazard 1 it would be nice to get a time bonus. 

This game make a mistake i don't think the main DRG makes in that it locks all but one class behind achievement unlocks. You no longer can try all 4 classes out to find what you think feels best for you. Now you have to start with the one class available till you have completed for me what was several runs. Then you will only unlock one more class. I hate when games do this. Its fine locking some stuff behind progress unlocks, but not everything. If a game has a lot of play-style options let me taste the variety before i sink a bunch of time into it. The main game does this really well i think. You get a try each main play style while still having the variants of that play style locked. 

I started a return. If i cannot get it to run long enough to play then that is easy decision, but even before that became clear i was seriously frustrated playing this game.

It's hard not to recommend this to fans of the bullet heaven genre, as inspired by titles like Vampire Survivors.  It has all the charms of DRG's universe.  It uses terrain / mining to expand its gameplay in amazing directions.  It includes great combos and weaponry options.  It has a tough-but-satisfying difficulty curve with long-term meta-progression.  It has that near-constant dopamine rush we gamers crave from a looter. There's an incredible depth of strategy that can be derived from its simplistic control scheme.  And with our quartet of Dwarf Boys finally back in action after their previous foray into Hoxxes, it's just good news we can all play this game with one hand free...

This is an excellent game. I absolutely recommend if either a) you like the original DRG or b) you like vampire-survivors-esque isometric survival style games.

The gameplay will be largely familiar if you've played other horde survival auto shooters: you run around the map with a huge number of enemies bee-lining for you. Kills generate XP which you use to get upgrades. The enemies get harder as you upgrade, so it's an arm's race.

What does make this game unique is the DRG universe tie-in. So basically, each run of this game is modelled on a DRG deep dive. For one thing, this means that in addition to killing enemies, there are also resources to mine or collect. You also have destructable terrain, which is very important tactically, as you can create "tunnels" that will force enemies to funnel on one side of you, allowing certain weapons to be far more effective.

This DRG aspect really makes the game feel fresh, even if you've played many games that are mechanically similar (e.g. Soulstone Survivors, Halls of Torment, etc.) And for the price, it's totally worth it.

Tips for beginners:

* Always be mining, especially gold and nitra. 

* When you unlock the secondary mission objectives, go straight for them at the beginning of each mission since they become harder to complete later on. They reward tons of experience and gold.

* Loot bugs have gold and nitra and are faster to mine too.

* Gold and nitra are used to buy things between missions, but gold is also used to reroll items both in the mission and intermission.

* Unlock your overclock upgrades ASAP. To do this, focus all upgrades into a weapon and nothing else until the bar is fully unlocked. You can then simply die and repeat the process for other weapons.

* If you're cornered, remember: You've a pickaxe. Mine through it!

* On map 5, save the supply drop for the big motherbugger. It'll cleave half its health bar right off.

My current impression is that this game will hopefully still spend quite a bit of time in early access.
I do like that mining an mobility play a larger role here than they do in Vampire Survivors. And just like anybody else who played the original DRG game, I like dwarfs, snarky comments and killing Glyphids.

But unfortunately, there is also a number of major issues here:
1) Currently, you cannot do a lot with the terrain in terms of creating a tactical advantage (like carving out a more easily defensible zone) - feels like wasted potential
2) The four levels in each biome create a weird interruption in the flow.
3) Upgrades don't really feel all that meaningful, it's mostly a few percent more here and there
4) I would expect that your build becomes more powerful throughout each run, so that in the last third or quarter, you mow through normal enemies without effort (which is IMO one of the main things that makes Vampire Survivors so compelling)

All in all, especially for a more casual player like myself, the game is currently not that much fun.

As so often, I would prefer to give this a "mixed" review, but since Steam doesn't allow this, I'll rate it as "not recommended" and hope the devs will do major improvements of the game in the coming months. I'll probably try again after a while and will update this review, then.

I wouldn't have thought myself a fan of "bullet hell" games, but I wanted to support these creators because of how much I enjoy Deep Rock Galactic and their dedication to making solid titles without predatory transactions or scummy "pay to win" tactics.

I get it now.

I get why people play "bullet hell" games.

As it stands right now, in this first early access version, there isn't really much to this game. The four characters are barely differentiated and the available weapons do not inspire. Progress and unlocks are both very limited, and you'll find yourself finishing many 20+ minute runs where the only permanent progress you've made is enough resources to purchase +1% critical chance. This game doesn't have the wackiness or zany weapons of Vampire Survivors, the build variability of Brotato, or the proper challenge of Halls of Torment. While I look forward to seeing what future updates have to offer, I am not particularly hopeful that this product will end up being able to differentiate itself enough from the competition. A fun survivor game, but it needs to incorporate Molly, Beer, Dice Slapping, and a Rock and Stone Button.

TL;DR: I think DRGS has a lot of potential and I love it’s unique take on the genre, incorporating elements from DRG itself and creating something that is truly unique and not just a quick cash grab. However, I think it doesn’t take it far enough in some aspects, and the game suffers from some blandness. I do have hopes some of this will be ironed out as the game is in early access and came out just a few days ago, but other things are core design decisions the devs probably won’t walk back on.

The positives:

Adding a destructible environment was a great decision and it sets apart this game from every other in the genre. The environment can be used to funnel enemies and carve out paths to make your grand escape in those ball tickling moments the auto shooter genre is known for. It can also block your path and force you to plan your escape ahead of time. It’s just good.

Borrowing the minerals from the base game and using them as a way to get more upgrades in the run and permanent progression is a great way to add something for the player to do during downtime. Walking across halfway the map for an item in Vampire Survivors wasn’t the worst, but it certainly wasn’t very fun either.

The ability to use drop pods and exploders to kill bosses and large groups of enemies is both faithful to the original game and is just fun to do.

The deep dive system is a further compliment to the mining system making sure there is always stuff to mine, and serves as a reset of pace to make sure you don’t get utterly overwhelmed by enemies even if your build isn’t amazing. Although having to rush to the drop pod every time isn’t so great, sometimes I have an OP build and want to destroy everything in my screen.

The new weapons and some overclock ideas are really nice and hopefully get added to the base game.

The overclock system itself is a nice alternative to the more prevalent evolution system in this genre, but whereas some overclocks are nice others are quite lame, and it seems like there is a lack of many overclocks in general.

The 4 different classes in the game are represented quite well, but I really don’t like a certain design decision that I will get into now.

The negatives:

Your weapons are (mostly) limited to your class. This stifles build variety and kills experimentation, and what’s worse is how contradictory weapons and their classes can be. The driller is encouraged to dig tunnels to funnel enemies, yet lots of his weapons like the sludge pump, the flamethrower and the wave cooker are bad in closed spaces and better in open ones. On the other hand, scout’s mobility encourages him to stay in the open, yet lots of his weapons like the m1 garand, gk rifle and double barrel encourage him to stay in tunnels and funnel enemies. These weapons being restricted only makes sense in the base game which has completely different gameplay and therefore completely different gameplay balancing.

Like Halls of Torment, 95% of your upgrades are just generic stat increases. It becomes tiring taking the same upgrades again and again. Some weapons have unique upgrades like the additional beams and split beams, but it’s very rare and only for a few weapons. All weapons taking the same upgrades also leads to a lot of the weapons feeling very similar too, some weapon specific upgrades like additional pellets for shotguns, +x penetration for more penetration focused weapons etc. would be nice.

Runs are too short. Even though the deep dive mechanic is great, by the time you actually get OP the run ends. Having an endless mode with an extra 5-10 more minutes to go ham at the final stage would be great.

There is also no option to aim manually, but some weapons are balanced around this mechanic so it’s not as simple as adding that option like in Holocure or Halls of Torment. But it’s not fun running away from enemies as the gunner fully knowing you’re missing out on a lot of DPS but would die otherwise, or your double barrel shots targeting some small singular enemy rather than the huge wave in front of you.

I have some other nitpicks but overall I do think this game is good, however I would recommend people to play Holocure, Vampire Survivors and maybe Brotato first, as those games are simply better made with more content and imo more fun.

I’m sure more content will be added in the game like new enemies (macteras that actually circle around you and shoot stuff, opressors that can dig stuff/damage you with ground slams etc.) and new tools, but some core mechanics like the lame upgrades and weapon limitations are probably here to stay.

I basically never leave reviews but with so many complaining about the balance and difficulty, I wanted to offer some balance. 

I've played my fair share of survivor games, and tend to enjoy them but get bored relatively quickly. Vampire Survivors was a bit of an exception, that is a very satisfying game because you're crazy overpowered. This game is not Vampire Survivors.

This game is tough, it requires some real consideration of where you move, what weapons you pick, how you dig and funnel mobs, when you need to grind some exp from the swarm and when you need to go mining. There is strategy, there is difficulty and as you build yourself up there is occasionally that feeling of destruction as you overpower hordes of glyphids. 

Maybe this isn't for everyone, I remember seeing one person say the devs were "scared" to let you feel overpowered. The fact is, this is just a variation of survivor game and not everything has to be VS, that's what VS is for. If you want a challenge and to feel some real progression in the gameplay then definitely give this a spin! Probably my favourite survivor game right now.

Hello friends. In this year of our lord 2024, I finally came to my senses and broke free of the absurdly grindy, unrewarding, microtransaction mienefield laden hell that was destiny and came out of the other side wondering a few things:

- Where are my friends?
- *Who* are my friends
- What is that giant orange ball in the sky, what the hell is this green stuff on the ground, and since when did real life not come with a streamer with no real personality trying to sell me on their preferred energy drink while staring mindlessly at their screen.

Then, finally, after I settled on no forthcoming answers, I realised that thanks to no longer donating to bungie's never ending charity grift, I had much more money and that I would need a new hobby; at this point I opened up steam, ignored the back catalogue that I swore I would one day make my way through (but not today) and picked up Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor. What do I think of it? Well. It's fun! It works despite being in early access, (like palworld), it has an addictive gameplay loop which means I have something to focus on that isn't drink, cocaine or ladies of the night and most of all it's affordable and doesn't include any microtransactions.

Pick the game up. You won't regret it. And then with the other 60 bucks you would have spent on a triple A title that was developed by people that hate you, buy some sandwiches for the homeless if you feel the need to keep your wallet empty.

i like the game so far.

the gameplay loop:
you run around the map, mine as many ressource as you can while dodging or killing a ton of bugs. 
you regularily get upgrades for your weapons or base stats. you carry up to 4 weapons that you unlock during the run. meanwhile a timer runs out and after reaching its final destination, a boss will spawn. after killing the boss you have to "rush" to the landing pot or else game over. you do this 4 times and kill the big behemoth at level 5. after that your run is done and you start over again on a higher danger level or on a different (of 3) maps. 

but i would say content is lacking right now. dont get me wrong i havent unlocked everything yet and its fun to unlock stuff by doing little challanges, but 3 maps with the same structure is not enough. the bosses on lvl 1-4 are always the same. one is flying, one is walking and one is spitting. but basically they are just stronger standard enemies. 
the behemoth on lvl 5 is ALWAYS the same. destroy cocoons and kill behemoth. here the game needs more variety. 
i want different missions and not just wait till the same big unit appears. the final boss could use some variety as well. more creativity.

if we get these things, this game will be very good. for now its fine and if you like survivor-likes you probably like this one.

As much as I love this game (and frankly, that's only because of what it borrows from other games I love and not because it brings anything new or innovative to the table), it's currently a mess that I cannot recommend. 

It's incredibly unbalanced, and before someone comments to "git gud", you literally can't because the game doesn't give you the tools needed to put up any kind of meaningful fight against the utter INSANITY of the hordes it throws at you. On one of my best Hazard 2 runs, I completed with literally 1 HP remaining, and don't even bother trying with Hazard 3. I can't even fathom what Hazard 4 or 5 would look like. Meta progression does next to nothing to enhance your character, and it's honestly impossible to even notice the "buffs". The whole charm of a survivor-like rogue-lite is to be able to create a build from nothing that is viable against the challenges thrown at you to eventually crescendo into a power fantasy where you become a weapon of mass destruction. That never happens here, and you constantly feel vulnerable and weak. Also, don't even get me started with the Hollow Bough biome; it's possibly the worst and most lazily cobbled together level design I've seen in any game, ever. 

In terms of technical issues, there are optimization issues where the frame rate sometimes stutters to a screeching halt out of nowhere, for no discernible reason. More annoying though is a frequent bug where the camera just kinda jarringly jolts multiple times in a row to catch up to your character.

TL;DR: Devs, we need better (and more fun) tools to fight these ridiculous hordes. Fix the technical issues. You got a good foundation here but it needs a lot of love.

Start of the game is fun and concept of mining is cool as an additional objective. However once youre a few hours in you realize the game isn't balanced properly. Your power is not like other survivor games. As you get into level 3+ enemy spawning goes up exponentially while you keep getting the same mediocre upgrades. DOT build/weapons can do good but direct damage weapons are useless when half your screen is full of mobs and your weapons hit 2% of them. So 2/3 of the builds are DOA in higher levels.

Another bad aspect is all the directional firing weapons based on where youre facing but you cant back peddle like other games. And those weapon dont fire perfectly with your direction, its pretty scuffed.

Point of these games is to blast, you never feel like youre blasting. The most powerful effect in the game is causing chain explosions from the suicide mobs.

I'll update once we hit the 1.0 release, but DRGS is really fun and satisfying for EA. I've enjoyed my few hours of gameplay so far, but I'll probably be "played out" for now by the 6-8 hour mark.

I'm currently ~10 hours in, which is great value for the $9 I paid for this. 

The game play consists of diving solo into a 5-stage mine. Each level of the mine, you need to complete a main objective, while given the option to accomplish sub-objectives for more power-ups/upgrades. There are 3 planets currently, and each planet has multiple hazard levels that you unlock as you level up your dwarves.

Gathering resources and upgrade materials feels satisfying. Unlocking over-clocks for guns is a little tedious, but I think it's required for these types of games. Class progression is present as well - I'm unsure if there's a prestige mechanic, but I'm sure it's something they'll implement as EA progresses. The game runs smoothly and I haven't had any crashes or significant bugs. 

I don't have much to complain about for this game - I've been a big fan of DRG, and I think the devs/publisher do a great job appealing to the masses. 
Sometimes this feels quite grindy, but that's the nature of this type of game.
I would like to see more planets/dive locations, but I'm sure that'll come as development continues.

I genuinely have a handful of totally valid issues with the game that keep me frustrated after every run. The weapons that I've experienced through the Scout and Gunner class are underwhelming both in their initial utility as well as the utility they provide through upgrades. I've had runs where I stick to upgrading a variety of weapons, or upgrading a specific weapon in hopes of having something that will do reasonable damage at the last stage of a level. I unfortunately have not found a way to keep my damage output high enough to complete either of the 2 missions I've attempted. I also have a big issue with the bosses of these levels having attack moves that are A: not present in other low-level enemies and B: completely fuck a player if they have not geared into the upgrades that help them (movement speed, mining speed, weaponry that prioritizes high health enemies, all of which are fairly useless until you get to the boss). I also have an issue with the unlock system, as I am now stuck at level 4, unable to progress unless I beat one of these stupid levels, or until I can get a class I don't enjoy playing (Gunner, bc fuck a weapon that only shoots at the enemies in front of your player in a game like this, wtf were they thinking making this his primary weapon) to level 25 inside the run. FUCK THAT! I am going to keep trying, because there is the chance that I'm just missing something but I would consider myself a fairly technical gamer and I feel like I have the ability to pick up on what is useful/appropriate technique in a simple game like this. It's not complicated, it's not more complicated than Vampire Survivors, so it's either just a poorly made game, or I (a seasoned gamer) am missing something.

First of all, ROCK AND STONE! 
Then, some of my thoughts on the game. It's really something new for vampire survival games. Mining works absolutely well. It's a really entertaining and immersive game. However, there are two minor issues. 
1. Why can't I drink beer? 
2. Why do bullets just come from nowhere? Why can't they be fired by, for example, a drone? Every little detail has its own unique animation, but the firing is a bit of a mystery. It's getting on my nerves. 
(I know that this is a genre-specific thing, but everything else in the game is animated, which is why it is so important)

It's decent, but if you're a fan of bullet hell/heaven games, this might not scratch that itch. 
Currently new weapons are few and far between in a run, so it's really just buffing the ones you have with standard things like damage, reload, crit chance, range etc. You can't aim the weapons, yet most of them have very poor coverage or damage. So getting swarmed with 2/3 weapons (even with many upgrades) rarely feels powerful. 
There are no fun effects (from what I've found) like increasing projectile count, beam rotation speed, leeching + deal random damage when you heal etc. 
The runs can become very repetitive and grindy.

Visually it's great, sound design is really satisfying and I love the continuity coming from the original Deep Rock. I'd still recommend it because it's a solid base at a very good price.

I've made it half way through the meta progressing and each run is still either dying to a swarm you don't have damage to clear or barely winning by kiting the same final boss. The developers seem responsive to bug fixing an balancing. I'll come back after more content and balancing.

It's... alright? 

It's solo Deep Rock Galactic, but in a different package of being an action roguelike. That means most of the things that you've seen in the original game, you'll see here as well. Weapons, classes, voice-lines, music. There is hardly any new content besides the items that you get from the supply pod (and an occasional new weapon, but I think only Engineer had those) Even the little details like scoring a kill on a tough enemy with a supply pod. At times it actually feels like having a fever dream of playing Deep Rock Galactic simply because it all sounds exactly the same, save for the weapons. 

The amount of bugs simultaneously on the screen at times... Wow. It actually feels like you're playing against Zerg in StarCraft, especially if they get stuck on some impassable terrain. And they're having a lot of health, so you NEVER feel overpowered or strong. 

One of the things that rubbed me the wrong way, was the lack of depth other than using your WASD to move and aim. There would be times I'd really prefer having manual control of what exactly I want to shoot, primarily tanky elites. If a game wants me to kill it quickly (and actively punishes me for staying too long on the mission by making these enemies stronger) I'd much prefer an option to focus my damage on the target I actually need to kill first and foremost. 

Or, on several occasions the tactical genius of the gunner with a minigun would shine, and he'd lock onto the one small little bug slightly to the side, while the huge swarm was clawing it's way right in front of me. And that's with that specific gun behaving in a "fires the direction you're facing" and me staring EXACTLY at that big swarm in front of me. 

For the most part, for it's price and being a small rogue-like game, yeah, I'd probably recommend it, but it's... meh. It's pretty boring. There's not a lot of depth to it, and with the whole upgrade and unlock system, it quickly becomes a slow, grindy chore. There's simply not enough things that make it the replayable, addictive game that the other games in the genre are popular for. 

It does feel like it needs something else to it, a little more "oomph", but I can't quite figure out exactly what. Perhaps a more depth to it's mechanics and controls? Difficulty rework? Who knows. Time will tell if it becomes better or worse.

How amazing would a Deep Rock Galactic version of Gauntlet be?  Yes, I'm old enough to remember when Gauntlet was new.  I've played that and twin-stick shooters, which have their place.  Unfortunately this is like a single-stick shooter for people who can't do more than one thing at a time.

I've played this game for about half an hour now and I love DRG and the DRG board-game; both are designed to make you think and plan ahead.  This is nothing like those except for the DRG graphics and audio.  So far there is zero depth, pun intended.

It's literally just walking about, the game handles attacking for you, which is kinda half the point of playing?  Walk about to avoid bugs.  Walk into rock to mine through it.  Walk into loot bugs to pickaxe them.  Walk into a resource pod to get upgrades.  Walk into XP spheres to gain XP.  Literally just WASD to move about, RMB pauses the game.  No aiming, no using weapons, no choosing anything except for upgrades.

If I was playing this on a mobile device it'd be fine, of if my xbox X controller got mauled by a bear and only had one stick and one button working.  I struggle to find satisfaction in this nonsense: I'm hanging on to see if unlocking the Gunner is more satisfying that the initial Scout class but this is looking likely to be refunded on principle.  What an absolute waste of potential.  DRG Gauntlet would be perfect with multiplayer, this doesn't even have multiplayer.
Games fun but a bit buggy still. On several different runs I would enter the drop pod and it wouldn't recognize that I was inside and I'd fail the mission.

Here's a list of pros and cons that I'll update as I play this game through its updates.

[b] PROS: [/b]
- Solid foundation, controls feel tight and the gameplay loop is fun. Much like Vampire Survivors, this will be a fun game to watch grow and change as it approaches its 1.0 launch. 

- Excellently combines ideas from two games. The mining and digging elements are a welcome addition to the Vampire Survivor-like/Auto-shooter genre and give this game a uniquely Deep Rock feel.

- A slick translation of Deep Rock Galactic's art for a different style of game. Despite all enemies being bugs, each variety has a clear silhouette and behaviors that make enemy types feel distinct. Frankly, it's just cool to see the world of Deep Rock Galactic from a different perspective.

[b] CONS: [/b]
- Crashes and other early access quirks. This stuff will certainly be ironed out, but as of 2/17/24, the game is fairly unstable. The game doesn't save mid-run, so crashes usually result in some sort of lost progress. As of this writing, I've hit around four crashes in my ten hours of game time. One crash erased my entire save forcing me to restart the game entirely as if I had never launched it before. Erasing saves is egregious even for early access. 

- Runs can feel too similar. Because new equipment and weapons unlock at such a slow pace, and because the random drops in game are so inappreciable, consecutive runs will blend together in a way that makes it feel like you're doing exactly the same thing over and over again.

- No character customization. I am not referring to the cosmetic customization, which is also missing (it would be extremely cool if we could import the look of our DRG characters), but loadout customization. Loadouts are unlockable presets that you must select one of (there appears to be three for each of the four classes). These loadouts aren't distinct enough to feel like significant choices, but lacking any sort of mixing and matching with starting stats and gear does also contribute to that samey feeling I mentioned before. I would also argue that customizing your loadout is a distinct aspect of the DRG flavor that would help Survivor stand out in a crowded sub genre.

So far, I'm impressed. 

There are a few minor flaws with balancing and whatnot, but Ghost Ship has always excelled at listening to critique, so I trust most of these will be patched by the time the full version drops. 

DRG: Survivor is fun and engaging. In my opinion, it toes the line between needing to "sweat" and "I am become death" very well. I've obviously not played all that much (especially compared to the time I've sunk into the original) but I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of it. For an early access game, it looks fantastic and runs better than most v.1 games. 

With regard to flaws, the only glaring one is that I seem to be progressing rather quickly. I think veterans of this genre might find it a bit easy or perhaps just short. But I say this knowing that it's not yet finished, so I'm not too bothered by it at present. 

Many people seem to have a problem with the difficulty level, but I don't feel the same at all. I'm most impressed by the games ability to make each class feel unique and therefore more memorable. I think it's excellent thus far and I'm excited to see where it goes in the future.

Only actually good thing about this game is the thin DRG coat of paint.
Many reviews already point out the glaring issues, so look there if you want many more details I likely missed.

Seriously, I only tried this out because it was DRG... You take that look away and it is an entirely unsatisfying, stressful, unrewarding (for said stress) and ultimately completely forgettable gaming experience. 

---Hazard 1 means throwing a lot of runs to get anything done and unlocked which just makes it feel like bloating to lenghten "content". Hazard 1 will have you sweating your little butts to progress a bit. How is this Hazard 1 lmao. Probably done to slow down progress and make it seem like there is more to the game then there really is... Which is problematic since succeeding a mission through great effort was such a joy in DRG, here you'll get a LOT of "failed" for a lot of effort... Currently, what little they did bring from DRG CLASHES violently with the survivor genre.

---I do not appreciate the dance you have to go through with the bosses (Avoid killing them, which can be a challenge) to mine stuff (makes it lose the "survivor" feel since beating enemies is NOT what you want to focus on at all, which is hilarious when they throw so many at you from every single directions at once) as beating the boss is actually not a good thing, especially when they give you only 30 seconds to escape the moment you finish it off meaning you can't even pick up the paltry XP reward dropped by the bosses (they just drop some XP, not even that much...), let alone do a bit of mining to get a few more nitra or gold. 

---The meta upgrades are so lackluster that they are utterly disappointing, completing a few runs just to have the options be to: upgrade damage by 2%, pick-up radius by 2%, etc.... Pathetic upgrades. Not looking for anything OP at all, but at least something to look forward to upgrading. Each time a run ends I feel nothing.
Also, the in-run upgrades are not too fun as well (just damage, reload and fire rate upgrades mostly). They feel better because they give faster gratification (when you roll the rarer upgrades, which are still just like the lower rarity ones, only give more of what their inferior counter-parts offer), but that's it. Not too interesting and will keep you on the razor edge of failure, which means that of the 15-ish minute of every run, not once will you feel like your build is powerful (until the very end where MAYBE you'll feel good about your build (not that there is much variations to play with) before it is yanked away from you barely a minute later when the run ends... maybe... and again, this is on Hazard one, not end-game difficulty). Never do you feel like you achieved a great build, never do you feel like you actually achieved much at all in fact. I felt mostly empty, the only thing keeping me in the run being the fact that if I didn't sweat my little ass off then i'd be bug food (not without a fight, even if the game is lackluster and I ALT-F4ed from the menu after buying some upgrades (had a decent run, so no anger whatsoever), not even wanting to bother exiting it normally... because I didn't even want to spend another second in that game's menu... That's how empty buying the upgrades made me feel).

---ALL classes but the scout are locked at the start... yay, another way to make you grind which just ends up making the game feel bloated with mostly unfun and not-so-rewarding grind. The fact that all other classes are locked isn't REALLY necessarily a problem, but it certainly doesn't help me get rid of the opinion that they are padding the game.

---One of the best things from DRG, the bar and ordering drinks, is entirely absent. No small chill area, just kicked to the menu when you finish a run. Every time the runs end, I feel nothing and don't really look forward to going for another run. Much of the charm of DRG is actually absent as this feels like a coat of paint and nothing more.


Refunded and will just play DRG instead... as well as other Vampire-survivors-like games that are on the market. A lot are better in every aspect apart from IP. 
Such a complete disappointment from a game using the DRG IP... It might get better in the future, but I am tired of EA titles using the excuse that it is EA for being so lackluster, so empty feeling on release (if there is no soul, adding more paint coatings won't change much now will it). Might not be a "cash grab" per say, but getting real close there... especially when you consider how cheap or outright free (even though they shouldn't be) many of the competitors are. If one compares pricing, only reason this game costs more than the others is because of the DRG IP, otherwise it should be priced so much lower than those other games (if price reflects quality by comparison).
It's like putting the apple logo on an actual apple and upping the price, even though the apple itself is not juicy and way too starchy, leaving you not only unsatisfied but grossed out... But hey, smooth brained consumers will consume, am I right?

The weapon variety is good, I´ve unlocked something like 10-15 weapons and very likely more to come. Some of them are a bit sam-ey but most of them are great fun and the way they work add another layer and you have to style your play accordingly.
The balance of the game might not be quite 100% yet, would perhaps be good to be able to have easy/normal/hard. But then again you get hazard levels unlocked so the hard part will probably be unlocked as you progress.

This game is too hard, and not in a fun or fair way.  Unlike other survivor games, you immediately feel underpowered, and that feeling does not change throughout the run.  Even on the lowest difficulties, 

It is not feasible to stay put and fight, as your weapons do not deal enough damage to clear out the massive waves of enemies, so you are forced to constantly move and explore, which the game encourages with its side objectives and minerals to mine.  So you kite enemies as you explore the map, mining minerals and digging caves to make shortcuts.  This results in several problems:
- Enemy swarms are massive, and you don't know where they will spawn from.  Combined with the random map generation, you can easily trap yourself...  You might be kiting the swarm behind you, but you've reached a map dead end and the only place you can dig yourself out of is now blocked by a new swarm, and as previously stated, your weapons aren't strong enough to clear a path.  So cross your fingers that you can sprint through the enemy swarm without dying!
- Constantly kiting enemies means you're not picking up experience they drop as they die.  This usually means the optimal strategy is to find a good map spot to kite swarms in a large circle so you can eventually pick up the experience.  If you don't find a way to pick the experience up, you'll end up under leveled, further fueling the cycle of feeling under powered.

Other issues and complaints:
- The drop pod countdown timer is unforgiving.  If you get unlucky and it drops behind a massive swarm, you might be unable to get to it in time,  or without charging straight through the swarm (which will likely kill you).  I've lost more than one run after defeating the final boss because I died trying to get to the drop pod.
- Balance issues galore.  Some guns feel completely worthless, such as Recon Scout's starting gun that shoots in cardinal directions.  On Haz 3, I have to position very carefully and focus fire half a clip to kill a single grunt.
- Classses are less unique than you'd hope.  Driller felt the most different, getting a mining speed boost the longer you mine, but that interesting aspect was completely dropped for the Driller's second specialization (which instead gave reduced your damage and increased status damage, a tradeoff that you probably won't notice).
- Upgrades aren't that interesting. Percentage upgrades on damage or reload time are helpful, but boring.
- Overclocks aren't that interesting. I'd be able to forgive the levelup upgrades for not being interesting if overclocks did a bit more, but a lot of them are also just percentage upgrades... Double ammo capacity with slower reload?  I guess that's useful, but it really doesn't change anything interesting about how I'm playing.
- Needs polish overall (I know it's still early access).  I'd love a stats screen on the main menu that shows me previous runs.

And as I said at the beginning, you really never get over the feeling of being underpowered.  Maybe some people prefer this, but eventually becoming overpowered is my favorite part of these kind of games.  Perhaps I wouldn't mind feeling underpowered if they saved it for the highest Haz levels, but even Haz 1 has this feeling... You constantly scrape by, complete the missions, and hope you are lucky enough to make it back to the drop pod.

The 30-second drop pod timer is one of the most annoying / frustrating mechanics I have seen in what is supposed to be a "chill" genre. It feels like you are almost punished for killing the boss before you've finished picking up all the items laying around, as you have to abandon picking up all of the exp shards/ mining things and hope you don't get bad luck pathing your way back to the drop pod. Being forced to walk through enemies and take a bunch of damage, or have the run suddenly end because I missed the pod, does not feel good.

I hope the timer is changed ASAP, but am still going to recommend this because it's a solid bullet heaven combined with some interesting new mining mechanics that makes movement potentially more interesting / thoughtful.
Kiting simulator/10

The start is pretty good, but the longer you play, the more you're disappointed. Wasting a run to unlock overclocks - garbage idea. Miniscule stat upgrades as meta progression? Give me a break. Most weapons feel limp and useless. Very few overclocks are any good, and guess what, no reroll.

Rerolls and upgrade selection is also begging for an overhaul - all upgrades are just bland stat raises, moreover, the randomness is garbage - you can consistently reroll all your gold for gray crap despite minmaxing luck, and at the same time you can almost guarantee that if you reroll in a shop with low nitra it will roll a red upgrade that you can't afford adding insult to injury. 

Weapons that you can aim, the aiming is very poor - the dwarf rotation speed is very slow, with keyboard and mouse there is no mouse aiming, so you can't aim reliably unless you aim straight up/left/down/right. And it isn't any better on a controller too - I don't know how can you screw it up! 

The joy of coming up with some awesome build is so goddamn rare, it feels like you're feasting on scraps of stale bread when you manage to roll some good upgrades and overclocks. But you can forget about the most fun you get out of rogue-lites, when you manage to build an absolute beast of a character that's so ridiculously powerful it wipes everything on and off the screen, that game sadly doesn't have it. And how can it? Every level you're blocked by every way imaginable from leveling - the time limit is merciless. 30 seconds to extract, and every time you're forced to abandon huge pools of xp that just lie there, it feels absolutely terrible! WHY?! Every single time, even if you're doing well.

The boss of each level, if you're struggling, it's like the game engages in some sort of twisted sadism, ramping up the difficulty the longer it takes you to dispose of the boss, and at the same time, oh the irony, if you're good enough to kill it quickly, you're still prevented from doing some farming and gathering xp and powering up for deeper levels, nope, screw you, boss dead - no time to collect xp, get yer bum into the extraction drill, you got 30 seconds asshole. Fun - shattered.

The magnet pickup drops are so rare they don't make any difference. The shock spire overclock helps, but good luck rolling the weapon AND the overclock, this is horrible. 

The game badly needs a redesign of weapons, synergies, upgrades, overclocks, meta progression, christ, at least do a crude DE-balancing pass so you can make crazy builds at least based on stupid high stats - imagine char with crazy high luck, or +200% mining speed, or infinite xp pull range, or dodge. Add some cool OP items that you can find deep under that you can equip. Make em do something cool. Come on, breathe goddamn it, have some pulse! Add collecting all xp if you make it to the pod, or combine off-screen xp gems into a bigger gem and put it somewhere close. Oh and most upgrades in the support pod are utter trash.

Anyway, somehow the start of the game being good makes all the faults even worse - so the game has to pay the disappointment tax on top of everything else. I really hope this game receives some dev love and loses these issues. But in its current Early Access state I don't recommend it.
