A lot of potential but currently not very good for a survivor game.

I played a bunch of different survivor-autofire games and usually enjoyed them. And I played a lot of the original Deep Rock Galactic - time for a win, so I thought.

* The game has unique mechanics like digging and harvesting resources that can have a lot of potential
* The game is stressful from start to end compared to other survivor games, where your build might be lagging behind in early or midgame, but in this game you're almost always close to death and never own the stage.
* I've got my ass beaten multiple times on the easiest stage, which is normally a good intro to the game to learn the mechanics and get a feeling for what builds could work, but this was constant stress.
* There are no real builds. You just have weapons, and they get better. There are no secondary items that improve one stat and worsen another, that you carefully choose to follow a certain build, that becomes powerful eventually. 
* The supply drops are weak. One per level, close to worthless (except for killing elites) 
* No real RNG fun, normally you hope for getting one of the specific items you desire for your build so that you finally own the stage, because it changes the dynamic. Here it is just "meh, just pick the highest rarity and improve my weapon a bit".

I think this game could easily be turned into something really enjoyable, but where it's currently at, I don't enjoy it.

I am down-voting because while the game is EA and not necessarily a bad game, it needs a lot of work. I absolutely will change me review once (and hopefully) the game has been updated.

Graphically the game is solid. However, the classes seem to all blend together. The weapons are underwhelming, over-clocks are underwhelming, the bonus and level-up options are also underwhelming. At no point do you feel "overpowered" and able to blindly clear waves en masse. I was able to upgrade two weapons in a single run to 18 and I felt weak as the gunner.

Unlocking weapons at certain levels only to not be able to use the weapon's unlocked ability until the next round or next drop is a waste of time.

Maybe it is just me but the Dreadnaught at the end, beyond it's jumping mechanic, needs some sort of indicator as to when it is going to hit you. I've had times where the Dreadnaught vaults over me without a scratch and then other  times where he jumps over me but I end up getting one-shotted? Which leads me to the game-play loop of having to delay, delay, delay from bosses to mine and gather more. However, with how minimal upgrades are, even the % damage ones, you quickly get eaten.

As I mentioned before, it isn't a bad game. I did enjoy the few hours I put into it. It certainly has room for improvement and can become a great game. I look forward to any future changes and updates!

It's fun and by far the best take on the genre to date. Destructable environments and side objectives introduce a surprising amount of strategy to each level.

As it stands, there are just a few levels and one mission type, but I expect considerably more content to be added as this is developed through early access.

[h3]TLDR[/h3]
The game lives from its good graphics and the charm of the Deep Rock Galactic universe. Unfortunately, the game mechanics are often uninspired and sometimes horrible.

[h3]Fight or Run?[/h3]
Worst of all, the game punishes you for doing a good job. The more enemies you kill, the more new enemies will spawn. The many enemies make it more difficult for you to collect the precious minerals. As a result, you actively avoid killing enemies and spend most of your time running away to collect the minerals as quickly as possible before fighting becomes unavoidable. If you kill a big wave of bugs really quick you'll summon the boss before even discovering half of the map.

[b]If you kill a lot of bugs quickly, you should be rewarded and not punished with even more bugs![/b]

In the end, you often have to choose between fighting and mining resources. As a result, you usually miss out on a lot of minerals or experience orbs at the end of the level. That feels very unsatisfying to me.

[h3]Upgrades[/h3]
The upgrade system isn't particularly great or innovative, but not too bad either. Surely many of the upgrades feel relatively meaningless: +6% reload speed here, +2 movement speed there.
The "overclocking upgrades" have a bigger impact. Unfortunately, there are weaknesses here too. The upgrades are not balanced. Some upgrades are very strong while others feel completely useless. And of course it's those overclocking upgrades that can't be rerolled *sigh*

[h3]Progression[/h3]
[b]Upgrades:[/b] As already known from DRG, you can invest minerals to tweak some numbers like movement speed or damage. Well, not particularly groundbreaking game design, but why not.
[b]Milestones:[/b] The progress of unlocking weapons and classes feels good.
[b]Hazard Level:[/b] This feels extremly grindy. A little while ago I unlocked Hazard 4 and one of the biome goals is to reach level 55(!) with the Recon Scout. At that point my highest level for any character was 14. FML.

[h3]Rock and Stone[/h3]
Most autoshooters offer a boring, dull environment. The destructible environment of DRG: Survivor brings a new aspect to the genre. Thinking about how to use the environment to your advantage is fun and challenging.

[h3]Summary[/h3]
Take away the graphics, take away DRG and you'll get a mediocre game at this point. It can still become a very enjoyable experience if the developers fix some weird game mechanics.

This review is based on the early experience of the game. So like the first 5 hours or so. I am gonna continue playing because I survivor games tend to really bloom in late experience. So I am just reviewing the core of the game right now...

Again consider everything as 'so far from what I have seen'

General issues I find with the game:
- Balancing: tries to hard to balance things, making your choices useless. Basically there is an obvious way to go about things. Or you take the risk and hope for luck, but I haven't seen that pay off so far.
- Lack of settings: I haven't seen any options to customize your experience, for instance the 30 seconds to get to your ship, yeah screw that, I wanna be able to change that whenever I want to.
- Lack of consistent content: for example a campaign or maps (seeds for maps maybe would work?) that are always the same, everything is pretty much random. I wanna be able to strategize for my run, have a specific route, know exactly when and where I can get a magnet for example.
- Stats: It all comes down to stats, a bit too much. You got reload speed, fire rate, damage, and some specific upgrades.. And each of those is grouped, so you have to make sure you have the right group combination to get the most out of your stats. For example you have, damage for electric weapons, but it won't work on kinetic weapons. So all your weapons need to be the same group (electric for example).
- Upgrades: There is a chance you will get 3 useless upgrades to choose from, you have the option to reroll, but that doesn't mean the reroll will guarantee fitting upgrades for your kit. I tried a "reroll-run", so basically I would only pick what I really need, otherwise I reroll, that was my worst run. So you often have to pick upgrades you don't want, which means you can never have a "perfect" run.

Well that's it for the major things in my opinion, there are some minor things such as lack of detailed information and mining being overly complicated, but those are things that I expect will be no problem if you play long enough.

This is game has nice visuals and a good twist on the survivor style game.  However I have not recently come across a game that has rare, epic and legendary upgrades that mean so little.  This game is missing a key ingredient,  FUN.  I never once in several hours felt like a build was clicking, or I was making any meaningful progression.   is is a sweaty game from start to finish.  Every time the developers give you something, they take something away and enemies just keep pace with you all the time.  The fun of games like vampire survivors is struggling to a stage where you eventually feel bad ass.  This does not happen in this game and will turn off many players, who will not find it fun.  The bad or non existent levelling experience is highlighted in classes that have you stand still to lay down turrets.  You cannot stay still in this game long enough for this to be viable because, you never have enough fire power to make this work and have to keep on the move or die.  Another indicator this game has issues, explosion damage, enemies in this game often explode, but the developers in no way give any mitigation to this in class or a perk, or upgrade.  This game needs a massive overhaul to tune the game to FUN.  The levelling experience is pitiful and reminds of Diablo 4 and why I don't play that game anymore because it's boring with such small, meaningless upgrades and gear.

I'll go ahead and edit this into a more proper review later (maybe) after some sleep, but after seeing plenty of what there is in the game right now and as a big fan of the growing Survivors genre it can be safely said this is one of the weakest takes on that genre yet. The game has a long list of really poorly designed aspects with just some big notable ones being a lack of any meaningful upgrades and progression, systems that actively get in the way of one another, horrible balance, and an apologetically incomplete UI.

I do not quite think there are any issues that cannot be fixed down the road but there shouldn't be so much that needs fixed already to begin with. If you like Deep Rock, this isn't for you. If you like Survivors style games, this also isn't for you. The saving grace right now is how cheap the game is and I would still suggest grabbing it on sale or later if feedback is listened to.

I feel like a lot of the positive reviews for this game were from people who hit "would recommend" purely based off of visuals or the fact that it's DRG.

The gameplay loop for me has been as follows:
1: spawn in on haz 1 (haz 1 is the easiest difficulty)
2: run around mining gold and nitra while shooting bugs.
3: oh lord that's a lot of bugs
4: level up a few times and get some boring upgrades that dont feel impactful in any capacity.
5: HOLY SHIT THAT'S A LOT OF BUGS
6: run around digging through walls to escape the 20000 bug armada behind me and pray to god that the game plays nice and doesn't completely surround me with bug spawns.
7: An unreasonable amount of bugs
8: bait the elite into the supply pod so it dies instantly.
9: repeat until i get unlucky on step 6 and get fully surrounded and die.
BONUS: get a legendary upgrade in step 4 that lets me kill one (1) more bug per magazine.

the 3 issues i ran into so far:
1: upgrades dont feel impactful
2: holy heck thats a really rough difficulty floor
3: no goddamn tutorial
I could go on, but other reviews have summed it up better.

I'm gonna stick with actual DRG, thanks.

In its current state, I would advise staying away from Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor. Player damage is too low, the auto-shooter mechanics are annoying, swarms are constantly thrown at you, and there's no time to mine minerals on the level.

Weapon upgrades feel practically useless because you're not dealing much damage anyway. From Level 3-4 onwards, swarms can almost only be defeated with a supply pod or the Exploders. At times, I had to battle three swarms simultaneously, as even the basic enemies in the later levels have far too many hitpoints.

I like the idea, I definitely enjoy the mining factor that makes it unique from other games of similar kind. 

However, as many people have stated, the upgrades are mediocre. Increase damage/hit rate/speed/mining speed/armor. Couple of more, but you get the point. There are no combos, no unique upgrades to make a weapon especially OP or anything of the sort (although you can change damage type and add some modifications). The game definitely missed that in my opinion.

Some other things that tick me wrong:
 - There are weapons that attack only in front of you, which makes them really, really bad and a factor to never get them instead of turrets/other weapons that attack around you.
- Some grenades go to really random and non optimal places.

Needed QoL - when I hover a locked Class Mod to be able to see how to unlock it.

Heads up: there is a goal to equip four kinetic weapons. I did that and then I changed their damage to elemental because it works for me. Well, I didn't complete the goal. Shouldn't be a thing.

I do recommend the game though, I find it fun. As it is in Early Access, it is only natural to have issues. I am confident the Devs will work on the issues that come.

Pros:
- Game feels good to play, i haven't experienced any bugs so far

Things to be improved imo:
- Progression feels really slow (even compared to games like Death Must Die, where it also takes a while to ramp up). I think lowering level requirement to unlock new classes/sub classes is needed
- Let players use at least very first overclock when they reach level12 on a new weapon for the first time
- Kinetic weapons feel kind of bland, would love some better visual feedback on them
- Let us lock upgrades in post mission shop, so that players can work towards unlocking them during next dive
- There needs to be better variety with Dreadnoughts (one for each biome or depending on hazard level)
- swarm -> supply -> swarm -> elite loop could use more variety. There are many good modes in base game  that would work well with survivors style (like Egg Hunt, Point Extraction or Salvage Operation)

So far, I'm having a lot of fun with this game.

There's definitely a bit of balancing to be worked out, and I've come across some minor bugs, but other than that, it's pretty smooth and enjoyable for a roguelike. It can get a bit challenging, but leveling up the permanent upgrades really helps.

This initially seemed really fun from the trailers, but I was disappointed when I finally got to it.

I was expecting a twin-stick shooter, but it's not really "twin-stick". It's one stick, you run around and sometimes select upgrades. Everything else is automated.
The game is heavily reliant on RNG. If you don't get a good set of upgrades/items at the beginning, you won't be able to kill a boss and the level will keep throwing more and more at you until you die. You shouldn't be able to look at five items and know "Yeah, I won't make this run, may as well start over".
The bugs getting stronger when the boss has been active for too long happens incredibly fast, and they will be able to catch up to and surround you after around 90 seconds, leading to a guaranteed game over.
There is no real targeting system. Weapons aim at the nearest enemy, or sometimes certain extra variables are added. When there's one small enemy near you, and a boss slightly further away, the game will prioritize the small enemy for auto-target because it's always proximity based, unless you have a very specific overclock or certain weapons.
Gunner is just very underwhelming. His primary requires that you stop moving and look at the enemies constantly running at you in order to shoot them, which leaves you open for close encounters and flanks.

I would've refunded this, but Steam has the strict two hours policy that makes it nearly impossible to actually try a game to form a real opinion of it.
For a drg game, this is okay. I think vampire survivors is better. What they should do now is balancing difficulties and buff up some weapons.

English/French


━●━ Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor offers a captivating single-player experience in the beloved Deep Rock Galactic universe. Wielding the full arsenal of the famous dwarf mining company, players find themselves thrust into a reverse bullet hell, where survival relies on mastery of the art of marksmanship and the ability to navigate through the deadly caverns of Hoxxes.

━●━ The essence of the game lies in the fine balance between the destruction of deadly aliens and frenetic mining. The innovative concept provides a constant challenge as players descend ever deeper, facing relentless waves of procedurally generated enemies. Collecting devastating weapons and creating tunnels to extract riches adds a strategic dimension to the experience, ensuring that each mission remains unique and thrilling.

► Complex mission objectives guide the player as they explore the oppressive caverns, adding an extra layer of tension as the alien threat intensifies. The need to return to the capsule in time for ever more lucrative rewards creates a balance between risk and reward, reinforcing the survival dimension of the game.

► The bird's-eye perspective offers a whole new look at the Deep Rock Galactic universe, allowing players to rediscover familiar environments in a new way. Whether you're a veteran Greybeard or a Bluebeard, immersion in this beloved universe is guaranteed. Management demands it, and you'll love every moment of this gripping single-player adventure.

► Initial release during Early Access promises a variety of content, with 4 classes, 40 weapons, 20 enemy types, and 3 biomes. The complexity of progression through class mods, artifacts, and upgrades provides a depth of gameplay that should satisfy even the most demanding miners.

In summary, Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor promises an immersive single-player experience, skillfully blending fast-paced action with mining strategy in a rich and captivating universe. Dive into the depths of lone survivor Hoxxes and prepare to face exciting challenges and lucrative rewards.

ROCK AND STONE, SURVIVORS!

=====================================================================================


━●━ Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor offre une expérience solo captivante dans l'univers bien-aimé de Deep Rock Galactic. Maniant l'arsenal complet de la célèbre entreprise minière naine, les joueurs se retrouvent plongés dans un bullet hell inversé, où la survie repose sur la maîtrise de l'art du tir et la capacité à naviguer à travers les cavernes mortelles d'Hoxxes.

━●━ L'essence même du jeu réside dans l'équilibre subtil entre la destruction d'aliens mortels et l'exploitation minière frénétique. Le concept novateur offre un défi constant alors que les joueurs descendent toujours plus profondément, confrontés à des vagues incessantes d'ennemis générés de manière procédurale. La collecte d'armes dévastatrices et la création de tunnels pour extraire des richesses ajoutent une dimension stratégique à l'expérience, garantissant que chaque mission reste unique et palpitante.

► Les objectifs de mission complexes guident le joueur dans son exploration des cavernes oppressantes, ajoutant une couche supplémentaire de tension à mesure que la menace alien s'intensifie. La nécessité de revenir à la capsule à temps pour des récompenses toujours plus lucratives crée un équilibre entre le risque et la récompense, renforçant la dimension survie du jeu.

► La perspective plongeante offre un tout nouveau regard sur l'univers de Deep Rock Galactic, permettant aux joueurs de redécouvrir des environnements familiers d'une manière inédite. Que vous soyez un vétéran Grisebarbe ou un Bleubarbe, l'immersion dans cet univers bien-aimé est garantie. La Direction l'exige, et vous allez adorer chaque instant de cette aventure solo captivante.

► La sortie initiale pendant l'accès anticipé promet une variété de contenus, avec 4 classes, 40 armes, 20 types d'ennemis et 3 biomes. La complexité de la progression à travers les mods de classe, artefacts et améliorations offre une profondeur de gameplay qui devrait satisfaire même les mineurs les plus exigeants.

En résumé, Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor promet une expérience solo immersive, mêlant habilement l'action effrénée à la stratégie minière dans un univers riche et captivant. Plongez dans les profondeurs de Hoxxes, survivant solitaire, et préparez-vous à affronter des défis passionnants et des récompenses lucratives.

Really fun survivors-like. It seems like some people have a misconception that this was supposed to be Vampire Survivors with a DRG skin, and it might've even been better from a marketing standpoint, but the game actually feels unique. The point isn't to become an OP destruction machine, it's to make good decisions to barely survive against the enemies and to use the environment to your advantage. The fact that there's a mining mechanic in the first place should already tell you that this is different from most other survivors-likes. I also think the difficulty is fine, the unlocks system is fun, and the meta-progression is alright. The game simply feels satisfying and rewarding to play.

Worth the money.
The game does feel early access as it stands, but I'd fully expect cleanup by release.
Each class has an interesting identity, but right now I would not consider all of them of equal power. Certain things feel powerful by default, and other things feel HEAVILY reliant on good run RNG. Survivor games are always going to have RNG, but the slower pace of this game (which I inherently like) makes spending 20 minutes of grinding, then failing a DPS check, feel a bit bad.
Im not completely sure I love how players have no control of firing weapons after they reload. There are many instances where weapons may just fire into walls if you are attempting to mine an ore.
Also, I think the cheese of exploding bug chaining and dropping the supply pod on final zone boss are both too powerful. It feels optimal to do those two things on every single zone in the game, minimizing player option.
On the positive side, I think players feel constant agency about how to navigate/farm the map. The progression is fun, the game is hard, and the unlock system keeps you curious and invested. You can easily get a good hours played to cost ratio if you enjoy survivor games.

Pros:
- Easy survivor game to get into, super easy to understand. Simple

Cons:

- +% upgrades are mostly the only upgrades outside of overclocks (which means if you dont have them on your weapon yet your first runs are crazy uninteresting) and there aren't enough synergies to make it fun like Halls of Torment.
- Glyphid exploders in every swarm gets boring, since early on it's just about triggering the explosion then running out of range over and over. A fun gimmick at first but every swarm gets boring.

Initial impressions are good.

It's a survival rogue-lite, but it has some cool unique features.

As you move around the map and slay hordes of enemies, you also get to mine for resources that allow you to improve your character for that run, as well as unlocking permanent improvements for future games.

The interesting thing about the mining mechanic is that you can create your own choke points and manipulate where the enemies come at you from if you plan out where mine.

So far, it's a thumbs up.

I was worried after reading some of the reviews. I think they are more wrong than right. The gameplay is fun, the dive mechanic is fun (although the timer is a bit harsh sometimes), and the mining terrain adds a surprising amount of depth and skill to the game.

That said there def is a lack of interesting upgrades. Every upgrade is just a percentage of more damage. They have a few more interesting ones, like adding more beams onto beam weapons, but their seen rarely due to their rarity. And a lot of the overclocks are just shifting stats around, rather than actually changing your gameplay.

I trust in the dev team, but even as is, is fun for the price tag. Get if your a fan of the genre and looking for a new take.

You can find some seriously awesome combos. There is a bit of roughness to this game but this developer has dumped tons of energy into the base game, for free. I bet if this game sells well we will for sure get the same love. Even as is, I feel this a full experience game regardless, there is maybe some tweaking and polish needed in some areas. On the other hand even if they abandoned it as is, it would be a more complete game than most and it is in early access.

It's a good start, there's a decent foundation here that if the devs work on and accept some feedback they'll have a real winner on their hands. There's some things in the game that are sort of antithetical to 'hands off' auto-shooters, namely the fact that at the end (sometimes in the middle) of every level - you have to kill a named elite target. 

Now, in a shooter you go ahead and click on the enemy, in this game you are more or less stuck waiting on whether or not your character decides to hit an elite or not. I have sat in some missions for over 10 minutes just watching my goofball scout whif a cryo grenade at 1 enemy, further away than the horde behind me including the elite. 

This is infuriating gameplay - even just switching it so you always target elites first would fix a lot of the things that don't feel right with the game. 

Mining feels alright, the upgrades feel a bit like busy work but you can swap over the special gems just like DRG.

I've played a good handful of these bullet heaven rogue-likes now and this is the worst one I've played by far.

I gave it a fair shot of about 7 hours, won a good handful of threat level 3 missions; Sadly this just game is just a grindy piece of garbage with no respect for the players time.

I already dislike meta progression, but will tolerate it if the game is good. This is the least fun bullet heaven I've played AND turns the grinding up to an 11/10.

This game spits in the face of the players free-time by not only making you grind to unlock new weapons, BUT THEN you have to sandbag a weapon slot leveling up said weapon to level 12 in another run, To unlock the ability to upgrade the weapon with meaningful upgrades in future runs. *THIS IS ON TOP OF THE GENERIC STAT UPGRADE META PROGRESSION THAT ALREADY PLAGUES THESE GAMES.*

There's no meaningful player choice in the upgrades; The different playable characters all feel the same with minimal stat changes and a different starting weapon.

Sadly this game is just really boring, and the stuff touched on in this review is only a small slice of the poor gameplay decisions made in this game.

As a big fan of the original Deep Rock Galactic it really hurts to say that I can't recommend the game at the moment. 

The two main problems are that progression is far too slow and enemies are way too strong, and as a result, you will feel very weak at almost all times during a run due to your limited options, while other survivor games are more about finding cool combinations of weapons to become overpowered, this really won't happen in DRG Survivor. 

You can't really stand and fight, you need to constantly be on the move and running away from swarms to create pathways via the mining mechanics, and even then the enemies are so numerous that you might just mine your way into the mid section of a swarm. Further, due to the number of tough enemies constantly pouring in and following you, you will constantly fail at secondary objectives and lose out on precious resources, making you even weaker during a run. 

There are weapons that fire in the direction that you're facing, but because you're constantly on the run, these are much less useful than weapons that target enemies automatically. I know survivors games are supposed to be simple, but I think a fix for this would be to simply add functionality to the mouse/ second thumbstick so that you can actually aim this class of weapon. 

Finally, if you manage to get to the last part of a mission and fight the dreadnought, the dreadnought can very likely kill you in one hit. Most enemies just walk towards you or fire bullets, but the dreadnought has a pouncing attack that, while decently telegraphed, has a hit box that's very generous for the dreadnought and can deal enough damage to one-shot kill you. Add on to the fact that you're navigating through a swarm of smaller enemies, cave walls, and even loot bugs that can get in your way and you have a very real issue with dodging this attack. so even though you powered through 4 difficult stages of grinding, you have very little leniency in the actual boss fight.

All of this is described while playing on Hazard 1, by the way. I can't even imagine how one would beat a run on the maximum difficulty.
9/10 whether or not there is a deep rock galactic survivor is up to you

Way more fun than it has any business being. Runs smoothly, progression feels meaningful, I'm only 4 hours in and I'm only 1/30th of the way through the levels, I'll update as I play more but it seems like this will be a 100+ hours game for me.

It's really cool to see all the facets and lore of DRG translated so well into this style of game. It also feels far more strategic than other games of this genre. In other games you are mostly just kiting enemies around. In this, it's imperative to mine yourself out of predicaments and create funneling systems for aliens. Which brings me to my next point: mining is an awesome feature. Mining gold and nitra alllows you to purchase upgrades in between runs. Just like regular ol' DRG, mining for materials is also an important part of meta progression. All the minerals such as bismor, jadiz, and croppa are here and can be used to purchase permanent upgrades. You can also sell these resources like you can in DRG. 


This game is so cleverly crafted and implements so many features from DRG that it almost feels like DRG should have always been a bullet hell game. I am glad Funday took up the IP and Ghost Ship Games allowed them to do so.

As much as i love the concept of a DRG Survivor, It just doesn't feel rewarding enough to properly enjoy it right now. Mining is something I was super excited for, getting to mine minerals for upgrades whilst getting swarmed by hundreds of bugs was seriously captivicing for me, Unfortunately the upgrades you get from spending possibly hours just mining (when you're able to), is severely underwhelming, I mean maxed out upgrades grant you merely like 20-40% increase to the stats, which you can get from a single legendary level up thingie.
I'd say either make the upgrades massively stronger, or decrease the cost substantially and let us upgrade them a whole lot more than 12 times.

Build diversity is also severly underwhelming, every gun just shoots bullets, some with different damage type and slightly different effects, I'd love to get more upgrades types, a piss poor example is "on cold damage, has a x% chance to explode, slowing nearby enemies", stuff like that. Much potential, But currently Lacking

Ok, so I do not leave reviews very often but since I am a fan of DRG I just have to.
The Good:
- The game itself is smooth and the graphics are good considering what type of game this is.
- The controls are ok
- You definitely know that you are playing a DRG spinoff from the bugs, quotes, weapons, and dwarves.
- The game doesn't cost much.
The Bad:
- Mission control never shuts up.
- The grind is real. You are not going play one or two rounds and feel like you are anywhere for you power level. You will have to play many rounds before you start to notice any kind of true increase in your ability to fight.
- You cannot aim your weapons, any of them so you have to do a lot of kite work.
The Ugly:
- There is almost never enough time to gather materials.
- When you kill the dreadnought you get 30 seconds to get back to your ship. This should either be taken away, or increased to allow players to go and search the map.
- When you get to the last boss it seems like there are so many bugs that kiting is the only thing you can do because your weapons do almost nothing to the Dreadnought.
- Once a weapon is fully leveled up, it should stop showing up on the weapon choice screen. I don't know about anyone else but this to me means that the weapons is not fully leveled up. If it is then that means that the level up is a wasted slot.
Overall:
This is an early access game and I believe that with some work could be a great game. At this stage of the game though if you are not a DRG fan I would recommend holding off. When they final get the game polished and more balanced then I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes DRG and Rogue games.

It's fun and looks great and I really like the mining mechanic mixed with the autoshooter concept.

However I can only *barely* recommend this game. More so if you like DRG. Because as an autoshooter, it leaves a lot to be desired. Halls of Torment is $5, half the price, and a lot more fun.

The biggest problem is that the roguelike element is pretty lacking. Your choices are more damage, faster reloads, or faster firing rate. You get some variety in weapon types, but there's almost no mixing-and-matching to create builds which is what makes autoshooters like Soulstone Survivors or Halls of Torment so great.

The second biggest problem, and this is a big one, is that there is no autoaim. Which means the majority of your survivability relies on navigating tiny avenues between bugs. If you're trying to kill an elite, you can't target that elite. Even the 'target highest health enemy' pickup will work against you if you're trying to kill an elite which is lower health than another nearby bug. Being able to clear paths with autoaim is a core concept to autoshooters. The mining through rock is a fun way around this, but the game really needs cursor autoaim.

As it stands, I imagine the game will get very repetitive very quickly due to the inability to experiment with build types from what I saw 2 hrs in.

A minor complaint is that when I got to the end of Hazard 1, after several failed attempts, I was about to kill the boss when he suddenly leapt into the air and on top of me with no telegraphing. He did 100 pts of damage (more than half my health) and killed me instantly. That isn't fun. It needs a warning animation and an indicator of where he'll land, even if it is only a quarter or half second warning.

Overall it looks great and it's fun and worth $10. But doesn't measure up against other autoshooters in early access. Looking forward to see where the devs take this though, as I loved DRG. Give us build variety and synergy.

Edit: After playing a couple more hours, I have to say it is very very repetitive very quickly. Hope the game improves soon.

At this point I can't recommend this game over others in the genre, despite its unique mining mechanics it needs several months of improvements before it can hold its own. This review is after only a few hours of gameplay, and this is more of a first impression than a Deep Dive, so take it with a grain of salt.

Pros:
- Unique mining mechanic has you collecting ores and lets you dig escape tunnels
- Has all the same colorful and quirky style of its namesake
- Its a difficult game and feels more rogue-like than others in the genre
- Mission objectives are completed fairly quickly, then you progress to the next stage with potentially new objectives, keeping things a little fresher

Cons:
- The weapons and shooting are one of the weaker features
- Guns either fire in a fixed direction, at the closest/strongest target, or only fire based on your dwarf's facing (you cannot aim other than to move)
- There is basically a soft timer for each mission, which is too short to complete some objective types, which require you to move quickly all around the map
- There are not enough "magnet" pickups that drop, which combined with the level timer and the 30 second drop pod timer, means you will be leaving a LOT of xp behind
- The map is a little too small, and sometimes you will be forced into a corner and surrounded on all sides while your weapons are generally ineffective at dispersing large swarms of high hp bugs until they are upgraded
- Mining is relegated simply to gathering minerals and making shortcuts through walls, due to the requirement that you be constantly moving to complete the mission and collect as much as you can before you have to finish the level, you are very limited in how you can use the terrain to your advantage
- The upgrade system is uninspired and seems to favor giving the same upgrade over and over. Weapons have to be "leveled" up in order to access overclocks, which can take most of a mission to complete, and the overclocks themselves are bland and unexciting
- There is a real issue with the isometric terrain/objects hiding bugs behind them, and sometimes hazards like exploding plants spawn underneath minerals
- The bonus objective types are very similar (just collect x amount of something) and don't add anything to the gameplay
- The dreadnought boss is very bland and far too punishing, it can kill you by leaping near you and if you don't have enough move speed or are in a tight spot with bugs/terrain, it will take you out in one hit. There are no other mechanics to it than watch it very closely and hope you have enough movement speed
- The progression system seems to be based on grinding experience on each of the classes and gathering minerals for global upgrades, there don't seem to be ways to control what build/weapons/upgrades you want to use or focus on other than picking a subclass and "rerolling" the random choices in a mission
- The xp orbs are far too bright, and the overuse of bloom combined with darkened screen edges is incredibly straining on the eyes

Overall the game seems to suffer from the challenge of trying to mash two types of games together and ends up being somewhat mediocre in both areas. I think this might be a game to keep an eye on in a year or so, but in its current state, there are more interesting games of the same kind to play.

This game is very fun, I had already tried it in the demo which was also very good. The one big problem I have with the game is the difficulty scaling. The game gets very hard very fast and constantly has swarms of bugs around you, making it hard to survive and ultimately feel powerful.

Another thing I don't like is the resupply pods with 'artifacts' making it so that you have to first mine out the area where they spawn, and then stand in the ring for a couple of seconds. It makes them hard to collect and get the artifacts when the bugs are swarming around you at the same time.

The guns are also not designed super well for what you are trying to do. Without manual aiming, it is almost impossible to be hitting the bugs that you want to hit.

Other than that, this game is a lot of fun and worth a try. I'm hoping the devs will make this game much better and improve on it eventually to where it can succeed a lot.

Hopefully you bought this knowing what a Survivors style top down arena shooter roguelike is...

Or you could just have known it is in the same genre as the game that started the Survivors genre, Vampire Survivors 


This game has similar style, the differences though, are huge. 

You mine minerals, this gives you EXP and lets you reroll with gold, upgrade stats between stages during a run with gold and nitra and upgrade passives between runs with the other minerals 

Which means you will be farming

The thing is, you don't have endless time, you passively kill things and the time ticks on and you will summon the boss and it gets harder and harder so you need to balance the resources gathering with the killing 

Now DRG is known for destructible environments and this has walls that you can dig through, which lets you make choke points and avoid hordes

It means that on top of doing damage you need a bit of movement and mining speed for pushing through a wall while a horde is crawling up your kester 


The differences between classes seems pretty good, different flavors of damage and different specialties 

I had a driller run, with sludge pump OC and lots of damage and the screen was melting on hazard 1

The dialog lines fit and the particle effects and sound design are great 

People are spending 65$ on horse skins in Diablo 4 while more indie studios are creating entire genres
Feels refreshing and fun for horde battler

Vampire Survivors is one of my all time favorite games.  A dear friend of mine got me into DRG, and I loved that as well.  I had nothing but high hopes going into this, but the game needs so much work to live up to its potential.  

Starting with the good, the game looks, sounds, and runs VERY well, and I am surprised at how well DRG translates over into this art style and isometric perspective.  I really like how the devs captured the feeling of the original, with side objectives, the mining system, and even mineral trade all being integrated in a charming fashion.  I also like the integration of stage hazards, like the ones in the Molten Core, that allows for maneuvering the horde into them for a massive AOE clear.  It is a shame then, that the gameplay outside of these systems really, really falters.

Vampire Survivors is hard at first, yes, but it becomes easier as you unlock the many items, characters, and upgrades.  The game, and genre by extension, are all about the power fantasy of slowly becoming this walking instrument of death.  It is even in the tagline "be the bullet hell".  Yes, you need to work to get to that point, but the game is a spectrum of difficulty.  You gradually get more powerful.  Here, you don;t feel that at all.  The upgrades don't really feel as impact because the hordes feel more relentless.  I think the maps being limited exacerbate this feeling; as do the amount of rocks to get stuck on.  While the mining is the point, I cannot help but feel like it is incompatible with the Survivors genre.  

In VS and other spin offs, the movement is the key way you survive.  The hordes feel manageable because of freedom of movement.  Your weapons also play into this, with different types that also move differently of each other.  The guns here feel the same, I'm sorry.  The spreads are different, yes, and the different damage type system is actually really interesting, but the weapons don't feel fun, especially starting out.  Even with a level 1 lightening rod, pentagram, or garlic in VS, these weapons feel unique and get you thinking about different play styles and builds you can incorporate to boost their effects.  I just do not feel that motivation here.  

I am now going to be blunt.  This game is BORING.  Painfully so.  VS, Holocure, Boneraiser Minions, etc have a LOT of flash.  From the chest opening animations, to the unique sounds and visual effects of all the weapons, to the fusion/union mechanics completely keeping the player engaged; these give players aspects to latch onto to make the walking around less monotonous. this has a whole mining system yet somehow feels LESS complete because of the lack of the above.  Even the side objectives, which I really like, don't feel as frantic or interesting as the tasks on the new Among Us map in VS.  

It is clear that there is a deep love of DRG here, but somehow this game failed to capture all of the charm of the original beyond a surface level.  Despite this, there is enough effort here to make me optimistic for this game's future, and I genuinely hope this game improves into something great.

It's very evident when you start doing "well" aka killing monsters too fast, the level progresses so fast you don't have time to go mine for resources to spend in between levels. I haven't seen any other reviews about this so it might just be a personal gripe but it is something that made me close out the game frustrated instead of continuing to play. Positive review for now because it IS fun, but hoping they slow down the level progression or let you walk around for a bit longer after the last elite kill.

As a fan of deep rock galactic I had high hopes for this but as a survivor game I can't recommend. I like the new mechanics they made for a survivor game like interacting and destroying the environment that you're in and the graphics and style are gorgeous but that's pretty much where the pros end. The game feels super grindy skills-wise, the difficulty feels like it amps up way too fast, barely giving you any time to upgrade enough throughout the run and there's nothing unique or special about the skills (it's all your basic stuff like fire rate, dmg, armor and etc, I wish they had just added a few extra unique skills like literally every other survivor game out there that made runs feel more unique and fun discovering new buffs). The thing that's truly a deal breaker is how the Gunner's lead storm gun only shoots the way you're facing like... If you're going to make bosses fast af that I need to constantly run away to avoid being smushed, then make it so that the gunner class can shoot the nearest enemy or the highest hp enemy because as it stands I just can't use gunner efficiently. I have to rely on guns that shoot in multiple directions at once or use a worse gun than lead storm to target the nearest enemy which is so frustrating. Like great my Lead storm has fire dmg and is lvl 15 but guess what, I need to constantly face a boss that catches up to me within a second so I get a solid second to do full dmg on it before I need to run away again only to repeat this awful cycle meanwhile there are acid spiders flinging acid from every-which-way all the while stabber vines are just spawning absolutely everywhere and the swarms of glyphids are stealing my closest enemy targetting guns. Love deep rock, rock n stone, but as a survivor game I just can't recommend, just play normal deep rock unless this game gets updated (it is early access after all)

TL;DR: Needs work to be a good survivor worth buying. Its not quite there yet.

I want to recommend this game but there is too much holding it back from a solid rogue-lite. The time constraints on runs is more annoying then challenging. Having to waste a run unlocking overclock abilities takes away from the progression flow.

In good rogue-lites you are capable of clearing to the end with what is given to you at base. Unlocks and rewards just accelerate your victory. In here it's almost impossible to get any edge on the swarm without grinding out a ton of unlocks for steady progression.

The rewards themselves are nothing to write home about either. Increase Damage. Increase Health. Increase Speed. Increase Reload. You are given base stat increases that do nothing to create interesting or notable builds. The most chaos you see on screen are the bugs that explode regardless of whatever weapons you're carrying. The only unique upgrades come from overclocks. Which are limited to 3 per weapon, and you will rarely get more then one weapon that far in your time limited run.

Runs are simple. Survive swarms, Find supply drop, Kill Elite. Once your Elite is dead, you have 30 seconds to leave and you lose all xp orbs you don't grab. Your runs now rely on you rushing for kills and xp gains. This in turn never makes you feel powerful. Only just barely scraping by the required damage threshold to get by the tougher stages. If you kill the Elite too fast you have no time to gain more xp.

One of the biggest highlights is the mining function. You can carve out parts of the map to get resources, escape swarms, or create killing funnels for bugs. This is by far the best feature of the game and I hope they expand on this.

All in all, its a barebones survivor-like with little repeatability outside of grinding for unlocks, which you will be doing a lot of. I hope they add more to it but I'm a little afraid this is just a small Survivor clone that will never go beyond anything besides its Deep Rock Galactic name.

Played for about ~8 hours now. My main criticisms are:

Perceived lack of enemy variety – it feels like all the creatures are either running towards you, exploding, spitting acid, or acting as turrets.
All three maps share the same end boss, which becomes a bit monotonous. Each map has five difficulties; I've only unlocked the first two, and the boss in those levels has only one move – a charge attack that is easily dodged, making the boss fight super easy.
Due to the uniform feel of the enemies, the maps also seem very similar. Despite different designs and effects, they lack diversity.

What I like:

The weapon and level-up system in the runs is enjoyable. The weapon evolutions and overclocks are cool.
The variety of weapons, classes, and overall build options is satisfying.
The game looks great for an auto-shooter, and the controls feel good.

What I would like to see:

A system where, during level-ups, in addition to rerolling choices, there's an option to block upgrades, removing them from the pool for that run.
Definitely more maps, and perhaps something to make them feel more distinct.
A clearer layout for the unlockables menu.

Regarding one aspect, I'm a bit uncertain. On one hand, it's a funny and valid strategy, but on the other hand, it feels a bit straightforward. Around 1/3 of the way through the stages, a supply drop occurs. You need to clear the landing zone and stand in it briefly; upon impact, it deals a significant amount of damage. It's so powerful that it one-taps the stage 1-4 elite bosses and brings the end boss down to half health. Therefore, for a min-max speedrun, it might be better to call the supply drop at the end to quickly kill or deal substantial damage to the boss.

For a game that just came out in early access, it's already completely worth the purchase price and easily the best of the genre. It looks great, runs extremely well, and has plenty of content to keep you busy for a while.

Without adding any mechanical complexity compared to games like Vampire Survivors and God of Weapons, DRG: Survivor adds tons of tactical complexity in terms of where you want to be in the map at a given time, and a surprising amount of strategic complexity in terms of when to take certain upgrades and how to spend your gold/nitra between levels.

The only bad thing I can say about it is that the permanent upgrade order is pretty obvious, but that's also true in those other games, and I can't come up with a good way to fix it that doesn't reduce the replay value.

If you like this type of game, DRG: Survivor will probably be your new favorite. Buy it now.

A resounding "meh" from me so far.

1. It's not fun. This game is difficult and stressful. Other "survivors"-style games tend to have a nice flow between power fantasy and razor's edge success. They're fun but still challenging, making you want to try again and again. After 8 hours of gameplay and unlocks in this game, each run leaves me either feeling unfulfilled or frustrated.

2. Dives are too short for the progression path. A successful mission takes about 15 minutes to complete. While that is a great amount of time for this style of game, the entirety of that 15 minutes is spent desperately trying to stay ahead of the difficulty curve. By the time my upgrades and gear start feeling powerful, I'm already on the final boss and it's over.

3. Upgrades and weapons are bland. Perhaps I'm spoiled by this game's competition in the genre, but the weapons and upgrades available here feel lackluster. If this was an isometric ARPG, these weapons would feel right at home. As a "survivors" genre game, they're not very exciting. With few exceptions, you shoot bullets and throw grenades. 

4. The mining mechanic feels out of place. Each level takes place on an island which you will regularly skirt the edges of during normal gameplay. Throughout the levels are walls that you can mine to dig tunnels and find resources. This is a really neat feature, but I feel like it is implemented poorly, given the island level design. If levels were larger or even procedural, this mechanic would feel so much cooler than it currently does. You don't have time to plan and dig out a "maze" similar to a tower-defense game. Also, a surprising amount of the weapons are directional-based. If you're mining a wall, you're not facing monsters, and if you're not facing monsters, you're not attacking. 

Overall, the game is alright. It looks great, runs well, and has a gameplay loop you'd expect. Compared to its competitors in the "survivors" genre, I'd suggest you spend your money elsewhere. If those other games aren't hardcore enough for you, give this one a try, it might be what you're looking for.

On the bright side, unlocking weapon types by unlocking sub-classes is very nice, and gives incentive for playing as more than just one class.)
Cons:
Scout just doesn't feel the same, the wheelchair is lost ;-;

Overall, my rating for this game has to be 96 Exploders (9.6) out of 10 Dreadnaughts, although the distinct lack of barrels to throw into the launch bay does give the big sad.

I was skeptical at first, but eventually found myself loving this game. At first, I had a lot of the same complaints as other reviewers here: I thought the game was too difficult, felt too slow, the weapons felt anemic, and the level design felt boring. I played through two runs and was about to call it quits and refund the game, but decided to give it a couple more tries. 

After progressing with my character and buying upgrades, and after really starting to understand how the upgrade system worked, everything started to change. I finished a run. I leveled up a couple weapons to their overcharge. I acquired new weapons and upgrades as my character leveled. I started to feel powerful. Soon, I was plowing through levels spamming absurd quantities of bullets as the gunner, or absolutely wrecking the bugs with electricity turrets as the engineer, all while continuing to gain new abilities that made my abilities feel even more insanely powerful. I would say things really started to turn around for me once I realized that I REALLY needed to keep moving at all times, need to constantly seek out resources, constantly dive headlong into the enemy to massacre them for their experience, and keep going up until the very last moment before I needed to get back to the extraction point. 

All in all, I've gone from intensely disliking the game in the first 20 minutes to absolutely loving it. And it's not a bad price either. Definitely would recommend it.

A fun game, with unskippable intros. Well worth the launch price I'd say, more than that I'm not sure.

Here is what I know from some limited play today and previous experience in the demo.

As an overall look, this game doesn't play like most other action-roguelite autobattler games, it doesn't seem to perform the usual twist or synergy weapon dynamics that most of this genre use to let the player go from struggle of "barely holding them off" to the fast and frantic "armies die under my crazy magic fireball goose boots mwahaha!".

This game is pretty much all uphill struggle. Sometimes you level up fast enough to feel like you're getting powerful, but it never lasts long.

BASICS:
You move with the WASD and/or arrow keys. Attacking is automatic when enemies are in range/line of sight. Digging is automatic as you press against rocks or resources, though I have noticed that sometimes it will stop if you don't keep pressing yourself into the thing that you are mining.

You spawn with a side objective such as "mine morkite", which is optional but rewards decently for completion, you should find resources and start mining everything available that you can until the boss spawns. Small minion-type bugs spawn frequently and wander toward you, your dwarf automatically attacks them, they die and drop XP orbs. Kill enough bugs to fill the bar on screen and the boss bug will spawn and come after you.

Bug spawn rate increases over time and you get more types appearing as well, especially as you hit the swarm timer milestones. If you take too long to kill the boss (a bit too busy mining are we?) all bugs get stronger, over and over again until you squish the big bad. Once the bossbug goes squish you get 30 seconds to escape to the drop pod amidst the remaining swarm, or it'll leave without you.

Once you reach the last level of the run there is a big boss to kill

PER-RUN PROGRESSION:
Collecting XP makes your per-run level go up, each level up gives you a choice of random upgrades and every so often you get to add another weapon to your arsenal. All weapons fire at the same time, each at their own pace and with independent aim and reload timings.

Some of the upgrades make your weapon(s) increase in level, and every so-many weapon levels you get to choose 1 of 2 random overclocks to add (if you have unlocked them for that weapon). Sadly sometimes these limited choices force you to change your weapon in a way you didn't want, but even an undesired choice brings its own benefits.

There are announced supply drop-pods which will provide unique per-run boosts such as gaining XP every time you take damage, and otherwise-unattainable benefits. These show up as a circular ping on the map if you are near the drop point. Upon reaching them you will need to A) clear all rocks and other fixed obstacles in the circle shown, and B) stay in the circle until the icon fills, which takes a few seconds. The drop pod will crush and push back nearby enemies, then just touch it to claim your free thingy.

Between levels you are afforded a chance to buy from a larger selection of upgrades using your gold and nitra (the red gold), as well as refill your health if you really need it. You can buy as many of these as you can afford and don't be afraid to reroll the remaining options if you have plenty of gold left.

META PROGRESSION (between runs):
As your class' meta/persistent level increases you gain access to more varied resources appearing in each run, and more weapons are unlocked to choose from when increasing your arsenal.

Meta progression is performed via the UPGRADE menu where you can improve different global stats such as overall reload speed, mining speed, critical hit chance and so on. These upgrades cost both credits and some of the unique resources you will find on your run, though you can also buy/sell resources within the upgrade menu if you have an abundance of one thing and not enough of another. The benefits provided from this menu are both diminishing and extremely expensive toward the top end. Definitely a feature in need of rebalance.

OTHER STUFF (notes):
The timer (it's a kill-counter) feels very tight at the start play, though no doubt that limit will become much easier to work with as meta progression is achieved.

Unfortunately at the start of a run it is rather easy to fall into a cycle where you are unable to damage the boss because there are too many minions in the way, and because you don't kill him fast enough all the aliens get stronger over and over, leading to more minions which just get harder and harder to kill. Don't hold off on killing the boss too long.

While supply pods are incredibly useful they can be positioned in really precarious places that get you killed, such as surrounded by A LOT of rock which you will probably die clearing if your guns can't hold back the swarm yet.

Take note that if you don't like the choices presented, most choice options in the game can be re-rolled (usually at the cost of a little gold) before you pick one.

Gold seems to be the king resource per-run as it is used for more things than Nitra.

Some of the best upgrades to focus on seem to be reload time (until you have a frequent stream of attacks going) and anything that will improve multiple weapons at once (sometimes you will miss the benefits of these if one or more of your weapons were forced into an elemental overclock, diverging your damage types). But don't overlook basic things like armour, move speed and dig speed too, especially if a rather large bonus pops up. It's not all about the guns....well okay its mostly about the guns.

Lastly, if you don't rock and stone....

THAT IS MY REVIEW SO FAR AND THANK YOU FOR COMING TO MY TED TALK.

For me, the point of games like Vampire Survivor and Brotato is the experience of ascending to godhood over the course of a run, and then having the game try and subvert that power with a ridiculous amount of enemies. This game not only fails to provide on this very basic premise, it doesn't give you an interesting alternative either. All the potential variety the game could have feels muted, resulting in an overall boring game where you never feel strong and each run feels the same.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a Vampire Survivors spin-off from Ghost Ship Publishing and is a smokescreen in terms of data collection. Extensive data is collected for the title without users being able to object.

[h1]What Does This Product Do?[/h1]
Upon starting the game, various trackers and geodata services by Unity Technologies are activated, collecting comprehensive data from players. The issue here is that customers are only informed about this behavior within the product itself, by then it's too late. Data is gone. There is also an opt-out option in the settings (thanks to my previous review of Deep Rock Galactic, the developers learned), but this feature is meaningless for the aforementioned reason and users are still tracked with disabled ingame placebo options!

[h1]Who Operates the Product?[/h1]
Ghost Ship Publishing

Ghost Ship Publishing is a subsidiary of Ghost Ship Games and was founded in 2023. The company is part of the Embracer Group.

[h1]Where Are the Service Providers Located?[/h1]
Ghost Ship Games - Wildersgade 41A, st., 1408 Copenhagen K, Denmark
Google, LLC - 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, California, 94043, USA
Unity Technologies - San Francisco, 30 3rd Street, CA 94103, United States

[h1]What Data Is Collected?[/h1]
Too much. A legitimate interest is hardly present here, especially with the data theft occurring as it does.

[b][u]Unity Analytics[/u][/b]

[b]Config[/b]
[code]{
"analytics" : {
"enabled" : true
},
"connect" : {
"enabled" : true,
"limit_user_tracking" : false,
"player_opted_out" : false
},
"dynamic" : {
"analytics" : {
"shouldCollectAutomation" : true,
"timeToWaitForUserInfoS" : 60
},
"coreBusinessMetrics" : {
"enabled" : true,
"timeToWaitForUserInfoS" : 60
}
},
"performance" : {
"enabled" : true
}
}[/code]
The settings indicate that analytics for automation and core business metrics as well as performance measurements are enabled. User tracking is not restricted, and the player has not opted out of tracking (the player doesn't even get to know about it!). It waits up to 60 seconds for user information.

Users should note that these settings are almost universally active in every product with the Unity engine, without users knowing about it, let alone consenting to this data collection. In short, user consent to data collection is akin to data theft, self-legitimized by Unity Technologies.

The core metrics can be deactivated by developers based on the Unity license, but very few do so.

[b]Customer Data Platform (CDP)[/b]
[code]appid: Identifies the application from which data is sent.
userid: A unique user ID.
sessionid: A unique session ID.
platform: The operating system the application is running on.
platformid: A numeric ID for the platform.
sdk_ver: The version of the Unity SDK.
runMode: The mode in which the application is running.
sdk_rev: The SDK revision number.
session_count: Number of sessions.
localprojectid: A local ID for the project.
build_guid: A unique build GUID.
deviceid: A unique device ID.
identity_token: A token for identifying the user.
previous_sessionid: The ID of the previous session.
ts: Timestamp of the event.
t_since_start: Time since the start of the application in milliseconds.
os_ver: Operating system version.
app_ver: Application version.
rooted_jailbroken: Indicates whether the device is rooted or jailbroken.
debug_build: Indicates whether it is a debug build.
device_info_hash: Hash value of the device information.
model: Device model.
device_name: Device name.
cpu: CPU type.
cpu_count: Number of CPU cores.
cpu_freq: CPU frequency in MHz.
ram: Size of the RAM in MB.
vram: Size of the video memory in MB.
screen: Screen resolution.
app_resolution: Application resolution.
dpi: Screen density in DPI.
lang: System language.
sensors: Number of sensors on the device.
flags: Various flags describing specific features or states of the device.
app_name: Name of the application.
app_install_mode and app_install_store: Information about the installation mode and the store.
app_build_ver: Build version of the application.
license_type: License type of the Unity version.
Graphics card information: Including device ID, manufacturer ID, name, version, shader level, API support, and much more.
Maximum texture units, render targets, and shader properties: Detailed graphics specifications.
D3D11 feature levels and supported graphics properties: Information about the device's graphics capabilities according to the Direct3D 11 specification.[/code]

[b]Unity Collect Analytics[/b]
[code]eventName: Name of the event (e.g., gameRunning, meta_start_dive, level_up, stage_completed, shop_purchase, dive_failed, gameEnded).
userID: Unique player ID.
sessionID: Unique game session ID.
eventUUID: Unique event ID.
eventTimestamp: Timestamp of the event.
eventVersion: Version of the event.
unityInstallationID: Unique Unity installation ID.
eventParams: Specific parameters that vary depending on the event.
Examples of eventParams:
platform: Player's platform (e.g., PC_CLIENT).
idfv: Unique device ID.
buildGUUID: Unique build ID of the game.
clientVersion: Version of the game client.
batteryLoad: Battery charge of the device, -1 if not applicable.
projectID: Unique ID of the project within Unity Analytics.
sdkMethod: Method called in the SDK.
number_of_dives, hazard_level, upgrade, reroll_count, weapon_skipped: Game-related data indicating specific actions or states in the game, such as the number of dives, hazard level, upgrades, number of rerolls, and skipped weapons.
weapons, hp, avg_weapon_level, player_level, stage, time_since_stage_start, nitra_collected, gold_collected, secondary_completed: Data describing the player's progress, collected resources, and achieved game stages.
fail_reason, objective_state: Reasons for failing a mission or the current state of an objective.[/code]

[b]Unity Geodata[/b]
[code]ageGateLimit: Indicated with a value of 0 - a setting to define age restrictions.
country: The ISO code of the user's country, e.g., "DE" for Germany, "US" for the United States, "RU" for Russia, and so on.
identifier: A key for identifying the privacy request, like "gdpr" for the European Union, "ccpa" for California, USA, and "none" for countries that do not have specific requirements.
region: A more specific geographical division, like "California" for CCPA requirements, or blank for countries/regions without specific regional data protection laws.[/code]

[b]SDR[/b]
Review character limit. More information on the project page

[h1]Privacy Policy/Terms of Use and Opt-Out/In?[/h1]
Nothing is visible on the product page on Steam. Information about product behavior is completely missing.

In summary, "Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor" has implemented an extensive tracking and analytics framework that collects detailed user data, including specific events and configurations. While some measures for compliance with data protection regulations are evident, such as consideration for GDPR and CCPA, the collected data and their unique identifiers could potentially lead to individual user identification.

This raises questions about transparency and user consent, as well as the possibility of identification based on collected data, especially since these data are collected prior to in-game consent. An opt-out option in the settings is therefore meaningless.

[h1]Can This Behavior Be Blocked?[/h1]
Unity services can (and should) be completely blocked without affecting the gaming experience. The UnityCrashHandler64.exe or *.32.exe in the installation directory should also be deleted.

[h1]Additional Info[/h1]
For additional details such as a connection overview for blocking connections and involved IPv4 addresses, company details, and a German version of the review can be found as usual at [url=https://gameindustry.eu/]https://gameindustry.eu/[/url]. If interested, join the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/penguindome]Penguin Domination[/url] group to ensure you don't miss any reviews on Steam.

For $10 (relative to the rest of the games in this space), it's hard to justify this as a worthy contender.

Have you ever wanted to play more games in the Deep Rock Galactic Cinematic Universe (DRGCU)?  No?  Well, what if we just reused the voicelines, sound effects and sound track from that game and slapped a topdown view of it?  Are you interested then?

This game only really appeals if you're already a fan of Deep Rock.  I am, I've played hundreds of hours, it's great!  But this feels like a half-baked cash grab, admittedly only after a few hours.  Ignoring the difficulty being cranked way too high on launch, but it never feels like you're winning.  There's no moments of reprieve, and the weapons aren't satisfying.  So far, it's all bullets all the time.  Sometimes the bullets have electrical or cold effects to them, but they're bullets all the same.

Deep Rock Galactic Survivor doesn't hook you in with the promise that the content you haven't seen is fun, and keeps new characters and levels timewalled.  It's literally the same grind as in Deep Rock, except they were foolish enough to think grinding solo survivor games would be a pleasant experience.  You're never excited about the new gun you've unlocked or new character, and the zones just steadily get more annoying than interesting, so progression is simply a frustrating experience.

I played Deep Rock originally in one of the early access periods when it was a not great game, so I'm optimistic, but I truly just expect this game to continue to be a stinker and fade into obscurity in a few years.  There's nothing new here, and it's more expensive - go play another survivors game that's more fun and cheaper.

Inspired by the best "survivors" games in the genre, this brings its own flair and fun style to the mix, along with a heck of a lot of mining (both for resources and strategically), and also... DWARVES?!?

It plays very smoothly. It is similar to Survivor.IO or Vampire Survivors. Basically you walk around and work on your pathing and your weapons automatically fire at enemies. As you collect xp you add additional weapons and upgrade them in different ways and get powerups for your character. It is a fun and short gameplay loop, so you can play for 10 minutes or an hour. It very much keeps the spirit of Deep Rock Galactic and the same energy and vibe carries through. Just a different gameplay style. I'm already loving it and excited to see how it progresses through development.

Nice twist on the "Survivor" genre. Can't deny that.
Unlike every other of this kind of games, DRG:S forces you to objectives and being mindful of your surroundings since enemies will overwhelm you in little time if you focus on something for more than a couple seconds while ignoring danger. The RNG is not stupidly against you and you will have to mine resources in order to get them between stages. Honestly, at first I had a hard time but going with the flow of the game it turns out to be quite fun.
The amount of upgrades is not very big but grindy over the time, which resembles the upgrading system on DRG perks and weapons. Speaking of weaponry, one thing that surprises is them being attached to drawves' levels for unlocking and then being available to any run you do. It is kind of hilarious an engineer with a minigun and a sludge gun.
My only complain is the art direction. Why would they go for a "smooth" modeling on the characters instead of the sharp polygonal of the original game is beyond me. Feels out of place, although in the game the camera is so far that it matters not.
This is for those times of "I don't know what to play that is fun, fast and short". A solid 8/10.

Oh please, make the levels shorter please.  I mean, I barely have time to enjoy it as it is, shorten it even more, what I want is to not have time to build my character and enjoy dishing out some ass whooping in "infinite mode" or something like that.  Just make the levels short, so I spend my time starting from scratch.

It's fun but it's like everything in the game gives barely enough to enjoy, every time you get on a roll, the boss dies and BAM, game over.

Do I recommend it?  I don't know.  There's much better out there, much much better.

Try it, or not...  You'll see.

I got my ten bucks worth from the demo alone, so this was an easy buy for me. I will say the demo seemed much more fun and less of a chore, but there were a lot less options to work with in the demo. If the team involved with this game are from the main Deep Rock Galactic, I have no doubt they will consistently improve and add new and exciting things. As of now, you can definitely feel the early access. Most of my issues are small things that can be improved, and some are just odd. For instance, the Tinkerer class mod starts with a terrible weapon, a front-firing shotgun that doesn't really aim the way you are facing and shoots off to the sides of enemies you are directly looking at. However, on another playthrough, I added plasma as the first overclock, and then a shoot behind overclock and easily beat the dive. I think that's a big part of the problem with the fun factor. Some of the weapons are pretty terrible unless you get a decent overclock, and some combos will just kill you. There was a mission with the Juggernaut class where I just couldn't kill the end bug, because I couldn't clear the horde with his dinky pistol and a badly selected grenade, so they just kept evolving. A few other times, I've had to leave a mission with single digit gold and nitra, which felt wrong. Some weapons and combos I'll play and wonder if they were actually play-tested. I also have to agree with people about the timers. It feels you are penalized for doing well, because the mission just advances quicker and you have less time to get the minimum resources for a few simple upgrades. In a strange sort of way though, all these little issues make it even more satisfying when you get the right combos and annihilate a dive. The game also needs some different final level and regular level objectives. These same deadnought hunts will get old after enough runs. I haven't gone past Hazard 3 yet on any level, so I'm not sure how it'll ramp up by then, but for now the game is definitely worth the price, despite having plenty of room to improve.
Absolutely fun game! Slow start because you wont have any upgrades but becomes more fun once you can start killing things faster!

While this is under the Deep Rock franchise name, it's a very different game than Galactic. DRG: Survivor is a "Bullet Heaven" style game in that you control your characters movements and positioning, they handle the shooting. (Think Vampire Survivors)

This game is different than the other survivor games in that it's a much shorter experience. You go through five levels culminating in killing a boss. Each level is about 2 minutes, you then need to hustle to your getaway vehicle or get left behind. What makes this game different is that you're less powerful here than in other bullet heaven games. While you get stronger, the need for careful positioning never goes away. There is also the mining aspect of the game which is probably the strongest addition. Carving out safe pockets into walls can allow you to create kill corridors, or to escape being cornered. There are also rare minerals to discover.

So far I've been enjoying the flow of the game. On the first level you actually get better experience from mining than fighting while on the last level you're focusing on mowing down hordes of bugs while nimbly maneuvering around them and the boss.

As of now, and in Early Access, the game content is a bit thin, but it's enough to justify the $10 price.
