[h1] Lot's of rock, not enough stone [/h1]
I want to recommend this game, but right now it is lacking in content, weapon variety, enemy variety, and meaningful perk options. For the price this game is at ($9 on launch week, $10 afterwards) for this genre, there is a shockingly little amount of content. This game does offer some fun for sure, but the fun [i] quickly [/i] faded for me after 6 hours. I will be drawing a lot of similarities and points to the more well known game of this genre - [b] Vampire Survivors [/b] , which people are [i] probably [/i] tired of hearing about when it comes to reverse bullet hell roguelikes.

[h2] The good stuff [/h2]
- I do like the mining mechanic, it feels true to Deep Rock and allows for interesting terrain manipulation at time to funnel enemies at certain points, making a good run shred through hordes of bugs squeezing through a choke point. However, when mining minerals this can be tediously slow to the point where it can potentially end runs due to the default speed of mining. Even with the passive upgrade halfway to being maxed out, it still feels very slow. I would like to see the passive upgrade buffed or the default mining speed raised just a little bit.
- Non gun weapons, like the flame grenade, bullet grenade, ice grenade etc feel unique and fun to build for. I had a run that had the ice grenade with the bullet grenade, and that run was the most fun I had in this game in the near 7 hours I have played. Freezing an entire horde, then throwing a grenade that split into 3 smaller grenades that shoot a fan of bullets at high speed did put a smile on my face. The turret also gets an exception for the "non gun weapon rule" because it involves at least [i] some [/i] interactivity from the player even if it is just standing still for 0.5 seconds to put them down faster. The turrets have unique overclocks compared to other weapon options.
- Some overclocks are well designed and offer a huge boost in power and visual variety when it comes to non gun type weapons, i.e the grenades and turret. Most of them are just general stat increases, but some of them can really change how a weapon feels and can make a weapon go from zero to hero. For most weapons however, they are not exciting as a lot of them are "gain X% damage and lose X% reload / fire rate" compared to having a grenade that splits into 3 smaller grenades that shoot a rotating fan of bullets. I would like to see more unique ones for most guns in this game.
- Classes feel unique, I like the idea of having the 4 dwarves have different "subclasses" as it were, giving them a different starting weapon and passive trait. The difference in what each character offers feels true to DRG and I hope this gets expanded upon in the future. 

[h2] The not so good stuff [/h2]
- Enemy variety is insanely limited and very boring. You will find yourself fighting the same 3 to 4 enemies the entire time while playing this game. Every enemy is pretty much the same braindead grunt but scaled up to have a bigger model and health pool. Detonators are very annoying as they become one of the more common enemies in higher difficulties and can wipe you almost instantly.
- Stage variety is non existent. There are only 3 stages right now, but each stage you unlock will contain the same type of enemies you have been fighting since the very first stage. There are no unique stage events to break up the monotony either. Each stage pretty much follows the same pattern of "kill enemies, claim supply pod for artifact, kill elite" then move on. There is no variety for the final boss either. You will fight the same Dreadnought at the end of each stage with the same stage progression each and every time.
- The passive upgrades are very boring and offer marginal stat increases. There are no unique passives compared to Vampire Survivors which has so many options like banishing an item or perk from showing up for the rest of the run. It is all just "gain X movement speed, gain X armor, X health" etc. I would like to see more unique options and some consolidated. I think movement speed, mining speed and MAYBE reload speed should be condensed into one passive labeled under "player action speed" or something to make room for more interesting options like a banish, cheaper costs for buying / rerolling, a free revive or buffs for BOSCO. You could make BOSCO have a special animation to revive you with the flask with the revive passive or something like that if you want to make it even more faithful to DRG.
- Weapon variety is insanely boring when it comes to most weapons in this game. Most of them are generic guns that shoot bullets, with the overclocks for these guns not being so much better, as those are also just general stat increases for most guns. Some guns have interesting overclocks when you unlock the more unique weapons, but for most bullet based guns, they are basically just juiced up level up perks.
- Stages move WAY too fast. No matter what, the stage will always progress and you cannot do anything to slow yourself down to give you time to collect all the XP you left lying around or to do the side objective. You may become so strong so early that you will progress the stage too fast that you do not have time to run around collecting everything, shred the boss faster than expected, then the Drop Pod comes and you have 30 seconds remaining to do whatever you want to do before you are forced to leave. You may progress so fast that you are short on some upgrades for the final stage making it more difficult than it has to be. I would like to see extraction time raised up to one minute to give me a little bit more time to do the side objective or have enough time to be safe enough to enter the drop pod, as you can be swarmed very fast during these 30 seconds making it much harder to get to the drop pod. 
- Enemies have an insane amount of health and I wish there was some way to tell how much health an enemy had that is not an elite / boss. These big numbers mean nothing to me when I do not even know how much health something has to begin with and what the scaling numbers are like.
- After you get each passive to about halfway, it becomes VERY slow to keep upgrading as you gain very small amounts of materials, and they keep becoming more expensive. It almost feels like the main point of this game is to get all upgrades maxed out and then stop.
For my smaller complaints : pickup radius feels too small at base and the upgrades feel like they do not change anything nearly at all unless you grab so many of the level upgrades on them. It feels like I gain too little nitra. The common level upgrades could use a buff (2% movement speed is laughably bad, common should be 5% at base with the rest being the same, this is just one example of useless common upgrades). 

Overall, I would not recommend this game if you are looking for another meaty reverse bullet hell roguelike. You can get Vampire Survivors with all its DLC for less than what this game costs and get way more playtime. 6 hours in VS felt like I was not even scratching the surface let alone started digging. In 6 hours of DRG Survivor, I felt like I have seen most of what this game has to offer in terms of replay value. I hope there are balance changes and overhauls to a lot of this game across the board. I do not hate this game, but when you compare this to other games of this genre, it offers very little. It will probably be fun for about 15 to 20 hours, but after that, you will not see anything really new and have some sort of endless progression that Vampire Survivors has where you can infinitely upgrade any character you want with Golden Eggs. Once you get all the upgrades, it sort of just stops. It would have been nice to have an endless mode. For $10 at default, it is fine, but nothing extraordinary.

Finally the Gods have blessed us with this mighty fine Boomstick!
After roughly 20 hours and 20 different Bullet Hell/Heavens I can safely say this one tops most of it's genre so far. Still seems very Early Access, so the potential for it turning insanely good OR bad is there.

Meta progression can be a bit grindy, but it took me from dying to the boss to near instant melting him with any class once acquired.

You don't just survive the waves, you have to make it back to the pod before it leaves you, which has a random drop location. Being able to kite the enemies with mining makes it more interesting, literally held back aliens like a Spartan in the Hot Gates. Trying to loop back to the safety of the drop pod end of wave is quite interesting at times.

Level design so far is awesome, each map bringing new elements like lava rocks burning you or growing brambles that get in the way as you try to escape doom. Characters have different mods to earn switching up how you normally play that class, sort of like God of Weapons or Soulstone. This game brings a nice pace of diversity for how early in development it's at.
 I seriously look forward to seeing how they choose to enhance this game further.

For an EA 1.0 launch, this is pretty solid, but very bare bones.
6/10 for now, but I have a feeling they get it right during EA.
I'm gonna give some categories here for more info:

The best parts of the game:
1. Mining
- Nice mixing of gathering resources for the current run, as well as the meta progression
2. Voice Acting/Sound desing
- Really well done, endearing and often funny
- Weapons could use a bit more oomph though
 3. Performance
- So far so good on my main PC as well as the Steamdeck (a solid game for the deck btw)
4. Art-style
- Looks really nice and pleasant, everything is readable and understandable - from enemy or resource types

As for the meh category:
1. Weapons
- Some balancing is required, as there are weapons that I'll never pick for their lack of damage or utility
- Overall a good variety with some weapons feeling better at CC, single target or AOE.
2. Enemy variety
- This game feels more skill reliant than other VS inspired games, some more variety would help.
3. Hitboxes
- Mostly good, but sometimes you take damage from an enemy while there's visible space between the models
4. Characters
- There isn't much difference between them, other than the starting weapon. I'd rather have 1 character with a starter weapon choice, than the current implementation
- I do love their distinct personalities though!

And now the bad - needs attention ASAP:
1. Overclocks
- Extremely boring stuff like 80% of the time. 25% damage + 25% reload speed? really?
- Would really benefit from more unique choices, like the Spiral fire on some guns. Give us multishot, every 4th shot pulls enemies together, shots explode at the end of their lifespan, anything more interesting than 2 levels worth of numbers
2. Meta-progression
- Currently so weak and boring, I don't even feel it. It takes a long time to unlock stuff, and with the difficulty constantly rising (unless you want to only play only hazard 1/2), no progression is felt
- Maybe add 1 choosable overclock per weapon to apply by default, which can be swapped in the main menu?
3. Difficulty
- Right now, the only and best strategy is to wait for exploding bugs, and detonate them. That's it.
- Any elemental build feels the same (except cold, cuz frozen bugs don't explode, so... Lower damage), and the kinetics aren't much better.
- Since the player is so weak, I'll never choose a "Mining speed" or "Movement speed" utility upgrades, because my lack of damage would get me killed.
- I want to feel rewarded for making smart decisions on level up - Swapping elements to fit together, or avoiding it to stay kinetic.
- Maybe elementals should proc status effects more often (and stronger), but be unable to crit - leave that to kinetics as their nieche?

Overall, I'm leaving this installed on my deck and waiting for future updates.

Firstly let me give you some positives,

- visual effects are nice
- the overall graphics is pleasing to the eye

Now I must get to the unpleasant part.

- There are very little unique powerups. Mostly you get fire rate, crit chance and damage. Most special thing I found would be overclock changing damage lement which is not much.
- Staying longer in a round to get some power only punishes you by spawning more bugs with more HP. 
- upgare currencies are very scares. You have to mine nitra and gold but rarely do You have time to do that resulting in you just looking at upgrades (the same you get from levelup) which You can't afford.

This genre is extremely saturated, you have to make something great to stand out, this isn't an example of a great game. I'll start with the Pros:
 [*] It is DRG
 [*] The tunnelling mechanic adds something new which does make the levels a bit more interesting
 [*] It is quite pretty for this type of game

That is honestly about it

Now for the cons:
 [*] Progression is very boring
 [*] I have unlocked 3 of the 4 classes so far and 2 of them are really bad
 [*] Enemy variety is poor
 [*] Stage variety is poor
 [*] Upgrades are extremely boring

Let me flesh out a few of the above points. The game is designed so that you are constantly on the move, this leads to enemies spending most of the level behind you. The Gunner' main weapon only shoots forward making it pointless of most of the map. The Engineer is reliant on turrets that are only placed when you stand still for a few seconds, in a game where you need to be on the move constantly, this is bad design.

One of the things that made DRG so compelling was the random nature of the maps, that is not seen here, there are 3 or 4 different variations and that is all. 

Upgrades are extremely mundane, you can add electricity, lightning, cold etc to weapons. Wow, so original. Nothing like VS where upgrades can entirely change how a weapon works. 

All in all this is a poor example of this genre that is relying on peoples love of DRG to carry it. Hopefully changes and improvements are made throughout EA.

Pros:
- it's fun.
- looks good.
- Plays well on steamdeck.

There are some issues that I hope will be fleshed out over time.

Cons:
- Some of the weapons are annoying to use.
- When you "win" a level you get 30 seconds to get to the dropship. It's really quick, doesn't feel great. I think it should be doubled.
- Very repetitive at the moment. Missing some of the other bugs from DRG. No real boss variation.

I'm optimistic about the future of the game think it will be decent, but if you're expecting a top tier survivors-like game right now, this isn't it. Rock and stone brothers.

So overall I'd have to say that I'm enjoying this game quite a bit but there are some glaring downsides to the game as it sits in early access. There is massive potential for this game to be one of the best survivor-likes out there but right now, at least, they aren't capitalizing on that potential.

Weapons feel kind of underwhelming and there isn't much in the way of synergy like you'd normally see in games like this. Where other games change the properties of weapons or add proc chains, etc., , most of the upgrades here are for damage and reload speed... which is okay and necessary but doesn't add to the feeling of becoming overpowered like you'd want from a game like this. Weapons with a large AOE seem to be super strong, as single target weapons just don't deal enough damage to feel like they are worth picking up. I can imagine so many interesting mechanics and combos off the top of my head that it seems odd to me that the devs of one of my favorite games of all time (DRG) wouldn't add more of that kind of stuff in.

Classes don't feel varied enough in my opinion. They all kinda do the same thing, outside of driller which seems to be the strongest as he can dig through the terrain better than other classes. Gunner can barely use his chain gun since you have to be looking at enemies for it to fire, which is super awkward in a game like this where you can only look in the direction you are moving. Classes need to feel unique... otherwise why have different classes at all? Most of them are a few upgrades away from basically being the same dwarf.

Meta progression is slow and underwhelming... I mean yeah its helpful to do more damage and get more XP but where's the fun stuff?? We need a reason for the grind to be worth it.

Why am I forced to mine loot bugs? They block shots and make for unnecessary obstacles in the horde.

All this being said, I still like the game a lot and see a bright future for it. Maybe wait for the game to live through early access a bit before snagging... but I do expect there to be massive changes as the game gets updated

Preamble: I'm writing this review when the game was just released, so take that into account when reading this ((p)review).
I amongst many people, since the genre is very popular nowadays, really enjoy the Action Roguelike genre. I first started playing this type of bullet hell, action roguelike, auto-shooter type of games with Vampire Survivors, but since then bought and played a bunch of them, but from all of them Brotato is still my favorite.
I’m a big fan of the Deep Rock Galatic game, played it a bunch with my friends and also solo, so buying this Action Roguelike spin off was a no brainer, specially at such a low price.
What to say about DRG: Survivor? Even in Early Release it’s already a pretty fun game. Yes it is not that different from the other games in the genre but it has an identity of its own that also sets it apart from the rest. For instance, the digging for minerals (makes sense since this is a Deep Rock Galactic game) adds a layer of complexity to the gameplay. Should I dig more here? Should I scan for gold, etc and risk not getting enough XP, etc, etc.

The game is pretty fun, it triggers that part of my brain that loves mining, combined with killing bugs, what’s not to love? The gun variety is also pretty good for an Early Release game. My only minor complaint is that apart from the Scout, the other classes are a bit too slow, I think the base moving speed should be increased a bit.
The performance is pretty good, runs flawlessly on the Steam Deck too, which is a big plus for this type of games since they are a match made in heaven for the Steam Deck.
Looking forward to the next updates!

Something is wrong balance wise.  Enemies have too much health or the guns base damage is too low.  Base mining rate is too slow.  No immunity between taking hits. Armor doesn't to do much of anything. I don't mind the rogue like elements of losing and doing another run, but every run feels like a waste of time as characters/guns feel ineffective.  

I'd love to give this a thumbs up but fun I've had has been overshadowed by the irritations of the games balance.

The game showcases potential, but my decision to pass on it stems from key issues, including the brevity of each level and the limited opportunity for significant character development due to progression constraints. The frequent 30-second return trips to the ship, coupled with the fast-paced nature of gameplay, hinder the ability to cultivate a powerful character build until later stages.

In contrast to other roguelite titles where early-game luck can lead to the acquisition of formidable builds, this game relies heavily on progression unlocking, diminishing the excitement of varied game play experiences. Consequently, the game play experience feels somewhat repetitive, requiring extensive grinding before substantial advancements can be made.

In summary, while the game shows promise, its current limitations regarding game play structure and character progression may deter players seeking immediate satisfaction and diverse game play possibilities.
The game-play and especially the weapons aren't much fun right now. I'd recommend to wait for further updates before buying the game.

I really enjoy this game, however, I cannot recommend it in its current state. I actively despise guns that shoot to where you face such as the warthog for engi and the default minigun for gunner. I don't understand why the upgrade that increases the damage of status effects doesn't affect the Cold modifier. I might also add that the game lacks the any upgrade synergy aside from bigger number, this just makes me feel underpowered while playing it. The best run I ever had still made me feel like I was barely powerful enough to fight the enemies and still lost (skill issue on my part, not game's fault). I know this is an Early Access game and it literally came out 2 days ago so I hope it improves and the devs listen to player feedback.

I loved the demo at Nextfest last year and this has been if anything an improvement.  It's a roguelike so early on and in various stages of the game death is a constant friend but you keep trudging and updating.  It stays really fun at least for me so far.

A truly excellent entry in this sub-genre, far more interesting than Vampire Survivors or any other variants I've played. Where Vampire Survivors is essentially an idle game with almost no skill required, DRG: Survivor can be properly difficult. It's pretty light on content right now and I would have liked to see them come up with something more clever than the standard metaprogression stat improvements that slowly make the game easier. Enemies are a bit bullet-spongey,  the dwarves are a bit too slow, and I've already run into a glitch that ended a run. All that said, even in the current state this game is a blast and I can't wait to see how 1.0 turns out.

The Good:
I never would have guessed the survival style could be mixed with DRG but here we are. The mechanics are essentially all there and it makes me want to go play actual DRG.

The Dwarf:
Rock and Stone, for Carl.

The Unfortunate:
I thought I would have loved a single player DRG experience, unfortunately due to how good this feels as a DRG style game with super close feeling to the original... it makes me feel alone without my dwarf brothers (and possibly sisters, you can't tell through the beards...). The lack of multiplayer is a double edged sword in that regard. So, plus: single player. Negative: it's single player.

The bad: the camera gets a bit twitchy for some reason, not sure why and it can be a distracting/immersion breaking for me. Seems to get better when you stand still for a second, but often returns when things get intense. Hopefully they fix it down the line.
FOR KARL!

I don't mind grinding other unlocks, but the weapon overclock upgrade system is too much currently.

[b]Tl;dr:[/b] Although DRG: Survivor is a promising game, at its current phase, its systems, I believe, are not properly crafted to provide fun and excitement for the players to a considerable degree.

DRG: Survivor is a unique game in the genre considering the mining feature. In procedurally generated runs, your goal is not only to complete objectives but also to explore the environment to find ore veins to unlock meta-progression upgrades and get access to certain upgrade-related features. The game plays great, and it has an addictive nature. Although that is the case, [b]I found the overall design of DRG: Survivor lacking many features that would make the game great.[/b]

[b]First of all, I want to mention that it is not so possible to reach a power level that would satisfy your "power fantasy" needs.[/b] In bullet heaven games and the likes of them, I'd expect to be able to be rewarded as I choose correct upgrades, utilize randomness manipulation to optimize the rarities of random drafts, create weapons synergies, and in the end, after all that hard work, become so powerful that no single enemy can stand in my way. In DRG: Survivor, enemies' and your power levels are mostly the same, and it is not so possible to exceed their strength to overwhelm swarms even if you create an optimized build.

When it comes to upgrades in the game, they feel bland. I would expect there to be a variety of upgrades that would affect the way you approach runs, but that, unfortunately, is not the case. Every single upgrade in the game is a flat stat boost, and the only difference between them is their rarities that change their effectiveness. In between sections of a run, you are provided with a shop-like interface to get more upgrades, but they are of the same kind as the level-up upgrades. [b]I found both the variety and effectiveness of upgrades in DRG: Survivor lacking.[/b]

On top of upgrades that come as leveling rewards and from shops, you reach certain "milestones" for your weapons during the runs as you get upgrades that increase the capabilities of those weapons. As you reach the milestones, you get additional, more powerful upgrades. Although these upgrades are different from generic upgrades, they still do not feel unique. These upgrades either change the element of a weapon, make it deal piercing damage, or change the stats of the weapon drastically. [b]The more powerful upgrades in the game, as other generic upgrades, leak excitement too.[/b]

[b]Meta-progression in DRG: Survivor comes in two ways.[/b] The first is related to spending specific ores to upgrade your stats, and the second one is about new characters and weapons.

As you progress in runs, you mine unique ore veins that reward you with various ores that are used to upgrade your characters' stats across all runs. Although the system is great, the upgrades offered in this system are the same as in-run upgrades, and [b]the first type of meta-progression in the game creates just a separate layer of grinding rather than providing meaningful gameplay.[/b]

When it comes to new characters and weapons, I can say that changing the starting conditions for each run is good, but that is pretty much it. The biggest problem with weapons in the game is that they don't particularly feel great, and they don't synergize properly with other weapons. [b]I found the second type of meta-progression in the game to not add a lot to the gameplay but just expand the game with some additional grinding process.[/b]

In summary, I went into DRG: Survivor with great expectations, but left it with disappointment. [b]It is hard to suggest DRG: Survivor to anyone[/b] considering its systems not being exciting and its price not being in line with the content it provides.

DRG: Survivors is clearly far from finished, I recommend holding off on buying it for now.
On occasions like this I wish there was a neutral review option.

The main reason it sits at a positive review score is because it looks good, I feel too many people are afraid to admit it's got flaws as it is right now.
I'll update this review in the future, I can't tell if this game will end up being good or not.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1][list]
[*]You never feel like you're getting stronger and most of your early runs will just end in failure due to not having enough unlocks.

[*]Where in other Survivor games you make builds as you go, DRG: Survivors makes the build for you and you try to make it work, which most of the time will just end in failure, you need to fully upgrade each weapon you use at some point in order to get overclocks that make a run viable.

[*]The balance is all over the place, some things are high tier while others are absolutely terrible.

[*]Instead of set patterns for you to aim, the game aims for you and what you'll shoot is completely random.[/list]

Very fun survivor game with mining mechanics!
Highly recommended!


[b]GOOD[/b]
- Graphics are good! Effects are balanced, it doesn't drown in special effects like other games.
- Gameplay is very fun and polished!
- Mining mechanics is a fresh new take on the survivor genre.
- One run spans over 5 levels, which makes things more interesting. You have to think long-term strategy from the very start.
- Permanent upgrades and unlockables.
- The Deep Rock Galactic theme fits this game style quite well.

[b]NEUTRAL[/b]
- Aim/fire is auto only. This is very typically for this genre, but some games do have an option to do this manually.
- No dodge key. I personally think this is a good thing, but some players may miss it.

[b]BAD  [i](may be temporary, as the game is EA)[/i][/b]
- Brutally hard! You do however gain XP and keep the stones you mined, if you die.
- Limited contents right now. Only 3 maps.
- Lacks depth compared to other similar games.

Great game.

As it stands, the game can not decide whether it wants to retain its identity with DRG's gameplay mechanical roots (Grinding for minerals/weapons/unlocks, mission leave timer, Objectives, etc.), or implement newer/existing ones to better suit or complement the survivors clone style (Having an ease of access to more variety leading to a variety of combinations, fueling that addiction to try multiple combos). 

TLDR: This game has unique gameplay mechanics which can be good, but until it decides on its identity, its just eh, maybe get it later.

Bought this when I got the notification at work that it was released.

The difficulty curb can be a bit high, and it took me a couple of runs to figure out what I was doing with the minibosses when fighting the dreadnought on the final level to trigger the fight sooner. A bit more of a tutorial would probably be helpful for new players.

Otherwise I'm enjoying the game so far. Some combinations are just objectively better, but it takes some time to figure that out. Mobile turrets on the engineer though with the overclocked fire rate melt the lower difficulties.

Am I having fun: yes.
Would I recommend it: no, not yet.

It feels less polished than the demo. There's no keymap so I assume the only controls you have are WASD, so how do I dodge? I need to reach level X to progress, I can see that I'm level Y so how much XP do I have/need? When I swap classes, it's still showing the sub-classes for the last character I played. I can upgrade healing from 0 -> 2, what does that even mean?

I've only played a couple of hours so I'm hoping that progression is more meaningful than it appears. Increasing stats by 2% here or adding +2 to a stat that isn't explained doesn't make me feel like I'm ever going to get past hazard level 1.
It's worth the cost and then some. Fun time killer and I did the "I will just do one more run" 4 times in a row before I finally decided to put it down.

Regardless, great addition to the Deep Rock universe and Bullet Heaven genre.

I can't reccomend this game in it's current state. This game has some major flaws that make the whole experience awful.

1.The meta progression is basically non-existant: finishing a dive and then being rewarded with the ability to buy a damage increase of 4% or a movement speed of 2% does not feel significant at all compared to other games in the genre. The game requires a lot more variation in the meta upgrade choices or a new system of cool perks (example: every X kills you emit a pulse that knocks back the enemies or a % chance that elemental damage will spread to nearby enemies).

2.Difficulty: the developers are proud of the fact that hazard 1 is meant to crush you at the start. The level up upgrades are very generic and barelly make you feel stronger. From the start to the end the bugs feel stronger than you. 

3.Overclock unlocks: in order to unlock the overclocks for a weapon you need to upgrade it to level 12, but you are only allowed to choose the overclocks for it starting from the next dive. This means players are encouraged to let the bugs kill them as soon as the weapon gets to level 12. I beat hazard 1 with driller with no overclocks and it wasn't fun. Every single class should have a starting weapon that has overclocks already unlocked. Also, getting unlucky and finishing a run with a level 11 weapon gives you no reward and you have to start again.

4.Extraction timer: as soon as you kill the elite at the end of a stage you have 30 seconds to escape, which isn't enough to do anything else but run to the drop pod. This means you are encouraged to pick weapons with bad single target damage so you can avoid the bosses in order to get minerals. Yes, a roguelike where you are punished for having a strong build.

I will also give some suggestions to fix those problems:
1.Create new meta upgrades: bosco auto-revives, one extra bullet penetration, bonus % damage against enemies affected by elemental effects, a few free perk rerolls, chance for extra choice at level up, % change to double the value of any mineral chunk you receive

2.Hazard 1 is meant to teach you the game not discourage new players. Make hazard 1 easy and give it low mineral rewards and scale the rewards and exp with hazard level just like DRG (for example, Haz 5 in DRG multiplies all minerals, credits and XP by x2,33). It also feels humiliating and demoralizing to constantly die in Hazard 1.

3.I would personally tie the overclock upgrades to a certain ammount of damage dealt by that weapon. For example, the rank 6 overclock can unlock at 500k damage, rank 12 at 2 million and rank 18 at 5 million total damage dealt with that weapon. You would also receive an overclock in the middle of a dive if the damage requirement is reached so you are encouraged to use and upgrade all your weapons.

4.When the elite dies the game should spawn endless swarms that get harder and harder each second and you should have the ability to call the drop pod whenever you want. This way you are rewarded for having a strong build by being able to spend some more time collecting minerals. As a trade-off, the enemies could stop dropping XP after the elite dies.

Run around for 45 minutes, constantly fleeing from enemies while digging for rocks. That's it. That's all they managed to do after how many months/years of development.

Classes don't mean shit anymore. They are basically the same with a few minor differences like slightly more damage. 

No manual aim. Seeing some exploders in the middle of a huge mob? Too bad, must cut through the mob first before your dwarf starts shooting the exploder. By the time your dwarf FINALLY targets the exploder, most of the small mobs are already dead.

Overall, you always feel weak, slow and vulnerable. There should be a point where you become the danger.

In the game's current state, it feels more frustrating than fun.

There's little sense of a meaningful progression within runs and the build up in power isn't significant. At hazard 1, level 1 it takes nearly as long to eliminate enemies as it does when  at hazard 3, level 3 w/ upgrades. The choices between upgrades feel insubstantial and while there is some variety in the weaponry, it never coheres into a strategic set of choices with the upgrade system.  Given the lack of variety within the actual levels or enemies themselves, this leads to each run feeling flat and there isn't a wide range of options for the player that creates unique combinations.

While there are some interesting strategies surrounding the use of mining to kite enemies, at later hazard levels, some of these strategies start to feel mandatory and repetitive. For instance, at higher hazard levels, it feels necessary to use the supply drop to finish off bosses since it's nearly impossible for standard weaponry to have enough raw power. Certain classes are particularly trapped into this strategy.

The meta progression also feels off and unsatisfying. Needing to first level a weapon to 12 to unlock overclocks can be frustrating since doing this once can lead to a run ending and it's unclear why this mechanic is in the game beyond extending play time arbitrarily. The use of resources for meta progression v. run progression does create interesting tension. However, the actual meta progression upgrades are modest and do not have a strong bearing on choices within runs. I would prefer to see a different mechanic like the perk system used in Deep Rock Galactic or a skill tree with slottable unlocks, similar to a game like tiny rogues. It would also be more niceto use the meta progression to change up Bosco or modify the player's starting equipment.

At the least, the game needs to be punchier, with more variety and objectives within runs. Additional intersting procedural generation within the environment would make the game more engaging, as would more compelling enemy types. The relics could also use a rework - many of them feel situational and the starting set seems to rely on self-damaging (which could make some sense if starting players are taking a lot of damage but the starting set of options are not fun relics to play with).

The actual mining mechanics are neat and pathing the enemies is a really coolfeature. I hope the devs build on this base and find a sense of progression within runs & meta that leads to a more satisfying growth curve, with much wider diversity in builds and meaningful player choices beyond stat upgrades.

It's early access and that shows. I see the potential, but as of now the game is horribly balanced and just generally feels like a slog to play. Take a look at the discussion forum here and other sites and you'll see many people complaining about the difficulty/balance. Everyone is going to of course compare this to other games in this genre, like Vampire Survivors and Halls of Torment, etc, but even when those games first launched they were much more fun than this game currently is. I'd recommend letting the game cook a bit before jumping into it if you're on the fence. I feel like the majority of positive reviews for this game are just because it's Deeprock Galactic... "ROCK AND STONE" and all that.

-Progression is simple and pretty boring.
-Weapons and upgrades are repetitive and boring.
-The whole Overclocking/Level 12 weapon thing is again, kind of boring.
-The levels are all the same and... yeah boring.
-The first two classes are terrible compared to the last two and you have to spend a lot of time with these to unlock them.

Game just feels tedious to play atm. There are so many fun/QoL systems/updates that have been added to similar games in this genre that this game is sadly missing. Anyway, game is cheap and is worth the price if you like the genre. Hopefully it'll continue to be improved and I'll likely change to a positive review then.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

+ its DRG through and through, the theme fits very well and the devs cleverly used all main staples of the game, like the loot bugs or the mining

+ although I dont recommend it in the early access as of now, I think it is one of the more interesting Danmaku games, because of the theme and gameplay idea

+ the mining mechanic is great, you dont only mine to gather minerals, but to carefully carve paths and get around a huge wave of bugs, which is a cool idea

+ simple controls, only move, auto aim

+ the visuals are very nice


[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- Its too hard. There is no way around it, the balance seems way off. I couldnt finish the first map in Hazard 1, which feels bad, when there are 3 maps with multiple difficulties up to 3. Each one getting harder and harder.

- Its one of those games were your meta progression is the only way to progress. No matter what your skill is, the game will make you lose, if you havent unlocked more stuff.....I dont like it.

- Upgrades during gameplay feel like you didnt upgrade anything at all, which for a Danmaku game is one of the worst things to do in my opinion. Its all about stats, like 10% more this or that, but you cant make that out in the gameplay. Its worse, that I have the feeling to always feel weak or underpowered, no matter what.

- I dont like the reload mechanic. Its nothing but another stat that you absolutely need to upgrade.

- Weapons feel weak and are mechanically not that great. I know they tried to implement the guns from DRG of course, but it makes for some uninspired gameplay and boring upgrades.

- The Gunner is the worst character in my opinion, as he needs to look at creatures to shoot them....In a game where you have to be constantly on the move and basically run away with auto aiming shots behind you....the Gunner does not work for me. Even if some people get this build to work, its the one I have the least fun playing.

- Some weapons did not work for me balance wise. You can get a gun that shoots in 4 directions, but enemies are 90% behind you, making the 4 way spread useless. This gun doesnt even auto aim, which makes it almost useless.

- Its one of those games, where I wish it was a twin stick shooter instead. The auto aim can screw you over. You want to kill the mini boss at last, but your low rate high powered shot aims at a smaller bug that crawls infront of that boss.....

- You have no map and I lost rounds due to fleeing from the bugs, only to end up in a dead end, not being able to get out. If I knew there was a dead end, I would go in that direction with the huge swarm behind me, but there is no way of telling.

- You get a mission that can be accomplished for extra gold and loot, but some are way off in terms of balance. Collect 6 flowers...okay....but collect 12 Boolo Caps.....thats often times way too much and it cant be completed. Same with Morkit, it takes the longest to mine and you need too much quantity.

- The timer is too fast. You get a new "quest" and all of a sudden a swarm. If you take your time on a boss, the game will simply make the swarm deadlier, which seems kinda unfair and makes no sense in the worlds logic. Why are the bugs getting harder to kill after some time? 

Its not a bad game overall, it just needs more balancing updates. I can see myself playing this more than any other Danmaku game in the future. But right now, its too hard to enjoy.

It is still in Early access and I have not played a lot yet but enough to touch every mechanics. It is a pretty simple survivor game, no complex combination to learn or secrets to uncover in a large map. What it brings though is digging and that brings challenge, risk and reward. 

You need to dig to get resources to upgrade the current run but also the small permanent bonuses, enemies only gives experience for the current run. Do you risk digging and get cornered, hoping you will be able to dig through fast enough to escape? Digging allow you to make your own map and play your own way instead of moving around in circle or even staying in place killing everything with no effort like you can end up doing in some survivor games. You can dig a hole and force the enemies in a chokepoint or dig as much as possible to have a large area to move around in. It all depends on what weapons you end up with.

Currently there are only 4 classes, like the original game, and they only have 3 different kits each, beside the starting weapon most of the kits bring only a small difference once you unlocked most weapons for everyone. For example, the Engineer starting kit brings turrets and seems to have a high chance to have other "deployables" as a second weapon but once unlocked anyone could get the turrets as a second weapon. Some of the kits have passive though, like the digger first kit that allow you to mine faster the more you mine without stopping. Other characters can get faster mining with level up bonuses but his passive is a bit more unique.

Overall it's a fun survivor game that brings some unique mechanics but you'll quickly run out of content right now and it is a bit repetitive, there are only a few different missions and the fifth "round", the last of a run, seems to always be the same. At the current price it's a no brainer if you enjoy survivor games and wants more. There are better games and with more content but this one is a little special if you've been a fan of Deep Rock and dwarves since the original game. If the developer show this one the same love and support as the main game it could turn into a solid contender to the genre.

A mostly disappointing entry for the crowded "Survivors" genre. Pretty much every other game in this style has more depth, more monster and boss variety, more weapons, more spells, more combos, more classes, more beer and more gold. Ok maybe not more gold, but definitely no beer. Dwarfs like to dig deep, so they are not happy with this hollow game. It feels like the corporate overlord took one of his spreadsheets and checked the boxes to produce a game with "easy but addictive" gameplay for the easily fished consumer.

I don't understand how there are so many great survivor type games to take inspiration from yet the devs decided to stray away from anything interesting or fun. The games does perform well and is easy to get in to but after the first few runs, 2 things seem apparent:

- The meta progression is unrewarding and slow.
- Many upgrades are excruciatingly pitiful tiny stat buffs (e.g +4% speed, +10% fire rate). That is never fun and mostly relies on RNG.

The thing that made me want to give this a review at all though are the bugs. Although the game is pretty polished, the very few bugs I experienced are dreadful. You have menu bugs which aren't game breaking but very intrusive such as when you level up and die or finish the level before the upgrades show up then they never go away unless you restart. The absolute worst and easy to trigger bug is in the 3rd stage. If you go to the exit while walking in those shrubs then your character will freeze at the door and the machine will take off without you.

Even as an early access title with the potential of improvement, its just not enough to recommend. Fixing the bugs and adding more content won't really change the fundamentals of the game. I'm hesitant to say that the game needs a rework but that would mean making a whole new game entirely. The mining aspect is fun though.

Changed from positive to negative because of the amount of missions I fail because I'm just... frustrated with the design. Some things below aren't true after some digging, but I'm done with this game for now. I hate bashing my head against a wall for a meager amount of progress.

I've played a lot of survivor games. There are some things in this one I disagree with, but it's overall a shakeup on the formula. It's not a copy paste survivor like, it takes things from different genres. Which if you like that, it's the game for you. Has the same voice lines and a few extra from DRG, has the same music, and level design. Weird choice to have everything more smooth, but I suppose that's the differences with a separate team. Below is going to be my criticisms.

Game hasn't changed much from alpha/beta playtest. It still has the same issues I've outlined before, but somewhat alleviated by health on level up and pushing things away. However, the issues of directional guns have only been magnified by some guns shooting forwards. These guns are pretty much useless, given your face is in the rocks mining for ore most of the time. Imo directionals were always a bad staple in this genre, because omnidirectional weapons are preferred and typically outperform them. They feel awkward to use, and even more awkward here.

Meta upgrades for the most part outside of damage feel useless and needlessly grindy. Thankfully they took the suggestion to input the mineral trading from DRG, but there's still quite a few issues. Since most dwarves aren't the driller, they do not get all the materials on a level often. Even the driller doesn't always grab them all, since you have to contend with a hoard. This is also due to the forced "fastness" of the game, which is baked in. I don't like being forced to kill things at a certain speed, especially when the game vomits enemies on me. If you take too long, the bugs get stronger. If you miss the drop pod, your run is over. So many things adding up that I don't get to explore the entire level... unless I'm a driller.

Instead of traversal tools, most of the dwarves instead got a class. However, the driller did not, and thus becomes my most preferred class due to my playstyle. There is two ways to increase movement speed, movement speed itself and mining speed. Without upgrades, the driller gets up to 50% more drill speed. That's a 50% bonus over other dwarves, and the scout doesn't even come close, even with his subclass. Considering the meta upgrade for drilling is pitiful, this is a major problem for other classes. I don't want to play other classes than the driller (I like the cryo cannon, and it's locked behind a high level) due to this, since it feels like I am playing a slower version where I don't have weapons always on bugs.

Sure the difficulty increases, but I'm not sure if it gives more rewards? There's still some things that are less clear. Like how fire rate or reload speed interact with weapons that don't have those stats, or where duration is despite some weapons having this stat, but I don't think it's a meta upgrade. DRG clearly labeled higher hazard levels at the mission select having an increase in mission rewards for the difficulty increase. It also said where I'd find the special upgrade resources, but that is also absent here. The more information I have on things, the better imo.

Lastly, to go with weapon design, anything with penetration/penetration overclock is superior to others. I always take penetration overclock if the weapon didn't start with it. Also, the game has 4 weapons but due to the design of the upgrades, you'll most likely only upgrade 1 or 2 at most. The game also forces you to get a new gun to level 12 before you can unlock overclocks, which often requires you to throw a run away because there are simply not enough upgrade opportunities to get a gun upgraded. I often was doing suicide runs all the way to the boss getting 2-3 upgraded a time. A normal run you'd waste 12 upgrade points on a gun but use all the others on weapons with overclocks already. Which feels even worse when your favorite gun from DRG is locked behind level progression and you're already grinding out levels to get the overclocks on other guns. This feels... intuitive. I honestly think you should lower it to needing 6 levels in a new gun because you already don't get overclocks for the rest of the run. It shouldn't be something you have to kill a run over just to unlock something. Drop pods are also guilty of this (75% crit chance, 300 hp, etc.) where you have to force a stat to get a potential bonus for the rest of your runs from drop pods. There's no way you would get these normally, considering the gameplay loop is get main gun to 18, get secondary gun to 12, other 2 weapons probably aren't going to get overclocks. Another thing you have to throw a run away for because you get lucky and you get enough upgrades to go for one of these achievements.

While I added some suggestions to my criticisms, I realize that most of these issues are baked into the game and my view point might not be everyone's. I do like fast paced survivor likes, but I never felt like I was missing out on meta progression before because the game is moving too fast. I also never quite so violently disliked gun's directional attack more than I do here because if it's pointing forwards then it's not shooting most of the time while I'm mining. Since my post before might have been absorbed into the forums and forgotten, hopefully here my voice is heard.

Been seeing negative reviews about how the game is boring and bland in comparison to other rouge-lite/top-down shooters- this game lacks complexity and over the top building, you don't feel overpowered, yadda yadda... 

I just want to say, complexity and a ton of extra mechanics isn't necessary for every game ever. Can they make games better? Sure. But there's nothing wrong simplicity in video games either. Frankly, a lot of players AND devs these days thinks making a overly complex game is how you make a good game and I'm really sick of it. 

This game is very simple and basic, upgrades are pretty straightforward and streamlined, and all you really do at the end is kite around while killing bugs from the beginning to kiting around and absolutely shredding or nuking bugs at the end. I see something with more legs than two, that thing will be dead in a matter of seconds and that gets my serotonin going awooga. Drop in, start from being a greenbeard that dies on stage one of Haz 1, become a greybeard that could even potentially compete with Karl himself at the end of Haz 5. Bonus points for the fact you can press V to RnS!

Simple games are fun. Simple games are good. Simple games are fine. If you want more complex rouge-lites, then there's plenty of other games to play. This is not one of them and that's perfectly okay. I'm personally happy to play something that's incredibly basic at its core and stays that way from beginning to end, very much like Deep Rock Galactic itself. That said, I'll be off to dip my gunk seeds in liquid morkite. Rock and Stone!

I will spare you of a long explanation.

- This is more like Gerty than Vampire Survivors.
- There is no multiplayer. You're going to have to wait for DRG Rogue Core for that.
- If you played the demo, you'll notice that the game has become harder and the grinding for upgrades will be a lot longer.
- Supply Pods now require cleaning of the landing zone before arriving. A bit annoying at first but manageable once you get some upgrades and/or know how to make the bugs clean the area for you.
- The bosses at the end of each one the 5 stages of the run have a "Stonger Enemies and Spawn new Enemies" Trigger during their battles. You can't take your time to kill them anymore and this trigger can be activated multiple times.
- There's still a chance that you will die on the first floor of the first stage on Hazard 1 more than once (The devs have slightly nerfed Haz 1 difficulty on Feb 15th). Don't get frustrated with that.
- Cryo is OP.
- Lootbugs can only be killed with the Pickaxe. They will block your shots and WILL block your path while the Dreadnought prepares their 100+ damage jumping attack.
- Golden Lootbugs are really rare in this game.

I think these are the most important things to know before buying. i suggest waiting for the game to leave Early Access if more than one of those keypoints bother you. I will update this review if anything changes.

There's... something here. I'm tenuously reccomending it, because I enjoyed it Enough. If you're new to the garlic-like/bullet heaven/survivors genre then you'll probably enjoy it well enough. If you're an Aficionado so to speak then you might end up dissapointed.

I like the destructible terrain, it creates interesting decisions and fits thematically. I also like the mining aspect, again, sort've gives you something to think about; do you have time to mine that gold or are the enemies trailing you going to catch up? Side missions are nice but ultimately I feel like they tend to take you away from the action. All in all a very active survivors game, something taht I think a lot of people will enjoy; I know I tend to get pretty bored partway through survivors runs once I start mulching everything. You're definitely running around and exploring in this game moreso then most survivors games.

Downsides... weapons and artifacts. Which are most of the upgrades in the game at current. I realize they were taking weapons from DRG, but something needs to be done to make them more interesting. The majority of them are "fire bullets at this angle", and it's just not very interesting. Similarly artifacts don't really seem to synergize with much of anything. I was expecting to be able to make a "cold build" or whatever, but the artifact synergies just aren't there. I think there's a lot to be done here in particular; I like the xp/nitra/gold scanners but it's just sort've boring. Would be neat to see an artifact that increases damage based on terrain mined or something. That sort've thing. Also in general there is just a lot of polish to be done. I'm confident it will get done, but expect to see placeholder text in some mostly cosmetic places, and some missing punctuation. It's not a huge deal.

It's got potential, it's in early access. I'd wait for a sale or updates, unless you're cutting your teeth on the genre, which you might be if you're coming from DRG.

A fun bullet-heaven made even better by the mining and terrain destruction mechanics adding an extra layer to the familiar gameplay, along with all of the DRG goodness. Definitely more "Brotato" than "Vampire Survivors", so keep that in mind. Kind of limited right now in terms of maps (three) and missions (just the one), but I'm excited to see how the game progresses through its early access period. All of our favorite classes and weapons are here, so I can't wait to see what's next.
Would love to see full Steam Deck Support, too. The game is playable on deck, but the UI certainly needs some adjusting. Or just add a UI scaling option, that'll work too. This genre is meant to be played on deck.

this genre is as oversaturated as are soulslikes or games with the "rogue" tag in general
but i got to admit
this one is still fun
the mining, side objectives and the progression are all very well done
also the scenario is just great. it's an established IP, but it's also sci-fi (thankfully)
the OST is okay, the VO is great, the gameplay is snappy and responive and the game runs pretty well, even when the screen is full of bugs (the creepers, not the code-ones)

however and this is a big caviat:
beeing EA or not, this one is as buggy as a game can be
soundeffects hanging, objectives not spawning, getting dropped in the void beneath the map
weapons not working or passive buffs: you name it, this EA got it

if you can look past this obviously pretty rocky state you still get a great little game
i'd recommend waiting however, waiting to see if these pretty in your face bugs get ironed out
tbh. with some of em, like the hanging sound, you gotta wonder how they didn't catch it before EA release...which makes you think.

Incredible fun! Such an awesome take on the survivor style game; the different objectives and resource gathering add a great amount of value to depth present with the four different character classes and myriad weapons. Great replayability here.

Unfortunately, it just can't hold a candle to others in the genre. It has a cool gimmick with the mining, but everything else is just mehhh

- Weapons are boring as hell - Shoot bullets in a straight line! Shoot electric bullets in a straight line! Shoot bullets in 4 straight lines! Shoot bullets in a horizontal line! Shoot one big bullet! Its so uninspired. 

- Upgrades are boring +% damage/fire rate/reload speed. No synergies or interesting status effect combos. Weapons have an overclock you can pick every 6 levels, but those are also for the most part stupidly boring like simply converting damage type or +% more damage but -% reload speed!!!!

- Meta progression is a joke honestly, multiple runs to get a +2% xp buff, fuck off

- The game just feels really... empty and unfinished? I know its early access, but it feels like its missing so much. You can't hover over anything for more information, you can't make the minimap larger (or anything even close to QoL options), you can't see ores on the map, you can't separate the direction in which you are moving and which you are shooting/mining, which is a big deal because some weapons only work from the front or from the back, making them extremely fucking clunky and unfun to use. There isn't even a dedicated rock and stone button, or if there was, I couldn't find it, because there is no options menu to rebind any key.

As someone who is a connoisseur of this genre, I just can't justify this price tag.
Great game                           Rock and ... :)          would be better multiplayer
For the price, well worth it !

It's an okay game, but it's a very basic survivor game with mining being the unique feature. Don't expect a ton of different unique weapons and powers. It's just assault rifle, shotgun, pistol, grenade, minigun, etc. It just doesn't have that addicting gameplay loop of other survivor games.

I don't often leave reviews but I'm seeing some negative feedback on this one and figured I'd throw in my two cents, or two "stones" rather.

Firstly, it's in early access and already provides that satisfying autoshooter loop we've come to love from hit titles like "Vampire Survivors" and for what it has on offer it's been a real treat. We have out of the box:

4 classic dwarves we've come to love from the DRG franchise with their own weapons and unique passives, lots of unlock-able artifacts that alter your playstyle for each dive, 3 unique biomes that are different from one another and challenge your playstyle, and the mining aspect we've all come to love from the original game.

Progression feels fair, builds feel satisfying as you level, each Dwarf (class) has progression that changes starting equipment/passives, and you have your overall account progression that helps every run going forward. On top of that, we can see our Dwarves individual levels, an account level (who doesn't love seeing their progress?) and milestones that further show off your progression while giving you unlocks for each run. 

Is it perfect? No, their needs to be more mission variety and objectives to spice up the runs. It would also be amazing if we could unlock cosmetics similar to the original game. But for what you're getting at this asking price it's an easy recommendation if you like these types of games. Also, we know these developers care and go the extra "rock and stone" mile so just look at their tentative road-map and think how big this game will be down the road.

Vote with your wallet, support these devs, and dive you dwarves!

boy this game is hard to enjoy!!! all of the charm of the original game feels totally stripped out. secondary minerals ubiquitously grow in stone and have a homogenized "ore growing out of stone" look which is very boring. class skills are stripped down to the bone - scout doesn't seem to possess a grapple at all, though maybe I just haven't unlocked it yet. on that, EVERYTHING is behind unlocks. to start you get scout, one gun, one map. unlocks are steady but feel unimpactful, and it's hard to tell how to unlock certain things, like other classes.

I probably wouldn't be as frustrated with that as I am if the game felt fun but boy does it not do that. the gameplay is slowly doddering around, running into walls to mine things and having your dwarf shoot for you, usually with confusing/frustrating targeting priority. it's really annoying to be getting shit from mission control about not clearing bugs quick enough when it's genuinely entirely out of my hands. when you see yourself getting surrounded, that's it, you have done all you can. there's no clever tricks or abilities to use to get around/through bugs, it's just stand there and hope the guns on your head shoot a hole through the bugs (they won't).

 a lot of the voice lines in DRG:S are reused from the base game too, and the environment of crystal caverns is stripped down to what's necessary to communicate information and nothing more. a blown-out jpg of a shock crystal stretched across the skybox would be more interesting than the black nothingness. oh yeah and the meta-progression is SLOW AS FUCK and NOT AT ALL INTERESTING. do a whole run for +2% xp in runs. great wow very cool. I really wanna like this game but I don't atm, who knows maybe I'm rageposting and in thirty hours I'll revisit this review like actually there is something here but god, I doubt it, I've got better games to play like Deep Rock Galactic (which regularly goes on sale for this game's base price so just wait for that instead imo tbph)

oh yeah also there's no independent look/move for the gunner which is so fucking annoying and would completely solve the class for me but instead I hate it

I've played this a fair bit now and rather than me being driven by fun, it was more me being driven by curiosity and the hope of finding something interesting in this game. 

-Every single dive is and feels the same but different biome. 
-The game looks really Really good, probably the best looking in the genre IMO. 
-The only classes that feel the slightest bit unique is Driller and Engineer.
-Weapons feel weak, even if you are shredding some of the swarm, it still feels underwhelming. 
-There's a clear "take this weapon or lose" choice (or lack thereof) in this game. Which will deter people from experimenting with other weapons. 
-Stat Progression barely adds anything, it's boring, slow and feels meaningless. 
-Unlocking an overclock for a weapon is done in such an unfun way, i wonder if the devs played their own game. 

Do hazard levels do anything? i wen't up to H3 and i genuinely didn't feel a difference between H1 and H3. 


Weapon variety is also lackluster. The game suffers from being too grounded in Deep Rock Galactic. While, of course, it's nice to see all the weapons from DRG, they should've added more unique weapons/gadgets to the game. The overclocks are uninteresting and most of them are either just stat upgrades ie: '25% dmg 25% fire rate' or an elemental effect that all kinda do the same thing ie: Fire damage, plasma(itbounceswhooooo...) and acid. The Worst part is the crappy overclocks that give IE: '100% damage but -50% fire rate.' it's such a huge draw back that you basically gain zero DPS benefit from taking this.

The game has the potential to be the best in the survivor genre, but my love for DRG is not gonna make me see this game through rose-tinted glasses. (nor do i care if some mad nerd is giving me free steam points)

I'm giving this a very hesitant Thumbs-Up. It's a rather good implementation of the Vampire Survivors or "survivor-like auto-shooter" genre, considering it status as day 1 Early Access. 

But it doesn't contribute anything really new/unique to the genre, other than mining/digging terrain, which isn't a very gratifying part of the gameplay overall anyway. 

And it lost everything that made DRG great in the first place:
* Significantly different gunplay mechanics between loadouts (e.g. Sticky Flames, GK2 Electrifying Reload, PGL Hyperprop)
* Synergistic Teamwork
* Terrain traversal 
* Multitasking / Task Stack
* Ammo Considerations

I was really hoping this game would have taken some notes from Helldivers, Hades, Moonlighter, or Children of Morta or others in the Isometric Action Shooter/Slasher genre
Best of the roguelike shoot 'em ups that I've played even in early access.

Having played the beta version, I'm saddened to see that the core gameplay loop has only gotten worse. The enemies are extremely over-juiced in strength and number, and the upgrade progression is still very slow for the benefits received, even more so due to the fact that you will mostly be too busy running for your life to collect any meaningful amount of resources during the average stage.

Unfortunately, I just can't recommend this game in its current state.

After putting some time into this game and getting curbstomped at every opportunity I think I can say it's not worth it [b]at the moment.[/b] I have hope that the developers will fix a lot of the issues the game is dealing with in the future, but for right now the balancing is near awful and you will run into a wall sooner or later, with my wall being the Dreadnought at the end of EVERY mission that will chase you down while more and more bugs come pouring in until the Dreadnought lands a charge on you that you couldn't dodge either because of a wall to your right, or a horde of exploders that would kill you even faster to your left, or the end of the map in front of you. As I'm writing this review one of those "Watch the Developers Play!" is going on and the dude's died like-- twice while writing this.

There are also a lot of things missing from the base DRG that really make no sense to me, with NO verticallity to caves, not even so much as a ramp you can walk on, NO unique aspects to classes barring the weapons they get since your meta upgrades are universal, and worst of all: No Rock and Stone button. Joking with that last one of course, but it feels like one of those games that got bought up at the last second and got a coat of paint to disguise what it initially was, like that Starfox game for the Gamecube, which even though I know is not the case, I can't really shake considering how little the game actually pulls from DRG.

Truly a Rock and Stone approach to the survivors genre.

I'm not entirely convinced. Putting aside the memey cult following, let's talk srs bsns.

The power level in this game is really low. It feels like you are always at a disadvantage early game. The weapons are weak, and the upgrades do little to make you feel any stronger. The great part of bullet heavens is the progression from lvl 1 weakling to a demigod walking turret of damage numbers. You don't get this here at any point during the early game. It doesn't feel fun from the start since you are so weak. You don't get much time to explore the map or mine materials, you are forced to leave almost immediately when you kill the boss. I'm sure that the power level increases as it you play more, however, I feel little motivation to get to that point with how much of a slog the game is at the start.

A very fun and challenging grind.

Dwarf Survivors.

Unlocks are boring, level ups are boring, meta progression is boring, you have to do throwaway runs with every single weapon to make them usable, and the sponginess of everything is absurd. I wanted to like it so much, but it's just worse than the demo was.

EDIT: So it turns out the meter for progression through the level is based on kills, not time spent. Since you get nearly all your money and a good chunk of your XP through mining rather than fighting, this means getting into combat is outright detrimental to your chances of winning.

In a VS-style game.

This decision is, to be blunt, so obviously terrible that it harms my ability to believe the devs can improve the game through patches, because it makes me think they have no clue what they're doing with the mechanics of the game. Avoid.

DRG has done it again! I have so far played this game for 3 hours, though it feels like I've played for 10. It is very addicting and I am having a lot of fun enjoying it. I haven't even beaten a run yet and still I keep playing. This game feels like DRG meets Spiral Knights, in a way, and I love both of these games. I also really like this game because I can get my DRG fix in while still being able to play with chill vibes, especially when I'm listening to music or just looking to de-stress. This game isn't perfect, though no game that has just been released is, but I will say of all the games I've played at launch, this is definitely my favorite. It is very playable, and I can also see many ways in which updates will improve. And, we know and love the DRG developers and can trust them to not forget about or dump this game, so I look forward to seeing what the future brings for DRG: Survivor. It is clear to me that the devs worked very hard to make sure this game is playable, not broken, and most importantly, enjoyable, before they released it into the world. Thanks, DRG devs!

An excellent spin-off of one of my favourite games.

Seems people keep misunderstanding that this isn't DRG 2, it's Vampire Survivors but DRG - and it does so excellently.

I'll re-review it when it leaves early access, but I bought it on launch and fully recommend it for the following reason:

1) If you're new to the genre, this is a good starting place (it was first autoshooter I played back when the Next Fest demo dropped)

2) If you already enjoy the genre, it takes the conventions and twists them around in interesting ways

3) It's Deep Rock Galactic

If you fit any of the three criteria above, get this game.

If you're a fan of DRG, just remember that this is a [i]spin-off[/i] and not a sequel.
